HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
This time it's Interpublic doing an internal merger to add another giant to Madison Avenue.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
FOR the second time in less than two months, a big merger reshaping Madison Avenue is a result of an internal realignment rather than an acquisition or takeover.
The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is combining two of its four global agency networks: Ammirati Puris Lintas and the Lowe & Partners Worldwide unit of Lowe Group. The merged Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide will have offices in 80 countries and billings of more than $11 billion, ranking it fourth among all agency networks. 
 Accounts of Lowe Lintas include Lowe clients like Coca-Cola, for the Sprite soft drink brand; Heineken beer, and Marriott International, for the Courtyard by Marriott lodging chain. Accounts coming from Ammirati Puris include the Ameritech unit of SBC Communications; Lego Systems, and United Parcel Service.
Besides the "Ammirati Puris" part of the Ammirati Puris Lintas name disappearing from the moniker of the merged agency, almost all top managers of Lintas Lowe, including those for American operations, are coming from Lowe.
For instance, Frank Lowe, chairman and chief executive at Lowe & Partners, will be chairman and chief executive at Lowe Lintas as Martin Puris, chairman, chief executive and chief creative officer at Ammirati Puris, resigns.
The primary reason for the merger echoes the explanation given by True North Communications in September when that giant agency company shifted about half the business handled by Bozell Worldwide -- including all accounts handled outside the United States -- to FCB Worldwide. The goal, True North management said, was to take advantage of the economies of scale by bolstering the larger agency network, FCB, to better handle assignments from multinational clients.
"We ask ourselves how do we resource these agencies with enough volume to support better responsiveness to clients on a worldwide basis," Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive at Interpublic, said Friday, the day the merger was announced after weeks of speculation in trade publications.
"The combination as we go forward provides for better growth, creating a top-five agency that can compete much better," he added. "This is a good move for the clients, the employees and the shareholders long term." On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Interpublic -- the world's largest agency company in billings, at $37.7 billion, and No. 2 in revenue. at $4.3 billion -- closed Friday at $40.625, up $1.125.
Lowe has 3,500 employees in offices in 41 countries with estimated billings of $4 billion and Ammirati Puris has 9,800 employees in offices in 78 countries with estimated billings of almost $7.7 billion. The merger comes five years after a similar merger when Interpublic acquired Ammirati & Puris, a midsize New York agency with a reputation for creativity, and merged it with Lintas Worldwide, known for its network of overseas offices.
This time, "A.P.L. is very strong around the world, strategically and so forth," Mr. Geier said, "and Lowe is very creative."
Clashes generated by the distinctly different cultures of Ammirati & Puris and Lintas, made worse by account losses and turmoil in the executive suite, kept that first merger from achieving its full potential.
Now, Mr. Geier is more optimistic.
"Frank has a great ability to lead an operation," he said of Mr. Lowe, "and creative people in particular like to work with him."
"And with Sennott coming over, you've got the creative and the realism working together," Mr. Geier said, laughing.
His reference was to Michael Sennott, 58, who joins Lowe Lintas as deputy chairman, the No. 2 post under Mr. Lowe, from vice chairman of an Interpublic sibling, McCann-Erickson World Group in New York.
"I am delighted to have assembled a team of such talent," said Mr. Lowe, 58, referring to the board of Lowe Lintas. Mr. Lowe joined Interpublic in 1990 when he sold Lowe Group, the parent of the London agency, Lowe Howard-Spink, he founded in 1981. In addition to his duties at Lowe Lintas, Mr. Lowe will continue as chairman and chief executive at Lowe Group and at Octagon, the Interpublic sports marketing division.
Other board members of Lowe Lintas include: Jerry Judge, 49, president, from president at Lowe & Partners; Adrian Holmes, 46, chief creative officer, from the same post at Lowe & Partners, and Lee Garfinkel, 44. Mr. Garfinkel, chairman and chief creative officer of the United States operations of Lowe & Partners, is to take on similar responsibilities for the domestic operations of Lowe Lintas; he will be assisted by Gary Goldsmith, 42, who has been vice chairman under Mr. Garfinkel.
As for Mr. Puris, he agreed to serve as a consultant to Lowe Lintas through the end of 2000.
"Phil discussed the concept of the merger with me about a year ago," Mr. Puris, 60, said Friday. "I said, 'It sounds interesting, but if you're thinking of me, don't. One merger is enough in a lifetime.' "
"We did a lot of the grunt work," he added, "replacing a lot of people who needed to be replaced, into the hundreds, and putting in some very good people around the world and in the New York office, which is now on its way."
"I'm now trying to figure out a way to get into the Internet business," Mr. Puris said. "The Internet feels like 1965, when I got into the advertising business."
The merger leaves Interpublic with three worldwide agency networks. The others are Draft Worldwide, specializing in direct marketing, and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of McCann-Erickson World Group.
The fate of some accounts in the merger is unknown as executives of both agencies try to resolve conflicts. For instance, Ammirati Puris works for the Burger King unit of Diageo, Dell Computer, General Motors and Johnson & Johnson while Lowe works for the Denny's unit of Advantica Restaurant Group, Sun Microsystems, Toyota and American Home Products.
And Unilever, a founding client of an Ammirati Puris predecessor, Lintas Worldwide, conflicts with a Lowe client, Henkel, the German soap and detergent maker.
One way the conflicts might be resolved is to move accounts from Lowe Lintas to Interpublic siblings like McCann-Erickson. And if Interpublic acquires MacManus Group in New York, as trade publications have speculated, some accounts could be shifted to MacManus agencies like N. W. Ayer & Partners, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and Kaplan Thaler Group. (MacManus executives have insisted there is no deal to sell to Interpublic.)
The most intractable conflicts seem to be those between Unilever and Henkel and General Motors and Toyota. The likely outcome will be to retain the larger clients in both cases, Unilever and G. M.
Also on Friday, as if unwilling to be left out of the realignment mania, McCann-Erickson announced that it would reorganize its media operations around the world under the name Universal McCann, which has been used in Europe.
Universal McCann will have more than 2,400 employees in 127 countries, providing media planning and buying on accounts with billings estimated at $13.2 billion. Ira Carlin, 51, will be chairman; he had been executive vice president and worldwide media director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising.
Other top managers of Universal McCann will include Murray Dudgeon, 44, worldwide operations director; Mark Stewart, 40, regional director for North America, and Bill Cella, 48, director for broadcast and programming.

HEADLINE: Awaiting Verdict, Microsoft Starts Lobbying Campaign

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The first part of the verdict in the Microsoft trial is due out soon, perhaps as soon as Friday. But the Microsoft Corporation is already looking past the legal case and lobbying the government to pass laws that would protect the company in areas where it is being challenged in court.
When the company distributed its annual report in September, two million shareholders also got a letter from Robert Herbold, Microsoft's chief operating officer, urging them to join a lobbying effort to protect what the company calls its "freedom to innovate." 
 Loosely translated, that catch-phrase means freedom to design products however the company chooses -- including the freedom to bundle other products, like a Web browser, with the Windows operating system. The decision to build a Web browser into Windows is a central element of the government's antitrust case against Microsoft.
Mr. Herbold's letter directs shareholders to the company's "freedom to innovate" Web site, where visitors are informed that the "freedom to innovate network was formed as a response to the overwhelming amount of correspondence" the company had received "regarding the trial with the Justice Department and other public policy issues."
With the court's findings of facts imminent, both sides in the trial are scurrying to anticipate and manage the public relations fallout. But Microsoft sees its lobbying effort as a long-term political strategy that will be followed whatever the outcome of the case.
A Microsoft spokesman said the site was set up earlier this year "as just a way to channel the thousands of people who wrote to us about the trial." The spokesman added that Microsoft's leadership had decided to send the letter to shareholders after the trial was essentially over because the company now viewed "freedom to innovate" as a broader term covering other political issues of interest to the company, like government policies dealing with encryption, software piracy and Internet taxation.
But the Web site does not reflect a change of thinking in any prominent way. The opening page complains about the trial, including a quotation from an unnamed Web-site visitor, printed in red italic letters, that says: "The actions of the government against the Microsoft Corporation are detrimental to the very system of competition that made the U.S. a world leader in technology."
In an upper corner is a link to a page that lists the company's additional concerns. (Even there, the second item reiterates the "freedom to innovate" theme, saying: "The government should continue to exercise great restraint in regulating this industry, which has brought such remarkable advances to consumers and benefits to the economy.")
But a more prominent link on the home page, labeled "Contact Congress," directs people to a page with the heading: "Tell your Congressional representatives and state officials where you stand on the Department of Justice's antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft." There is no mention of piracy, encryption or any other issue.
Moving on from there, visitors are presented with an interactive menu that allows them to send e-mail entreaties directly to members of Congress and to their state legislators. (Nineteen states joined the Federal government's antitrust suit.)
Hundreds of thousands of people have visited the Web page, the Microsoft spokesman said, and more than 100,000 have used it to send messages to Congress or to the company, he said.
He asserted that Microsoft had every right to lobby Congress on issues related to the trial because "a lot of people are dissatisfied with the case, and there are policy implications that come out of the case, and Congress has oversight responsibility for the Department of Justice, right?"
A senior Congressional aide who is generally aware of lobbying by Microsoft said the "freedom to innovate" campaign did not appear to be generating a focused, coherent message. In fact, the Web site does not offer suggested language for visitors sending e-mails, as many similar lobbying campaigns do.
But the spokesman said Microsoft was not promoting a specific legislative proposal, adding: "This really has nothing to do with the trial; it's totally policy focused. The trial is going along on a separate track."
On that track, the presiding judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, has announced that he will issue his findings of fact in the case on a coming Friday evening. Findings of fact are half of the judge's reasoning that make up a verdict. They are a statement of what he has concluded from the conflicting factual arguments the two sides have presented in court.
The finding might, as a hypothetical example, say that the judge does not accept Microsoft's reasoning for tying the Web browser to Windows. This would be a clear indication that he intends to find against Microsoft on that charge.
But a second element of the ruling will come later. It will comprise conclusions of law, the legal arguments and precedents justifying a conclusion. Both are required for a sustainable verdict.
Already, the company and its opponents are offering different takes on the significance of the findings of fact.
A group of lawyers who oppose Microsoft, working under the umbrella of the Computer and Communications Industry Association, held a telephone news conference on Thursday and generally proclaimed that the public should be able to see whether the judge intends to find Microsoft guilty by reading his findings of fact. That will be the case, "despite Microsoft's efforts to distract the analysis from the real issues in court," said Donald Falk, an antitrust lawyer.
But a Microsoft lawyer had a different perspective in an interview late last week.
"This is just a step toward a decision," he said. "I think there may be a lot things in the findings that are legally irrelevant."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
After Protracted Talks, a Disneyland Will Rise in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 1

 BODY:
In a deal that will bring Main Street, U.S.A. to the doorstep of mainland China, the Walt Disney Company has reached an agreement to build a theme park in Hong Kong, a government official close to the negotiations said early today.
The agreement, which comes after nearly a year of arduous talks between Disney and the Hong Kong government, is to be announced on Tuesday. The theme park will be Disney's third outside the United States, after those near Tokyo and Paris, but is precedent-setting in several ways. 
 For Disney, the park would be its first significant beachhead in China, a nation with which it has had a long and occasionally stormy history. For Hong Kong, which is shaking off the effects of its worst recession in decades, it would be the most costly government undertaking since the former British colony returned to Chinese rule in 1997.
Under the terms of the deal, Disney and Hong Kong are to be partners in a joint venture that will develop the park at a secluded bay on Lantau island, six miles or so west of central Hong Kong. The park, to be built on reclaimed land not far from the vast new airport here, would open in 2005.
Financial details were scarce today, but executives briefed on the deal said Hong Kong would put up the bulk of the project's cost through its contribution toward land, roads and other services. Disney's investment is expected to be less than $300 million, these executives said.
"My guess is that Disney would be reluctant to put a lot of its own money into the park because, remember, this is a Communist country that occasionally has disputes with the United States," said David Londoner, a media analyst who follows Walt Disney for Schroder Inc. in New York.
Indeed, the agreement comes after a tense period in United States-China relations that began with the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May. While anti-American feeling was not as fierce in Hong Kong, the Chinese government barred some American warships from docking here.
Disney seems aware that its brand of Americana could ruffle feathers in China's newest city. Last week, when a deal looked probable, Disney executives began meeting with economists, political leaders and academics here to build support for the theme park. They sought to allay fears about the project's financial, environmental and cultural effect on Hong Kong.
For example, Disney said it planned to give the park's restaurants and hotels a strong Chinese flavor, according to one person who met with the company. But he added that Disney left no doubt that it would build an all-American Magic Kingdom, where Mickey Mouse -- not Chairman Mao -- would reign supreme.
While the prospect of a Hong Kong Disneyland has drawn objections from a few people here on cultural grounds, it is not expected to be as emotional an issue as it was in France, where the opening of Euro Disneyland in 1992 provoked accusations of American cultural hegemony.
People in this money-minded city seem more concerned about the financing of the project, particularly Hong Kong's share. "The key is how much is this going to cost?" said Ian K. Perkin, chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "And how much of the project will Hong Kong own?"
Disney and Hong Kong missed a deadline for signing a deal in June. The two sides agreed to extend the talks until the end of October, and they continued to wrangle until after the midnight deadline.
Disney, which is based in Burbank, Calif., has promoted the deal as a tonic for Hong Kong's sagging economy. The company estimates that the park will attract five million visitors a year to the territory. Hong Kong now draws about 10 million visitors annually, but it has been struggling to revive its tourism industry after the 1997 hand-over to China and the Asian economic crisis.
Since Hong Kong has a population of 6.8 million, analysts said Disneyland would need to draw visitors from mainland China, Taiwan and Southeast Asia. One question is whether mainland Chinese will be able to travel here easily enough to visit the park in large numbers.
Although people from the mainland now account for one-third of Hong Kong's visitors, they generally travel in large tourist groups. The Chinese Government grants visas for individual visits sparingly.
During the long negotiations, Disney and Hong Kong have been mindful of the unhappy precedent of Euro Disneyland. In that case, Mr. Londoner said, Disney invested $140 million in the venture up front and the project borrowed heavily. When Euro Disney ran into severe financial trouble a few years later, the parent company had to inject an additional $700 million to rescue it.
Mr. Londoner said one of the French Disneyland's key weaknesses was a glut of hotel rooms. At the Hong Kong park, Disney plans only 1,400 rooms, according to one person briefed on the project. That is a conservative number, given the visitors Disney expects.
Once the deal is sealed, Hong Kong and Disney will each have to satisfy demanding audiences. Hong Kong's legislature must approve large public expenditures. Although the legislature is friendly to the territory's government, its members could ask tough questions if Hong Kong seemed to be giving too much away.
And Hong Kong's economy has bounced back since the negotiations began early this year, prompting some critics to argue that it does not need a Disney theme park as desperately as it did.
Similarly, Disney's shareholders will pay close attention to the size of the company's capital investment. Disney has been in a slump as it wrestles with slowing growth and problems at its ABC television network. The company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, has told shareholders that he will keep a tight rein on spending.
"The number $200 million to $300 million would not be a problem," said an influential media investor who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Anything approaching $1 billion would be problematic for investors."
But Disney's desire to expand its presence in China appears to have outweighed its short-term financial problems. The company has had a rocky recent history here. In 1996, China closed its film market to Disney after the company released "Kundun," a film about the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.
In February, China approved the release of "Mulan," an animated feature about a female Chinese warrior. The decision represented a thaw in relations with Disney. The film, though, performed poorly at the box office.

HEADLINE: Relieving Road Congestion Again on Colorado Ballot

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As one of the fastest-growing states in the country, Colorado has the traffic problems to prove it. On any given day, almost any given hour, highways are clogged and tempers are frayed. Arriving late has become a way of life.
But Colorado residents have a chance on Tuesday to speed things up, or so say proponents of two ballot initiatives. One would authorize state bond sales to improve highways. The other, for voters in Denver County and five adjacent counties, would expand the light-rail system. Passage of both measures would allow the state to borrow $2.1 billion, whichwould be repaid with money from the federal highway trust fund. 
 Recent polls suggest that both measures have about a 60 percent chance of passing. Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican who won election last year after promising to improve traffic conditions, has campaigned for both initiatives.
"I'm cautiously optimistic," he said in an interview, reflecting his belief that both measures will pass. "Historically with these proposals, the voting has narrowed at the end. This time we have more room to maneuver."
Unlike other Western states, including Oregon, California and Utah, that have forged ahead with expanded bus routes and new highways, light-rail systems and subways, Colorado has resisted any substantial spending to ease congestion. Its population has increased 677,000, to 3,970,971, since 1990, according to the Census Bureau.
Vehicle miles traveled around the country have increased by 70 percent over the last 20 years, compared with a 2 percent increase in new highway construction, according to transportation experts. And Colorado voters have consistently rejected measures to address traffic problems. They defeated two initiatives in 1997 and another last year.
Of the two initiatives under consideration, the highway measure is the more expensive at $1.6 billion. It would add lanes, rebuild interchanges and widen roads in 24 places around the state, a third of them along Interstate 25, the north-south axis that passes through Denver. Supporters say passage would fix problems in 10 to 12 years, rather than 20 to 25.
But opponents have called it a temporary solution that fails to consider other critical issues, like land use, employment centers and lifestyles.
"It won't work," said Greg Casini, chairman of the Rocky Mountain Chapter of the Sierra Club, one of several environmental groups fighting the highway measure. "It's just throwing money away as a short-term solution to a long-term problem. Adding a few lanes on a few highways is not a magical way to solve transportation needs."
Other opposition has focused on the cost of borrowing so much money that the total interest could reach $600 million and on uncertainties of the economy, which could reduce federal highway support.
Opponents say they would be more inclined to support highway construction as part of a larger plan that included alternative solutions. For that reason, the light-rail extension proposed for the Denver area has been viewed as a major step.
The current system is modest, 5.3 miles of track that runs through downtown into a few nearby neighborhoods, doing little to mitigate rush-hour traffic.
The proposed 19 miles of extensions would be built along two major highways, one of them a parallel spur to an insufferable stretch of I-25 between the state's largest employment centers, downtown Denver and the Denver Tech Center to the south. The extensions are expected to carry 30,000 commuters a day, the equivalent of three to five lanes of traffic.
Mr. Owens said passage of both measures would save money in the long run and would help accommodate population growth. Since 1990, only four other states -- Nevada, Arizona, Utah and Idaho -- have had a higher percentage of population increase.
"We are going to have more people," Mr. Owens said. "We would only be harming ourselves if we tried to pretend that not building roads for them is a good idea."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Outside the G.O.P.'s Big Tent, Hoping He's Let Back In

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SENATOR ROBERT C. SMITH, newly returned from the campaign trail, sat in his spacious office the other day and reflected on the importance of not being a thin-skinned grudge-holder.
He had just folded an independent presidential campaign that produced hardly a ripple, and even a newspaper in his home state, New Hampshire, had asked in an editorial, "Where did this down-home guy get this goofy idea?" 
 The senator laughed. No, he said, he would not respond in kind. He remembered the advice an old politician gave him years ago: "There's no point getting into an argument with someone who has an unlimited supply of ink and paper."
Turning serious, he said, "You can't succeed if you're afraid to fail." All right, he went on, he's not going to be president. But he got to talk about his deeply conservative principles, and he met a lot of wonderful people.
Nevertheless, Mr. Smith must be hoping, as he prepares for the next phase of his public life, that some other politicians don't hold grudges either. When he announced in July that he would run for president as an independent, he excoriated the Republican Party in an hourlong speech on the Senate floor, saying that it was too willing to compromise, that pollsters had become more important than principles, that the party was frittering away the victory it won through the Reagan revolution. His denunciation infuriated party stalwarts, not least Jim Nicholson, the Republican National Committee chairman.
Now, his campaign out of money, the polls he so disdains showing him registering barely a blip even in New Hampshire, site of the first primary, Mr. Smith wants back in the Big Tent. Apparently unwilling to contemplate becoming the only independent in the Senate, Mr. Smith has been making overtures to party leaders. Perhaps more important, there is the lure of a significant committee chairmanship.
The senator said he would wait until today before discussing his intentions. But he acknowledged that when he appears at a news conference to announce them, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and other top Republicans will be at his side.
"Two and two makes four, doesn't it?" Mr. Smith said, inviting a visitor to draw his own conclusions. "Well, with the new math, it may not."
More later about the old values Mr. Smith holds dear, and why. For the moment, there are more pragmatic considerations.
THE death of Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island on Oct. 24 left vacant the top seat on the powerful Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. Mr. Smith is the next Republican in line -- that is, if he is welcomed back to the party, and if party leaders do not count his few months in the wilderness against his seniority.
Mr. Smith is known to have signaled his desire to return to the fold well before Mr. Chafee's death, which was unexpected. But has the anger against him cooled enough for him to be awarded the chairmanship?
If Republican leaders hold a grudge, they may give the post to Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, who is next in seniority. (Unlike Mr. Chaffee, neither Mr. Smith nor Mr. Inhofe is considered an ally by environmentalists, although they rate Mr. Smith a bit friendlier to their cause.)
A big (6-foot-6), affable man, the senator, who grew up in New Jersey, told another story about grudges, or the lack thereof. A quarter-century ago, after leaving his job as a history teacher, he joined a real estate company.
But the economy was bad, and sales were slow, and Mr. Smith was fired. Nothing personal, his boss said.
Mr. Smith and his wife, Mary Jo, had a family to feed (they now have three grown children), so Mr. Smith borrowed some money and went into real estate on his own. The economy picked up. Mr. Smith prospered. After a while, his old boss's company was for sale. As it happened, so was his old boss's house. "I bought his business and his house, all in the same transaction," he said with a smile.
The real estate turnabout was not his life's defining moment. That came on March 28, 1945, two days before his fourth birthday, when his father, a naval aviator, was killed. Lt. Cmdr. Donald Smith had lived through combat in the Pacific only to die in a Navy plane crash back home. His wife, Margaret, never remarried.
Senator Smith, who served in the Navy in the Vietnam War, has only a hazy memory of his father. The senator's younger brother, Richard, has none at all. On the wall of the senator's office is a picture of his father shaking hands with Adm. Chester Nimitz.
Growing up without a father, wishing he had one, taught him what a gift life is, the senator said, and that is why he is among the most dedicated opponents of abortion.
And having felt the cost of war, he said he opposed sending Americans into harm's way unless doing so was clearly in the national interest. (He opposed American involvement in Bosnia in 1995 and Kosovo in 1998.)
Some of his most vivid memories are of cemeteries. His parents are buried in Arlington National Cemetery.
Then there was the visit he and his wife made to an American military cemetery in Italy a few years ago. They came upon the grave of an American soldier who was killed on May 29, 1944, the day the senator's wife was born.
Think of the sacrifice and the symbolism, the senator said with a catch in his voice, "He died so she could live free."

HEADLINE: Mexican Runs on Both Change and Stability

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31

 BODY:
After a recent campaign speech, Francisco Labastida Ochoa slid behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Suburban, roared onto a two-lane highway and accelerated to 100 miles per hour.
As Mr. Labastida, Mexico's leading presidential candidate, rocketed past a line of farm trucks, his chief bodyguard was four Suburbans back in the campaign convoy, clinging to the dashboard and shouting to his driver to try to keep up with the boss. 
 Mr. Labastida drives like a maniac. But his approach to politics is methodical and discreet. He has served six presidents in 37 years of public life and never rocked the boat.
Now as he seeks the governing party's nomination, in a primary election scheduled for Nov. 7, he is navigating with characteristic caution. His positions on economics, drugs, relations with the United States and other issues diverge sharply from those held by President Ernesto Zedillo.
Yet mindful that he needs the backing of the president's supporters to win the vote that could well choose Mexico's next president, he has portrayed himself as the candidate of stability rather than an agent of dramatic change.
Polls suggest that his strategy is working. After a sluggish start, Mr. Labastida has appeared to move out ahead of his closest rival, Roberto Madrazo Pintado, a populist former governor who cast himself as a maverick. But since this presidential primary is the party's first and turnout is difficult to forecast, predicting the winner is impossible.
A primary victory would leave Mr. Labastida on the doorstep of the presidency, because the opposition is divided and unlikely to overtake the governing party's candidate in the general election on July 2.
Even if he wins the primary, his biggest challenge may be preventing a rupture in the party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known by its acronym in Spanish as the PRI. The party is bitterly split between foreign-trained economists who have dominated Mexico's government for years and its old-guard politicians, who blame economic policies that have led to a drastic erosion in living standards for the PRI's decline.
Mr. Labastida is offering a unity program that promises something for both sides. For the economic technocrats, he vows to keep Mexico's deficit slender to prevent a financial crisis such as those that have followed every presidential succession since 1976. And to the old guard, he is promising to open the domestic spending spigot.
"Our first rule is, 'Don't risk a crisis,' " Mr. Labastida said, neatly daubing red chili on a shrimp taco during a meal aboard his executive jet. "But we're going to have more room to maneuver and to spend more freely. Our government won't have to concentrate on recovering from a devaluation. Instead we're going to be able to build."
He has promised to create a million jobs a year -- double the rate of the last three years -- by extending low-interest loans to small and mid-sized businesses, establishing tax-free investment zones, and especially by subsidizing the construction of low-cost homes; he wants to triple the current rate of housing starts.
To farmers, he has promised new subsidies for crops and a doubling of existing subsidies for those who buy new tractors and other equipment. Subsidies have been anathema among Mr. Zedillo's technocrats. He has also questioned the usefulness of further privatizations, a keystone of government policy since 1988.
"My main goal will be to generate jobs and recover social mobility," he said.
If his approach differs dramatically from Mr. Zedillo's, Mr. Labastida still appears to be running with the president's blessing. But how he got it remains murky.
"He was certainly not Zedillo's first choice," said Jorge Castaneda, the author of a book detailing how modern Mexican presidents have chosen their successors. "They have almost nothing in common." The Mexican president is limited to one six-year term.
At 57, Mr. Labastida is 10 years older than Mr. Zedillo, and they had never worked together before Mr. Zedillo made him his secretary of agriculture in 1995. Early in his presidency, Mr. Zedillo seemed to be grooming other potential successors. But after they fell victim to crises and left the cabinet, Mr. Zedillo last year promoted Mr. Labastida to head the powerful Interior Ministry, and a parade of PRI leaders began to praise him as a man who could unify the party, said Guillermo Ruiz de Teresa, Mr. Labastida's private secretary.
Mr. Labastida insisted that the announcement of his candidacy on May 18 came on his own initiative.
"Just before I resigned, I told the president I was being mentioned a lot as a potential candidate and that it was making my work as interior minister difficult," Mr. Labastida said. "Before that, we'd only joked about it. 'They mentioned you again,' the president would say. Phrases like that."
Most of the party establishment is backing Mr. Labastida, but the president, as recently as last week, said he had no favorite.
Some columnists have portrayed Mr. Labastida as a mediocre politician who is running strong only because he is "the official candidate." He has in fact received plenty of logistical support from state governors, leaders of PRI-controlled unions, farm organizations and neighborhood groups. But that backing also reflects two decades of patient spadework by Mr. Labastida.
"He's been building this candidacy for 20 years, forging alliances," said Jorge Montano, a former ambassador to the United States who has known Mr. Labastida for many years. "His detractors don't understand him, because he's tough to decipher. He's not a political elephant; he's a political cat. He has a great sense of smell. He operates in silence. He calculates his movements carefully. He's cautious, but he can be audacious."
Mr. Labastida appears most eager to show audacity in law enforcement. When he became Sinaloa's governor in 1987, the steamy coastal state was a big drug producer. He fired hundreds of corrupt police officers. In reprisal, gunmen assassinated several of his aides, including a former state attorney general.
Even his opponents acknowledge that his record contrasts with other PRI governors, who have grown wealthy by turning a blind eye to the drug trade.
"With Labastida, traffickers did not have the governor's collaboration," said Humberto Rice, who dealt with Governor Labastida as the opposition mayor of Mazatlan in Sinaloa.
Mr. Labastida likes to recall a 1990 investigation he led as governor into the slaughter of an entire family that chanced upon corrupt police officers unloading cocaine from an aircraft along a Sinaloa highway. Dishonest federal prosecutors initially sought to cover up the killings, he said. But as a result of his pressure, he said, six federal police were tried for murder and given long prison sentences.
What would he do as president to attack the problem? a reporter asked.
"Let's just say there will be war," he said.
Mr. Labastida would probably prove more assertive on behalf of national interests on other issues of importance to both Mexico and the United States. Unlike Mr. Zedillo, who attended Yale and speaks English fluently, Mr. Labastida studied economics at Mexico's National University, has never lived north of the border and speaks limited English. He is a vigorous nationalist.
Asked about relations with the United States, Mr. Labastida recalled the 1847 invasion of Mexico engineered by President James K. Polk, which brought 50,000 Mexican deaths and the loss of Mexican territories stretching from Texas to Oregon.
"Mexicans still mourn the dead from that war, but that shouldn't poison our future," he said. "We need a relationship that benefits both nations."
He wants to widen the North American Free Trade Agreement. As Mexico's ambassador to Portugal in 1993, he studied the half century of negotiations that have eroded borders in Europe. "With Nafta, we've only touched on trade and investment flows," he said. "I'd push to broaden the treaty into new areas."
Immigration is one. "We need an agreement for temporary workers, something like we have with Canada," he said, referring to an accord that allowed 7,000 Mexican agricultural workers to work there legally this year.
His vow to seek a better deal for migrant workers fits Mr. Labastida's campaign slogan, "Make Power Serve People." As part of this thrust, his image makers are distributing a comic-book biography of him entitled, "An Exemplary Life."
"Never expose yourself to the shame of taking a single peso dishonestly," his father, a country doctor, lectures young Francisco on a page portraying his boyhood.
His opponents have not challenged this version of events, although there was skepticism over his recent assertion that his personal wealth, including the value of a weekend home in Morelos state, totals just $700,000.
"I know nobody believes it," Mr. Labastida said. "But my objective in life hasn't been to amass a fortune." He said he relinquished most of his assets in a 1986 divorce, and a top aide added that he is supporting a daughter born outside of his marriage. His second wife is Maria Teresa Uriarte, a distinguished Mexican historian.
In this campaign, in which the PRI is trying to cast off its reputation for back-room deals and vote fraud, his campaign offers a revisionist version of his 1986 election for governor by portraying him as a pioneer for democracy because he "proposed using transparent ballot boxes" to ensure honesty.
But participants recalled the balloting as blatantly unfair. The PRI authorities used vast government resources on Mr. Labastida's behalf, and thousands of ballots marked for the main opposition candidate, Manuel Clouthier del Rincon, a vegetable grower, were later found in the trash. Mr. Labastida won with 69 percent of the vote.
Mr. Clouthier cried fraud, and demonstrators delivered a coffin labeled "the Death of Democracy" to Mr. Labastida's Sinaloa home. After Mr. Labastida took office, peasants controlled by the PRI occupied Mr. Clouthier's lands, a time-honored PRI tactic against its enemies.
Manuel Clouthier Carrillo, the candidate's son, who publishes Sinaloa's opposition newspaper, offered a description that contrasts with the charming image Mr. Labastida projects to others: "He's a man who bears a grudge."
But many PRI leaders have also benefited from vote fraud. When Mr. Zedillo took office in 1994, he appeared embarrassed by the party's authoritarian legacy, and he infuriated many party members with his vow to put "healthy distance" between the presidency and his party.
Mr. Labastida has vowed to re-establish a "healthy proximity" with the PRI. That sounds good to the leaders of the old guard, who are often called dinosaurs because of their resistance to change.
"This dinosaur, as they call him, has a young heart and can be renewed and can change," Mr. Labastida said.

HEADLINE: Reseeding Ivy: Columbia on Comeback Trail From Troubles

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Columbia University is on a roll.
The university, which during the 1970's and 80's was struggling with a declining reputation and flat alumni giving, has edged out Yale as the third-most selective Ivy League college, after Harvard and Princeton. 
 Last year it raised nearly $400 million in gifts -- behind only Harvard and Stanford. And Columbia is collecting more money from its patents and royalties than any American university. Even the normally testy relations with its Morningside Heights neighbors have turned adulatory. And to cap it all, Robert A. Mundell, a Columbia economics professor, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics last month, Columbia's third Nobel in four years.
This is clearly a good time for most elite universities. Applications are pouring in. Donors are lining up. And some of Columbia's good fortune clearly stems from New York City's prosperity and rising reputation, which have inflated applications to other local colleges.
But Columbia seems to be particularly blessed. Last year, the university fielded a record 13,012 applications to its undergraduate college and accepted just 13.6 percent of them -- fewer than one in seven. As recently as the 1980's, Columbia was forced to take nearly half of its applicants to keep its classrooms filled.
Once one of the richest and most admired institutions of higher learning -- home to the critic Lionel Trilling, the poet Allen Ginsberg and the physicist I. I. Rabi, among others -- Columbia, by the 1970's, had slid. Its students still spilled off the Renaissance-style campus into the bookstores and bars lining Broadway, signaling the presence of a world-renowned university at 116th Street on the edge of Harlem, and it still held sway as one of the city's largest employers, real estate owners and research institutions.
But internally, things had soured. Alumni were dismayed by the violent student takeovers of five buildings in 1968, aimed at stopping its expansion into Morningside Park, and many stopped giving money. Respected faculty members were bailing out. And students sought safer havens than financially strapped, crime-ridden New York.
Columbia's resurgence now shows not just the benefits of being in the right place at the right time but also the payoff from careful management of a $1.5 billion institution that is as much a business as an ivory tower.
George Rupp, Columbia's preacher-turned-president, who served as dean of Harvard's Divinity School and president of Rice University before joining Columbia in 1993, has proved to be an attentive manager and a careful strategist as well as a nonstop fund-raiser, many Columbia insiders say.
"Rupp is watching the store," said Kenneth T. Jackson, a renowned professor of history and the social sciences, who was on the search committee that chose Mr. Rupp.
Stephen Friedman, chairman of Columbia's trustees, likens Mr. Rupp to John F. Welch Jr., the hard-driving chief executive of General Electric Corporation, who insists that each of his businesses be among the best in their fields.
"George is a guy who very aggressively wants to be excellent and outstanding in every area he is in," said Mr. Friedman, a Columbia Law School graduate and former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs.
Outside the university, too, Mr. Rupp is perceived as a strong manager who has helped raise Columbia's stature. Although it is still generally not thought of as part of the fabled trio of Harvard, Yale and Princeton, in some respects it is now seen as nipping at their heels.
"Columbia has ascended nationally and among its peers," said Kay Hanson, executive director of the Consortium on Financing Higher Education, a group that includes Columbia and 30 other elite colleges and universities.
The son of German immigrants, Mr. Rupp, 57, brought an Ivy League pedigree (Princeton undergraduate, doctorate in theology from Harvard) and a long record as an administrator. A tall, gangly man with a preppy look, he is more determined than charismatic.
The Rupp touch is evident in many ways: He has improved operations at a university that had a reputation for loose -- some say sloppy -- management. He has increased revenues by expanding the number of tuition-paying undergraduates, stepping up fund-raising and squeezing greater profits out of the university's intellectual properties -- from biomedical patents to new media projects. And he has polished and expanded the physical plant at a time when first impressions count mightily.
Mr. Rupp has also placed new emphasis on the undergraduate college, the smallest in the Ivy League, with about 3,400 students when he arrived.
"The first thing I did was to insist that the college should be at the heart of the university, and that the other schools had to overcome their fortress mentality," he explained in an interview in his neat, ornate office in Low Library overlooking Columbia's quadrangle. "In American higher education, the way John or Mary Q. Public establishes a hierarchy of quality is by an appraisal of the undergraduate unit and how hard it is to get in."
Detractors say the growth in the number of students at the college -- now 3,850 -- has not yet been matched by a similar rise in modern classrooms or in the number of faculty members, and that more graduate students are being used to teach.
"I would rate my experience over all as very good, but there is mediocrity lurking, in bad professors and unspectacular graduate students" said J. J. Lando, a senior from West Orange, N.J., who is triple-majoring in philosophy, physics and mathematics. "There has been a fair amount of student backlash over overcrowding of classes," he added.
Columbia says that when it finishes renovations, there will be more appropriately sized classrooms. And it has introduced fellowships to attract more professors to teach its celebrated core curriculum, anchored by contemporary civilization and humanities literature -- interdisciplinary courses grounded in Western classics. Graduate students, who are only supposed to teach about a third of the seminar-style classes, now cover about 40 percent of the sections.
While most students who were queried said they had not met Mr. Rupp, most said they were quite happy. Mr. Rupp's strategies, in short, seem to have paid off. Last year, Standard & Poor's added Columbia to its short elite list of triple-A universities, citing its $2 billion capital campaign, its diversified revenue stream and its effective planning and budgeting process.
Michael I. Sovern, Columbia's president from 1980 to 1993, is widely credited with laying the foundation for today's renaissance by selling the land that the university owned beneath Rockefeller Center and putting it into higher-yielding investments; doubling the application pool by going coeducational; conducting a major capital campaign to replenish the university's endowment, and expanding the school's housing.
But while the Columbia that Mr. Sovern left for Mr. Rupp was greatly improved, it was still not flying. And as the 1990's progressed, Columbia officials looked enviously at the buzz surrounding New York University, their downtown rival.
When Mr. Rupp arrived, he overhauled the central administration -- keeping the provost, Jonathan R. Cole, but recruiting most of his other close aides from outside the university. He picked Emily Lloyd, Sanitation Commissioner under Mayors David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani, as his executive vice president for administration. He lured John Masten from the New York Public Library to be executive vice president of finance. And he brought in Alan Stone from the Clinton White House to run public affairs.
Academically, Mr. Rupp focused on shifting the balance between graduate students and undergraduates and encouraged aggressive hiring to restore the reputations of weak departments.
Still, the college sometimes seemed like an afterthought in a university of 20,000 students that was best known for its graduate and professional schools in areas like law, medicine, journalism, business and the liberal arts.
Columbia is expanding the college by more than 15 percent (to about 4,000 undergraduates) to make it a higher-profile part of the university and to bring in additional revenue. (With tuition and fees at more than $32,000 a student, an extra 500 students adds up to more than $16 million annually.)
At the same time, it hopes to downsize the graduate program, freeing more faculty time for undergraduates.
The most visible sign of the new attention to undergraduates is the investment in new buildings and renovations. With the help of large donors, Columbia has sunk $85 million into an architecturally arresting new student center and has spent heavily to renovate Butler Library, undergraduate dormitories and the gymnasium. A new residence hall, at 113th Street and Broadway, is scheduled to be completed next fall.
Columbia is also trying to rebuild departments that had slipped, like anthropology, for which it hired six new faculty members, mostly from top-ranked University of Michigan.
Its effort to stage a similarly bold move in economics, however, backfired, when Robert J. Barro, a prominent economist at Harvard, decided at the last minute not to come. But this year, it hired 10 new economists, including young professors from Princeton and Harvard, for the department, which is the most popular major among undergraduates.
Under the executive vice provost, Michael M. Crow, Columbia has also tried to squeeze as much income from its research and other intellectual property as possible. Last year, it brought in nearly $100 million.
Columbia is taking a similar hands-on approach to relations with the community. As the largest property owner in the area, the university has long been regarded by many as the enemy; the decision to build a gym in Morningside Park touched off the 1968 protests.
Columbia now consults more with the community about its construction plans. Maritta Dunn, chairwoman of Community Board 9, which encompasses the university, said that when the community protested the university's plans to condemn a building at 116th Street and Riverside Drive, the university said it would re-examine its plans.
"Five years is too short to turn around 30 or 40 years of bad blood," Ms. Dunn said, "but the current powers that be are really trying."
Columbia still has much left to do. Student satisfaction surveys, for instance, show some improved ratings, but they are still only fair to middling. Its $3.6 billion endowment is less than a third the size of Harvard's and smaller than those of its other main competitors, leaving Columbia more dependent on tuition and with a shallower pocket for financial aid.
Then there is the critical question of how attractive Columbia will remain if New York City's current popularity cools. Professor Jackson, editor of "The Encyclopedia of New York City," speculates that even if there is a downturn, many students will continue to come.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Essay;
Running Huge Risks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Americans are unaware that Congress and the president have just agreed to put us all at extraordinary financial and personal risk.
Senate Banking Chairman Phil Gramm has struck a deal with Clinton Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers to knock down all fire walls between banks, insurance companies and brokerage houses. Global financiers are given the green light for ever-greater concentrations of power. 
 Few remember the reason for those fire walls: to curtail the spread of the sort of panic from one financial segment to another that helped lead to the Great Depression. But today's lust for global giantism has swept aside the voices of prudence; generous financial lobbies have persuaded our leaders that in enormous size there is strength.
Not everyone has forgotten the adage of "the bigger they come, the harder they fall." In a little-noticed speech to bankers about the need for oversight of the growing "appetite for risk," Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan said that megabanks are becoming "complex entities that create the potential for unusually large systemic risks in the national and international economy should they fail."
Fail? That's a word that has been all but stricken from mergermania's vocabulary. It can only be used in the phrase "too big to fail" -- where the American taxpayer would have to bail out a failing multitentacled financial network lest it sink the whole jerry-built global edifice. A few of us have no appetite for assuming that risk -- which would be 10 times as costly as the 80's S.&L. debacle.
But that's just a monetary risk that, come hard-to-imagine hard times, would wipe out a decade's projected surplus. More irreversible is a greater risk that we are assuming this month -- the much more imminent risk to our private lives.
We have already seen the veil over our health records ripped away. The feckless G.O.P. Congress tossed that hot potato to Clinton, who caved to the insurance and hospital lobbies. The key word is consent. Instead of requiring written permission from patients before confidential health records are shopped to drug marketers or shown to prospective employers, Clinton's phony "controls" put patients and doctors at a disadvantage.
As for financial privacy, the Gramm-Summers sellout makes your bank account everybody's business. You will hear much huffing and puffing about privacy protection as the fire walls are torn down, especially about allowing you to object after the fact to the handing-around of your personal records, like a plate of cookies, to other companies.
Here's the catch: What happens when those "outside companies" are not outside at all -- but are part of one great big family of broker-banking-insurance services? Then, without your consent, the private information you write on your mortgage application, with your tax return attached, goes to your insurance company, which already has your health history -- and its snoops can also see your investment behavior and what you've been buying with your credit cards.
Under Gramm-Summers, giant financial conglomerates -- using other surveillance to protect against fraud -- will know more about your money habits, your assets, your diseases and your genetic makeup than your spouse or paramour does, and probably more than you do.
And just as he has done with his health-privacy "protection," Mr. Clinton will sign the bipartisan legislation, leaving you naked to any prying eyes with an Orwellian statement about how this protects your privacy.
Listen for the word consent. Listen for the word permission. You won't hear them, because that puts the expensive obligation on the marketers and snoops to seek your consent and alert you to their intrusion.
Instead, you will hear malarkey about how you will have control. That code word means that you must search for invasions of your privacy from punch-this-number telephone-answering computers and impenetrable bureaucracies. Some "control."
Sheer size rules. We look to government either to regulate monopoly or enforce competition. But as we have deregulated to let the free market operate, government has failed to enforce antitrust laws to maintain competition in media and now in money.
Today's result: mergermania, dangerous concentration of financial risk, and the even greater risk to that part of our freedom we call privacy.

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Neighbors Balk at a Baseball Plan

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
The idea was to turn a sandlot near Prospect Park in Brooklyn into a site fit for minor league baseball, to bring professional ball back to the borough 43 years after the Dodgers left.
The multimillion-dollar playing field at the Parade Grounds, opposite the southern edge of the park, would be constructed as a stand-in until a permanent stadium was built in Coney Island. Then it would be left to the city's young players, offering a grand forum for the development of their own baseball dreams. 
 But this city proposal has run into opposition from many of those it is said to benefit, with users angry over the potential loss of what has turned into a popular spot for soccer and other sports. Residents of Flatbush and other surrounding areas have been circulating petitions calling for more community input into the plan, and local officials have been offering proposals of their own.
Their general complaint is not a new one for City Hall: the stadium's opponents say the Giuliani administration has acted unilaterally in deciding what team to woo to the borough and has kept mum on the details.
"The administration has not been forthcoming with any information despite our repeated written requests for it," said Alvin Berk, chairman of Community Board 14, in Flatbush. "Right now we have no idea how big the field will be, what it will look like, how traffic will be handled and what it means to all the other users of the park.
"We've heard a lot of concerns from residents," he said, "but haven't been given enough information from the administration to even take a vote on the proposal ourselves."
Repeated calls over three days to officials with the city's Economic Development Corporation and the Parks Department produced no details. Bruce Brodoff, a spokesman for the agency, finally said, "There is nothing to say because everything is still in negotiations.
"There are a lot of things that go into this and things can change," he added. "It wouldn't pay to put out a press release."
Edward Skyler, a Parks Department spokesman, floated the idea six months ago, saying that the city would spend $3 million to build the playing field and a 3,000-seat temporary grandstand. At the time, he said that after a 38-game season next summer, the Mets farm team would move to a proposed $20 million stadium in Coney Island that would seat 6,500 people. That would leave the field for tournament-level high school and sandlot games.
Mr. Skyler's comments came after the city had already announced a $2 million plan to upgrade the Parade Grounds, saying the money would be used to build a football field, to refurbish some soccer grounds and to rebuild two baseball diamonds. The notoriously bad drainage and watering systems at the 40-acre site were also to be redesigned.
But if the Mets plan goes through as initially described, it appears that at least two fields will be lost to general use and a third will be taken over for parking, at least temporarily.
Angered by what he sees as the administration's recalcitrance in disclosing its plan, the Brooklyn borough president, Howard Golden, has scheduled a public meeting of the borough's board for today. Mr. Golden's office said the special session at 6 p.m. in Borough Hall was called to force the administration to meet with the community, adding that officials with the Economic Development Corporation and the Parks Department had been invited to speak.
The city officials are likely to be met by a barrage of questions, from why the administration chose a short-season Mets farm team for the site to how other uses for the fields will be curtailed, particularly the youth soccer games now held at the Parade Grounds.
For the last several months, Mr. Golden has accused the Giuliani administration of not acting in the best interests of Brooklyn on the deal. He has said that the administration's refusal to consider other minor league ball clubs is short-sighted, and that a higher-level team -- playing a full season instead of the shorter Single A summer schedule -- will bring more money to the borough and more fans to the games.
In the meantime, parents whose children now play soccer, lacrosse or other field games on the Parade Grounds fear that they will be squeezed out. And those living around the Parade Grounds worry that problems with securing a stadium site in Coney Island will leave the farm team playing in their neighborhood permanently -- bringing with it traffic, unruly fans and parking problems.
Mostly, those opposing the plan say they just want some input before the city's Franchise and Concession Review Committee votes on the plan in two weeks.
"This is a big thing for everyone involved in the Parade Grounds and we really deserved to hear the facts about what's being proposed," said Howard Helene, whose 9-year-old son has grown up playing on the fields. "Maybe this is a good thing for the park but because of the way it's been handled, nobody really knows."

HEADLINE: A Plan to Rebuild Bridges Widens Gap on Aid to Serbs

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Over strong American and British opposition, France and Germany are backing a European Union plan to aid Yugoslavia by building a temporary bridge over the Danube and clearing the wrecks of the bridges bombed by NATO earlier this year.
Under the plan, the European Union would provide $25 million and the technical means to haul away debris of three bombed bridges at Novi Sad, Serbia's second-largest city, which block traffic on Europe's longest river. The plan would include sending an old dismantled Danube bridge now stored near Vienna and temporarily installing it at Novi Sad. 
 European officials and experts involved in the negotiations, some of whom attended a conference here led by Patriarch Bartholomew of the Eastern Orthodox Church, said that details were being worked out and that the money was available.
If approved, aid is likely to cause new friction between Europe and the United States, which has argued it would violate sanctions that prohibit economic assistance and trade with the government of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.
Washington's backing is important because the Americans can best assess whether there is still unexploded ordnance on the river bed, and, if so, how to clear it.
The United States and its European allies have already clashed over how best to isolate and weaken Mr. Milosevic. Washington objects to a European plan to send heating oil to two Serbian cities, Nis and Pirot, that are controlled by Mr. Milosevic's opponents. The shipments are to start in mid-November.
Washington argues that Mr. Milosevic could use assistance to his advantage; the Europeans, led by France and Germany, counter that an American policy that envisages a cold and hungry population ousting Mr. Milosevic is too tough on ordinary people, and unlikely to succeed.
In the case of the bridges, there are other practical concerns: blockage of the Danube is crippling shipping and trade along the 1,800-mile waterway, which links 10 countries. There are also fears of flooding.
"Freeing this great European river has important practical and financial consequences for all the Europeans who live on its banks, but most significantly for the people of Romania and Bulgaria," Patriarch Bartholomew said in a letter appealing for European Union aid after he traveled through the region.
Losses in trade and shipping revenues, estimated at some $200 million, have had the most impact in the poorest countries, notably Bulgaria, Romania and Ukraine, where hundreds of barges lie idle and some shipping companies have laid off half their workers.
"Moving cargo like coal, iron ore or wheat is four to five times cheaper by river," said Anatoli Georgiev, a director of the Ukrainian Danubian Shipping Company, which he said has had to let go many dockworkers and boat crews.
There is almost no traffic on the Danube, normally bustling. At Galati, a Romanian port, several boat captains said they had not worked for four months.
Under a treaty regulating traffic on the Danube, Mr. Milosevic's government is obliged to clear obstacles from the river, or let others do so. But Serbia says the wrecked bridges can be cleared only if the West pays for and builds three new bridges.
Even if agreement is reached, it is unclear whether work can be done before winter. The Danube is low now, which will ease the clearing work. Once frost sets in, work would be impossible, experts say, and the river would close until next year.

HEADLINE: Parties Closer Than They Seem In Budget Fight

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress begin final budget negotiations this week, the combative debate and expected vetoes obscure a fundamental reality: the two sides have only modest differences over how much to spend.
The talks nonetheless could still take some time. A handful of high-profile policy disputes remain over such issues as the environment, education, the payment of back dues to the United Nations, and other foreign policy questions. And the Democrats, who are accustomed to making political gains when budget talks drag out, are stepping up their criticisms. 
 "We continue to be haunted by the agenda of the extremist wing of the Republican Party, stuck in the Gingrich past," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, said recently, trying to tie Republicans once again to a speaker who resigned after the last election.
But step by step, across the last few months, the Republican Congress has moved toward Mr. Clinton. Republican leaders quickly abandoned their drive for a $792 billion tax cut after the president vetoed the legislation. And over the summer, Republicans quietly gave up on their promise to adhere to the stringent limits on spending set in the balanced-budget agreement of 1997.
The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office found last week that the Republicans were spending nearly $31 billion more than the $580 billion target set in July as necessary to stay within the limits.
Perhaps there is no better example of the sea change than in education. In a spending bill covering an array of programs including education, the Republicans have included $300 million more for the Education Department than Mr. Clinton requested. The bill is set for Senate passage this week and then a certain veto by the president, who still objects to the measure for a variety of reasons, including the fact that the education money does not go to his own signature initiatives.
Even after the Republicans' last-minute 1 percent across-the-board cut to government agencies is factored in, the Republicans would still be allotting $37.1 billion for education, the same level proposed by Mr. Clinton.
The president himself said recently about education: "The big issue in Washington now is more on how we spend the money. I mean, I've been fighting for four or five years on whether to spend adequate amounts of money. Now we're fighting about how to spend it."
Another telling moment came when the National Republican Congressional Committee, the House Republicans' campaign arm, churned out press releases this month attacking seven Democrats from traditionally competitive districts. The Democrats were assailed not, as might have been expected, for being big spenders, but for opposing spending projects by voting against a bill financing the Interior Department.
"In all my years in Congress this is a first: a member of Congress actually voting against a project that would have benefited his own district," Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, was quoted in each release as saying.
What all this suggests is that if there is the political will for a compromise, a deal could be struck reasonably quickly. Mr. Clinton and the Republicans are still fighting over 5 of the 13 annual spending bills.
"If we could get the political bull gravy out of this debate, we could solve all the remaining dollar problems in about three days," Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in floor debate last week. "We are not that far apart."
The White House, however, has been trying hard to play down any expectation that a compromise is in sight. "I think people are thinking it's all easier than it is," said Jacob J. Lew, Mr. Clinton's budget director, insisting that the president had several important initiatives he wanted put in place.
Some Democrats acknowledge privately that they do not want a quick solution. In years past, the Democrats have been able to use the budget fight to portray the Republicans as hostile to popular retirement and education programs or as irresponsible partisans who would shut down the government.
The Republicans' spending bills have made this line of attack much more difficult this year. But Democrats are still trying to focus on those differences that remain, particularly by denouncing as "mindless" the Republicans' resorting to a 1 percent across-the-board cut.
In fact, many of the final points of contention have less to do with dollars than with policy.
Mr. Clinton objects to a bill for the Interior Department because of several riders objected to by environmentalists. They include provisions that pave the way for more logging in national forests, keep oil companies from having to pay fair market royalties for drilling on public land and allow companies that mine on federal land to leave behind waste.
When he vetoed another bill for the Commerce, State and Justice Departments, Mr. Clinton listed many objections. Most significant, the bill provided only a fraction of the money he requested for 50,000 new community police officers. It did not include language giving the federal government more powers to fight hate crimes. And it did not free up money to pay dues to the United Nations.
Other foreign policy issues concern the Republicans' failure so far to provide money for the Wye River peace accords in the Mideast and for helping with disarmament in the former Soviet Union.
The most intractable fight could well come over education, because each party wants to run in 2000 as a champion of schools. The struggle is not over money but over whose policy initiative is adopted.
Mr. Clinton wants another down payment on his program to put 100,000 new teachers in classrooms across the nation. Republicans, who argue that schools are a local issue, want states left flexible to use federal education money for whatever purpose they chose.
"I wouldn't treat things like education language and U.N. arrears as insignificant issues," Mr. Lew said.
The partisan animosities have been made more strained by the Republicans' stance on Social Security. Democrats and Republicans alike began promising this year to end the longstanding practice of drawing on tax revenues that are supposed to finance Social Security to pay for other programs. But that has proved difficult because both parties want to spend too much on other programs.
Still, Republicans contend that their spending bills protect Social Security. And House Republicans are running television commercials accusing the Democrats of wanting to use Social Security reserves for "big government" programs.
Democrats, stung by the advertisements, have seized on a report by the Congressional Budget Office showing that once fiscal gimmicks and creative accounting techniques are discounted, the Republicans' spending bills might well use up an estimated $17 billion in Social Security revenue. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said Senate Democrats would soon begin running their own commercials to counter the Republicans.
Fiscal analysts say there is a way that the Republicans' claims that they are protecting Social Security reserves could prove true -- if the economy does better across the next year than is now projected.
Republican leaders are gambling that as has been the case in the last three years, estimates of revenue will prove low, and the government will bring in more tax revenue in the fiscal year than expected. If that happens, the federal surplus will be larger than is now forecast, and federal spending would most likely not dip into Social Security reserves.
But if the economy does not prove as robust, the Republicans could be left in next year's campaign season trying to explain away official figures, traditionally released in October, that could show that Social Security reserves were not left untouched.
"They're betting the ranch," said Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, "that the economy is going to get better, not worse."
