HEADLINE: For Election Day, Ho-Hum Races, but a Rare Bit of Hope for Nassau Democrats

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Oct. 31

 BODY:
For the first time in a generation, Democratic candidates in Nassau County are looking forward to Election Day with gusto.
Nassau's renowned Republican machine has had a lock on county government since politicians wore crewcuts. But a fiscal crisis that produced a $300 million deficit this year and prompted a steep property-tax increase over the weekend has made this otherwise prosperous suburb seem an aberration in an age of widespread budget surpluses. And it has turned Tuesday's elections for the Nassau Legislature into some of the most competitive and closely watched contests in the New York region. 
 As off-year elections go, this year's are further off than most. In New Jersey, in the absence of a major statewide issue, the races for 80 Assembly seats are expected to draw a record low turnout. In Connecticut, a state record 40 percent of the candidates for mayor or first selectman face no opposition or only nominal opposition, the mayors of Hartford and New Haven among them.
And in suburban and upstate New York, state politicians say next year's presidential and United States Senate races overshadow several local contests this week. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both made recent appearances on behalf of candidates in close mayoral races upstate -- Mr. Giuliani in Troy, on behalf of Carmella R. Mantello, a Republican who is trying to unseat Mark Pattison despite the Democrats' 3-to-2 edge in enrollments, and Mrs. Clinton in Schenectady, where a Democratic city councilman, Gary McCarthy, is challenging the incumbent Republican, Albert Jurczynski.
In Erie County, the strongest Democratic area in western New York, the race for county executive has drawn the attention of national Republican and Democratic officials in recent weeks. In most statewide elections, a victory in Erie is essential for a Democratic candidate. But despite a Democratic enrollment edge of 100,000 voters, the incumbent, Dennis T. Gorski, has struggled in his race for a fourth term against the Republican challenger, Joel A. Giambra. Mr. Giambra, the city comptroller in Buffalo and a former Democrat who switched parties last year to endorse Gov. George E. Pataki and former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, held a commanding lead until this weekend, when a new poll by The Buffalo News showed the race up for grabs.
In Nassau County, however, local politics, for the first time in memory, have galvanized the two major parties and excited voters.
This year began with a series of embarrassing scandals, from soaring cost overruns in a county health insurance plan to revelations of widespread brutality by guards in the county jail that followed the beating death of an inmate. But it was the county's ailing finances in a time of economic plenty that gave Democrats an issue that aroused Nassau's wealthy residents.
For years, the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, had held property taxes to a minimum while allowing county expenses to rise quickly; he closed the widening gap each year by selling assets and taking other one-time steps to produce revenue. But after several large asset sales failed to materialize on time late in 1998 and early this year, Nassau suddenly found itself with a $300 million deficit. Wall Street rating agencies, which had threatened for months to lower their rating of the county's bonds, made good with a vengeance, dropping Nassau's debt rating two notches to a level just above junk.
Mr. Gulotta is not up for re-election until 2001. But the Republican legislators, who now hold a veto-proof 14-to-5 majority, are all up in Tuesday's elections. So, while Democratic candidates attacked Republican incumbents for approving Mr. Gulotta's budgets, the Republican lawmakers attacked their fellow Republican, Mr. Gulotta. They passed laws that significantly reduced his power to incur deficits. They shredded his proposed 2000 budget and vowed to rewrite it entirely. And, although they loudly claimed credit for cutting patronage jobs, most of the positions they threw out turned out to be those of clerks and officials seen as more loyal to Mr. Gulotta than to the party.
Despite making good on a promise to cut more than $40 million in spending, however, the Republican lawmakers, led by the presiding officer of the Legislature, Bruce A. Blakeman of Woodmere, find themselves in the unenviable position of having to defend a series of tax increases in the face of Democratic opposition.
In August, they enacted a 1 percent tax on real estate sales that they said would raise $50 million a year, but which Democrats immediately charged would unfairly penalize the elderly and others selling their homes. Finally, shortly after 1 a.m. on Saturday, they passed a budget that includes a 9.4 percent property tax increase.
The fiscal troubles seemed perfectly timed for Democrats, who rallied behind a new chairman, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli of Great Neck, last spring. Suddenly, and for the first time after years of petty infighting, the party's crop of challengers and its incumbents began speaking as if with one voice. And despite a vast financial disadvantage -- Republicans expect to spend $1.2 million on the legislative races, about four times as much as Democrats -- officials in both parties say four Republican seats could be in jeopardy.
In Roosevelt and Uniondale, Patrick Williams, who lost a three-way race in 1997, is challenging the incumbent, Darlene Harris. In Rockville Centre and Baldwin, Joseph Scannell, a former prosecutor who quit the Republican Party in disgust in June, is challenging Thomas A. Glynn. In Merrick, a Democratic lawyer, David Denenberg, is challenging Edward Ward, the third-ranking Republican legislator and a former aide to Mr. Gulotta. And in Long Beach and the Five Towns, Jeffrey Toback, another lawyer, is challenging Mr. Blakeman. Democrats also believe that Brian Muellers, a former aide to Mayor Thomas Suozzi of Glen Cove, could win his race against Legislator John Canning, if Mr. Suozzi is re-elected Tuesday by a wide margin.
Gaining just two seats would give Democrats the power to block the county from issuing bonds, a crucial bit of leverage; five seats -- an almost unimaginable outcome -- would give the Democrats a 10-to-9 majority.
As in most races around the region, turnout is expected to be light. But Mr. DiNapoli said today that the mix of voters could produce surprising results. "The key dynamic is whether Republicans who are frustrated about things stay home as a protest," he said. "If they do, and independents swing our way, and Democrats come out in significant numbers, that's a recipe for significant change."
Turnout is also expected to be extremely light in New Jersey, where the 80 seats in the State Assembly are up for election, but where the paucity of important and clear-cut issues has many experts predicting that voter participation could reach a new low.
"People aren't even unhappy about auto insurance anymore, which is unheard of in New Jersey," said Gerald M. Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University. "To get people to vote you need a little bit of an incentive. But there's nothing driving people now, other than their sense of civic duty."
Democrats would need to win nine seats to regain a majority, but most political strategists expect incumbents to win in at least 70 races.
The most fiercely contested race is in the Fourth District, in and around Camden, where Democrats have campaigned aggressively against the two Republican Assemblymen, Gerald Luongo and George Geist. But groups representing gun owners have rallied to defend the two, providing volunteers and telephone banks to urge thousands of gun owners in the district to turn out on Election Day.
In Connecticut, many people might reasonably assume that their votes will make little difference Tuesday.
In Hartford, the state capital, Mayor Michael Peters is unchallenged. In New Haven, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. faces two candidates who made it onto the ballot by gathering petitions but lack any party's backing. In Plainfield, only two candidates are on the ballot for the three-member Board of Selectmen, meaning that the write-in candidate with the most votes will win.
"If the trend continues, of course, it could be a terrible thing," said Sandy Astarita, a Republican town chairwoman in New Haven. "But it is also a mistake to enter token opposition. Fielding no candidate is more honest with the party and the public."
In Westchester County, the most closely watched election will be for the 17-member county Board of Legislators, which two years ago switched from Republican to Democratic control for the first time, and by a single seat. Making the race even more important is that the party that controls the board will be in office when election districts are redrawn after the 2000 census; historically, those boundaries are drawn to help the dominant party's candidates.
In an unusual race in Rockland County, incumbents are running against incumbents on the county Legislature, in the first election since a court order in 1997 led to a redistricting that reduced the number of seats to 17 from 21.

HEADLINE: THE CRASH OF EGYPTAIR 990: THE PLANE;
An Aircraft With a Good Record, but a Carrier With Security Failures in Its Past

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The Egyptair Boeing 767 that crashed this morning was a relatively new model with a good safety record, operated by an airline with extensive international experience and relatively few operational problems, although some horrible security failures.
The plane was delivered new to Egyptair almost exactly 10 years ago, on Sept. 26, 1989, and had completed about 6,900 flights, covering about 30,000 flight hours since then -- about normal for a long-range plane of that age. 
 Egyptair operated five 767's, including the plane that crashed. It was one of its two extended-range 767-300's, the newest version produced by Boeing; it could fly 7,080 miles nonstop, putting Cairo well within range of New York.
Egyptair is one of the world's oldest airlines, tracing its operations to 1933. It is owned by the government and a candidate for privatization under a new policy of economic liberalization.
In the 1970's, when Egypt was allied with the Soviet Union, it acquired a fleet of Ilyushins and other Russian jets; now it flies Boeings and Airbuses. The airline said its planes are an average of six years old, which would make it one of the youngest fleets in the industry.
But Egyptair has frequently been a target of hijackers, most recently on Oct. 19, when a passenger kicked in the cockpit door on a flight from Istanbul to Cairo and forced the crew to fly to Hamburg. All aboard were released without injury. In November 1985, a Boeing 737 was taken over by hijackers on a flight from Athens to Cairo. The hijackers shot two passengers, and Egyptian commandos stormed the plane in Malta, where 57 more were killed.
One month earlier, an Egyptair 737 was carrying the hijackers of the ocean liner Achille Lauro when the plane was intercepted by American fighter jets and forced to land in Italy.
The 767, a twin-engine jet with two aisles, seats seven abreast in economy class. The model has become very popular with airlines for trans-Atlantic flights, replacing older planes, partly because it has a lower operating cost.
The plane's operating record is generally good. One owned by Lauda Air, an Austrian airline, crashed in the jungle near Bangkok, Thailand, in May 1991, killing all 223 people aboard. Investigators found that a thrust reverser, a device usually used on the runway shortly after landing to redirect the jet exhaust and slow the plane, had deployed during the flight.
According to a Web site that tracks airplanes, the plane that crashed today came off the assembly line at the Boeing plant in Seattle immediately before the Lauda plane.
The Boeing 767 is covered by a number of "airworthiness directives," or orders from the Federal Aviation Administration to inspect or fix certain parts, because of crashes involving other airplanes. Among the directives are inspections of fuel tank wiring required after the explosion of T.W.A. 800, which was a Boeing 747.
A difference between the Egyptair flight and T.W.A. 800 could be the functioning of its flight data recorders and cockpit voice recorders. The ones on T.W.A. 800 stopped at the beginning of the event, apparently because of a complete loss of electrical power. But the Egyptair plane had electrical power for at least 36 more seconds, with its transponder continuing to function, and its recorders may have continued.
In addition, as a later vintage airplane that is about 15 years younger than T.W.A. 800, the Egyptair 767's flight data recorder might have captured more information. Boeing was not able to say this evening, however, what it equipped the plane with when it was delivered.

HEADLINE: Charges Unravel Drug-Use Scholar's Career

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
For a quarter-century, Dr. Ansley Hamid was a creative researcher and trailblazing anthropologist, discovering and documenting trends in urban drug use that were closely watched and, in some cases, celebrated by academics and drug-use experts nationwide.
With notebook in hand, Dr. Hamid, with his bushy beard and jumble of hair, would trudge into America's drug underworld, talking to addicts and users and documenting such trends as the advent of crack in New York. But his "crowning achievement," as the professor put it, came in 1996, when the federal government awarded $2.6 million to Dr. Hamid's employer, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, so he could head a five-year study of heroin use in New York's toughest neighborhoods. 
 "Finally," the professor said, "I get national and international recognition."
Instead of finding acclaim, though, Dr. Hamid has watched his career disintegrate.
Last Monday, a federal complaint filed in Manhattan accused Dr. Hamid, 55, of misusing money from the grant, which was made by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, a division of the federal Department of Health and Human Services. Based on a two-year investigation, the complaint said that Dr. Hamid used at least $5,000 to take trips, buy CD's and hire researchers to work on a book manuscript -- all unrelated to the research for which the money was earmarked.
The complaint also said Dr. Hamid directed a researcher to use fund money to buy heroin for his subjects.
In addition, Dr. Hamid, who remains free on a $25,000 bond after appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, faces the loss of his position at John Jay, where he received tenure in 1992 after teaching there for eight years. The professor was suspended from the heroin project in December 1997 and removed from teaching in January 1999, though he is still being paid.
College officials are building a case to revoke his tenure, said Robert E. Diaz, the college's counsel.
The professor remains adamant about his innocence, charging that colleagues envious over his success conspired with university officials to ruin him.
"I'm looking at 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000, for what is really trumped-up charges," he said.
Dr. Hamid does not deny spending money on some of the items outlined in the complaint, but he disputes the federal complaint's assertions that the spending was not related to his research. The money, the professor said, came from a discretionary fund that made $30,000 available to him annually.
"I spent most of my money on additional computers," he said. "The first $30,000 I got, I got more assistants. I bought more books. I bought some of these famous CD's."
College officials and several former colleagues disagree with the professor's assessments. Joy Settembrino, whom Dr. Hamid hired to supervise workers and handle the direct-cost account from the federal grant, contended that the professor "started getting carried away with the spending."
Ms. Settembrino said Dr. Hamid requested money from the account for items that did not appear related to the heroin research. She said she refused. So Dr. Hamid instead spent from an indirect-cost account, Ms. Settembrino said, in the process accumulating such items as a tapestry worth about $800, computer equipment that is no longer at the university and furniture that never arrived at the project's offices. Her assertions are backed by other project workers.
"It almost seemed that he acted as if the check for the full $2.6 million was written out to him to do as he pleased," Ms. Settembrino said.
Colleagues and drug experts who said they had long admired Dr. Hamid's work, and even some of those who denounced the professor's supposed excesses, have been saddened by the revelations. The long career of a serious academic and investigator appears to have met a scandalous end, they said.
"I don't want anyone to imply I'm taking a position, but I'm very unhappy about a man of achievement who's in this situation," said Dr. Nathan Gould, chairman of the anthropology department at John Jay. "It's a tragic situation. It may not be Shakespearean in scope, but for him, it is. For him, it's a terrible, terrible situation."
Nothing in Dr. Hamid's past could have portended such a messy future. The son of a lawyer in San Fernando, Trinidad, Dr. Hamid said he and his siblings were "very respectful of law and order."
His first major stop in academia was the London School of Economics, where he received a sociology degree in 1968 and developed far-left political theories he never really abandoned. After teaching and studying in Nigeria and India, Dr. Hamid arrived at Columbia University in the mid-1970's.
Working under Dr. Lambros Comitas, he developed a keen interest in the role drugs and drug policies play in society. To Dr. Comitas, who has taught at Columbia since 1958 and heads anthropology programs, the young man "was one of our best students, one of our brightest and best."
"He really became an expert on the poor and how they survive in places like Brooklyn," Dr. Comitas said.
After receiving a doctorate in anthropology in 1980, Dr. Hamid soon distinguished himself by heading into the bleakest neighborhoods in the city, developing rapport with residents and, ultimately, drug dealers, users and addicts.
The professor earned a reputation for building trust with the people in an underworld suspicious of outsiders. In fact, in dank apartments and on blighted street corners, Dr. Hamid would often be greeted enthusiastically by his subjects.
"His strength has always been to get people from the world outside the ivory tower to talk about their lives," said Karen Colvard, program officer for the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation, which gave Dr. Hamid two grants. "Hamid's style is a little bit more mellow and laid back. He schmoozes more with people, than asking direct questions."
Dr. Hamid's findings began to receive notice. He developed theories detailing the structure of the informal drug economy. He wrote about how Washington's tough marijuana interdiction policies in the 1970's and 1980's hastened the international trafficking of cocaine.
Ethan Nadelmann, director of the Lindesmith Center, a New York organization that pushes for change in drug policies, said Dr. Hamid's findings could presage trends that had yet to be acknowledged by drug-abuse experts in and outside government. Mr. Nadelmann said that in the early 1990's, he told an official from the federal drug czar's office that crack cocaine use had peaked, as Dr. Hamid had begun to tell him.
The official scoffed, Mr. Nadelmann recalled, but six months later, he acknowledged to Mr. Nadelmann that the assertion was true.
"The answer is Andy Hamid," Mr. Nadelmann said. "He was picking it up on the street. He went to Harlem. He went to Washington Heights."
Dr. Hamid also published papers and one book, "Drugs in America: Sociology, Economics and Politics," in 1998. He also said he edited another book and wrote manuscripts for two more. His work brought him grants from foundations, universities and government agencies. Most of the amounts were modest, though the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation gave him $130,000 for two projects that listed him as principal investigator.
So for the professor, nothing could have been seen as more of an affirmation of his work than the government's $2.6 million grant, which was made to John Jay and the Research Foundation of the City University of New York, for a project titled Heroin in the 21st Century. Then, in 1997, the National Institute on Drug Abuse notified the college that an additional $2.8 million grant had been approved, this one for Dr. Hamid to study drug policies in the Caribbean.
"These awards were crowning achievements of this whole 25-year career," Dr. Hamid said.
But by early 1997, Dr. Hamid's reputation had begun to unravel. His demeanor had begun to deteriorate, former colleagues said, and he became volatile and verbally abusive. Dr. Hamid, who had overall authority on the project, also cut salaries and fired at least five researchers, current and former employees of the project said.
"He would not give grandfatherly advice," said Dr. Richard Curtis, an anthropology professor at John Jay who was a co-writer of the grant request for financing for the heroin project and who served as project director. "He would sometimes be quite nasty about it, and people would leave in tears. People were kind of traumatized, because they felt they had done their best."
Travis Wendel, a doctoral candidate at John Jay, said that during a dispute over a paper he had written, Dr. Hamid became so angry that he challenged Mr. Wendel to a fight.
"Having a bit of power and control and so on went to his head, and he couldn't handle it," said Mr. Wendel, who said he was the first employee fired by Dr. Hamid. "He's just worse with people than anyone I've known in my life."
With questions over Dr. Hamid's management style threatening to derail the project, exasperated researchers at first went to Dr. Curtis for advice. Dr. Curtis responded by going to the department chairman, Dr. Gould, and college officials. When allegations arose in late 1997 about the possible misuse of grant money, sources close to the case said the college notified the Department of Health and Human Services and an investigation ensued.
Dr. Hamid is especially vehement in his accusations against Dr. Curtis, who was once a close friend and studied with him at Columbia. The fact that the heroin project is continuing with Dr. Curtis, who remains as project director while another professor has replaced Dr. Hamid as principal investigator, only seems to raise Dr. Hamid's ire further.
"There's one person given this grant, and that was myself, and it was based on my published work," Dr. Hamid said. "The college did not want to see me have that prominence, and from the very beginning began to promote Curtis as some kind of equal."
Dr. Curtis, who is highly regarded by colleagues and drug-abuse experts, said that Dr. Hamid had been "paranoid that people were out to get him" since receiving the grant.
And Jerry Capeci, a spokesman for the college, called Dr. Hamid's accusations "utter nonsense."
"The college moved against him because staffers and others involved in the grant's activities made serious allegations against him, and the allegations proved to be credible," Mr. Capeci said. "We gave him tenure. We had nothing against him, but it was our duty to move against him."
The professor still has his supporters, people like Suzana Maia, a part-time researcher on the project, who said: "I never had any problem with Professor Hamid. I was very well treated during the short period I stayed in the program."
But Dr. Hamid, who has remained away from the university during the saga, is wistful about his years of work and worried about the future.
"It looks like this whole action at John Jay has destroyed my viability and made it more difficult for me to go to funding agencies," he said. "So it's a little heartbreaking that all of that has been destroyed."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Computer Scientists Are Poised For Revolution on a Tiny Scale

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Scientists at a variety of elite laboratories around the country are sharing a growing sense that they are on the brink of a new era in digital electronics. It will usher in a world of circuits no more than a few atoms wide, with a potential impact on computing, in terms of speed and memory, that may be too profound to fathom.
It was only in July that a group of researchers at Hewlett-Packard and the University of California at Los Angeles reported that they had successfully fashioned rudimentary electronic logic gates -- a basic component of computing -- that were the thickness of a single molecule. Now other groups are preparing to announce that they have succeeded in creating other basic computing components at this ultramicroscopic scale, known as molecular electronics. 
 Researchers at Yale and Rice Universities, for example, plan to report in the journal Science in a few weeks that they have taken an important step past the Hewlett-U.C.L.A. work. In the July demonstration, the molecular gate could be made to move into open or shut positions, but could not be switched back again. But the Yale-Rice team says it has created molecular-scale switches that can be repeatedly opened and shut -- a necessary step in representing zeros and ones, the basic binary signals used in the circuitry of digital transistors.
And now Hewlett-Packard scientists say they have recently taken an important step toward creating rows of conductive wires that are less than a dozen atoms across -- a crucial part of hooking together the molecule-sized switches that could one day result in computers vastly faster than today's.
The rapid sequence of breakthroughs is giving the researchers a new sense of confidence. "We're on the scent, and we know the fox is out there," said Stan Williams, a Hewlett-Packard physicist who is a pioneer in molecular electronics.
According to the buzz in this research community, meanwhile, other laboratories are making progress on a number of fronts, working under top-secret conditions. One of these labs is said to be working on a molecular device capable of holding random-access memory, or RAM.
If molecular memory devices could be constructed, they might offer vast storage capabilities for just pennies in cost. One near-term application might be to permanently store an entire DVD-quality movie in a space much smaller than a conventional semiconductor chip.
As an applied science, molecular electronics would begin at a minute scale far beyond the theoretical boundaries of the conventional technology of silicon transistors.
Today's silicon-based microelectronic devices have a minimum size between electrical components of 0.18 micron (about one-thousandth the thickness of a human hair) and could potentially go as small as 0.10 micron. That would be 100-billionths of a meter, or 100 nanometers.
But in molecular electronics, the smallest components may be able to shrink to one-hundredth that size -- a single nanometer. The difference could mean chips exponentially more powerful than anything of a comparable size today or computing devices unimaginably tiny by contemporary standards.
The recent rapid pace of advance has led to a palpable sense of mission among a small group of physicists, chemists and computer designers, who until recently were viewed as impractical dreamers by much of the computer industry.
"In two to five years, you will begin to see functioning circuits which are of recognizable utility," said John C. Ellenbogen, a molecular electronics researcher at the Mitre Corporation, a research center for the military and private industry.
Such optimism leads a number of researchers to believe that rapidly cascading advances in molecular-scale science may soon constitute what economists refer to as a disruptive technology -- one that changes basic industrial assumptions, just as the transistor did in replacing the vacuum tube during the 1950's, and as integrated circuits overtook individual transistors during the 1960's. Some molecular electronics researchers envision an entirely new industry, perhaps within the next decade.
The consequences of such a revolution would be immense and possibly destabilizing for the world's semiconductor industry. Although the chip industry now believes that it sees a path at least until 2014 for making ever-smaller solid-state silicon devices, the cost of the manufacturing systems to make the chips is enormous -- and continuing to mount with each new chip generation.
Today's semiconductor chips are made in multibillion-dollar fabrication plants -- or "fabs" -- that use light waves to etch successive layers of circuitry on a silicon substrate. It is an expensive process, in part because of the high cost of creating and maintaining the "clean rooms" required for avoiding contamination by dust. But researchers in molecular electronics are optimistic that they will be able to use much less finicky methods by creating chemical reactions that "self-assemble" vast numbers of molecular-scale circuits at infinitesimal cost.
"This should scare the pants off anyone working in silicon," said Mark Reed, a Yale University chemist, who is co-author of the forthcoming Science article and co-leader of a related memory project to be announced Dec. 6 at the International Electron Device Meeting in Washington. "It will be dirt cheap and it will create a discontinuity."
A colleague in the field agrees. "If you can make computers as easily as photographic film, then a lot of companies are going to be wondering what they're doing with their $15 billion fabs," said James R. Heath, a U.C.L.A. chemist who is part of the Pentagon-financed Hewlett-Packard-U.C.L.A. research team that demonstrated molecular logic gates last summer.
The vision of a new industry has captured government and corporate attention. The Clinton administration is now considering the possibility of a National Nanotechnology Initiative as early as next January to set up financing and help organize diverse research activities in nanotechnology -- a range of manufacturing technologies that begin at the scale of individual molecules. Moreover, a number of computer and semiconductor companies, led by Sun Microsystems and Motorola, have been quietly meeting with scientists to discuss the formation of an industry consortium to seek commercial applications for molecular electronics.
And yet, researchers acknowledge that so far they have taken only the first baby steps toward the larger challenge of building molecular-scale computers. No one, for example, has figured out how to interconnect billions and billions of molecular switches with wires 11 atoms in diameter.
"It feels like we're a year before the invention of the transistor and we're asking: 'What does solid state look like?' " said Paul Saffo, a researcher at the Institute for the Future who has tracked the development of new technologies.
And there is a general agreement that if such systems are to be assembled into workable computers, it will require radically new architectures alien to today's semiconductor-based computers.
At Hewlett-Packard, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Laboratory of Computer Science and at Mitre, computer scientists are beginning to explore computer architectures that are far more fault tolerant than today's microelectronic computers and whose structures resemble biological systems.
Manufacturing might involve assembling trillions of circuits and then identifying and mapping out the bad ones -- much as faulty sectors are declared off limits in today's disk drives.
"We will try to program with what we've got," said James Tour, a molecular scientist at Rice University. "It's a very biological approach: everyone's brain is the same, but the pathways are all unique."
Much of the research financing in this field now comes from the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. "We've built this entire program on the idea of thinking differently," William Warren, a program manager at the agency, said. "We don't want to be standing on the shoulders of silicon."
That is why the recent first steps toward eventual self-sufficiency have created such excitement in the molecular computing research community, a group that for years had a consistent vision but no empirical results.
"All of us were constantly on the defensive," Mr. Ellenbogen, the Mitre researcher, recalled. "Although we believed in some rational way this was the way to go, among ourselves we were continually forced to reassure ourselves that we weren't crazy."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about research breakthroughs in molecular electronics misstated the academic specialty of Mark Reed at Yale University. He is the chairman of the electrical engineering department, not a chemist. The article also misstated the given name of a researcher at the Mitre Corporation. He is James C. Ellenbogen, not John.

Diagram: "A Close-in Look at Molecular Switches"
Scientists are working to perfect a new type of integrated circuit that uses a chemical process to create an electronic switch as small as a molecule.
 
HOW IT WORKS
Electricity travels from the titanium-coated wires to the aluminum-oxide-coated ones, passing through rotaxane molecules. If the voltage difference between the wires is small, the molecules will not change; they will conduct electricity. A large difference will cause the molecules to become insulators, making them open switches.

HEADLINE: For the Musical Alchemist, a New Tack: Cryogenics

BYLINE: By TERRY H. SCHWADRON 

 BODY:
It was a chance meeting. Dr. Joseph Markoff, a Philadelphia ophthalmologist and a classically trained trumpet player, was entertaining at a family party when one of the guests made a startling proposition: would Dr. Markoff consider having his trumpet frozen?
"I thought he was some kind of nut," Dr. Markoff said. "I could not imagine what he was talking about." 
 But the guest, Steven Wasser, a flute manufacturer, was perfectly serious. As president of Powell Flutes, in Maynard, Mass., he had been experimenting with deep-freezing techniques, and had become convinced that something musically interesting occurred as a result. Cryogenics had a lot to offer musicians, he said.
Dr. Markoff, who knew of the uses of cryogenics in the operating room, was intrigued. He agreed to send Mr. Wasser an old trumpet.
It was not a valued instrument, said Dr. Markoff, who described it as "best suited for a lamp." But when he played it after it had been frozen, Dr. Markoff found the instrument had become "one of the freest-blowing" and most superbly focused trumpets he had ever owned.
Mr. Wasser said he had experienced such success with the freezing process that he now regularly included that step in the flute-manufacturing process. "I don't publicize cryogenics because I can't prove it scientifically," he said. "But almost everyone who has tried a blind test picks the treated instrument."
Deep-freezing musical instruments may sound extreme, but it is just one example of how brass and woodwind makers are wrestling with deciding just how much to allow technology to remake their craft.
For hundreds of years, brass-instrument makers have tinkered with their processes and hoarded their secret tricks like alchemists of old, all with the hope of making it easier to amplify the sound made by a vibrating column of air. It is a business in which science traditionally has run a distant second to the art of tailoring the instrument to the musician. The musician is invited to visit the factory and all but create the instrument in hope of supplying a perfect combination of acoustics and alloys to satisfy the human, if not the scientific, ear.
As the technological revolution expands into music, however, instrument makers find themselves split over whether to welcome or shun the economic benefits of computerization, robots and precision tooling. While the new technologies can make manufacturing cheaper, instrument manufacturers resist a one-size-fits-all approach. They talk about another goal: the creation of instruments individually suited to the musicians who play them.
"In the end, every instrument is different," said Richard K. Breske, vice president of United Musical Instruments of Elkhart, Ind., one of the largest musical instrument manufacturers. "We stretch metal and pound it, heat it, cool it. We give people interchangeable parts to make the sound brighter or darker, more or less resistant and then make lots of small changes to fit the sound our musicians want," he said.
So United, which makes instruments under brand names like Conn and Benge, as well as Yamaha Musical Products, the Edwards Instrument Company, the Getzen Company and the Selmer Company, makers of Bach instruments, all now sell brass instruments with multiple bells, lead pipes and other parts that vary in size or thickness or alloy. The variety is all meant to help musicians who are trained to hear such differences more easily make the sounds they prefer.
A yellow bell on a trombone, for example, is generally about 70 percent copper and 30 percent zinc; a noticeably more red bell is about 90 percent copper, 10 percent zinc. Jazz musicians generally seek the yellow bell for its "brighter" tones, while redder bells seem more preferred among symphony musicians, who seek "darker" coloration in sound. The difference is in the timbre of the sound rather than in loudness or range. Attentive concertgoers might see musicians changing instruments for different pieces.
The basic processes of producing a horn have remained unchanged for decades, even centuries. Brass alloys are stretched, cut, hammered, spun. The metal is shaped against hard surfaces, brazed, soldered and buffed. Some companies are using computer-guided production and robots for hammering, but the basic idea is age-old.
But somehow, some instrument makers believe, these manufacturing techniques seem to be causing problems.
"All that soldering, bending, banging causes actual stress in the metal itself," said Andrew Naumann, director of development for trumpets at Edwards. Mr. Naumann, who himself builds models of historical trumpets, explained that stretching and soldering "can make an instrument blow 'tight' rather than freely. It is that free sound that most professionals want."
Enter cryogenics.
Stretching metal into the contortions that make up the average trumpet or tuba may upset the alloy's molecular structure. What was a discernible arrangement of molecules becomes less orderly, and stressed. Heat may make metal more malleable, but it may also spread the molecules. Supercooling treatments appear to return the molecules to a more orderly arrangement, relieving stress in the metal.
Or so goes the theory.
Almost all the scientific work on supercooling metal has involved ferrous metals, steel mostly. Brass has received little attention, relatively speaking. In fact, a dozen or more companies around the country offer to deep-freeze a variety of steel products, including razor blades, golf clubs and drill bits. They display performance charts assuring greater longevity and hardness in metal after cryogenic treatment.
So why not musical instruments? Those who have tried the deep-freeze say there is a difference in ease of playing and in the range of "color" in the tone.
Wayne Tanabe, owner of the Brass Bow music repair shop in Arlington Heights, Ill., has a cryogenics tank big enough to hold a tuba.
For about $200, Mr. Tanabe cleans an instrument with ultrasound, then he wraps it, and, over 35 to 50 hours, he gradually lowers its temperature to about 325 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, well above absolute zero (459 degrees below zero Fahrenheit).
As Mr. Tanabe explains it, the extreme cold can accelerate what seems to happen to brass instruments as they age. Sound quality improves, he said, because resonance is clearer. He believes that his is a once-in-a-lifetime treatment, and that the effects last indefinitely.
Mr. Tanabe offers testimonials from musicians, including several from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. But his advertising is by word of mouth. "Otherwise, people think you're talking about voodoo," he said.
Because there has been little scientific research on the effect of extreme cold on musical instruments, several of the larger manufacturers have decided not to pursue such techniques. "We've heard about it, but we cannot show that it works," said Mr. Breske of United Musical Instruments. Fred Powell, who directs brass instrument development for United, said that the techniques might relieve structural stress, but that there was no evidence that the metal changed.
Even some specialized brass instrument manufacturers are skeptical. David G. Monette of Portland, Ore., has built the unusual, recognizable trumpets that Wynton Marsalis uses. At seven pounds, his trumpets, which include a built-in mouthpiece and a rare inner and outer bell, can weigh up to three times as much as more popular trumpets. "Brass is brass," Mr. Monette said. "It is what you do with it that matters."
Cryogenics, he said, "is the poor man's answer to problems in resonance," the problems of creating a pleasing tone.
Mr. Monette believes in the theories about stress, but says he has a secret proprietary manufacturing process that is a better antidote. He was part of a study performed by the Materials Research Society with Sandia National Laboratories that probed resonance both in his trumpets and in a golf club he produced. The study suggested that the patterns of resonance were similar. "Resonance is the name of the game," Mr. Monette said. "It is what we all are after." .
By contrast, Powell Flutes, which uses precious metals, not brass, has been swayed, even if Mr. Wasser cannot prove his belief. Mr. Wasser, the company's president, has sought scientific verification for introducing cryogenics to his manufacturing process for several years, ever since he learned that supercooling had helped strengthen fasteners used on the space shuttle.
At least one expert rejects Mr. Wasser's theory. Dr. Harry C. Gatos, a retired professor of materials science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a flute player, insisted that several diagnostic tests he and a team had run could turn up no measurable differences in silver, gold or platinum used in the instruments that had been supercooled. Furthermore, he said, if there had been any change, it would probably wear off. "Theory tells us that nothing should happen under cooling, and we saw no evidence of it," he said. "But people swear they feel a difference."
Dr. Markoff, the ophthalmologist, has been spreading the word about cryogenics among 20 musicians in the Philadelphia Orchestra, where he is a substitute player. As a result, about 45 instruments have been frozen, and while results were not uniform, many musicians described the sound as "richer" and "more focused" and the instruments as having "easier response."
Scientifically, Dr. Markoff said, "I believe that cryogenics stabilizes the brass and reduces extraneous vibrations and harmonics. It dampens whatever interferes with resonance and eliminates obstacles between the musician's lips and air column and the instrument. But the bottom line is that it makes me sound better."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Yield 6.18%, Amid Hopes of Only One Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Yields of Treasury securities held near their four-week lows yesterday amid hopes that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates more than once in coming months to check inflation.
Michael Andreas, chief of fixed-income trading at Advest Inc., said the chances are pretty good that the Fed is going to raise rates 25 basis points at its meeting on Nov. 16, adding, "That would finish out what it has to do.". 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its yield, fell 7/32, to 99 9/32. The bond's yield rose to 6.18 percent, from 6.16 percent on Friday.
Bond prices crept lower in afternoon trading after the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, Michael Moskow, said inflation would become a threat without a slowdown in the "robust" pace of growth, which ran at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter. But core consumer-price increases, excluding food and energy, increased 2.1 percent annually, which was less than in the 12-month period a year earlier. But Mr. Moskow said that future news on inflation might not be as good as it has been in recent years.
Gary Madich, senior managing director for fixed income at Banc One Investment Advisers, which has $70 billion in investments, maintained that "there's still that whiff of inflation out there." He agreed that an interest rate increase by the Fed was highly possible but that a series of rate increases after that was not likely.
Investors said another round of gains after last week's rally was unlikely before the employment report on Friday, which some analysts predicted might show the biggest addition of jobs in three months. If this occurs, that could shake expectations fueled by reports last week that nine years of economic expansion were still not generating much inflation.
Treasuries initially dropped yesterday after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its prices-paid index rose to 69.4 in October from 67.6 in September, indicating that more companies reported price increases in the month. October's price index was the highest since it was 70.5 in May 1995.

HEADLINE: Fresh Gains Are Reported in Manufacturing

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded in October for the ninth consecutive month, a survey of business executives showed today.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its factory index was 56.6 last month, meaning a majority of the manufacturers surveyed reported improved business. The decline from 57.8 in September reflected a drop in new orders from a five-year peak that month and a similar slowing of production. 
 The economy "is still looking quite good," said Samuel Siegel, vice chairman of Nucor in Charlotte, N.C., the nation's second-biggest steel producer. "We don't see the classic signs of a peak." Demand is strong for commercial and industrial construction projects, he added.
A separate Commerce Department report today showed that construction spending rose five-tenths of a percent in September, to $700.1 billion, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. Spending has held close to that level all year. Government spending on highways and schools rose last month while residential building fell for a sixth consecutive month.
The association's index of prices paid by factories for raw materials rose to 69.4 in October from 67.6 in September. It was the highest since a reading of 70.5 in May 1995 and indicated that more companies reported price increases in the month.
Still, that does not mean inflation is going to accelerate, analysts said. "Commodity prices are no longer rising continuously," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. "We expect the price index to moderate next month."
Part of the rise in the index could be because of increases in oil prices, which are up 80 percent since the start of the year. Last month, however, petroleum prices fell.
Broader gauges of commodity prices also showed declines. The Goldman Sachs commodity index has fallen 6 percent from a peak in late September.
The association's overall index has been above 50 since January, after declining to 45.3 in December. That was the lowest reading since May 1991, when the economy was emerging from the last recession. Readings above 50 mean that more manufacturers said business had picked up than said it had declined.
The association's index of new orders fell to 59.5 from September's 64.4; it was the highest since a reading of 65 in June 1994. The production index fell to 58.3 from 61.7; it was the second-highest since July 1997.
The index of export orders held above 50 last month for a ninth month after 14 months of shrinking sales overseas.
Today's Commerce Department report suggested that construction had leveled off as a force in the economy. Spending rose steadily from August 1998 until it peaked at an annualized rate of $715.4 billion in March. September's small rebound put total spending 4.2 percent higher than a year earlier.
Economists said higher borrowing costs -- 30-year fixed mortgage rates are now close to 8 percent -- contributed to the slowdown.

HEADLINE: Scotland's Technology Nexus;
Silicon Glen Blend: Equal Parts Theory and Practice

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: GLASGOW

 BODY:
John Dunlop might very well have the look and manner of an archetypal academic or a midlevel bureaucrat, aloof from the high-technology revolution sweeping the globe. In reality, though, rather like a digital Braveheart, he is very much part of his country's updated assault on the electronic barricades.
Since late last year, behind the imposing Gothic ramparts of Glasgow's Strathclyde University, Dr. Dunlop, 55, a professor of electronic systems engineering, has been working on a project to monitor incoming radio signals so efficiently that as they begin to weaken, they can be bolstered back to full audibility. 
 What lifted this modest, $100,000 venture out of the groves of academe was that it was conducted in conjunction with the local subsidiary of Motorola. And its intention was far from theoretical: as Europe prepares to embrace a new generation of mobile phones, the technology developed by Dr. Dunlop and his small team will, he said, eliminate the fade-outs that are among the biggest irritants of wireless telephony. That could give Motorola a potential edge over competitors if the company chooses to exercise its first option on licensing rights.
The notion of collaboration between university researchers and corporate partners is nothing new in the United States, or in parts of England to the south. But here, it is new and heretical -- and central to a major effort to break away from dependence on imported technology as a source of manufacturing employment, or "screwdriver" jobs, and burst into an era of innovation generated at home.
Increasingly, its proponents say, that shift is the cornerstone of Scotland's effort not just to attract foreign investment to the corridor of technology companies between Glasgow and Edinburgh -- an area nicknamed Silicon Glen -- but to harness Scotland's output of college graduates in a high-technology revolution of its own.
Silicon Glen has one big edge over Silicon Valley: while California companies compete avidly to hire talent, Scotland produces far more highly trained graduates than its fledgling electronics design industry can employ. But that is also the problem: little of that home grown talent stays at home.
"The most important thing is that we are able to take our ideas from the academic environment into the industrial department," Dr. Dunlop said. And the development of wireless technology is only a part of what he termed a wide range of scientific development at the university linked to businesses.
Such thinking, Scotland's boosters maintain, is the forerunner of a fundamental change in the way Scotland handles its high-technology future, seeking a commercial edge from its successes in biotechnology -- like the cloning of Dolly the sheep -- to its advances into the domain of intellectual property in the semiconductor business.
Even now, in a project backed by Cadence Design Systems of San Jose, Calif., Scottish authorities are preparing a 97-acre campus offering research facilities to corporations, cheek-by-jowl with an academic center -- known as the Alba Center -- designed to train graduates in advanced chip design. The intention, according to an Alba statement, is to put "Scotland at the forefront of shaping the global electronic design industry."
The project, taking shape over the last year, reflects a perception among some Scottish electronics entrepreneurs that the focus of Scotland's ambitions has rested for too long on the employment potential of foreigners' imported technology.
"We should be doing more, looking beyond job creation to knowledge creation," said David Milne, 56, managing director of Wolfson Microelectronics, a successful semiconductor design company in Edinburgh that was created in 1985 as a spinoff from an academic research foundation and this year expects sales of $20 million, up from $15 million last year.
Scotland has proved adept at persuading American concerns and other companies to set up the kind of job-producing plants and telephone call-centers that are a feature of foreign investment across Britain and Ireland. Indeed, some 40,500 people have found jobs in electronic manufacturing -- with some 29,000 more employed in the supply chain -- since companies like I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard set up manufacturing plants.
Scotland's ambition now, though, is to build centers of high-technology innovation challenging rivals like Cambridge (Silicon Fen) or Oxford (Silicon Spires), both set up explicitly to tap academia's knowledge for industrial purposes.
To do that, said Crawford W. Beveridge, chief executive of Scottish Enterprise, a government development agency, "what you have to do is to play the hand you are dealt."
"And," he added, "we've been dealt a better hand with the university system" than some of Scotland's European rivals.
Indeed, with some 9 percent of Britain's 50-million-plus population, Scottish universities produce 21 percent of the nation's postgraduate degrees in computer science. And even at the college level, they punch above their weight, turning out some 2,406 engineering and technology degrees, or 11 percent of the British total of 21,010. The idea now, Mr. Beveridge said, is to create clusters, bringing together university brain with the financial brawn of the world's $7 billion semiconductor market.
The scale of ambition is not altogether surprising. In August, Scotland's parliament was revived after 300 years, formalizing the land's claims to a separate political identity. Scotland's banks, moreover, have shown a new feistiness, competing in hostile -- if slow-moving -- maneuvers to take over one of England's biggest retail banks, National Westminster.
In a nation whose heart once beat to the rivet guns of ship-building on the Clyde, steel and other heavy industry, Scotland has mixed a newer economic life-blood from North Sea oil, tourism, food industries and technology. That shows in familiar ways: once the depressed domain of savvy bargain-hunters, the housing market in upscale sections of Glasgow and Edinburgh has "gone berserk," Mr. Beveridge said.
And anyone who doubts that Scotland sees itself as a land apart need only contemplate the recent draw for a major soccer tournament between Scotland and England. That mid-November fixture sent a frisson through the nation's sports fans with headlines gleefully feting the looming confrontation with what Scots call the "auld enemy" south of the border.
But the stand-alone ambitions are offset by a somewhat more glum reality.
Unlike Ireland, say, Scotland has yet to reverse the brain drain that takes its graduates away to other high-technology centers offering more established career trajectories. And while Silicon Valley quests in vain for more people to employ, Silicon Glen searches desperately for technology start-ups to employ Scotland's surfeit of talent.
"There are a lot of graduates out there," said Colin Thompson, a semiconductor design expert with a Scottish subsidiary of Micro Linear of San Jose. "But there aren't enough companies that want to hire them."
There is, though, a showcase of Scotland's ambitions to change all that, and it is to be found in the Alba Center, in a converted factory on the blustery outskirts of the town of Livingston, between Glasgow and Edinburgh. There, for the first time, four separate Scottish universities have joined with corporate supporters to establish a master's degree course in what its backers say is the way of the silicon future.
What makes the $50 million project distinctive is its fusion of Scottish academic teaching and research talent with American investment to produce what its director, Kevin Casey, calls the world's first master's degree in the new technology of assembling entire systems on a single chip. And the long-term goal is to strengthen Scotland's claim on a future as an electronics design center.
"It's not just about a job, it's about a career -- the first job, the second job, the third job," Mr. Casey said. "The idea is to grow the company base so that people coming out of university and people overseas recognize that there are career opportunities in Scotland." And that, he said, will "create the image of Scotland as a hotbed of activity" in the design of single units performing functions that once required several different chips.
Additionally, the Alba Center -- which takes its name from a ninth century union of Picts and Scots -- has a putative marketplace for chip designs that will go beyond the existing catalogs of available technology, drawing designers of "intellectual property" into a regulated exchange with potential corporate buyers like Advanced RISC Machines, Cadence Design Systems, Hitachi and Toshiba.
The idea, said Andy Travers, head of what is called the Virtual Component Exchange, is to lower the marketing costs of low-budget individual designers -- known generically as "Fred-in-a-shed," a term suggesting techie types laboring over high-powered computers in their back yards to produce design breakthroughs.
Additionally, Mr. Travers said, the exchange will establish regulations and legal norms intended to cut out hefty and laborious legal processes and accelerate the transition from "Fred's" inventions -- known as virtual components -- to commercial products.
In a way, Mr. Travers, 37, is an example of what Scotland wants to achieve. In 1986, with a degree in physics from Strathclyde University and four years' experience in chip design, he said, he "wanted to see the world" and took a job in Switzerland. After three years, though, "I got a hankering to come back and I did," albeit for a "vast cut in salary."
Now, he reckons, things are changing. "We have an influx of opportunities," he said. "You can live in a country where you don't have to sit in traffic for two hours. And you can get a job that's at the forefront of the technology that matters to you. You are going to be at the cutting edge."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Chase Manhattan must cut its revenue after discovering some nonexistent trading profits.

BYLINE: By Patrick McGeehan 

 BODY:
THE Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter trading revenue would be reduced by $60 million after the bank found it had booked nonexistent trading profits. The bank has dismissed a currency trader involved in the matter.
Bank officials declined to identify the trader or to say why he was dismissed. But people inside the bank said that a senior currency trader named Christopher Goggins was dismissed last week after an internal audit found he had been exploiting a flaw in the bank's systems to post gains on long-term trades that the bank could not realize. 
 They said the bank had not determined whether the breach was deliberate or inadvertent. Traders are usually compensated based on their annual trading performance.
A woman who answered the phone at Mr. Goggins's home in New Jersey said he was no longer employed at Chase. Mr. Goggins did not respond to messages left at the home.
In a statement, Chase said that no money was embezzled from the bank and that no customer funds were affected. Chase also noted that the $60 million cut in fourth-quarter revenue was barely significant to a bank with trading revenue of $2.2 billion in the first nine months of 1999.
"Clearly, this is something that they're embarrassed about and should be embarrassed about," said Lawrence Cohn, director of research at Ryan, Beck & Company in Livingston, N.J. "It's a breakdown in their internal control mechanisms."
The reversal of the paper gains will reduce the bank's net income this quarter by about 5 cents a share, analysts said. Chase's stock dropped $3.6875 a share yesterday, or 4 percent, to $83.5625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
According to people inside Chase, the trader had taken advantage of slight discrepancies in the bank's pricing of currency and interest-rate contracts for about a year. The trades involved currency forwards, or contracts to buy or sell currencies at a predetermined price on a future date. To limit risk, such trades typically involve the simultaneous purchase of one contract and sale of another.
These people said the trader was inflating the paper profits on his trades by using inappropriate methods to measure their value. The small differences in those pricing methods added up as the size of the positions grew larger through the year, they said.
"He was picking and choosing from two different cash streams on the same contracts to make it look like profits were being made that really weren't," a Chase executive said.
Chase officials declined to say whether the bank planned to take legal action against the trader.
Analysts who were briefed on the matter by a Chase executive said they were persuaded that the bank had rooted out the problem and repaired the flaw in its systems that allowed it to occur.
Mr. Cohn said that as he heard about the problem, he was reminded of Joseph Jett, a one-time star trader at Kidder, Peabody, a securities firm that has since closed. Mr. Jett was dismissed from Kidder after he was said to have exploited flaws in risk-management systems to book huge gains on trades that the firm never realized.
In 1996, an arbitration panel rejected Kidder's case seeking $82.8 million in fraud claims from Mr. Jett, though it withheld millions of dollars of his deferred compensation. Last year, Mr. Jett was found guilty of false record-keeping, ordered to repay $8.2 million of bonuses, fined $200,000 and barred from the securities industry.
Other analysts played down the Chase incident, calling it so minor that it would never have been noticed had the bank not disclosed it.
"This sort of thing -- traders getting beyond their scope -- happens occasionally," Diane Glossman, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said. "In all of the cases where it has happened to an American bank, they've proven to be isolated cases rather than an indication of faulty oversight."
Chemical Bank, one of the banks that merged to form Chase, had a big loss from one person's trades in 1994. Victor Gomez, a currency trader, lost $66 million in what his supervisors called unauthorized trading of contracts on the Mexican peso. Mr. Gomez was sentenced in 1997 to 37 months in jail for conspiring to defraud the bank by falsifying records.
"If something like this happens to them every five years, with as much currency trading as Chase does around the world," Ms. Glossman said, "that would indicate that their controls are pretty good."

HEADLINE: Andersen Consulting's Chief Makes E-Commerce New Goal

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Andersen Consulting said yesterday that Joe W. Forehand, a high-ranking partner with 27 years of experience at the firm, would be its new chief executive. Mr. Forehand said in an interview that he planned to make e-commerce the central part of the consulting firm and that the company intended to take stakes in clients more frequently.
Mr. Forehand, a native of Alabama who now lives in Texas, most recently led the firm's communications and high-technology practice, which accounts for about 25 percent of the company's revenue. He replaces George T. Shaheen -- who left in September to run Webvan Group, an Internet grocery delivery company -- as the head of the $9 billion firm, which employs 65,000 people in 48 countries. 
 The 51-year-old Mr. Forehand takes over at a crucial time for Andersen, the world's largest consulting firm. Its 1999 growth rate will fall below 20 percent for the first time since 1994 as its strength in installing back-office systems has become less lucrative and it has been embroiled in a nasty breakup with its former parent, Arthur Andersen. After bringing in $8.3 billion in revenue last year, Andersen Consulting will report a growth rate in the mid-teens for 1999, Mr. Forehand said.
Following in the footsteps of the dynamic Mr. Shaheen, the new chief executive is little known outside of Andersen, where he has spent his entire career, and one analyst said the appointment was a surprise, though strategically sensible.
"Andersen doesn't really need a dynamic, colorful leader anymore," said Tim Bourgeois, the vice president of research at Kennedy Information, a New Hampshire research firm that tracks consulting. "It makes sense to have a kinder, gentler person" as chief executive.
Mr. Forehand said he envisioned an Andersen that had a consulting practice at its core but increasingly invested in Internet ventures that would then be aligned with the firm. It would also use its consultants' ideas to start businesses.
Andersen, he said, should "become a part of the fabric of this new economy, not just watch it happen." Currently, 14,000 of Andersen's consultants are taking internal classes to improve their understanding of e-commerce, he added.
The firm already holds about a dozen stakes, typically worth $2 million to $3 million each, in start-ups for which it has done work, said Mr. Forehand, who majored in engineering at Auburn University. Mr. Forehand said he would aggressively expand such projects, particularly in business-to-business ventures.
Owning parts of other companies raises potential conflict-of-interest problems for consulting firms, which have long worked for more than one client in an industry. Clients could be reluctant to hire a firm that owns parts of a rival.
Mr. Forehand said he was confident that Andersen would be able to resolve such issues.
He also said he would not alter the firm's confrontational strategy of seeking a divorce from Arthur Andersen, from which it tried to break off almost two years ago. Andersen Consulting became a separate unit of Arthur Andersen in 1989, and the two have spent much of the 1990's arguing over how to co-exist.
The firms began an arbitration hearing on Oct. 25 in New York. It will wrap up at the end of next week, Mr. Forehand said, and he expects a ruling early in 2000 on the future structure of the firms.
That could end a process that has kept some of Andersen's top partners busy with internal business rather than on revenue-producing work. "It has been a distraction for them," said C. Scott Hartz, the managing partner for global consulting at PricewaterhouseCoopers, a rival firm.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Falls in Mixed Trading As Nasdaq Hits a New High

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday as traders and investors took some profits after the big run-up in market gauges over the last two weeks.
"It was a consolidation-type day," said Bryan Piskorowski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. "There was a little bit of profit taking, and word of another earthquake in Taiwan got people a little scared and took a little of the froth out of the Nasdaq." 
 While some semiconductor stocks, including Intel, dropped after news of the quake flashed across trading screens, the Nasdaq composite index managed to eke out another record.
At the close, the Nasdaq was up 1.22 points, or four-hundredths of a percent, to 2,967.65. Early in the session, the index flirted with 3,000 and got as high as 2,997.90.
Meanwhile, big declines in two conglomerates, General Electric and Tyco International, helped to push the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down by 8.81 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,354.12. Tyco fell 4 9/16, to 35 9/16, and G.E. dropped 6 1/8, to 129 3/8.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which included four new stocks -- Intel, Microsoft, Home Depot and SBC Communications -- for the first time, slumped 81.35 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 10,648.51. Declines in G.E., American Express, down 5, to 149, and DuPont, down 2 3/8, to 62 1/16, were largely responsible for the drop in the blue-chip index.
Two of the new Dow stocks -- Intel and Microsoft -- fell yesterday, with Intel down 1 7/16, to 76, and Microsoft dipping 3/16, to 92 3/8. SBC Communications and Home Depot gained, with SBC rising 2 1/8, to 53, and Home Depot rising 1/2, to 76 1/4.
Small stocks had a solid session with the Russell 2000 index of small-company shares gaining 3.18 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 431.82.
The pace of business was fairly brisk for a Monday, although much reduced from the heavy traffic recorded at the end of last week.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 861 million shares. On the Nasdaq stock market, 1.07 billion shares changed hands.
Traders said it was likely that business would not pick up significantly until after the Government releases October employment numbers on Friday.
Despite yesterday's mixed performance, many participants and analysts are coming to the view that the weeks and months of uncertainty that have impeded a broad advance may be coming to an end.
"I tend to be biased toward being pretty positive," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
"I don't think there is a lot of risk to the market," he said. "Interest rate fears are largely overblown, and Y2K is the ultimate one-time event. As a business issue, people will start to look past it."
Ebbing concern that interest rates will move higher prodded Byron R. Wien, a United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, to commit some spare cash from his model stock portfolio to a handful of financial service stocks.
"I am still quite cautious on the overall market," Mr. Wien said yesterday. "This was a tactical move because I think we are in a benign interest rate environment."
Several factors favor financial stocks at the moment, Mr. Wien said, including the pending elimination of the Glass-Steagall Act, strong economic growth with minimal inflation and the sense that a decision by Federal Reserve policy makers to raise short-term interest rates on Nov. 16 may be the last such increase for some time.
Financial stocks, which have climbed in the last two weeks, retreated a bit yesterday.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange/ KBW Bank Index, which had risen nearly 25 percent in two weeks, fell 10.68 points yesterday, or 1.2 percent, to 873.51.
Software companies had a good day, as investors began to focus on how they may help big companies transfer some of their business to the Internet.
Oracle and Siebel Systems, which sell customer-service and call-center software, were two big winners. Oracle gained 3 5/8, to 51 3/16. And Siebel jumped 7 7/8, to a record 117 11/16.
Telecommunications companies posted mixed results.
Sprint fell 2 5/16, to 72 1/4, after The Financial Times of London reported that the company faces seven lawsuits stemming from its agreement to be bought by MCI Worldcom.
But BellSouth, which lost the bidding war for Sprint, rose 2 3/16, to 47 3/16.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

White House Seeks Deal To Allow China Into W.T.O.
After a series of secret exchanges with Beijing during the last two weeks, the White House is racing to close a deal by the end of this month that it hopes would pave China's way into the World Trade Organization.
Senior Administration officials say there is a 50-50 chance they will be able to close the huge deal, which President Clinton views as his best shot at stabilizing American relations with China during his last year in office. Page A1. 

Chase Dismisses Currency Trader
Chase Manhattan said that its fourth-quarter trading revenue would be reduced by $60 million after the bank discovered that it had booked nonexistent trading profits. The bank has dismissed a currency trader involved in the matter. Chase's shares dropped $3.6875, or 4 percent, to $83.5625. Market Place. C8.
 
Online Retailers Turn to Television
Convinced that this Christmas season will be make-or-break, online retailers are in a costly race to bring their names to consumers through TV advertising. A1.
 
Bell Atlantic System Not Quite Open
The Justice Department said that Bell Atlantic had come close to fully opening its local networks in New York to competitors but had not quite made it, a condition for entering the long-distance market. C2.
 
AT&T argued before a Federal appeals court that Portland, Ore., exceeded its authority when it sought to force AT&T to open its cable lines to rival Internet service providers. A20.
 
 
Stocks Mixed; Nasdaq Hits Record
Stock prices were mixed, but the Nasdaq composite index eked out another record, rising 1.22 points, to 2,967.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell by 8.81 points, to 1,354.12, and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 81.35 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 10,648.51. C9.
 
Yields of Treasury securities held near their four-week lows amid hopes that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates more than once in coming months to check inflation. The yield on the 30-year issue rose to 6.18 percent, from 6.16 percent on Friday. C9.
 
New Chief at Andersen Consulting
Andersen Consulting announced that Joe W. Forehand, a high-ranking partner with 27 years of experience at the firm, would be its new chief executive. He replaces George T. Shaheen, left, who departed in September to run Webvan Group, an Internet grocery delivery company. Mr. Forehand said that he planned to make e-commerce the central part of the consulting firm and that the company intended to take stakes in clients' businesses more frequently. C3.
 
Daimler to Test New Plastic Roofs
Taking a big step forward in the development of automobiles with plastic bodies, DaimlerChrysler said it would equip 5,000 of its Jeep Wranglers each year with lightweight, low-cost roofs made from a new kind of specially hardened plastic. C8.
 
McCaw Plans to Invest in ICO Global
Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, said he had agreed to raise at least $1.2 billion to take ICO Global Communications, a struggling global satellite phone business, out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. C3.
 
Chairman of Daewoo Offers to Quit
Disgraced by the collapse of the business empire he founded 32 years ago, the chairman of Daewoo Group, Kim Woo Choong, submitted his resignation to the domestic creditors who are overseeing the sale of the South Korean conglomerate's vast array of heavily indebted businesses. C4.
