HEADLINE: Assembly Races Draw Big Money and Little Interest

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Tuesday's election for New Jersey's 80 State Assembly seats is expected to earn the unenviable distinction of having both the highest cost and the lowest voter turnout of any State Legislature elections in New Jersey history.
With the state's economy booming, no national or statewide contests atop the ballot, and no burning political issues, many pollsters and analysts predict a turnout below 35 percent, possibly as low as 30 percent. Records at the state attorney general's office show that the lowest turnout on record for any statewide election was the last Assembly race in 1995, when 38 percent of voters cast ballots. 
 "People aren't even unhappy about auto insurance anymore, which is unheard of in New Jersey," said Gerald M. Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University. "To get people to vote you need a little bit of an incentive. But there's nothing driving people now, other than their sense of civic duty. I think there's a shot that this could be an all-time low in terms of turnout."
But that tepid interest on the part of the public hasn't slowed the flow of cash from contributors to candidates. Assembly candidates from both parties have already collected a whopping $9.8 million, according to Fred Herrmann of the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, and are on pace to surpass the $12.7 million that made the 1995 Assembly race the costliest in state history. Democrats were helped in their fund-raising efforts by President Clinton, whose appearance last month brought $500,000. Republican candidates collected hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations during a benefit featuring their party's presidential front-runner, George W. Bush.
Some advocacy groups blame the increasing amount of fund-raising for the drop in turnout, saying that dizzying sums of money driving the political process have disenfranchised many voters.
"Entities that don't even have a right to vote are giving money in ways that decide who wins and loses," said Steven Ma, who analyzed Assembly campaign contributions for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group and found that political action committees, businesses and law firms accounted for 90 percent of all donations. "Citizens are running away from the civic arena. They're not voting because they believe their voice won't be heard through all that money."
Republicans, who hold a 48-to-32- majority, say they interpret the low turnout as a sign of voters' contentment. Steve Torpey, who is directing the Republicans' Assembly campaign, said he has tried to make the election a referendum on the improvement in the state's economy and quality of life since they won the majority in 1991. "We've cut taxes, there are more people working, crime is at a 20-year low, we've just voted to preserve a million acres of open space, and we've enacted insurance reform," Mr. Torpey said. "That's not a bad record to run on."
But Democrats still hold out faint hope that they can pull off unlikely upsets and recapture the nine seats needed to regain the majority. They contend that the economic recovery and drop in crime are part of a national trend and the result of Democratic leadership in the White House. Democrats say that just below the placid surface of New Jersey voters' moods runs a deep current of anxiety about the declining state of health care, New Jersey's high property taxes and troubled public schools. And they hope the Republicans' success in blocking a Democratic push to mandate "smart guns" will agitate antigun voters.
Even the most excitable political strategists expect incumbents to retain their positions in 70 or more of the 80 races, and Republicans hope they will hold all 48 of their seats. Several districts are considered competitive.
The most fiercely contested battle is in the Fourth District, in and around Camden, where Democrats have been issuing attack ads against Assemblymen Gerald Luongo. Mr. Luongo, who is also Washington Township mayor, was involved in a controversial land deal that benefited a group of investors with whom he has close ties. But pro-gun groups have rallied to defend Mr. Luongo and Assemblyman George Geist, the Republican who holds the other Assembly seat in the district, providing volunteers and telephone banks to urge thousands of gun owners in the district to turn out on election day.
Democrats are also hoping to unseat the Assembly majority leader, Paul DiGaetano, in the 36th District in Essex, Bergen and Passaic Counties, by focusing on gun control and campaign finance issues. Mr. DiGaetano has set a fund-raising record for New Jersey Assembly candidates by taking in $669,123, some of which was rolled over from his last campaign. Mr. DiGaetano said his contributions came from a wide array of donors, including nurses, teachers and other average New Jerseyans.

HEADLINE: Private Acres in Public Parks Fuel Battles on Development

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PAGOSA SPRINGS, Colo.

 BODY:
Nestled in the San Juan National Forest here in southwestern Colorado are a small rectangle of mountains and a valley that straddles the meandering East Fork of the San Juan River.
For now, the rectangle's 2,780 acres are indistinguishable from the surrounding landscape, a dream scene of 1.8 million pristine acres at the Continental Divide, where the only sounds are the water rushing over rocks, the wind and the occasional cry of birds high overhead. 
 But that is about to change.
Like more than 50 million other acres inside America's national parks and forests, only a fraction of the total, the rectangle of acreage is privately owned. It was one of thousands of land grants made available, in some cases almost 140 years ago, for homesteading, mining operations and railroads.
Although most of the private tracts remain undeveloped, here in the San Juan forest and with growing frequency elsewhere, owners of "inholdings," as they are known to the federal government, are developing acreage for commercial gain. That issetting off intense fights with preservation groups and community organizations concerned that development could damage the ecology by disturbing wildlife and scarring landscapes.
"It has become a major concern," Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said of private development inside federally owned lands. "We need the resources to buy them out before problems start, and there are willing sellers for most of them. But we don't have the money, so the willing seller decides to sell on the open commercial market."
Owners of the rectangle here are planning to build a members-only resort on 200 acres that they call Piano Creek Ranch, where membership shares cost $385,000 to $535,000. Designed to accommodate 395 families, the resort would include spacious houses, lodges, a golf course and an equestrian center. A ski area would be built on another part of the rectangle. Already, 175 families have signed up, and groundbreaking is scheduled for next June, with completion planned in two years.
Preservationists say developments like Piano Creek represent only the beginning of a major problem throughout federal lands. It is "the undiscovered crisis," says the National Park Trust, a nonprofit group that buys land and donates it to the park system.
"This is one of the results of the booming economy and a lot of new disposable wealth," said Steve Thompson, senior vice president of the Trust for Public Land, another nonprofit organization that works to preserve national parks and forests.
"With population pressures and beautiful places disappearing, people of means are saying, 'I'll get my little corner of paradise,' and they do what they want with it," Mr. Thompson said. "They have the legal right to do it. But it's sad that resources that are so spectacular, so beautiful would not be made available to a broader audience, only to a limited group."
And with land prices soaring in areas within some of the country's more popular parks and forests, the federal government and nonprofit agencies that buy land for preservation may be unable to compete with private investors. Paul Pritchard, president of the National Park Trust, predicted that "in 5 or 10 years, we'll be priced out of the market in high-demand parks."
The private ownership rights were honored when Congress began designating national parks and forests in the 1890's, and through recent years, most of the land owners have either kept their tracts in a natural state or have sold them to the federal government for preservation.
Each year, the major federal land management agencies -- the National Forest Service, the National Park Service, the Bureau of Fish and Wildlife and the Bureau of Land Management -- provide Congress a list of privately held property they want to buy.
The park service list alone has a backlog of 10,184 private tracts in 145 parks -- more than one million acres in all -- that officials say would cost the government $1.35 billion to buy for preservation. The National Park Trust estimates that 20 percent of the privately held land within national parks and forests is "in imminent danger" of development.
But Congress never appropriates enough money to satisfy all the needs, so which properties are bought depends on the threat of development, the willingness of the owner to sell and the price. In recent years, Mr. Babbitt said, the four agencies have received a combined $300 million to $400 million annually for the acquisition of private land. As a result, conflicts are brewing throughout the country as more developers build on their land inside national parks and forests and market it for profit.
In the Maryland suburbs outside Washington, the National Park Service is trying to buy 88 acres within the Monocacy National Battlefield, a major Civil War site, to prevent any development of housing subdivisions and shopping centers.
The owners of 11,000 acres within the Bitteroot National Forest in western Montana resisted efforts to sell the land to the federal government and, instead, sold recently to a company headed by Craig Barrett, chief executive of the Intel Corporation. Mr. Barrett said his group did not intend to develop the land. But preservationists are skeptical and they complain that because the acreage is a patchwork of about 14 separate tracts, the private ownership makes it difficult for the federal government to manage the public lands around them.
In the Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska, developers are planning to turn an old 20-acre mining site into a remote resort with 30 lodges. For access, which the federal government is required to provide, the developers are asking the park service to improve a 10-mile road through park land that would cross a valley creek 27 times. Park officials fear that the improvement will encourage other land holders to develop sites near the road.
Gettysburg National Military park in south-central Pennsylvania includes three privately held tracts, and park officials say that proposed commercial development would destroy the integrity of one of the most sacred battle sites of the Civil War.
Cattle grazing on 532 acres of private land around the Golden Spike National Historic Site in Utah, where rails from the east and west linked for the first time in 1869, is speeding up erosion, a process that officials say can be reversed only by buying the land.
Population growth in Arizona, one of the fastest growing states in the country, is threatening the Saguaro National Park, where the saguaro cactus has been known to grow as high as 50 feet and weigh as much as 8 tons. But in recent years, encroaching development has affected the cactus, and the park service wants to buy 250 surrounding acres as protection.
Those fights are similar to the conflict here. Dan McCarthy, a Chicago businessman and majority owner of the San Juan property, once considered building a large ski resort on the land but said he was persuaded by members of his family to abandon the plan because of the potential effect of the traffic and people. More recently, the 81-year-old Mr. McCarthy agreed to sell the tract to developers whose idea for a country-club-like project more suited his sensibilities.
"I'm extremely sensitive to the environment," he said in an interview. "And I am concerned about what happens to the East Fork after I die, whose hands it might be in. My kids like it the way it is, but someone might come along and they might feel like selling. I think this is the best practical answer."
A growing number of people disagree with him. While recognizing that as a property owner Mr. McCarthy can do whatever he wants with his tract, a coalition of environmental groups, Friends of the East Fork Valley, and residents of Pagosa Springs, the nearest town, have vowed to fight the project as inappropriate for the site.
They contend that the lavish resort would disrupt elk migration routes, threaten lynx, deer and other wildlife and destroy landscape that remains as it was when wagon trains rolled westward across the same access road that would serve the ranch.
"We keep thinking that every time you develop something, wildlife can go over the next hill into the next valley," said Mark Pearson, chairman of the Sierra Club's National Wildlands Committee. "Well, this is the last next valley. There is no other place wildlife can go."
Mr. Pearson is helping lead a campaign to stop, or at least delay, the Piano Ranch project by challenging developers as they seek permits from federal, state and local governments for necessities like road improvements, electric lines and sewage operations. Opponents also say they intend to appeal any approval by the Forest Service, which is required for construction to begin.
"This is a cancer in the heart of a national area," said Betty Feazel, 83, who has lived on an 800-acre ranch at the foot of the access road to the Piano Creek site since 1922 and remains a friend of Mr. McCarthy despite the development plans. "I don't think he realizes how much impact this thing is going to have. People are going to be crawling all over the whole area."
But Jo Bridges, a district ranger for the San Juan National Forest, said that unless an environmental study concluded that development of Piano Creek posed insurmountable problems to the forest, she would approve the project, as the first level of review, and "development will happen."
Mr. Pearson said that opponents of the development would appeal her approval to the Forest Service regional office, and if necessary, to headquarters in Washington. Beyond that, either side could appeal to the courts.
Gerald R. Sanders, chairman of the development company that is buying the land from Mr. McCarthy, said in an interview that if Mr. Pearson and others would only listen, they might be convinced that the impact of the project on the area would be small and certainly less than that of the ski resort once under consideration. Mr. Sanders said he thought the opponents' public campaign had been disingenuous, filled with half-truths and overstatements to attract more allies. He cited as an example assertions that the project would cover all 2,780 acres of the rectangle. That is wrong, he said.
"I know it's not easy to believe a developer, that I could have good intentions," Mr. Sanders said, pointing out that he could just as easily have built residential subdivisions. "But I am trying to protect the environment. I'm attracted to this area for the same reasons other people are. Environmentalists want to see the land remain pristine, and so do our members."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Speed It Up, but Watch Those Elbows

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
After various Knicks had been whistled for holding, grabbing and chucking with their forearms, the referees conducting a clinic on the new rules during training camp last month asked whether the players had any more questions regarding what the league expected of them from now on.
"Maybe we should be wearing tutus out there," one player said. 
 The 1999-2000 National Basketball Association opens today at about the same time the door on aggressive physical play is closing.
Commissioner David Stern wants and needs a more balletic style of play and more points to be scored to sell his product -- and fewer bullies to depress television ratings.
From rule changes to personnel shake-ups, the league is in the middle of a transformation. Losing ground is the plodding halfcourt style, which is being replaced by an up-tempo, end-to-end running game. And it is not just the Sacramento Kings and the nouveau Knicks. The fast break, dormant for much of the 1990's, is experiencing a sudden rejuvenation.
"That's the way everyone wants us to play, so I'll guess we'll just have to deal with it," said Coach Pat Riley of the Heat, whose brutish teams in New York and Miami were annually accused of bringing down the league's quality of play.
"It's not who we are. It's not our identity. And it will take us a while to adjust. But maybe it will be good for the league."
After a decade of declining scores and field-goal percentages, and dramatically improved defense, something had to change. Michael Jordan's former team, the Chicago Bulls, averaged a paltry 81.9 points a game last season, fewest in the league.
Nine teams averaged fewer than 90 points a game, including the Knicks and the Heat. Sacramento was the lone N.B.A. team to average more than 100 points. It is no coincidence that a former almost invisible N.B.A. outpost has become must-see television. The colorful Kings of Jason Williams and Chris Webber have already secured 20 national television appearances, including nine on NBC.
In explaining the network's decision-making process, Dick Ebersol, NBC Sports' president, recalled sitting up late one night in May and watching a playoff game on Turner Sports between the upstart Kings and the Utah Jazz.
"College or pro, it was the most extraordinary basketball game I'd seen all year," Ebersol said of Utah's last-second victory in Game 4. "It was a game we didn't even televise. People were making baskets, scoring on both ends. The offense was startling. That game was one of the reasons we made some of the scheduling decisions we made."
Aside from the defending champion San Antonio Spurs, Allen Iverson and the Philadelphia 76ers; Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers, and Allan Houston, Latrell Sprewell and the Knicks will be featured a maximum 11 times on NBC.
"I think that's what America wants to see," the Kings' Williams said recently. "We run. We have fun. We push it up the court. Growing up, that's what attracted people to the game. If we have anything to do with getting back to that, then that's good."
With many members of the original Dream Team closer to retirement than their primes -- Charles Barkley, Patrick Ewing, Scottie Pippen, John Stockton and Karl Malone among them -- it appears the league and the network have made a conscious decision to showcase rising young stars rather than fading, aging icons.
The Kings did not make an appearance on NBC during the regular season in the nine previous years of the network's contract with the league. An advertising campaign titled "It's Our Turn Now" aired during the World Series, featuring Iverson and Williams. Bryant and Kevin Garnett of Minnesota have also filmed commercial spots.
"I will always say a game that is centered at the very least on offense as much as it is defense makes for much better TV fare," Ebersol said. "There's no question we cherish a wide-open game and we believe in a lot of these young players."
After Magic Johnson and Larry Bird retired, Jordan's transcendent popularity masked many of the league's quality-of-play problems. Now that Jordan has been gone from the game since the abbreviated season that began last January, the league seems to understand the need to return to more free-flowing, fluid offenses to increase fan interest. It is a marriage of simple economics and aesthetically pleasing play.
"I'm not sure it's right to say we've acted in concert or that the game is going to dramatically change," Stern said. "The network's decisions are based on research and judgment. And our owners have decided they'd like to return a less physical, more open game."
The rule changes involving excessive contact were by far the greatest indicator that the game had become too physical. But not everyone is in agreement that they will help the quality of the game.
"I'm not so sure that it's going to be the answer," said Lakers Coach Phil Jackson, who also decried the adding of a timeout in the second period, believing it will impede the flow of a game. "We hope it is because we like to see more cutting and movement on the floor, less physical holding, contact of bodies and physical play being the dominant factor, rather than speed and mobility. Some of the rules have been enforced very well. Some haven't because it's a very difficult thing for the referees to make that adjustment."
Geoff Petrie, the Kings' general manager, was named executive of the year last season by his peers for trading for Webber, draft Williams and acquire the offensive-minded center, Vlade Divac. Putting together a team of entertaining passers and scorers, Petrie seemed to also see the changing landscape of a league literally in transition. "The classic example of the running game flourishing would be the Knicks of the early 1970's," Petrie said recently. "They had five or six really skilled players, and each had the ability to do more than just one thing. Now we have all these specialists, and suddenly the game has drifted."
He added: "I can't say I or anybody else went out and decided to build a running team. But I knew early on we were going to be able to play up-tempo. Do I think the rule changes and getting back to running are good for the game? Definitely."

HEADLINE: There Goes the Airspace? Clintons Close on a House

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST 

DATELINE: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Nov. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton closed on their $1.7 million house here today without attending the closing, but their presence was felt in the neighborhood long before they signed the papers and wrote the checks.
Last Tuesday, the Town Board of New Castle, which includes the hamlet of Chappaqua, passed a law requiring that protesters obtain a permit before demonstrating along its quiet woodsy roads. And last month, officials from the Secret Service and the Federal Aviation Administration met to discuss increasing the altitude at which planes must fly over the Clintons' new house, which is under the landing path to the busy Westchester County Airport. "We may have to put up with the demonstrations, but we won't have the noise from the planes," said Clinton B. Smith, the New Castle town supervisor. "So I guess we'll take the good with the bad." 
 The Clintons' lawyers handled the details of the closing today at the Manhattan law firm Battle Fowler. The loan, for $1.36 million, is a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage, starting with an annual interest rate of 7.5 percent for three years, said Jim Kennedy, a White House spokesman. The loan, from the PNC Mortgage, a subsidiary of PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, allowed the Clintons to call off a much-criticized arrangement with a Democratic Party fund-raiser, Terry McAuliffe, who had guaranteed an earlier loan with $1.35 million of his money as collateral.
In the new mortgage, the Clintons put up a 20 percent down payment, or $340,000. Neither of the Clintons attended the closing, and they did not say when they planned to move in.
But owning property does not necessarily a New Yorker make.
Though she now officially owns about an acre in New York State, Mrs. Clinton was not considered a New Yorker by 69 percent of the people questioned between Oct. 23 and Oct. 28 for a New York Times/CBS poll, and 43 percent thought she could not effectively represent New York in the Senate without having lived here for many years.
But to some people in Chappaqua, however, the newcomers already seem like a lingering headache.
For months, the New Castle Town Board has considered creating a law to regulate an onslaught of demonstrations they expect the Clintons' presence to invite. The board began considering the law in September after a small group of demonstrators marched in front of the house, a white clapboard colonial on Old House Lane, to protest mass killings in East Timor. The Clintons had not moved in and the couple they bought the house from had not moved out.
"We have to know what's coming," Mr. Smith said of the need for the new law, which requires organizers of demonstrations and parades of more than 10 people to apply for a permit at least a week in advance. "We have to make sure we don't have overlapping demonstrations. Otherwise it could overwhelm the police and disrupt traffic. Besides, if I'm a protester holding a sit-down demonstration in the middle of Route 117, I'm going to hope that somebody's around the bend telling cars to slow down."
When most people buy a house, they have to consider the impact that a nearby airport might have on their lives. In the Clintons' case, the airport has to worry. The house is about a mile from the landing beacon that pilots follow to approach the Westchester County Airport in bad weather. Depending on the altitude requirement, the Clintons' presence could have a significant impact, said Berl Brechner, president of the Westchester Aviation Association, which represents 170 corporate and private plane owners who use the airport.
The Westchester County Airport is no sleepy little windblown strip. It handles 200,000 annual takeoffs and landings and a million passengers a year on commercial airlines, corporate jets and privately owned planes, Mr. Brechner said. To land safely on Runway 16, which 90 percent of the planes use, pilots have to fly about 2,000 feet above sea level or, because of Chappaqua's hilly terrain, about 1,500 feet above the Clintons' house, Mr. Brechner estimated. Any flight restriction requiring pilots to fly higher would mean the approach to the airport would have to be changed. Changing the direction of the landing approach carries the risk of a plane's encountering dangerous tailwinds, Mr. Brechner said.
"You would have thought that somebody would have considered the impact on everything in the vicinity in making the decision where to buy a presidential house," said Mr. Brechner, a broadcaster who flies his own single-engine Mooney 231, a four-seater. "I suppose the first family is entitled to live wherever they want, but now we are left dealing with the potential consequences."
James Peters, a spokesman for the F.A.A., said the Secret Service had not yet requested that the F.A.A. study the potential impact a flight restriction in the area. Given that the Clintons now own the house, the Secret Service is expected to make that request shortly.
There are flight restrictions over the White House, the Capitol, Camp David, the vice president's house and George Washington's home at Mount Vernon. Flight restrictions over the private homes of presidents and former presidents are not uncommon, Mr. Peters said. There have been no-fly zones imposed over the homes of all of the presidents in recent memory except Gerald Ford, Mr. Peters said. Most restrictions remain in place for several years after a president has left office.
The only restriction on flying over a former president's home that is currently remaining, however, is over former President George Bush's home in Kennebunkport, Me. That restriction prohibits flying below 1,000 feet when Mr. Bush is not present and prohibits flying below 3,000 feet when Mr. Bush is at home.
"When the Clintons were in New York City for Hillary's birthday party and fund-raiser, they had a no-fly zone that reached 2,000 to 3,000 feet," Mr. Brechner said. "If they did that in Westchester, it would be outrageous."

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs European Effort To Send Heating Oil to Serbs

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The Clinton administration, worried that it could be blamed if Serbs freeze to death in the winter, has decided to support a European-run pilot program to send millions of dollars worth of heating oil to Serbia, senior administration officials said today.
If the pilot program goes well, Washington will consider helping to expand the oil deliveries. 
 "We want to be supportive of any proposal that meets humanitarian requirements and can assist the opposition, so long as we are not bolstering the regime," said James P. Rubin, a spokesman for the State Department. He added that the United States already provided tens of millions of dollars to international groups toward that end.
At first the administration had opposed the European proposal, fearing that President Slobodan Milosevic would divert the oil to his business cronies or to the Serbian military. The administration also feared that by alleviating the hardships of a cold winter, the oil might diminish public protests against his government.
But American officials said they had decided to back the European plan for humanitarian reasons, and with an understanding that the oil would go to two cities in southeastern Serbia that are governed by opponents of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party.
In the middle of the month, the European Union agreed to supply $5 million of heating oil and to pay to transport it to the cities, Nis and Pirot, beginning this month.
If the project is seen as a success, the officials said, the United States will consider supporting -- and helping pay for -- an expansion to other cities. Serbia is faced with devastating energy shortages after the NATO air war over Kosovo destroyed petroleum refineries.
Administration officials said the United States remained firmly opposed to other proposals by European nations to end the economic and diplomatic isolation of Serbia, most importantly one to allow international airlines to resume flights to Belgrade, the Serbian capital.
A delegation of high-ranking Serbian opposition leaders who are now visiting the United States has been pressing for American support for the shipments of heating oil. They are also trying to display their solidarity before Washington and to portray Mr. Milosevic as a wounded leader.
Members of the group, which is expected to meet Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and White House officials this week, say the oil is needed to prevent a human disaster.
"Without it, people will freeze to death," said Mayor Zoran Zivkovic of Nis, a delegation member. "If the heating oil is not provided, it will be a great victory for Milosevic, because it will just reinforce the position that the West hates all Serbs."
The delegation leader, Dragoslav Avramovic, a former governor of the Central Bank and a candidate for prime minister in any transitional government in Serbia, said Mr. Milosevic was far weaker politically than he was often portrayed in the West.
"The economic situation of Milosevic is desperate," Mr. Avramovic said. "Prices are increasing 10 percent a week, which is 50 percent a month, and it is difficult to see how the regime will survive. He is now the obstacle to the recovery of Yugoslavia."
The president of the Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, said he was convinced that Mr. Milosevic would soon be ousted from office, despite his willingness in recent weeks to use violence to put down antigovernment street demonstrations.
"Milosevic is history," he said, drawing comparisons to the final days of President Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania and President Suharto of Indonesia.
"A dictator must be strong or he doesn't exist," he said. "Ceausescu was very strong until two days before his execution. Suharto was strong a month before he was gone. Milosevic now is like a fireman with five different fires, and with very little water."
The delegation is also trying on its visit here to put an end to the perception in Washington that the Serbian opposition is fragmented and that it is incapable of offering a serious alternative to Mr. Milosevic and his loyalists.
"The genuine opposition is not divided," said Vladan Batic, coordinator of the Alliance for Change, an opposition group that has organized many of the recent demonstrations that have drawn tens of thousands of antigovernment protesters to the streets of Belgrade.
Mr. Djindjic, a philosopher who was imprisoned in the 1980's for trying to establish an independent student organization in Serbia, said it no longer mattered whether there were policy or personality disputes among the opposition parties.
"The parties are not important now," he said. "The people on the streets are now the opposition."

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks China Deal On Trade by Month's End

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
After a series of secret exchanges with Beijing over the last two weeks, the White House is hoping to close a deal by the end of this month that could pave China's way into the World Trade Organization, even if Congress cannot pass judgment on the agreement until next year.
Spurred by a telephone call from President Clinton to President Jiang Zemin of China late on the night of Oct. 16, the United States and China have since engaged in what one official called an "intense set of interactions." Nonetheless, senior administration officials say, there is only a 50-50 chance that they will be able to close the deal, which Mr. Clinton regards as his best shot at stabilizing American relations with China during his last year in office. 
 The White House has not described the two leaders' conversation nor an internal strategy debate presided over by the White House chief of staff, John Podesta, about how to close the elusive deal. But according to Chinese and American officials, Mr. Clinton offered during the call to make the first move to break a long stalemate in the talks, volunteering to send China's leaders the details of an agreement he characterized as Washington's bottom line.
The details of that offer are being closely guarded, but areas up for discussion include telecommunications, financial services, textiles and sanctions in retaliation for the dumping of exports, among others.
The initiative indicates how desperately Mr. Clinton is trying to put back together the far-reaching China trade deal he walked away from in April, a move his aides say he deeply regrets.
While some in the White House say the April terms would still not satisfy the administration, one top official remarked last week that "if we could get it again, we'd probably take it and run."
The time of greatest American leverage in striking a deal is fast approaching, as Mr. Clinton prepares to open a meeting of the world's trade ministers in Seattle on Nov. 30. That session is expected to set the agenda for a new round of global trade talks that will take years -- and which China can only help influence if it is clear that it is about to join the group that sets the terms of world trade.
Negotiations on China's entry into the World Trade Organization and the predecessor General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have been going on for more than 13 years.
Once China is in the organization, it will be required to abide by the group's extensive rules on opening markets -- meaning it would have to allow in far more foreign investors, farm goods and providers of services. That would likely result in a boon for American companies, which have been lobbying hard for this agreement. But it would also reduce Washington's ability to impose its own sanctions on China because the Chinese could use the trade forum's court to arbitrate disputes.
Since Mr. Clinton's phone conversation with President Jiang, trade officials have been working to put together the draft of an agreement, based on the American understanding of the deal that did not come to fruition in April.
But the process is made harder by continuing disagreements between China and the United States about exactly what concessions China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, brought with him on that trip.
Moreover, the White House's decision to publish a long list of those concessions so inflamed some powerful Chinese business executives and their political patrons that Beijing has been forced to pull back, according to people informed on the negotiations.
For example, it is no longer clear that China is still willing to let American companies own 51 percent of its telecommunications providers. But if the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, struck a deal that gave American phone companies less of an inroad into the booming Chinese communications market, she would have to make the case that she had extracted other concessions that went beyond China's offer in April.
"They clearly still want a deal and want it soon," an administration official who has been in touch with the Chinese said recently. "But it's becoming clear it won't be exactly the same deal. The politics have changed."
One of the questions that the White House has not yet resolved is whether Mr. Jiang is still committed to striking a deal, especially at a time he is under growing economic pressure at home. Mr. Clinton was frustrated in New Zealand early in September, when the Chinese president was slow in restarting negotiations.
His Oct. 16 call was followed a week later with a trip to China by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. While Mr. Summers was not sent to negotiate -- President Jiang and China's top trade negotiators were all in Europe -- he saw Prime Minister Zhu, and after a three-hour meeting reported that the embattled prime minister was still committed and eager for China to join the trade organization. The competitive pressure created by opening China's markets, Mr. Zhu once again told Mr. Summers, would help spur China's own reforms.
But the pragmatic prime minister's domestic political adversaries have seized upon the list of concessions the White House published in April to help undermine a deal. And American diplomats say Chinese leaders seem concerned that Mr. Clinton, in the last year of his presidency, lacks the ability to push a deal through Congress.
Both houses would have to approve a change in the Jackson-Vanik amendment of the mid-1970's, which requires Congress to review China's trade status annually, a vote that gives many in Congress a chance to voice their disapproval of China's human rights record, its posture toward Taiwan, or its ballooning trade surplus with the United States.
Favored trade status would be implicit in any deal that got China into the World Trade Organization. But under one scenario being discussed in Ms. Barshefsky's office, Washington would reach an agreement with China but invoke a seldom-used provision of World Trade Organization rules that would prevent the Chinese from enjoying some trade benefits with the United States until there was a vote in Congress.
"I think we could get a deal through Congress even in an election year," Representative David Dreier, Republican of California, said in an interview last week. "If American industry says it's a good deal, I think that would be enough."
Ms. Barshefsky is being unusually tight-lipped about the talks, which would be the biggest trade deal in her tenure and a major part of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy legacy. She does not want to appear too eager to strike an agreement, always a dangerous negotiating stance. And her influence in the White House remains murky: Her advice that Mr. Clinton take the April deal was overruled, after then-Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and other officials said it could not get through Congress.
Today, though, Ms. Barshefsky said she expected formal talks with China to resume this month. "We have got to see," she said, when asked about the possibility of a deal. "I'm neither an optimist nor a pessimist."
"There is quite a bit of work to do as we look ahead," she added, noting that China would also have to conclude deals with Canada and with Europeans and Latin Americans, though these might follow whatever agreement was struck with Washington. Some officials close to Ms. Barshefsky say she may travel to China before the Seattle trade meeting if there is sufficient progress to suggest that a deal could be wrapped up in time for Mr. Clinton to announce it at Seattle.
Ms. Barshefsky has two big hurdles to clear. One concern is textiles: At a moment when the United States is urging other countries to drop trade barriers, she is under pressure from members of Congress representing textile-manufacturing states to force Beijing to agree to an extension on import quotas and tariffs on Chinese fabrics. China is resisting, but may agree in return for other concessions from the United States.
Then there is a bigger stumbling block: Beijing's insistence that Washington give up its ability to invoke sanctions against Chinese products that it determines are being dumped at below-market prices in the United States. The matter is considered vital by labor unions, which insist that anti-dumping measures are critical to saving factory jobs. They are already putting pressure on Vice President Al Gore, who has courted them assiduously, to protect their interests in any deal.
Mr. Gore, his aides say, has no intention of getting near the Seattle meeting.

HEADLINE: Aid to the Arts: Who Gains

 BODY:

To the Editor:
When patrons' money underwrites art, interest is always factored in. Did wealthy benefactors commission innumerable portraits, landscapes and still lives during the Renaissance to help the careers of artists or to massage their own egos and trumpet their economic superiority? Why does it seem as if companies today subsidize the arts in direct proportion to the amount of damage their products do? 
 Patrons have never acted altruistically. Your Oct. 31 front-page article about the Brooklyn Museum of Art's quest to subsidize the exhibition "Sensation" merely spotlights the most recent episode in an increasingly complex and sometimes ethically fuzzy enterprise.
 
STEVEN C. DUBIN
New York, Nov. 1, 1999

HEADLINE: Dangerous Curves: The New Banquettes

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER

 BODY:
THE deep, curved banquette at Union Pacific is the most alluring table in the room: plush and cozy, dimly lighted. And if you are lucky enough to get it, you nestle into your own little pod, protected yet part of the passing scene, and feel smugly content. You know you have snagged the best table.
There's just one problem. Once you're in, there's no easy way out. Escaping from the cushioned embrace of a banquette may be dining's most awkward moment, requiring a wriggling contortion that's about as graceful as exiting the center seat on a 747. 
 It's a maneuver New Yorkers are coming to know all too well, as restaurants around the city fill their rooms with more banquettes, bigger banquettes, banquettes of all shapes and sizes. Partly it's fashion: the curvy, round banquette is the style of the moment in restaurant design. But it's economics, too: restaurateurs can fit many more seats into a room when they use the sofalike banquettes instead of chairs.
At many new restaurants, banquettes outnumber freestanding tables. They line the walls, lurk in corners, make sculptural statements as centerpieces to their rooms.
Jacks Fifth, a new restaurant in Midtown, could be described as one big banquette. There they border the room, with a cluster of balloon-shaped ones anchoring the center. Atlas, on Central Park South, is filled with small, firm banquettes. The oval corner ones at Cello are like softly framed box seats with high, mist-green mohair backs. At the new Sono, on East 57th Street, a circular banquette two steps up overlooks the entire dining room.
"People kill to sit in those seats," said Gabriel Blanco, a manager at Celadon, where oval banquettes stand in the entranceway like a chorus.
There's no denying that initial attraction. Next to a grounded, thronelike banquette, an unmoored table can seem like driftwood at sea. At a table, diners can hide nothing. Clothing hangs at their sides in loose flaps. They have to sit up straight. There is no hand-holding under the table. In a banquette, people slouch or preen against a high, velvety backdrop. They cling together in romantic huddles, or sit back and take in the view. Once in a while, as I've noticed in the Oak Room, they even nap.
"I like that it's back to the womb," said Sylvia Weinstock, the owner of Sylvia Weinstock Cakes, and a regular in City Hall's round banquettes.
Actually, banquettes were designed to encourage just the opposite feeling. They emerged in Europe in the heyday of cafe society. People went out to see and be seen, to hear and be heard. Tables were close and could be pulled together, people could socialize with diners next door. Adam Tihany, the designer of Jean Georges and Le Cirque 2000, said it best: "They're borderless."
For New Yorkers, that intimacy seems to breed an unusual openness. The same people who wouldn't think twice about cutting in front of you at the coat check are transformed when seated at banquette tables squeezed close together.
Julie Bain, an editor at In Style magazine, prefers banquettes for just this reason. Recently in the lipstick-red banquettes at Heartbeat, in the W New York Hotel, she and her companion found themselves chatting with diners on both sides of them. "I've even had strangers taste my food and vice versa, trading bites," she said.
Most restaurants have a different sort of togetherness in mind. Banquettes, particularly the straight European ones lined up flush against a wall, maximize seating. A normal table needs a valuable few inches behind the seat for getting in and out. By using banquettes, Mr. Tihany said he can fit 15 to 20 percent more tables in a room. Round or elliptical banquettes are less efficient. But they are great space fillers for corners and have a way of making the typically dark, inhospitable corner inviting.
Restaurants are favoring curvy circular and elliptical banquettes, and in every part of the room. "They're really big pieces of furniture that really connect you to the idea of the sofa," said David Rockwell, whose restaurant designs include Heartbeat and Nobu. He pointed out that they anchor a room better than anything else. "Sitting in a banquette gives people a great vantage point to look at the room, and visually, you're surrounding the dining room with beautiful fabrics," he said, adding, "It kind of gives the psychological feel of sitting around the kitchen table."
A very large kitchen table. At the future Do Hwa in the West Village, the brown leather backs of the banquettes will rise seven feet high. The corner one at Osteria del Circo can seat eight -- enough for a board meeting. Packed, it is fun, unless you happen to be the poor person in the middle. To let you out, either the entire table must be moved or half your party must get up.
It's a spectacle that has aroused the pity of designers and restaurateurs. Mr. Ashworth and Mr. Tihany have begun to make banquettes with seat bottoms of leather and smooth materials. After 14 years of textured upholstery and comments from women, Danny Meyer has gone with leather for the banquette at Union Square Cafe. But some problems will never be resolved.
"A banquette to me is more intimate than I usually need," said Alan Roberts, a consultant to law firms. At business meals, in particular.
Matthew Murray, a floor broker at the New York Stock Exchange, agreed. "I don't like touching the person next to me," he said. "Even if it's my wife, who I've been married to for 34 years."

HEADLINE: Online Sales Of Savings Bonds

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
An Internet site called the Savings Bond Connection opened today to allow people to buy savings bonds online at all hours seven days a week.
"It never used to be possible to buy a savings bond at 2 in the morning on a Tuesday; now it will be," said Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who introduced the Web site at a news conference. 
 The Series EE bonds, which sell for half their face value, will be available in denominations from $50 to $1,000. Series I bonds, which carry a lower interest rate but are adjusted to reflect inflation, will be sold in $50 to $500 denominations.
To buy savings bonds online, consumers must go to www.savingsbonds.gov and link to a page to conduct a transaction. Online buyers must provide information, including name, Social Security number and mailing address, just as they do when they buy bonds at financial institutions.
Bonds bought on the Internet must be bought by credit card. For now, only MasterCard and Visa will be accepted. After orders are processed, the bonds will be mailed to buyers.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Joseph R. Gregory

 BODY:

ASIA
 
SRI LANKA: REBELS BREAK THROUGH -- Tamil rebels overran a government outpost at Oddusuddan, 155 miles north of Colombo, the capital, killing more than 150 soldiers and wounding 400 others, a military official said. The army said many rebels were killed but could not give an exact number. The casualties were the worst since September 1998, when more than 1,000 soldiers died in fighting along a highway that links the capital to Jaffna. The latest attack came as a Tamil member of Parliament, Ramesh Nadarajah, who supported the rebels, was shot dead in Colombo. (AP) 

BANGLADESH: EX-PREMIER SENTENCED -- A former prime minister, Kazi Zafar Ahmed, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for embezzling funds intended for a new cancer hospital. Mr. Zafar, who served from 1988 to 1990, was said by his Jatiya Party to be in Australia for medical treatment. (AP)
 
CHINA: CATHOLIC BISHOP ARRESTED -- The police have arrested Bishop Jia Zhiguo of the underground Roman Catholic Church, the Cardinal Kung Foundation of Stamford, Conn., said. The group said the bishop was detained on Aug. 15 in northern Hebei Province. The police have denied his arrest. China frequently imprisons Catholics who refuse to take part in the state-approved church, set up in the 1950's. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: PRESS COURT RULINGS -- A newspaper editor, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, was arrested for defying an order by the conservative press court to appear on charges of insulting Islam in a pro-reform newspaper that the court banned six weeks ago. The court also sentenced two students to three-year jail terms, and a third to six months, for a satirical play published in a campus journal in September that the court found to have insulted Islam. John F. Burns (NYT)
 
AFGHANISTAN: NO DEAL WITH U.S. -- Osama bin Laden will very likely remain in Afghanistan after the United States rejected an offer by the suspected terrorist to leave for a secret destination, a spokesman for the ruling Taliban said. Washington is demanding that Mr. bin Laden be handed over for trial on charges that he masterminded the bombings last year at two American embassies in Africa. Afghanistan faces United Nations sanctions if it does not deliver him by Nov. 14. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
YUGOSLAVIA: MONTENEGRO ADOPTS MARK -- Montenegro decided to make the German mark legal tender alongside the Yugoslav dinar to protect the republic from economic turmoil in Serbia. The decision was the first concrete step by Montenegro to turn away from the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav federation. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
SPAIN: ARGENTINES INDICTED -- Judge Baltasar Garzon indicted 98 Argentines for genocide, terrorism and torture during the years of military rule, from 1976 to 1983. Buenos Aires has refused to cooperate with the judge, who has sought the extradition of Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean leader now being held in Britain. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
SPAIN: DEATH PENALTY PROTEST -- Protesters held demonstrations in Madrid and nine other cities to demand the release of the only Spaniard on death row in the United States. Joaquin Jose Martinez, 27, sentenced to death in 1997 for a double murder in 1995, has appealed to the Florida Supreme Court. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
ARMENIA: REBUILDING LEADERSHIP -- Armenia's Parliament chose a new speaker and two deputy speakers, replacing colleagues who were killed along with Prime Minister Vazgen Sarksian last Wednesday. President Robert Kocharian said after the election of Armen Khachatrian as speaker that a new government would take shape soon. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: RIGHTS LAWYER ATTACKED -- International human rights groups called on the Government to ensure the safety of Digna Ochoa, a lawyer who was tied up, beaten and interrogated during a nine-hour ordeal on Friday by assailants who broke into her home in Mexico City. Ms. Ochoa and her organization, the Miguel Agustin Pro Juarez Human Rights Center, have suffered serious harassment in the last year. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: ZULU PRINCE SLAIN -- Cyril Zulu, a 35-year- old Zulu prince and African National Congress leader who tried to broker peace between political rivals in the fractious KwaZulu-Natal Province, was shot dead near his home in Lamontville, south of Durban. Violence between the A.N.C., which controls the national government, and the Inkatha Freedom Party, which controls the provincial government in KwaZulu-Natal, dropped off after the 1994 elections but still flares up periodically. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
NIGERIA: MORE ETHNIC CLASHES -- Fighting between the Yoruba and the Ijaw has left 15 dead in Lagos in recent days. The deaths apparently stemmed from disputes in the oil-producing Niger Delta region between the Ijaw and a Yoruba subgroup called the Ilaje. Fighting among Nigeria's hundreds of ethnic groups has intensified in recent months, especially in the Niger Delta, which remains desperately poor despite its large oil deposits. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
 
UNITED NATIONS
 
CONCERN OVER AFRICANS -- As of January, Africa had nearly 6.3 million people of concern to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, including 3.3 million refugees, 1.6 million displaced people and 1.3 million former refugees. This is a million fewer than in 1998. The agency said that, this year, Sierra Leone had the most refugees, 410,900. Christopher S. Wren (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The gospel according to Greenspan: rising home prices.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that in some ways surging home prices give a greater kick to the economy than rising stock prices do.
Mr. Greenspan has pointed out with increasing frequency that the real estate market influences the personal finances of many households as much as, if not more, than the stock market does. In a speech today to America's Community Bankers, the trade group for the savings and loan industry, Mr. Greenspan fleshed out his point, relying in part on data from internal Federal Reserve studies. 
 By most measures, he said, gains in the stock market remain more important to increases in consumer spending than those from housing or any other asset market. The appreciation of stock prices has been "vastly greater" than that of home prices, he said, noting that housing accounted for one-sixth of what economists call the wealth effect -- the tendency of consumers to spend rather than hold or reinvest some of the gains they reap from rising asset values. The rest came overwhelmingly from Wall Street.
But he said the influence of rising home values on the economy would most likely grow in coming years. And he said that on a dollar for dollar basis, gains from the sale of a home translate into bigger increases in consumer spending than do gains from rising equity values, probably because consumers view rising house prices as much more of a sure thing than rising stock prices.
Stock market gains permanently lift the level of consumer outlays by 3 percent to 4 percent of the value of the gain, while the permanent increase in spending that results from gains in housing wealth appears to be about 5 percent, Mr. Greenspan said.
"The major reason for these significant differences in spending out of household wealth is doubtless that, while home prices do on occasion decline, large declines are rare," Mr. Greenspan said. The general experience for most homeowners, he said, "is a modest but persistent rise in home values that is perceived to be largely permanent."
The consistency of gains from housing stands in sharp contrast to "volatile and often ephemeral gains in stock market wealth," Mr. Greenspan said.
Moreover, he said, most big gains in the stock market go to people in the highest income groups, whose spending patterns do not change much based on how their investments are doing. Capital gains from housing are concentrated further down the income scale, where they are more likely to be translated into higher spending levels.
Mr. Greenspan did not make any comment on the level of stock prices, and he did not give any clue as to whether the central bank will raise interest rates for a third time this year when its policy-setting committee meets in two weeks.
Instead, his remarks took a long-term view of trends in the housing industry and amounted to another session in Mr. Greenspan's long-running seminar on the forces reshaping the economy.
Over the years, the Fed chairman said, the portion of all home sales accounted for by newly built homes has declined, to about 16 percent in the last five years from 40 percent three decades ago. The reason is that new-home building tracks the growth rate in household formation, which has been declining.
During the 1990's, single-family home starts have averaged 1.10 million a year, down from 1.14 million in the 1970's, Mr. Greenspan said. Annual sales of existing homes have averaged about 4 million during the 1990's, he said, up from 2.8 million in the 1970's.
"The trend has important implications for economic activity beyond its impact on home building, because the sale of a newly constructed home does not generate capital gains financed through the mortgage market," Mr. Greenspan said. "Sales of existing homes almost always do, and the purchasing power released through converting home equity to unencumbered cash can affect overall consumer demand and the economy, just as the stock market gains of recent years have boosted consumption."
The Fed's research shows that the average capital gain over the last five years on the sale of an existing home, after accounting for transaction costs, was more than $25,000. Homeowners also tapped into their equity through home equity loans and by refinancing their loans in a way that allowed them to take some of their equity gains as cash, he said.
"To the average seller of an existing home, the equity extracted net of transaction costs generally far exceeds the down payment on his or her next home purchase," Mr. Greenspan said. A significant amount of the money, he added, "is spent on consumer goods, especially on big ticket items in a manner not materially different from windfall income in general."

HEADLINE: Danger at the Crossroads

BYLINE: By Sheila N. Heslin; Sheila N. Heslin was the director for Russian, Ukrainian and Eurasian affairs at the National Security Council in 1995 and 1996.

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
When President Clinton met yesterday with Vladimir Putin, the Russian Prime Minister, to convey concerns about the 200,000 refugees fleeing Russia's attack on Chechnya, he was addressing a part of the world where there is a wider American interest.
Nearby, Armenia's internal balance is shaken after five armed men burst into its Parliament last week and killed the prime minister. That attack set back negotiations between Armenia and Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh, the disputed province that led the two countries to a bloody war from 1988 to 1994. As Chechnya burns, tiny, impoverished Georgia could be overwhelmed with Chechen refugees. 
 The United States has a big stake in the future development and political makeup of the South Caucasus and Central Asia, which lie between Europe, the Persian Gulf and Asia. The region's vast resources and unresolved tensions make it both attractive and potentially a point of conflict for ambitious powers that have been weakened in this region, including Russia, Turkey, Iran and China. Its location makes it a potentially profitable trade route; simmering conflicts and porous borders make it a corridor for shipment of arms and drugs.
The people in this region have endured great hardship as they have built their nations since the breakup of the Soviet Union, and they have emerged strongly committed to their independence. In Georgia, for example, despite grinding poverty, a pro-reform, pro-West, and pro-NATO majority was elected on Sunday in free and fair elections. Presidents in Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia have all taken personal and political risks in pursuit of peace. Georgia, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Moldova have buried their rivalries and are cooperating with the goal of creating a formal regional group. Caspian oil has begun to flow through a newly constructed pipeline through Azerbaijan and Georgia to the Black Sea.
Yet unresolved ethnic conflicts and border disputes hamper stability and invite Russia and other outsiders to meddle; by inflaming tensions within and between the region's states, the outsiders hope to expand their own presence in the region and assert control over their own restive border lands. Economic growth is slow. Weapons have poured into the region, particularly with the help of ethnic extremists living in the United States, Europe and the Middle East, and more are amassed at its borders with Russia.
The Clinton administration has rightly stated that American interests would be best served by the emergence of independent, stable, energy-exporting states in the South Caucasus and Central Asia, at peace among themselves and enjoying solid links to the West. But by focusing narrowly on rapid Caspian energy development while soft-pedaling the political and military instability, the administration has undermined its own objectives.
The United States has declared support for the independence of the South Caucasus countries that were once Soviet republics, while at the same time pressuring them to go along with Russia's rejection of limits on arms deployments in the region that it had observed in the days of the Soviet Union. The Clinton administration has said too little too late in opposition to the wars in Chechnya, leading Russian nationalists to think that pursuit of their goals will meet little effective resistance from the West.
Unconstrained, Russia tends toward heavy-handedness because it underestimates popular commitment to independence while overestimating its ability to impose order. Armed to the teeth, Russia gets itself in trouble, fomenting instability in the South Caucasus and increasingly in its own Caucasus provinces.
American support for peace in the region has been unconvincing: deferential to Russia and largely silent on arms buildups in Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan; halfhearted in advancing peace talks, having replaced four United States representatives at the Nagorno-Karabakh negotiations in less than three years, and maintaining a ban on assistance to Azerbaijan while giving humanitarian and technical aid to Armenia. Meanwhile, areas where there are unresolved conflicts serve as unregulated conduits for arms and drugs, reinforcing local organized criminals and creating powerful interests in favor of the status quo.
It is time for the United States to clarify its policy toward the South Caucasus and Central Asia, not in words, but in action. Some trade-offs will have to be made in our policy toward Russia. There will be no easy victories.
First, far more must be done to promote regional arms control. President Clinton should lead the way, at the meeting this month in Istanbul of the Organization on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in resisting Russian efforts to loosen treaty constraints on the deployment of weapons in the Caucasus. The restraints were part of the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty that the Soviet Union signed in 1990.
There should also be greater American efforts, independent and through institutions like NATO's Partnership for Peace program, to help the Caspian states build up the military forces needed to control their borders and protect their pipelines and transportation routes. Over time, most of these states will be prosperous enough to build modern militaries capable of defending their countries from attack; along the way, we should help them develop disciplined forces.
Equally important, there should be a regional security organization in which these countries can cooperate, perhaps building on the group of five states -- Georgia, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Moldova -- already starting in this direction. Large nations close by, like Russia and Turkey, and Western countries could be accorded observer status in a structure similar to that of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
In regional peace negotiations, we should recognize that it will not be enough to support only elites engaged in secret talks, as the administration did repeatedly in the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute. Citizens should be involved in national debates about how peace would affect them. To resolve the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, it will be necessary for the United States to work with those Armenian-American groups that support a nonviolent settlement.
And President Clinton should lift the ban on giving Azerbaijan the same kind of economic assistance that it provides to all other former Soviet republics. This would serve both to recognize the risks that Heydar Aliyev, Azerbaijan's president, has taken for peace and begin to bring about more realistic attitudes in Armenia. If we are to be an effective broker, we must adopt a balanced approach.
Together, these steps would help the countries in a politically complex and resource-rich part of the world achieve a reliable peace. The alternative is more chaos and bloodshed, which may not stay confined to the Caucasus for long.

HEADLINE: Senate Backs Lower Import Tax On Africa and Caribbean Goods

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
A popular package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations escaped a procedural thicket in the Senate today and advanced toward final approval when the senators voted to limit debate and consider amendments to the far-reaching legislation.
The senators voted 74 to 23 to end one of a series of filibusters led by Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who fears that African exports will hurt his state's politically powerful textile industry. Organized labor, worried over the impact on jobs in the apparel industry, also opposes the bill. 
 A final vote on the measure is expected later this week.
The bills would reduce or eliminate duties on a wide range of goods made in sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and the Caribbean, mostly those assembled with fabric made in the United States. President Clinton and a large majority in Congress support the measures.
In a sign of the measure's importance to the White House, Mr. Clinton issued a statement from Oslo, where he is taking part in a two-day summit meeting on the Middle East peace talks, calling the vote today "an important milestone in our effort to build a new economic relationship with sub-Saharan Africa and deepen ties with our Caribbean and Central American neighbors."
Mr. Clinton is also keen to take a deal with him to Seattle on Nov. 30, when he is to open a meeting of the world's top trade officials.
Today's action breathes life into a measure that seemed in jeopardy just last Friday, when all 40 Democrats joined together to oppose a Republican effort to cut off debate. That Democratic vote was in protest of a parliamentary move by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, to bar Democrats from offering amendments to the bills.
But Mr. Lott and the Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dekota, both strong supporters of the bill, agreed to allow trade-related amendments and to consider unrelated amendments, like raising the minimum wage, on a separate bill.
Mr. Lott had said last week that if today's vote failed to end the filibuster -- a process called cloture, which needs 60 votes -- he would pull the measure from the Senate agenda and the trade bills would be dead for the rest of the year.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican who heads the Finance Committee, proclaimed today's vote a sign of the "strong bipartisan support for the legislation." After the vote last Friday, Mr. Roth angrily accused Democrats of "isolationism."
Mr. Clinton, his top national security aides and Senate Democrats have emphasized the issue of isolationism since the Senate's rejection three weeks ago of a treaty to ban underground nuclear testing.
If the Senate approves a trade package this week, it still must reconcile differences with the House, which approved a bill, for Africa only, by a vote of 234 to 163 in July.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Breaks 3,000, Then Settles for Another Record

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The technology-heavy Nasdaq market racked up its third consecutive record close yesterday after a history-making jump through the 3,000-point level, while the broader market fell victim to further profit-taking.
The Dow Jones industrial average was off 66.67 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 10,581.84, after giving back an early gain of more than 100 points. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 13.98 points, or nearly five-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,981.63 after having spiked to 3,014.84.
"Technology continues to lead the market," said John Cleland, chief investment strategist at Security Benefit Group of Companies in Topeka, Kan.
The Standard and Poor's 500-stock index finished down 6.38 points, or nearly five-tenths of 1 percent, at 1,347.74.
"I think we just have some people taking a little profit," said Doug Myers, the vice president for equity trading at Wachovia Securities in Atlanta. "I don't know of any news events affecting the market. This just might be normal intraday wave motion of the marketplace."
Wall Street was also bracing for a possible interest-rate increase by the European Central Bank and the Bank of England tomorrow. A rate increase overseas could give the Federal Reserve an opportunity to raise domestic interest rates for a third time this year.
Meanwhile, comments on mortgage rates by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, did not rattle financial markets.
Mr. Greenspan, whose remarks are monitored for clues as to whether he favors lifting interest rates, said rising home prices affect spending more than do rising stock prices. The speech, delivered by satellite to a conference of community bankers in Orlando, Fla., did not mention the economic outlook or interest rates.
He said most economic estimates show that every dollar of wealth created by rising stock prices increases consumer spending by 3 cents to 4 cents, while rising housing prices increase spending by about 5 cents.
The Commerce Department said personal income held unchanged in September because of the impact of Hurricane Floyd, while spending rose four-tenths of a percent. Without the hurricane, which hit the Eastern Seaboard in mid-September, personal income would have risen three-tenths of a percent.
Among active stocks, General Electric was off 1 5/16, at 128 7/16, on news that its chairman and chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., will retire in April 2001.
PurchasePro.com, a business network, soared 21 1/2, to 61 5/8, after Workflow Management designated it for its business printing needs. Workflow was up 1 3/16, to 14 3/16.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Increase
 
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as investors speculated that the Federal Reserve would not have to raise interest rates much more to keep inflation at bay.
"The market not so long ago was trading on the idea we would have a string" of rate rises, said Dana Johnson, head of research at Banc One Capital Markets in Chicago. With reports last week pointing to tame inflation, he added, investors are "seeing with more clarity that the Fed is not behind the curve."
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32, to 99 25/32, also on speculation that limited supply of the benchmark will buoy prices. Its yield dropped to 6.14 percent, the lowest level since Oct. 4, from 6.18 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Stays Flat As Consumer Spending Swells

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Americans spent at a brisk pace in September, but their incomes remained flat -- a combination that pushed the nation's savings rate to a record low.
The Commerce Department said today that consumer spending rose four-tenths of a percent in September. The increase was slightly higher than what had been expected by private economists, who attributed it to a prosperous economy in which low unemployment and tame inflation have left people with cash to spend. 
 At the same time, personal income, comprising wages, interest and government benefits, held steady as Hurricane Floyd resulted in large, uninsured losses to residential and business property. It was the worst showing since December 1998 when personal income also was flat.
Income posted by farm owners fell sharply, reflecting losses from the hurricane even though overall wages rose by three-tenths of a percent in September.
Putting aside the impact of the storm, which hit the East Coast in September, the government said personal income would have grown three-tenths of a percent in September, in line with many forecasts.
"If you take out the impact of Floyd, income growth is good and shows a solid, thriving economy," said Gary Thayer, chief economist for A. G. Edwards & Sons.
Economists anticipate income will bounce back in October. In August, income rose four-tenths of a percent, while spending rose twice as fast at eight-tenths of a percent.
"Consumers are in a buying mood, but not quite as aggressively as earlier in the year," Mr. Thayer said.
Spending on nondurable goods, like food and fuel, rose eight-tenths of a percent in September, while spending on big-ticket manufactured goods, like cars, was down four-tenths of a percent.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity, rose at a solid annual rate of 4.3 percent in the third quarter, down slightly from 5.1 percent in the second quarter, the government reported last week.
With consumer spending outpacing income, the nation's savings rate -- savings as a percentage of after-tax income -- was pulled into a record monthly low of 1.6 percent in September.
That 1.6 percent rate reflects changes to how the government calculates the savings rate. Under new methodology -- part of a broader overhaul of a gauge measuring the nation's economic growth -- savings associated with a worker's government pension plan is counted as personal savings, rather than government savings.
