HEADLINE: Foreign Nameplate Autos Are Sales Favorites in U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Buyers snapped up cars and trucks with foreign nameplates last month, forsaking some of their past favorites -- American-made sport utility vehicles.
Nearly every foreign brand reporting sales results today showed increases, and many notched double-digit gains. Toyota sales rose 12.6 percent in October compared to the same period a year ago. Honda sales rose 3.2 percent and Nissan jumped 27.6 percent. 
 Meanwhile, General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler's American brands had a disappointing month. Ford sales sagged 4.9 percent, and G.M. sales fell 3.6 percent. Their foreign brands, however, posted increases: G.M.'s Saab saw its sales rise 6.5 percent, while Ford's Volvo and Jaguar divisions posted increases of 37.8 and 75.8 percent, respectively.
DaimlerChrysler's Dodge, Jeep, Plymouth and Chrysler brands dropped 3.8 percent, while Mercedes sales rose 12.2 percent. Foreign makes won buyer's hearts because they offered "lots of new products," said David B. Healy, an auto analyst at Burnham Securities.
The strong showing from foreign brands helped the industry's sales rise 2.8 percent in October, compared to the same period a year ago. But the Big Three's lackluster results dragged down seasonally adjusted sales of cars, pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans for the industry as a whole. The industry's seasonally-adjusted annual sales rate plunged to 16.6 million, the weakest since January. While the industry has been enjoying record sales levels all year, and an annual rate of 16.6 million is still considered terrific, the annualized rate was 17 million in September.
Still, Asian and European auto makers were the big winners in October. Asian auto makers watched their collective slice of the United States market climb to 28.4 percent last month, up from 24.9 percent in the same period a year ago. European auto makers -- excluding DaimlerChrysler -- saw their market share increase to 3.8 percent from 2.6 percent, largely on the strength of Volkswagen's strong sales. G.M.'s market share dropped to 28 percent, down from 29.9 percent a year ago. Ford's drop was almost as large: Ford's share was 23 percent in October, down from 24.9 percent. And DaimlerChrysler's market share hit 16.8 percent, down from 17.7 percent a year ago. DaimlerChrysler's Mercedes brand added 1.3 percentage points to the parent company's results.
Some of the most popular American sport utility vehicles saw their sales slide. Ford Explorer sales dropped 11.7 percent last month compared to the year-ago period. And sales of the larger Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator fell 14.5 and 8.6 percent respectively. Ford's newest entry, the giant Excursion sport utility vehicle, registered 4,373 sales in its first month, perhaps attracting some would-be Expedition and Navigator buyers. Ford's total sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups fell 6.0 percent in October. Ford's car sales fell 4.1 percent. Sales of the Oldsmobile Bravada sport utility vehicle plunged 32.4 percent, but other G.M. sport utility vehicles saw their sales increase. That left sales of G.M.'s light trucks up 9.1 percent, while G.M.'s car sales fell 13.7 percent, dragging down the company's results.
Sales of DaimlerChrysler's Dodge, Plymouth, Jeep and Chrysler brands fell 3.8 percent overall, with car sales dropping 9.3 percent while truck sales slipped just 1.5 percent.
"Industry demand continues to be brisk," said Roy S. Roberts, G.M.'s group vice president of sales, service and marketing in North America. "The challenge for all manufacturers involves coping with twin pressures -- intense competition and robust consumer demand that has resulted in tight inventories in some market segments." DaimlerChrysler said its sales were still strong, despite the decline this month, since the year-ago period set a record for October sales, and last month was the second-best. "This is like two runners going across the finish line, both breaking the world record, but the second guy is still the second guy," said Jamie F. Jameson, vice president of sales and marketing operations. "It was still a terrific month."
DaimlerChrysler's economists have increased their industry sales forecast for next year, said Mr. Jameson. The new forecast is for sales of 16.4 million cars, light trucks and commercial trucks, up from a previous forecast of 16.0 million.
DaimlerChrysler is expected to go into next year with one fewer brand sold in the United States, former employees of the company said. The company is expected to announce tomorrow that it will drop the Plymouth brand from its stable, just as it discontinued the Eagle brand a few years ago.

HEADLINE: Russians Balk at Opening Nuclear Sites to U.S. Eyes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 2

 BODY:
This was supposed to be a banner day for American-Russian cooperation. The American ambassador was scheduled to cut the ribbon at a gala opening of a United States-financed business center in one of Russia's closed nuclear cities.
But after Russian authorities barred him last week from bringing his top science adviser or inspecting other American-Russian projects at the site, known as Krasnoyarsk-26, Ambassador James F. Collins angrily canceled his visit. 
 Energy Secretary Bill Richardson protested the Russian restrictions in terms so strong last weekend that the Russian Atomic Energy Minister, Yevgeny Adamov, stormed out of the room in Denver, where both were attending a conference.
Since the end of the cold war, the United States has worked hard to protect nuclear materials in Russia and to prevent them from falling into the hands of Iran, Iraq or other aspiring nuclear powers. But the question of access to Russian nuclear sites, always a delicate issue, has become increasingly troublesome of late.
There are many reasons for the dispute, including the frustration of the Russians over restrictions placed on their visits to the United States Energy Department's headquarters and laboratories, the sheer number of American visitors to the Russian weapons complex and a residual distrust of American intentions within the Ministry of Atomic Energy.
Another key factor in the dispute is the influence of Russia's internal security service, the F.S.B., no friend of expanded cooperation with the West.
"At the same time that we are making significant progress on the nuclear cities initiative we are starting to experience more access problems," Mr. Richardson said in a telephone interview. "We have set up a task force to examine access questions and resolve what is becoming a problem: the continued interference by the F.S.B. with our joint operations."
None of this means that nuclear cooperation is on the verge of breaking down. Experts from American nuclear laboratories and the Pentagon work with their Russian counterparts in ways that were unthinkable during the cold war.
But Russia's uneven policy on access is threatening to erode support in the United States Congress for the Clinton administration's program to create civilian jobs within Russia's closed nuclear cities -- nuclear-weapons complexes where 750,000 Russians live, but which remain off-limits to foreigners and Russians lacking special permits.
Even before the latest dispute over access, Congress slashed the administration's primary program of assistance to the closed cities to $7.5 million from the $30 million proposed for the 2000 fiscal year.
Certainly, the access problems at Krasnoyarsk-26 came as an unpleasant surprise to Mr. Collins, the American ambassador.
The aim of the center he was to inaugurate is to help develop new businesses, an important step toward creating jobs for former weapon scientists and reducing their temptation to sell bomb-designing skills abroad.
Russian authorities approved a visit by Mr. Collins to Krasnoyarsk-26 and, after some importuning, allowed him to bring his interpreter. But they would not allow his science adviser, Thomas Maertens, to go. Mr. Maertens had been in Krasnoyarsk-26 earlier this year, and Russian authorities sometimes limit the frequency of such visits.
Mr. Collins insisted that he, not the Russians, should be able to determine the composition of his team.
The American Embassy sent the Ministry of Atomic Energy a blunt letter noting that the restrictions were hampering the ambassador's ability to monitor United States assistance to Krasnoyarsk-26. Still, the business center was inaugurated as scheduled by midlevel Energy Department officials.
Mr. Adamov, the atomic energy minister, declined comment. But Andrei V. Katargin, the mayor of Zheleznogorsk, the civilian area within the Krasnoyarsk-26 complex, complained that that some of the restrictions Russian authorities have imposed on access to his city are excessive. "The U.S. Ambassador is an important person," Mr. Katargin said in a telephone interview. "His presence would have increased the status of the opening."
Kransoyarsk-26 is not the only place where American officials have run into problems. Mr. Richardson has unsuccessfully pressed to visit Avangard, a factory for assembling and disassembling nuclear warheads, which is located in the closed city of Arzamas-16.
The United States has offered to finance the conversion of the plant to civilian production if the Russians agree to close it ahead of schedule.
There have also been problems at Mayak, where the United States is financing the construction of a warehouse to protect bomb-grade plutonium extracted from nuclear warheads.
Thomas E. Kuenning Jr., a retired Air Force general who directs a Pentagon program to help the Russians reduce their strategic arsenal, said the Russians still have not provided the necessary access for the new American project manager at Mayak. He said the Russian Ministry of Defense tended to be more cooperative than its Ministry of Atomic Energy.
Some former American officials said the Russians were not the only ones at fault.
"This is a problem that exists on both sites," said Kenneth Luongo, a former Energy Department official and the head of the Russian-American Nuclear Security Advisory Council, a private group that focuses on the problems of Russia's closed cities.
Mr. Luongo said the Energy Department headquarters has imposed new background checks for Russians. And while foreign reporters have been allowed to visit Pantex, the United States warhead disassembly plant, Russian visitors are not allowed.
"The Russians are slowly tightening the noose, but the United States is doing the same thing," Mr. Luongo said.

HEADLINE: When Biotechnology Crops and Their Wild Cousins Mingle

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON

 BODY:
Since genetically engineered crops came on the American agricultural scene in 1992, farmers have enthusiastically adopted these plants, last year harvesting genetically altered corn, soybeans and cotton from 50 million acres -- an area one and a half times the size of New York State. Meanwhile, several studies have been published pointing toward ecological risks from genetically modified plants.
A major concern is that foreign genes from these plants could escape into wild plants by interbreeding. The fear is that wild plants endowed with new genes and potent new abilities, for example, to produce insecticide or withstand herbicide, might spread quickly, becoming difficult or costly to remove. 
 Previously researchers talked about the movement of foreign genes into wild plants as unlikely, but the picture emerging today is that with many crops it will be inevitable. Recent studies of radishes, grain sorghum, canola and sunflowers found that genes, in one case foreign genes, moved quickly and easily from crops to wild relatives.
Corn, soybeans and cotton pose no such risks in this country, as there are no plants with which they can interbreed. But other genetically engineered crops in development do have wild relatives in the United States with which they can interbreed including rice, beets, canola, sunflowers, cranberries and strawberries.
There have also been a number of recent reports suggesting that the popular crops that produce the insecticidal toxin known as Bt may pose previously unsuspected risks. Bt corn, cotton and potatoes are already on the market but many more Bt crops are in development.
Normally Bt is sprayed on plants to kill pests and is thought to remain active for a matter of days. But in sharp contrast to industry studies, Dr. Guenther Stotzky, soil microbiologist at New York University, has found that Bt toxin in the soil, as it might be found after a crop is plowed under, can remain active for at least eight months.
"We were surprised," Dr. Stotzky said. "I'm sure it hangs around longer. We just terminated the experiment after eight months."
In addition, recent studies of insect genes and insect development suggest that resistance to Bt may evolve more quickly than expected and that current resistance-management schemes for these plants may be ineffective.
Other new studies suggest that Bt crops may have adverse effects on non-pest species. A study published earlier this year showed that, in the laboratory, monarch butterfly caterpillars can be killed by eating Bt corn pollen. Again in contrast to industry studies, Swiss researchers have published evidence that beneficial, predatory insects get sick when they eat Bt or eat pests that have eaten Bt corn.
Ultimately, as with any new technology, risks must be weighed against benefits. So far researchers have found that some crops can provide striking financial and environmental benefits, but only under some conditions.
The Department of Agriculture released a report in July showing that many farmers planting Bt cotton enjoy increased yields and decreased insecticide use, but many also do not.
"Proponents of the technology would like it to be all things to all people," said Ralph Heimlich, deputy director for staff analysis at Economic Research Service, which put out the new study. Opponents prefer to claim it does nothing. The messy truth, however, lies somewhere in between. "It really is a mixed bag," Mr. Heimlich said.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Civil Rights Crusader Takes On the World

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN

 BODY:
THE REV. LEON H. SULLIVAN, the Philadelphia civil rights legend, anti-apartheid warrior and grandmaster corporate guilt-tripper, set down in New York briefly this week to address the world.
This is not a flip statement. He was at the United Nations yesterday with Secretary General Kofi Annan to announce that a dozen companies with international operations -- Chevron, Colgate-Palmolive, KFC and General Motors among them -- have signed far-reaching socially responsible guidelines, drafted by him. 
 Now 77, Mr. Sullivan is a man of grand vision and gargantuan accomplishment, large in stature (6 feet 5 inches) and with a robust sense of self. Of course he named these guidelines the Global Sullivan Principles.
You get to do that when the first Sullivan Principles, written in 1977 for companies doing business in South Africa, are so widely cited for their moral and economic contributions to ending apartheid.
He chuckles, his face bright with memory, as he sips coffee at the Plaza Hotel.
"In 1974 I met with hundreds in South Africa and I realized that apartheid was sinful. When I was getting on the plane to go home, the police took me to a room and told me to remove my clothes. A man with the biggest .45 I'd ever seen said, 'We do to you what we have to.'
"I stood there in my underwear, thinking, 'I'm the head of the largest black church in Philadelphia and I'm on the board of directors of General Motors. When I get home, I'll do to you what I have to.' "
Although a renowned orator, Mr. Sullivan compelled companies to abide by his first set of principles, which included desegregating foreign-owned plants in South Africa, and his latest set, which includes supporting human rights and equal employment at home and abroad, by being a quietly skillful boardroom negotiator. Using moral imperative as well as a shrewd understanding of the relationship between corporate image and economic gain, he would not be denied.
"He'll talk about an issue and then go around the room and say, 'How are you going to help me solve this?' " said Robert H. Campbell, the chief executive of Sunoco, who consulted with Mr. Sullivan about how to do business ethically in Nigeria. "It's tough to say no to Leon."
To spend a few hours with Mr. Sullivan is to be swept by his gale-force tales from "the dirt alley at the end of the alley" in Charleston, W. Va., where he was raised by a devout, illiterate grandmother and was the pastor of two churches by the time he was 17.
On a lecture tour through the South in the 1940's, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. met the tall, poetry-spouting preacher. Several years later, he introduced Mr. Sullivan to the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York with the announcement, "I can take a young man from the hills who looks like he never wore a pair of shoes in his life and make him a leader!"
Postwar Harlem: Mr. Sullivan finishes a master's degree in religion at Columbia, talks Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia into hiring black police officers to work with gangs, marches with A. Philip Randolph, Bayard Rustin and Paul Robeson and persuades Sugar Ray Robinson and Joe Louis to appear in fund-raising fights for a youth center.
Then his new wife, Grace Banks, grabs him by the ear and takes him to a park bench. "She said, 'Your head's too big and your feet are flying off the ground. It's time to leave the glamour of New York.' "
A FIVE-YEAR pause at a Baptist church in South Orange, N.J. Then, in 1950, the 600-member Zion Baptist Church summons him to Philadelphia, where, he recalls, "No blacks drove trucks, there were no black tellers."
Mr. Sullivan organized more than two dozen boycotts of businesses large and small that would not employ blacks. The campaign became known as selective patronage.
"I spoke to real estate developers," he recalls, "and said, 'All of you should be put in jail!' Half of them booed and left. But I literally opened a whole city for black people. Martin Luther King with a fellow called Abernathy said to me, 'Tell us how this works!' "
Jobs were becoming available, but, Mr. Sullivan realized, many blacks were unskilled. Brainstorming with city and corporate leaders, he built his first Opportunities Industrialization Center, a training program that now has 70 branches nationwide and 46 in 18 other countries.
He galvanized his congregation with a vision blending middle-class values, economic independence and religious revival. By 1988, when Mr. Sullivan moved to Phoenix for his health, church membership had grown tenfold and the church itself, which had burned down, had been rebuilt by black steel workers. Under his aegis, Philadelphia had a black-owned shopping center and housing for the elderly and the handicapped.
In his down time, of course, there was South Africa, his decades-long gadfly role at General Motors, 50 honorary degrees and visits with every president from Johnson to Clinton. In May, he led more than 1,000 professionals and business leaders to Accra, Ghana, for the fifth African-American African Summit. That's his baby, urging black Americans to invest in Africa.
Travel, age and a nasty African bush insect's bite have rattled his health. Retirement, Reverend?
"Nobody can tell me what to do, when to do it, or when to stop!" He is laughing. "Except God. And Grace."

HEADLINE: Maybe 'the Best Manager in America,' Clearly a Model for Other Executives

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
When John F. Welch Jr. resigns from General Electric in April 2001, he will actually leave two vacancies: those of G.E.'s chief executive and corporate America's most-admired manager.
The first post will be filled quickly, the appointment will likely be announced months before Mr. Welch steps aside. For the second job, however, there is no clear successor, management experts said yesterday, and that is a testament to the rarity of Mr. Welch's nearly two-decade run at the top of one of America's biggest companies. 
 Mr. Welch, who announced his retirement date on Monday, is not the most famous chief executive in the country. That title probably belongs to William H. Gates of Microsoft or Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway. But among board members, executives, and business-school students and professors, Mr. Welch's name is a touchstone for smart corporate management in a way that no other chieftain matches.
"He's the best manager in America," said Gerard R. Roche, the chairman of the executive search firm Heidrick & Struggles. "What he's done at G.E. has become the benchmark for other companies," said Christopher A. Bartlett, a professor at Harvard Business School. "I'm on four boards of directors," added John O. Whitney, a former consultant to G.E. who now teaches at Columbia Business School, "and at every other meeting, someone brings up what Welch would do."
The candidates to take Mr. Welch's place on this score are familiar names in corporate America. They include Mr. Gates, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. of I.B.M., John Chambers of Cisco Systems and Jacques A. Nasser of Ford Motor. But other than Mr. Gates, who recently cut back his control of day-to-day operations and is known for his company's antitrust trial as much as for his management theories, none has nearly the profile that Mr. Welch does. As a result, the management experts said, none is on the verge of being so influential.
Many of the decade's popular management theories had their start, or became widely known, after G.E. adopted them. In the 1980's, Mr. Welch said every G.E. unit should be No. 1 or No. 2 in its field. He then sold or closed those that he thought could not be fixed, laying off some 100,000 employees in the process.
Mirroring the shift in the United States economy, he also moved the company's focus from making products to selling services, and he preached the importance of global business. More recently, he began a quality initiative to improve manufacturing efficiency and watched many of his proteges become chief executives at other companies.
Even during a bull-market run, the results have stood out. When Mr. Welch took over on April 1, 1981, G.E. was worth $13 billion. At the close of business yesterday, its market capitalization was $425 billion. "The magnificence of the story of Jack Welch is the longevity of his success, "said Hobson Brown Jr., the chief executive of Russell Reynolds Associates, a New York headhunter.
Mr. Welch has his critics. He earned the nickname Neutron Jack after ordering the layoffs in the 1980's. And a 1998 book by a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal contended that under Mr. Welch, G.E.'s obsession with profit led to questionable accounting practices and ethical lapses.
The company has denied the accusations in the book, and Mr. Welch has often said he believed that closing unprofitable businesses was both financially and morally sound.
There is no debate, however, about whether other managers use Mr. Welch's tenure as a model, and that is the standard that anybody filling his unofficial job would be judged on, professors and executives said yesterday.
The first place to look, they said, are the technology companies that have captured so much of the popular imagination. Mr. Gates and Michael Dell of Dell Computer are good examples of executives who understood the importance of the Internet long before many others did, and mainstream companies are now following in their tracks. But Mr. Gates and Mr. Dell founded their companies, and the vast majority of chief executives take control of organizations that have at least some history. "The task is very different," said Mr. Bartlett of Harvard.
Mr. Gerstner and Mr. Nasser are similar to Mr. Welch in that they took over large companies and set about changing them. Indeed, I.B.M.'s Mr. Gerstner is frequently mentioned, along with Mr. Welch, as an executive who changed an old, enormous company by making service businesses more important. Ford's Mr. Nasser, meanwhile, has received attention lately for overhauling a company that was long associated with industrial decline. But until now his successes have been only occasionally cited at other companies, management experts said.
A chief executive who both hails from the high technology sector and took over a company after its founding is Mr. Chambers of Cisco. Adrian J. Slywotzky, a well-known author and vice president at Mercer Management Consulting, said Mr. Chambers understands the fundamental premise of business today: Technology must be at the center of everything, but it cannot replace time that executives spend with their customers and employees.
That attitude, Mr. Slywotzky said, "is very Welch-like."

HEADLINE: New York Authority Negotiating to Sell 2 Nuclear Plants

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The New York State Power Authority said today that it was negotiating to sell its two nuclear power plants, which would be one of the largest asset sales ever by the state, and signals the continuing, rapid evolution of the electric power industry.
The authority said it had begun talks with the Entergy Corporation, a major energy company based in New Orleans, for the sale of the Indian Point 3 reactor on the Hudson River, 35 miles north of Manhattan, and the James A. FitzPatrick plant on Lake Ontario. The Indian Point 2 reactor, neighboring Indian Point 3, is owned by Consolidated Edison. 
 Power Authority officials would not say how much they expected to reap from a sale, but industry analysts said the figure would almost certainly be in the hundreds of millions of dollars, and perhaps more than $1 billion.
The authority said that as a condition of any sale, it would continue to provide low-cost power to certain corporate clients under the state's economic development programs, and to local government agencies like New York City, the city's Housing Authority and the subway system. Last year, the two nuclear plants accounted for 32 percent of the electricity produced by the Power Authority, which also runs several hydroelectric plants.
As recently as two years ago, there was no market to speak of for power plants, but in New York and many other states, state regulators have forced utilities to sell off their plants to encourage competition in an industry that has been dominated for a century by government-sanctioned monopolies. For the utilities, that has produced a windfall, as plants powered by gas, oil and coal have fetched prices several times the values that the companies have listed for them on their books.
Nuclear plants are generally considered less desirable because they can be expensive to operate and, later, to decommission. Only a few companies have actively shopped for nuclear plants, and the handful that have been sold have gone for a small fraction of their book value. But industry analysts say the FitzPatrick and Indian Point plants are better properties than most nuclear plants that have gone on the market so far.
"I think we're going to start to see more attractive plants like these being sold, and more bidders, and at more attractive prices," said Stephen Fetter, an energy industry analyst at Fitch Investors Service.
The Power Authority, a quasi-independent agency whose board is appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, did not set out to sell its nuclear plants, according to Mike Petralia, a spokesman. "But over the past 18 months or so, we've been approached by several companies expressing interest in purchasing the plants," he said, while refusing to name any but Entergy.
Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group who follows energy issues, said he was troubled that the authority did not select a buyer through a formal, competitive process.
But Mr. Petralia said the authority had made its standards clear to each of its prospective suitors, including an idea of its asking price and its insistence on job security for plant employees and a continuing role in economic development programs. "Entergy seems to be the only one willing and able to meet those conditions," he said.
Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, a Democrat who heads the Energy Committee, applauded the proposed sale, which he has advocated in the past, but he complained that the process had so far been cloaked in secrecy, making it difficult to determine whether the state was getting the best possible deal.
Indian Point 3 went into operation in 1976 and has a 980-megawatt capacity, making it one of the largest-output power plants in the country. FitzPatrick began operation in 1975 and has a capacity of 800 megawatts.

HEADLINE: In Search of a Chinese Trade Deal

 BODY:
President Clinton's new efforts to salvage a trade deal with China enabling it to join the World Trade Organization come as welcome news. The initiative, begun with a phone call last month from Mr. Clinton to President Jiang Zemin, seeks to repair what administration officials now concede was a policy blunder in April when Washington rejected market-opening terms offered by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on his visit to the United States. Worse yet, publication of the Chinese terms by the administration triggered opposition by opponents of Mr. Zhu's reforms inside China, making any deal more difficult to achieve.
If Mr. Clinton wins terms this time around as favorable as those he rejected in April, he will have performed a remarkable feat of recovery. More likely, China will offer less, and the administration will have to accept it as the price of getting a deal. It may then be difficult to sell the arrangement to Congress, where skepticism of Chinese intentions is running high just as the presidential campaign has begun heating up. 
 The April deal, according to the administration's own summary, would have propelled Chinese economic institutions toward market discipline. Mr. Zhu agreed to cut tariffs below those of most American trade partners, eliminate export subsidies, permit foreign investors to buy substantial shares in insurance and telecommunications companies, protect foreign investors and intellectual property rights and commit state-owned enterprises to make purchases on the basis of price and quality, thereby eliminating discrimination against foreign companies.
These terms were seen as concessions to the West. In fact, they would benefit the Chinese economy over all, though some parts of that economy might suffer. The United States economy is already open to Chinese products, and consumers reap the benefits of unfettered trade. But China's borders are often closed. Opening them would bring Chinese consumers attractive imports and force domestic companies to compete with foreign ones.
But beyond the narrow impact of trade, China's admission to the W.T.O. could have dramatic political impact. Mr. Zhu, like economic reformers throughout the third world, wants to use commitments to the W.T.O. to make it hard for domestic opponents to overturn reforms. Violations of China's commitments to the W.T.O. invite retaliation by China's trade partners.
The administration faces an obstacle to reaching a deal because of Congressional opposition and anxiety about foreign competition in the labor movement. Congress can scuttle the deal by refusing to relinquish its right under current United States laws to deny China trading rights that it would automatically enjoy as a member of the W.T.O.
The most vigorous opponents of China in Congress represent Southern textile and apparel industries that fear cheap imports. But recent studies show that these fears are exaggerated. Chinese exports to the United States would rise by a modest amount. But almost all would come at the expense of exports from other third-world countries rather than from American manufacturers and workers.
Mr. Clinton must also deal with a Chinese demand that the United States promise not to invoke "anti-dumping" rules to drive out low-priced Chinese exports. If China won this demand, it might cause distress among a small number of American workers but would do low-income American consumers an enormous favor. The administration faces the challenge not only of reaching a good deal with China but of then selling it to Congress and to anxious workers.

HEADLINE: Packard Bell NEC Plans Layoffs Of Up to88% of Its Work Force

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Packard Bell NEC Inc., the struggling personal-computer maker controlled by the NEC Corporation, said today that it would lay off as much as 88 percent of its work force in the United States. The company also said that its chief executive would resign and that it would stop selling the Packard Bell brand in the United States.
Packard Bell will slash its payroll in the United States from 2,600 jobs to 300 to 400 positions by the end of first quarter 2000, a spokesman, Ron Fuchs, said. The company's chief executive, Alain Couder, who had been brought in to turn the troubled PC manufacturer around, will step down, as will other senior members of his team. 
 Shareholders expected Packard Bell to cut its losses from $650 million in 1998 to $100 million this year. But the computer maker is on track to lose $150 million this year. The company considered other options, including possible mergers, Mr. Fuchs said.
The cuts cross all manufacturing and administrative positions and will hit the company's Sacramento headquarters and plant hardest. Packard Bell employment in Sacramento will fall to 100 workers, from 1,600.
The company's European manufacturing operations will not be affected. Mr. Fuchs said that Packard Bell was the leading brand in France and Britain.
"The U.S. brand has been damaged because of quality and service problems three and four years ago," he said. "We took our eye off the ball, and though we've made substantial improvements, perception doesn't catch up quite as quick."
Manufacturing workers in the United States are on double shifts now to meet Packard Bell orders, and all of its future products will be sold under the NEC brand.

HEADLINE: Mickey and Minnie Go to Hong Kong;
A Proposed Disney Park Raises Queries on Tourism and Cost

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 2

 BODY:
On Aug. 23, 1998, a delegation from the Walt Disney Company arrived at the office of Hong Kong's chief executive to pitch the idea of building a Disneyland here. That summer day, Hong Kong was far from the happiest place on earth.
Its economy was in the depths of a recession, unemployment was soaring and financial markets around the world were gripped with panic. Just a week earlier, the government had spent billions of dollars to buy shares of companies in its own stock market to fend off what it called predatory foreign speculators. 
 A new Disneyland was just the tonic this downtrodden city needed -- and the team from Disney knew it. What followed was 13 months of grinding negotiations as Hong Kong struggled to achieve two seemingly irreconcilable goals: win the Magic Kingdom without losing its shirt.
Today, Disney and Hong Kong announced their long-awaited plan to open a theme park here by 2005. The total cost of the park and related projects is $3.6 billion, of which Disney will contribute only $316 million. Hong Kong may not have lost its shirt, but critics say it has given away the sleeves.
"There's a substantial upfront cost to the Hong Kong administration, no question about it," said Ian K. Perkin, the chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "But in the long run, the fact that we'll be one of five cities in the world with a Disneyland is a huge positive."
At a news conference here today, Hong Kong and Disney talked a lot about the long run. Hong Kong's leaders said the park would help it fashion a new identity as a tourist destination in the wake of its return to Chinese rule in 1997. Disney executives see it as a powerful launch pad into China.
"This is the world's largest market, despite a temporary financial crisis or a temporary political problem," said Judson C. Green, the chairman of Disney's theme park division. "We think it's the right time to be here."
Anson Chan, the chief secretary of Hong Kong, said, "You cannot put a price on the message that the Walt Disney Company sends the world in choosing Hong Kong for its third international theme park."
Behind these upbeat comments, however, is the tale of how a small government made hard choices to win over a big corporation.
Hong Kong, which desperately sought some good news to offset the gloom of the Asian economic crisis, squared off against Disney, a company with a reputation as a fearsome negotiator and a long list of suitors. Shanghai and several other Chinese cities were also lobbying for a Disney park.
Making the job even harder for Hong Kong, Disney's chairman, Michael Eisner, has been in a slump of his own, as he struggles with slack earnings, difficulties grooming a successor and troubles at the ABC network. Having bought big-ticket items like two $350 million cruise ships, the company, analysts said, was under pressure to keep a lid on spending.
"Michael Eisner has been telling the Street he's going to cut capital spending," said an influential media investor. "That makes them an even tougher negotiator."
Facing Disney across the table was Mike Rowse, Hong Kong's commissioner of tourism. Mr. Rowse, a bluff, 50-year-old Englishman, is used to tense negotiations. He represented Hong Kong when it was engaged in talks with Britain over how much it should pay to take over the British military garrison after the colony returned to China.
But even Mr. Rowse admitted that was poor preparation for Disney. "It was by far the hardest thing I've ever done," he said, recalling the negotiations, which finally ended at 3 a.m. Monday.
The company's initial proposal, according to people involved in the talks, was to build a park on land donated by the government. Disney would have made no upfront investment in the project, and its involvement would have been mainly to collect license fees for the use of its characters.
With property in Hong Kong among the most expensive in the world, accepting such a proposal would have been politically untenable for the government. But Disney told Hong Kong it would be unable to finance the park if it had to pay for the land, people involved in the talks said.
The standoff almost doomed the negotiations. In early June, however, Hong Kong officials proposed a compromise: the government would accept shares, rather than cash, for the land. Hong Kong valued the land at $516 million and agreed to accept subordinate shares in the joint venture that will build the park.
For its part, Hong Kong demanded that Disney also invest in the joint venture, rather than simply license its characters. Much of the period from late June until last weekend was consumed by the negotiations over the respective equity contributions of Disney and Hong Kong.
"The government thought it was important for us to take a stake in the project, and we were happy to do so," Mr. Green said. "But at the same time, we felt it was important for the government to play a role as well."
In the end, Disney agreed to invest $316 million for a 43 percent stake in the joint venture. Hong Kong will contribute $419 million for 57 percent. In addition, the government will extend a $787 million loan and arrange an additional $296 million in commercial loans. That puts the total cost of the 315-acre park at $1.8 billion, of which Hong Kong is contributing $1.5 billion.
And Hong Kong's costs do not end there. It has also agreed to spend $1.75 billion to build roads, a rail link and other services to connect the park to the rest of Hong Kong. Disneyland will be built on reclaimed land in Penny's Bay, a secluded cove on Lantau Island, just west of Hong Kong.
Mr. Rowse noted that Hong Kong would have had to spend this money to develop Lantau into a tourism destination, regardless of whether Disney was the main attraction. But economists are skeptical.
As for Disney, the company pointed out that it does not put money into all its parks. Tokyo Disneyland, for example, was financed and built entirely by a Japanese developer. Disney invested $140 million in Disneyland Paris. But the company later had to spend millions more to rescue that park after it ran into crippling financial problems.
The checkered history of the Paris park, originally called Euro Disney, was clearly on the minds of negotiators during the talks. Mr. Green said Disney would build a smaller-than-usual park, with only 2,100 hotel rooms. That would enable it to operate profitably with only five million visitors a year -- a number that analysts said was conservative.
The Paris operation, by contrast, needs 10 million visitors a year to fill its hotels and operate profitably. After a strong first year, it drew well short of that for several years. The park, after a substantial write-off, is now profitable.
In defending its deal today, Hong Kong officials said Disneyland would bring vast benefits to the local economy. They said it would attract 1.4 million additional visitors a year to the city in its first year. Hong Kong now has 10 million visitors a year, though its tourism industry has been lagging.
The officials also said that the park would generate 18,400 jobs, either directly or indirectly, in its first year, and 35,800 in later years. That is an alluring prospect in a city with an unemployment rate of 6 percent.
Some economists were also encouraged that the government said it might sell off part of its investment in a few years, either through a stock offering or to an investor.
"The downside is fairly low and the upside is large, in terms of giving Hong Kong a new arrow in its quiver," said David Dodwell, co-author of a book about the local economy, "The Hong Kong Advantage."
Beyond the bottom line, though, some local business people say there was an unseemliness to the way Hong Kong pursued the deal with Disney. Senior officials publicized the talks as early as last March, which gave the impression that Hong Kong was hungry for a deal.
"There is absolutely nothing wrong with Disney coming to Hong Kong as an investor," said David Tang, the founder of Shanghai Tang, an upscale boutique. "But do they require a subsidy of $2.5 billion?"
Mr. Tang also worries that Hong Kong's embrace of Disney could exclude the development of Chinese attractions in China's newest city. He seems to be in a minority here, however, in worrying about the suffocating effect of American popular culture. In a daylong series of briefings on the project, the question of Disney's impact on the cultural life of Hong Kong scarcely came up.
Critics were more worried that Disney is not barred from building another theme park in Asia, perhaps even in China, that could compete with Hong Kong. Mr. Green affirmed that Disney would continue discussing other projects. But he added that Hong Kong would be its main focus for the next decade.
Despite all the quibbles, Hong Kong officials were in the mood to savor their victory. Even Tung Chee-hwa, the stolid former shipping tycoon who is Hong Kong's chief executive, smiled gamely when Mickey Mouse threw a brightly colored arm around him at the news conference.
Mr. Rowse spoke for many in Hong Kong, which was handed over to China two years ago, when he said: "We kind of faded out of the spotlight after 1997, and everybody wrote us off. This project tells the world that we are alive and kicking."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
JENNY CRAIG PLANNING MAJOR CUTBACKS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
With sales and profit shrinking, the weight-loss chain Jenny Craig Inc. said late on Monday that it would close 86 of its weight-loss centers in the United States and reduce staff by 15 percent at its headquarters in the San Diego suburb of La Jolla. The company, hurt by a trend of do-it-yourself dieting and the introduction of a new line of snack bars and drinks that cannibalized existing product lines, also reported a loss for the quarter that ended Sept. 30. The centers slated to be closed, about 16 percent of the total in the United States, were losing money. A total of 103 jobs, including 26 at the La Jolla headquarters, are being eliminated

HEADLINE: A Policy Shift On Serbia Tied To a Free Vote

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton administration, trying to strengthen the opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, has agreed to end its economic sanctions on Serbia as soon as there is a free election there, senior administration officials said today.
Washington previously vowed that the sanctions would last as long as Mr. Milosevic stayed in power. 
 But officials said the new strategy should let the opposition put more pressure on Mr. Milosevic, because an early election could remove the oil embargo, air-travel ban and other sanctions levied by Washington.
The sanctions, with the bombing during the war in Kosovo, have devastated the economy. But the sanctions have proven unable to dislodge President Milosevic, whose term runs to 2001.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is expected to make the announcement on Wednesday, but it carries a risk: that bickering opposition parties would so fragment the election results that Mr. Milosevic could cling to power.
Thus the United States might find itself compelled to lift its sanctions on a government still led by Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicted for war crimes by an international tribunal in The Hague. But American officials say Dr. Albright and her aides have determined that the risk is tiny and that an internationally monitored election would end Mr. Milosevic's political career.
A delegation of leading Serbian opposition figures now visiting Washington pressed for the policy change, arguing that it would allow them to increase popular pressure on Mr. Milosevic to call an election that they are certain they can win.
Polls in Serbia indicate that nearly 70 percent of voters want a new government. But the United States cannot be certain that voters will cast ballots for change and that the opposition can capitalize on the discontent to win control.
If he were to remain in power after an election, the administration would almost certainly try to prove that the vote had not been free and fair, and thus the United States would not be compelled to lift its sanctions.
"We cannot imagine, based on our analysis, that a genuinely free and fair election would allow Milosevic to remain as president," said a senior official.
Administration officials said the White House and State Department had decided on the policy shift because Washington has become convinced that the long-fragmented opposition in Serbia, the larger of the two republics remaining in Yugoslavia, is now unified in its determination to force early elections and to oust Mr. Milosevic.
"Our assumption is that Milosevic will only hold elections as a result of the pressure of the opposition's efforts," one official said. "And we are bolstering the opposition's efforts by taking away from Milosevic the idea that the sanctions are the result of American evil."
The administration has already agreed to another request from the delegation of Serbs: that Washington support a European-run pilot program to allow about $5 million worth of oil to be delivered this winter to two cities in Serbia that are governed by opponents of Mr. Milosevic.
The United States had initially been hesitant to support the program for fear that the oil might be diverted to Mr. Milosevic's business associates or the military.
American officials had also hoped that economic privations and the prospect of winter might lead to a new wave of public unrest against the government.
But American officials said they were persuaded to support the program both for humanitarian reasons and because safeguards should make it difficult for the oil to be diverted. All other economic sanctions remain in place, they stressed, and the lack of heating oil and other energy supplies in the rest of Serbia could still deepen discontent.
Serbia faces a brutal energy shortage after NATO bombers destroyed its oil refineries in the campaign to drive Serbian forces out of Kosovo.
The administration's concessions to the Serbian delegation are considered vital to the public standing of the opposition leaders, who are being portrayed in the government-controlled news media in Serbia as pro-Western traitors.
"They can now return home and announce -- with conviction -- that they helped convince the United States to shift its policy and speed up the timetable to end Serbia's isolation," an administration official said.
At a news conference on Wednesday, officials said, Dr. Albright is also expected to hold out the possibility that in exchange for free elections, the United States would commit itself to reconstruction aid for Serbia -- to help rebuild the country after the NATO bombing.
Although the Constitution of the Yugoslav Federation of Serbia and Montenegro does not grant President Milosevic direct power to call elections, the reality is that his powers are dictatorial.
"He snaps his fingers, and there will be elections," one senior administration official said. "We're trying to increase the pressure on him to snap his fingers."

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 5; Workplace

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
As Hours Lengthen, Workers Gain Freedom to Set Them

BYLINE: By ALISA TANG

 BODY:
Americans are putting in longer hours than ever, but at least they have more say today than in years past about when they work them.
 In 1985, only 12.4 percent of full-time workers had flex time agreements with employers giving them a role in deciding their work schedules. Six years later, flex time still covered only 15.1 percent of the work force. But then the concept caught fire, and by 1997, the number had shot up to almost 28 percent. The overall idea of flex time is becoming less tied to an option for new mothers and parents to take care of their children, and more of a benefit that can be enjoyed by everyone, said Tom Beers, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which conducted the surveys. 
 Flex time comes in three forms: the gliding schedule that allows workers to vary arrival and departure times; variable schedules that require a specified number of working hours but set no schedules, and compensatory-time arrangements that allow employees to apply overtime to future time off.
 The movement is still largely unofficial; only 6 percent of employees in 1997 had formal agreements. And not all job categories are created equal: 65 percent of university teachers enjoy workplace freedom, compared with 10 percent of machine operators. ALISA TANG

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 870 words

HEADLINE: New M.T.A. Spending Plan Badly Flawed, McCall Says

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A fiercely contested proposal by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to spend $17.5 billion on repairs and expansion of its subway, bus and commuter train service is based on unclear and flawed financial assumptions, according to a report issued yesterday by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
The five-year plan for large capital projects, the costliest ever proposed by the authority, is "overly reliant on debt," Mr. McCall said in an interview yesterday. To pay off its new borrowing, his analysis concluded, the authority might have to raise bus and subway fares by as much as 30 cents by 2004. 
 While offering no easy solutions to the financial squeeze, Mr. McCall said the authority's best hope was to seek more money in direct subsidies from the state, which he said should have been contributing more to mass transit projects under Gov. George E. Pataki. His assertion was challenged yesterday by a spokesman for the governor.
The comptroller's report, coming two months after similar financial warnings from the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan research group that advises the New York City Council and other elected officials, was released in advance of a hearing today in which senior authority officials are expected to defend their ambitious plan before state legislators.
Although Mr. McCall concluded that the plan was too expensive, the hearing promises a forum for those who think it does not go far enough, particularly in providing money for a Second Avenue subway. The hearing, to be held in Manhattan, has been called by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who represents the Lower East Side and has threatened to block the authority's capital plan if it does not give higher priority to the Second Avenue subway project.
A spokeswoman for the authority, Lisa Schwartz, declined to comment on the comptroller's report yesterday, saying the authority chairman, E. Virgil Conway, would address it in testimony at Mr. Silver's hearing today. A spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, Patricia Lynch, said the speaker would reserve comment until after today's hearing.
Mr. McCall's report acknowledged that the authority was subject to conflicting demands and said the proposal was "laudable because it furthers the process of restoring the regional mass transit system." Flush with sharp increases in riders on its buses and subways and buoyed by the region's strong economy, the authority has proposed expanding its system, instead of merely maintaining it, for the first time in more than 50 years.
The capital spending plan, which would succeed a smaller, $12.5 billion capital program that expires Dec. 31, includes $3 billion for new trains, tracks and tunnels. The biggest projects would be a new $1.5 billion tunnel to bring service on the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, and work on the Second Avenue subway, budgeted at $700 million.
The plan faces an uphill battle in Albany, since it can be vetoed by any of the four members of the Capital Program Review Board, which includes a representative selected by Mr. Silver. Board members are also selected by the State Senate, the governor and the mayor.
In his report, Mr. McCall joined Mr. Silver and several elected officials in Manhattan in warning that extending Long Island Rail Road service to Grand Central would severely aggravate crowding on the Lexington Avenue subway line, since the plan calls for completing the tunnel long before a new subway along Second Avenue.
But Mr. McCall's chief criticism was that the authority had failed to explain how it would pay for its plans, even if they were not revised to provide more money for the Second Avenue project.
Among the financial questions left unanswered, Mr. McCall's report said, were whether the authority had set aside enough money to reach a new contract with Local 100 of the Transport Workers, its biggest union, whose current contract expires Dec. 15. It said the authority's spending plan also failed to provide for contingencies if the regional economy sours, carving into the economically dependent real estate transfer tax, sales tax and other tax revenues that make up its biggest source of government support.
Even without such a downturn, the report said, the five-year plan would require the authority to take on more than $20 billion in new debt through new municipal bonds. Payments on that debt would come on top of the authority's bills to pay off $13 billion in existing debt, the report said, calling the projected debt payments "an extraordinary amount in a relatively short period of time."
Mr. McCall said the state was the culprit in the authority's financial difficulties. In contrast to the city and the federal governments, he said, the state has refused to increase its contribution to the authority's budget since 1995, when the Pataki administration diverted $220 million in state money to other state obligations -- money that had been sought for authority projects.
Michael F. McKeon, a spokesman for the governor, said yesterday that Mr. McCall's charge was based on "political partisanship." He said Mr. Pataki had "restored millions to the system" and helped create a "true renaissance of mass transit."

HEADLINE: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY ASSEMBLY;
Democrats Win Seats in Three Districts, Narrowing Republicans' Majority

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Democrats picked up three seats in elections for New Jersey's 80 State Assembly districts today, narrowing the Republicans' majority in the lower house of the Legislature to 45-to-35.
In an off-year election that set records for high campaign spending and low voter turnout, Democratic challengers picked up at least one of the two seats in the 4th District in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Republican incumbent Gerald J. Luongo, who has faced criticism over involvement in a questionable land deal, appeared headed to defeat. His running mate, the incumbent George F. Geist, won re-election. 
 Democrats also picked up two seats in Mercer County, where Assembly candidates rode the reverse coattails of Glen Gilmore, a Democrat who won the Mayor's race in Hamilton Township.
But Republican incumbents fended off challenges in several fiercely contested races, where Democrats unsuccessfully sought to make gun control and health insurance the crucial issues.
A Democratic challenger, Edward Werner, whose 7-year-old son was the victim of a sensational murder case, failed to unseat either Republican -- Joseph R. Malone or Melvin Cottrell -- in the 30th District in Burlington and Ocean Counties.
The Assembly majority leader, Charles DiGaetano, who set a state fund-raising record by collecting more than $700,000 for his race, also survived a challenge for his seat in Bergen, Essex and Passaic Counties.
Republican party leaders hailed the results as an endorsement of their leadership since seizing the Assembly majority in 1991. Republicans outspent Democrats two-to-one, according to records filed in the Election Law Enforcement Commission, and in the weeks before the election some Republicans had predicted that the party's candidates might retain all 48 of their seats.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said that although Democrats did pick up three seats, Republicans still fared far better than majority parties in previous midterm elections.
"Given what has happened in the past during off-year elections in a Governor's second term, we did pretty well," Mrs. Whitman said.
Political analysts said the results would do little to shift the balance of power in the state capital, where both Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco are believed to be interested in running to replace the Governor when her term expires in 2001.
"It means pretty much status quo politics, no change in power," said Cliff Zukin, a political science professor at Rutgers university. "The seats which changed hands were largely decided on local issues. Incumbents won and incumbents should win when the economy is good, there's no grass roots anger and incumbents raise a boatload more money than do challengers."
With no statewide or national offices at the top of the ballot, and New Jersey enjoying a strong economy and a drop in crime rates, many experts predicted voter turnout would break the record low of 35 percent, set the last time Assembly races led the ballot, in 1995.
But despite tepid interest, fund-raising and spending for this year's campaigns was expected to surpass the record of $12 million set in 1995, according to the director of the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission.
Democrats had hoped to make the election a referendum on gun control and health care. Many public opinion polls show that New Jersey's historically cantankerous voters feel uneasy about gun safety, public education and the restrictions by health insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.
In many races, Democrats blasted Republicans for blocking a bill to make New Jersey the first state to require that all handguns have "smart gun" technology -- devices that prevent them from firing for anyone but their owners.
"Republicans try to talk about how rosy things are, but just beneath the surface, people are concerned about their futures, and whether their children are going to be safe in school," said Julie Roginsky, campaign director for the Assembly Democrats.
But Republicans countered by pointing out that Assembly Speaker Jack Collins had led the successful fight for a bill requiring trigger locks on all guns sold in the state. Republicans also won approval of a bill to set aside $1 million to finance research and development of smart-gun technology. Republicans also pointed out that Democratic legislators and Jim Florio, the former governor who is running for United States Senate, raised taxes by $2.8 billion when they controlled Trenton.
"Under Republican leadership, the Assembly has controlled spending, cut taxes, unemployment is in an all-time low, and I haven't heard of anyone returning their property tax rebate checks to the Treasury," said Chuck Haytaian, Republican state party chairman. "When you compare it to 1991, when the Democrats lost favor, unemployment was in double digits and there had been a $2.8 billion tax increase, today is a good day to be an incumbent."
Indeed, before the night was over, the attention of many elected officials had already turned to next November's race to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat. In recent days, two Republican candidates have announced plans to form exploratory committees for the Senate race: State Senator William L. Gormley and Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
A Democratic Senate candidate, Jon S. Corzine, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, also won endorsements, one from the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, who easily won re-election today. Also, Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat who was once considered a likely candidate for Mr. Lautenberg's seat, announced today that he would hold a news conference in Washington on Wednesday to endorse Mr. Corzine in his primary battle against Mr. Florio and a former state party chairman, Tom Byrne.
"I waited until after the Assembly elections because I didn't want to detract from the attention from races we were trying so hard to generate attention for," Mr. Menendez said.
In other election results, about 65 percent of voters approved a referendum to issue $500 million in bonds to rebuild some roads and bridges on state and county roads.
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark also helped Democrats retain the only State Senate seat being contested this year, by handily defeating his Republican challenger in a race for the seat vacated when Senator Wynona Lipman died in May. Mr. James won the right to serve the final year of her term, and will have to run for re-election in 2001.

HEADLINE: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: CHARTER REVISION;
NEW YORK VOTERS STRONGLY REJECT CHARTER REVISION

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
New York voters resoundingly rejected revisions to the City Charter yesterday in a defeat for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had campaigned for the changes as a referendum on his policies. The vote was a victory for Mark Green, the Public Advocate, and other Democratic politicians, who had criticized the revisions as a mayoral power grab.
"The mayor picked this fight, and now lost this fight," Mr. Green said last night at a celebration at the Two Boots restaurant in the East Village. "Although City Hall outspent our grass roots coalition 10-to-1, our effort won by 3-to-1 because New Yorkers know a scam when they see one." 
 Mr. Giuliani conceded late last night that he should not have promoted such changes this year, and urged the City Council to pass legislation reflecting the goals of many of the charter proposals. "I made a mistake in presenting charter revision this year," Mayor Giuliani said in a news conference at the St. Regis Hotel in Midtown. "The vote against it makes it clear that it was a mistake, and I accept responsibility for it and certainly respect the views of the voters."
Mr. Giuliani, in an unusually conciliatory tone, congratulated "the people who ran the campaign on the other side. They did a very good job, and they're entitled to feel elated by the victory."
Mr. Giuliani had been expected to use a charter victory as evidence of voter support for his programs in the 2000 Senate race as a likely opponent of Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Peter Vallone, the speaker of the City Council, who had campaigned against the charter revisions, said the results were "sweeter than any personal victory I've ever had" and that it proved "that you can never underestimate the intelligence of the voters." Voters understood, he said, that the mayor "was using the charter revision for political purposes, as a weapon."
With 100 percent of unofficial returns tallied by 11:20 p.m., the vote was 76 percent to 24 percent against charter revision, or 281,265 people opposed and 90,838 in favor.
The Board of Elections reported that 11 percent of the city's 3.4 million registered voters turned out on a rainy, blustery day in an off-year election with few major races at stake. But opponents of the charter revision said they believed that voters turned out in relatively high numbers on the Upper East Side, the Upper West Side, in Park Slope and in Brooklyn Heights -- heavily Democratic areas targeted by charter revision opponents. Critics of the changes had predicted that a low turnout would help their side, and argued that only people who were strongly against the charter changes would make the effort to vote.
The most important changes would have required a two-thirds vote of the City Council to approve certain tax increases and would have imposed a cap on city spending tied to the rate of inflation. Mr. Giuliani said the changes were necessary because, in essence, he could trust no future mayor with the fiscal discipline he said he has imposed on the city. Therefore, he said, he had to create a "shadow" of himself.
Critics countered that Mr. Giuliani was behaving like a despot, and that he was trying to seize control of city spending. Critics also said the proposals would make it so difficult to raise taxes that future City Councils might be forced to increase property taxes instead, which would have been exempt from the two-thirds rule under the charter changes.
Among the most politically popular proposals was a requirement for gun-free zones around city schools, the first of the 14 revisions listed altogether on the ballot as Proposition 2, which voters had to vote for or against as an entire package. Critics said such changes should have been more properly enacted through the normal legislative channels of the City Council, and not by changing the city's basic governing document.
Both the mayor and Democratic officials had campaigned extensively for and against charter revision in the week before the election, provoking criticism from good-government groups who said both sides were stepping over a legal line. Under state law, taxpayer-funded entities, like the mayor's office and the City Council, may "educate" but not "advocate" about the contents and consequences of ballot questions. Although neither side explicitly said "vote for" or "vote against" in a series of mailings to voters, critics said the views were implicit.
The Charter Revision Commission also spent taxpayer money on television cable commercials.
"This has been a pretty shabby week in New York politics," said Conn Nugent, the executive director of Citizens Union, a civic group. Mr. Nugent said that the mayor and Randy Mastro, the commission's chairman and a former deputy mayor under Mr. Giuliani, had gone further over the line than the opposition, and had spent what he estimated to be at least $1 million of taxpayer money. "Those guys are getting away with murder," he said.
The mayor's political action committee, Solutions America, also paid for radio commercials and prerecorded phone calls from Mr. Giuliani that did urge people to vote yes, as is allowed with private funds. The calls from Mr. Giuliani had startled many voters, and opponents said last night that they may have backfired.
Although voters seemed to see the proposed charter revision as a deeply uninteresting government debate, the changes were in fact born out of a political feud between Mr. Giuliani and one of his most nettlesome tormentors, Mr. Green, that has rarely been dull. When the Mayor announced the creation of a Charter Revision Commission in June, for example, he did not even bother to deny that a primary motivation was to block the liberal Mr. Green from succeeding him as Mayor -- a nightmare scenario, in the eyes of Mr. Giuliani, that would take the city back to the days of high taxes, rampant crime and a politician unable to say no to special interest groups.
Under the original proposals, the commission would have required a special election within 60 days if the mayor leaves office early, as could happen if Mr. Giuliani is elected to the Senate in 2000 with a year left in his term for mayor. Under the charter's current provisions, the Public Advocate automatically finishes the term of any mayor who leaves office early.
Critics immediately attacked the special election proposal as a vendetta by Mr. Giuliani against Mr. Green, who by the nature of his job and his temperament has aggravated the mayor since since both men took office in 1994. Randy Mastro, the commission's chairman and a former deputy mayor under Mr. Giuliani, eventually retreated under the assaults, and in September announced that the commission would delay the special election provision until 2002, when both Mr. Green and Mr. Giuliani are out of office. Had the voters approved the changes, the rest of the revisions would have gone into effect on Jan. 1, 2000.
Without an impending confrontation between two contentious political personalities, both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Green seemed to lose interest in the proposed changes. As recently as three weeks before the election, the most striking thing about each side was its silence, although both said they were reserving their money for public education campaigns just before the election.
Last Monday, Mr. Giuliani finally made a speech strongly urging voters to support the charter changes. Meanwhile, a coalition of labor groups and Vote No on Charter Inc., an advocacy group led by Richard Schrader, who is on leave as Mr. Green's chief of public affairs, had been busy canvassing, sending out mailings and operating phone banks.

HEADLINE: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: ERIE COUNTY;
Republican Defeats Incumbent In Race for County Executive

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Joel Giambra, the Republican candidate for Erie County executive who was endorsed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, defeated the Democratic incumbent, Dennis Gorski, who quickly conceded last night.
Mr. Giambra, a former Democrat who switched to the Republican Party last year to run for county executive, will lead upstate New York's largest government, including Buffalo and its suburbs. And he will presumably become an important ally in Mr. Giuliani's all-but-announced race for the United States Senate next year. Mr. Giambra's victory may also help Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, by weakening the local Democratic Party organization, the state's largest outside of New York City. 
 Mr. Gorski, speaking of Mayor Giuliani's endorsement of Mr. Giambra, has said he found political endorsements "repulsive" and "the height of arrogance." He added, "You have somebody from out of town telling people in the community who to vote for, knowing full well he knows very little or nothing about the community in question."
With 79 percent of 1,007 districts reporting, Mr. Giambra had posted unofficial returns of 123, 020 votes, or 54 percent of the total, and Mr. Gorski had 99,185 votes, or 43 percent, with two other candidates, Jeffrey Baran and Mo Saladin, making up the balance.
Mr. Giambra, 42, the City of Buffalo comptroller, campaigned on his proposal for a 30 percent cut in property taxes over the next four years. Mr. Giambra drew some criticism for having only a two-year community college degree. Nonetheless, The Buffalo News endorsed him because, it said, his overall vision and tax cut proposal "most accurately depicts the kind of leadership that Erie County needs at this time."
Mr. Gorski congratulated Mr. Giambra about 9:45 p.m. and began a televised concession speech about 10:15. Previously, he had criticized Mr. Giambra. "I don't think he understands the dimensions of this government," Mr. Gorski, 55, had said.
Last night, Mr. Gorski's press secretary, Michael Hughes, said Mr. Gorski would not be giving interviews. But Mr. Hughes said in a prepared statement that Mr. Giambra was "poised to inherit a government that is well positioned for the 21st century." In his victory speech, Mr. Giambra said, "The community embraced our agenda for change, and now it's time to respect the will of the people."
Steve Pigeon, the Erie County Democratic chairman, has described Mr. Giambra as "a Benedict Arnold" for switching to the Republican Party, but he also noted that the economy upstate had been sluggish and that Mr. Gorski was a 12-year incumbent. "He's the closest neck to strangle," Mr. Pigeon said.

HEADLINE: Kenneth L. Schnitzer, 70, Dies; Innovative Houston Developer

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Kenneth L. Schnitzer, a visionary Texas real estate developer and civic leader whose 30 commercial buildings form much of the Houston skyline, died on Monday after a six-month battle with lung cancer. He was 70.
Casting out on his own after a stint as salesman for his family's Magnolia Paper Company, Mr. Schnitzer, still in his 20's, began a career that over almost five decades produced such Houston landmarks as Greenway Plaza, the 71-story Wells Fargo Bank Plaza, the 50-story Enron building, the Mcorp Plaza and Citicorp Center. 
 Another monument was the Houston Summit, a sports arena now known as the Compaq Center that, as a public-private joint venture, served as a model widely copied elsewhere.
Some of his projects, particularly the 127-acre Greenway Plaza, were also among the nation's first large-scale, planned urban developments to emphasize greenbelts and extensive landscaping.
A third-generation Houstonian who attended the University of Texas and the University of Houston, Mr. Schnitzer started in 1967 to assemble the land for the Greenway Plaza project by negotiating separate purchases of 300 homes for an average price of $45,000 and five years of rent-free occupancy. Few homeowners held out in those negotiations, which his sons said he regarded as one of his proudest achievements.
By the early 1980's, the complex had a 400-room hotel, an underground shopping mall, the Summit home of professional sports teams and a workday population exceeding 12,000 spread through 10 office towers. He won a political fight to have the city build the arena, which opened in 1975, at Greenway Plaza instead of downtown.
In the arena's early years, Mr. Schnitzer was co-owner and managing partner of the Houston Rockets basketball team and the Aeros hockey team, both Summit tenants.
"He could see things others miss," said Don Jordan, chairman of Reliant Energy. "He really changed the skyline in this city."
Among other things, Mr. Schnitzer was a founding director of Houston Proud, which was created to spur a rebound from the oil price collapse in the 1980's; founding chairman of the Houston Economic Development Council, and director of the Greater Houston Partnership and the Greater Houston Convention and Visitors Bureau.
His reputation as a civic leader and a philanthropist survived charges that he and two other local businessmen committed fraud involving an ailing savings and loan in Pasadena, Tex., an industry that suffered acutely in Texas when the price of a barrel of oil plunged to single digits. A Federal jury convicted the men, but the judge, in a rare intervention, acquitted them and was upheld on appeal. The land deal central to the case, it was ruled, had been a substantive transaction and not the "cash for trash" exchange that prosecutors maintained.
Bob Lanier, a former mayor of Houston, said Mr. Schnitzer "was scapegoated" by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for selling distressed savings and loan assets. "It was a business transaction that backfired because the value of the property went down," Mr. Lanier said.
In his mid-60's, a vacation in Mexico inspired Mr. Schnitzer to create and develop a master-planned resort in Los Cabos, near the tip of Baja California, raising his sights from a handful of units to a $200 million luxury community called Villas del Mar overlooking the Sea of Cortez that is to be completed in 2005.
Mr. Schnitzer is survived by his second wife, Quinlan Quiros Schnitzer of Houston; two sons, Kenneth L. Jr. of Dallas and Douglas W. of Houston; four grandchildren, and three stepchildren. His first marriage, to the former Joan Weingarten, ended in divorce.
