HEADLINE: Ayatollah Rebukes Iran Liberals and U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Iran's supreme religious leader today marked the 20th anniversary of the seizure of the American Embassy here with a fiery speech denouncing Iranian reformers who have called for reconciliation with the United States as "either simpletons or traitors."
Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the conservative Muslim cleric who wields paramount religious and political power in Iran, appeared to slam the door on any easing of tensions between the two countries. 
 At the same time, he appeared to open a potentially explosive chapter in a bitter power struggle between conservatives and reformers within the ruling clergy, one in which conflicting attitudes toward the United States will be as much a battlefield as demands for more democracy and human rights.
For nearly an hour Ayatollah Khamenei -- before a student audience that interrupted with cries of "Death to America!" and "Death to Israel!" -- kept up an anti-American diatribe that was stunning in its virulence. As though the Islamic Revolution of 1979 had occurred only yesterday, he depicted the United States as a country dedicated to subordinating and exploiting Iran and suppressing the Islamic beliefs of its people.
"It is very clear today that America has no other fate in mind for us today than before the revolution, that of submission, and obviously we will fight that," he said.
But even worse, he said, summoning up the specter of a treacherous fifth column within Iran, was that "a small but active minority" of clergy, secular politicians and journalists, people for whom "the dictates of Islam are not important," was working for the United States against Iran's interests.
Those people, Ayatollah Khamenei said, even suggested that the 20th anniversary of the embassy takeover, to be marked on Thursday with an officially organized demonstration in front of the former embassy compound in central Tehran, be changed from its traditional format of banner-waving, slogan-shouting hostility to something less confrontational. That appeared to be a reference, in part, to the main student group at the University of Tehran.
"Some people are even trying to convert 'The Day of Confronting Global Arrogance' " -- the celebration's formal title -- "into a day of softness toward America," Ayatollah Khamenei said. "I can only say they are either simpletons or traitors."
Since a presidential election 30 months ago that was won by Mohammad Khatami, a high-ranking, reform-minded cleric who reached out to the United States with a call for "a dialogue of civilizations," the governments in Tehran and Washington have maintained a frequent exchange of public messages, each speaking of its interest in opening contacts while setting conditions the other side has rejected. Meanwhile, both governments have encouraged a resumption of unofficial contacts.
But Ayatollah Khamenei's speech gave an ominous twist to the internal debate in Iran. Without mentioning President Khatami, whose powers are mostly subordinate to his own, Mr. Khamenei appeared to invite a showdown, one that many Iranians fear could stretch tensions to the breaking point.
In recent weeks conservatives have appeared to be looking for any opportunity to crack down on the reformers, in an attempt to gain advantage ahead of key parliamentary elections in February in which the reformers are widely expected to win a majority.
At the worst, reformers worry that popular frustrations on a wide range of issues -- mainly those dealing with political repression and the battered state of Iran's economy -- could touch off fresh outbreaks of violence, of the kind that erupted when the police and armed Islamic vigilantes cracked down on proreform students in July.
In turn, the reformers fear, conservatives could use public disorder as an excuse to cancel the elections, or to disqualify large numbers of reform candidates.
In his remarks today, Ayatollah Khamenei adopted what amounted to a time-tested revolutionary tactic, of setting a litmus test that could be used to identity and eliminate opponents. In effect, he put reformers on notice that further advocacy of improved ties with Washington would be regarded as un-Islamic and treasonable, terms that have been used since the revolution to justify severe punishments.
While many Iranians seem exhausted with the drumbeat of anti-American polemics, Ayatollah Khamenei insisted that hostility toward the United States should be unremitting.
For "three or four years," he said, senior American officials had been saying they wanted a new relationship with Iran. But he said American intentions had been become clear recently when a "woman official" in Washington -- meaning Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright -- had said Iran would have to abandon its hostility toward the Middle East peace effort as a condition of the United States dropping economic sanctions and other aspects of its "containment" policy.
"Zionists are the main policy makers of America," Ayatollah Khamenei said, "and the problem is that Iran is the biggest and most important center of confrontation with Israel."
Among reformers, the stridency of the ayatollah's remarks were a shock. Although courts that are under the religious leader's control have stepped up prosecutions of reformers in recent months, Ayatollah Khamenei appeared to hold out an olive branch to President Khatami as recently as a month ago. But subsequent actions have persuaded many Iranians that the religious leader may have only been seeking to put the reformers off guard.

HEADLINE: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: CHARTER REVISION;
Coalition of Democrats Helped Doom Mayor's Charter Plan

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's huge defeat on the City Charter on Tuesday was engineered by a classic, sometimes stealthlike coalition of labor unions, Democratic officials and political clubs that targeted 20 key neighborhoods around the city and then deployed 1,500 people to knock on doors and bring voters to the polls on Nov. 2. Even Mr. Giuliani acknowledged yesterday that his opponents "did a much better job of pulling the vote."
But Mr. Giuliani and his supporters also said the loss did not mean trouble for him in his unannounced United States Senate campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton, and pointed to a crucial Republican victory in Erie County as far more important to the mayor's political future. 
 Mr. Giuliani went so far as to say that a catastrophic loss for his party in Nassau County was not a problem either, because the county executive, who was not up for re-election, is still a Republican.
The election, the mayor's supporters said, was like losing a Yankees game at the start of the season. Voters rejected 14 proposals to revise the City Charter that the mayor had campaigned for as a referendum on his policies.
"I don't think it'll have any bearing on anything six months from now, much less a year from now," said Mr. Giuliani, who was strikingly cheerful during a news conference yesterday in City Hall Park. "I can look at last night's election and say, from a political point of view, if you had a choice of one of the two things, winning the charter vote, or Erie County going into Republican hands, I can tell you which would be more important politically."
On Tuesday, the Republican candidate for Erie County executive, Joel Giambra, defeated the 12-year Democratic incumbent, Dennis Gorski, in the state's largest Democratic stronghold outside New York City. Mr. Giuliani campaigned last week for Mr. Giambra in an Italian restaurant in Cheektowaga, saying it would be "terrific" to have him in office.
Despite Mr. Giuliani's dismissal of the charter vote, jubilant Democrats at a news conference on the City Hall steps said their coalition was also a training run for the work they planned to do for Mrs. Clinton after her expected announcement in January of her Senate candidacy. Then they eagerly described the extent of operations that they kept quiet to avoid a confrontation with the mayor.
"If this got turned into Rudy versus the unions, we thought the issue would get submerged," said Richard A. Riley, the spokesman for the teachers' union.
Officials from the teachers' union said the group had 1,000 rotating volunteers making telephone calls against the charter changes four nights a week from mid-October until the election. Union officials said members eventually contacted, either by phone or by mailings, all of its 100,000 members who live in New York City.
District Council 37, the municipal union that supported Mr. Giuliani in his 1997 mayoral campaign, also operated phone banks from its offices in Lower Manhattan five days a week during the six weeks prior to the election. Lee Saunders, the union's administrator, said yesterday that the callers reached 90,000 union members but were careful not to publicize their efforts.
"We did not want to show our hand too early," Mr. Saunders said. "We knew that we were going to be outspent."
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which did not get a special productivity wage increase that it sought from the city in its most recent contract, also turned up on the City Hall steps with the groups against the charter revisions. Pat Lynch, the union's president, said that "you cannot change the Constitution in the dark of night" and that "we want a say in how this city is run," adding that "we're here, and we're not going away."
Labor unions particularly disliked two important changes in the charter revisions: one requiring a two-thirds vote of the City Council to approve certain tax increases and another imposing a cap on city spending tied to the rate of inflation. Labor officials said yesterday that the proposals would have made it harder for the city to raise money and therefore could have led to layoffs or at least made it more difficult for union members to get raises.
Another important group in the coalition was Vote No on Charter Inc., an advocacy group led by Richard Schrader, who is on leave until next Monday as the chief of public affairs to Mark Green, the city's public advocate, whose five years of quarrels with the mayor led to the proposed charter revisions in the first place.
(Under the original charter proposals, Mr. Green would not have automatically succeeded the mayor, as is now law, if the mayor won the Senate race and left office a year early. Critics attacked the proposal as a political vendetta by Mr. Giuliani against Mr. Green, and the mayor's Charter Revision Commission eventually withdrew it.)
Mr. Schrader said yesterday that his group selected 20 neighborhoods, from the Upper West Side in Manhattan to Park Slope in Brooklyn to Riverdale in the Bronx, where volunteers and Democratic club members stuffed mailboxes and knocked on doors during the six weekends prior to Nov. 2.
On Election Day, Mr. Schrader said, volunteers in each neighborhood knocked on doors from 5:30 to 8:30 p.m. and drove people to the polls on a rainy, blustery evening when turnout was only 11 percent of New York City's 3.4 million registered voters.
Mr. Schrader also said he thought that an expensive telemarketing campaign of prerecorded phone calls from Mr. Giuliani, urging voters to approve the charter changes, backfired, in large part because many calls were made to traditionally Democratic voters who intensely dislike the mayor. "We had 10 or 12 voters who said, 'I just got a call from Giuliani -- I don't want to hear from him,' " Mr. Schrader said. "I thought he wandered into the lion's den and pulled out some adversarial votes."
Mr. Giuliani conceded as much yesterday. "When you make telephone calls, sometimes you make them to the right places, and sometimes you make them to the wrong places," the mayor said, adding that "the only solace in the election of yesterday is that when you lose 75-25, a few phone calls to the wrong place wasn't the reason you lost."

HEADLINE: U.S. Spending Limits Set in '97 Now Are Largely Ignored

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
As Congress and the Clinton administration head into the final stages of their negotiations over the federal budget, both sides say they are determined to avoid spending any portion of the money that flows to the government through the Social Security system.
Neither side, however, is saying much about another benchmark for fiscal restraint, the spending limits that became law as part of the 1997 bipartisan budget deal. 
 Without any announcement, or a specific vote to do so, the Republican-controlled Congress has shattered those caps this year in all but the most technical sense, voting to spend at least $23 billion more than the $580 billion limit for the fiscal year that started Oct. 1. It is the second year in a row that Congress has exceeded the limits, and like last year the White House has gone along. For all practical purposes, the caps are dead.
In shunting the caps aside, the two parties are to some extent confirming what some budget analysts contended all along: that the caps as set in 1997 were a sham from the start. Under that view, the limits were too low to be sustained and were nothing more than an effort to put off dealing with the political pain that both sides assumed would be necessary to bring the budget into balance.
"The caps set in 1997 for '99 and later years were unrealistic at the time they were set and certainly have become unrealistic since then," said James Horney, a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning research organization. "They probably became less realistic both because with surpluses it's harder for people to talk about cutting spending and because there was a bipartisan consensus this year to keep defense spending at the same level or increase it."
Indeed, the caps are the product of a time when no one expected the nation's fiscal health to improve as rapidly as it has. There is clearly a case to be made that there is more room for spending now than anyone anticipated in 1997, when no one in either party could foresee that the budget deficit would be wiped out so quickly and that Washington would be consumed by a debate over what to do with huge and growing surpluses.
"In Washington, caps have been hard to meet," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, "and while they haven't been met, to be perfectly candid, they have provided some pressure and some resistance to out-of-control spending. I think they served a positive purpose, but like any law, any budget agreement, two, three years down the road, circumstances change."
In effect, Washington has now substituted a new standard of fiscal responsibility: the looser goal of not spending surplus Social Security money. Only through budget gamesmanship can either party claim to be meeting even that new standard this year, with the Congressional Budget Office estimating that the spending bills as passed by both chambers would dip into Social Security to the tune of $17 billion.
But neither party has been willing to acknowledge the obvious and call for the caps to be increased or abolished before they expire in 2002, fearing with some reason that the other side would immediately lob charges of fiscal irresponsibility. And in hanging on to the fiction that they are living within the caps by employing all manner of legerdemain, they are arguably undermining the credibility of the entire federal budget.
"It's been death by gimmick to the budget caps," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a research group that advocates fiscal restraint. "Even those of us on the fiscal conservative side think it would be better to adjust them to more realistic levels than to have a dishonest budget."
Barring an increase in the spending limits or their repeal, the problem will only get worse. The caps for the next two years are even lower than for this year. They would fall to $575 billion next year and $569 billion the following year.
The limits apply to the one-third of the $1.8 trillion federal budget known as discretionary spending, the part that has to be appropriated annually and encompasses everything from the military to Head Start. (The rest of the budget consists of mandatory spending on longstanding commitments like Social Security plus interest payments on the debt.)
The limits were applied starting in 1990, when Congress and the Bush administration agreed on the first major effort to reduce the deficit. For most of the time since then, they functioned just as they were intended to. The question before Congress each year was not how much it should spend, but how it should divide up a defined pot of money.
Between 1991 and 1998, according to the Concord Coalition, discretionary outlays increased only about 4 percent, or $20 billion, to $555 billion.
But last year a combination of factors led the two parties break their pattern of restraint.
The deficit was erased, as long as Social Security money was included in the government's revenues, and it became clear that the budget could be balanced within a few years even without Social Security money. Both parties displayed a pent-up demand for spending, with aid to farmers, increased spending on education and a renewed commitment to Pentagon programs heading the list.
Under the law, Congress and the administration must remain within the caps or the White House must enact across-the-board cuts to bring spending back into line -- a politically unappealing step. So last year they exploited a loophole intended to deal with wars or natural disasters: they designated $20 billion in outlays as "emergency" spending that is not technically subject to the limits.
They have employed the same technique this year. Although many of the bills are likely to change as negotiations between the Republican leadership and the White House continue, the appropriations committees have almost arbitrarily placed $17.5 billion in discretionary spending -- including spare parts for the Pentagon and financing for the 2000 census -- under the emergency umbrella.
They have also used a tactic that compares spending estimates for particular programs from the Congressional Budget Office and the White House's Office of Management and Budget, and then chooses the lower of the two. Doing so has allowed Republicans to claim a "savings" of $16 billion on discretionary programs relative to the official estimates from the Congressional Budget Office.
Together the two techniques bring discretionary spending subject to the caps down from about $603 billion to about $570 billion, $10 billion below the caps.
Hardly anyone in either party defends the gimmicks. They tend instead to suggest that Washington has already succeeded in meeting the spirit of the 1997 pact if not its letter.
"You can hold them up as the ultimate tripwire, as the test of whether Congress did or did not perform," said Senator Larry E. Craig, a Republican from Idaho. "Or you can say they were made obsolete by Congress's performance and the economy's performance. The latter is a much fairer analysis."

HEADLINE: The Healer of Injured and Ailing Hospitals

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
DR. LUIS R. MARCOS loves the little ironies in life.
Like this one: For the last four years, he has overseen the city's 11 public hospitals, which treated 1.5 million patients last year. But there was a time in his medical career when he didn't even know what I.C.U. stood for. 
 He had immigrated from Spain and was working as an intern at a Long Island hospital in the late 60's. One day, he heard his name echo across the public address system.
"Dr. Marcos! I.C.U! Dr. Marcos! I.C.U!"
He pondered this and decided it was a practical joke. He smiled sheepishly and replied in his thick Seville accent: "I don't see you! I don't see you!"
"In Spain, we had no such abbreviations," he says. "Someone had to explain it to me."
He keeps another of the little ironies on a shelf by his desk. It is a diploma he received in 1972 after his psychiatric residency at Bellevue Hospital. The diploma is signed by Dr. Joseph T. English, the first president of the newly formed Health and Hospitals Corporation, the agency created to save the city's foundering public hospitals.
Yesterday, wearing his trademark wire-rimmed glasses and a bright red tie decorated with ducks, Dr. Marcos dashed across the room to get the diploma and show it to a reporter. "See what history does to you?" he said, laughing.
In the 29 years of public hospital history from Dr. English to the present, the procession of leaders through the corporation has been so swift -- 11 presidents and 3 acting presidents -- that no one has bothered to put up their pictures at the headquarters in Lower Manhattan.
Five presidents lasted just a year. One cleaned out his desk after five months and pointed out that he had been careful not to sell his house in another state when he took the job.
All of which makes Dr. Marcos's tenure -- four years, no big deal at many city agencies -- a cause for celebration in itself within the agency. As of last month, he has survived longer than any other hospitals corporation president.
For three of his four years, through a combination of aggressive layoffs, renegotiated contracts and the help of a healthy economy, the corporation has managed to run modest surpluses.
It has conducted its first consumer satisfaction survey, and it has even begun to advertise on city buses and billboards, a move Dr. Marcos said would have been viewed as "almost psychotic" only a few years ago.
"If the president had proposed that," he said, "he would have been fired, I am sure."
ALL of this good news is not to say that the agency is completely out of the woods -- it still faces an aging infrastructure, mounting numbers of uninsured patients and the advent of cost-cutting managed care for its Medicaid patients. But it has been a while since anyone has called it an "unmitigated disaster" or a "festering bureaucracy," as it once was.
In a rambling conversation yesterday that touched on everything from pipe smoking (Dr. Marcos, 56, has quit) and endurance running (on Sunday, he will compete in the New York City Marathon for the seventh time) to Francisco Franco (his older brother was jailed and then exiled for making anti-Franco speeches), Dr. Marcos recalled that he came close to turning down Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani when he asked him to take over the corporation.
Before becoming the city's Commissioner of Mental Health in 1992, he had been a senior vice president at the hospitals corporation and the head of its office of mental health and substance abuse. From his fourth-floor office, he said: "I could hear the shouting above me in the president's office on the fifth floor. So I knew."
"But there's a part of me that likes adventure," he explained, sitting in the same spacious office where all that shouting took place. "I think most immigrants are a little like that. I mean, I took a big chance when I came to America, right?"
In fact, he did. When Luis Rojas Marcos, the son of a concrete-factory owner, decided to come to New York after graduating from Seville University Medical School, he knew no one in the city, except his first wife, who immigrated with him.
His father, a Franco supporter and a conservative Roman Catholic, was angrily opposed to his son's leaving. "He couldn't understand why anyone would want to leave Spain for anything. God was there and all the answers were there."
For years, Dr. Marcos said, he believed he had decided to leave Spain solely to become a better psychiatrist. In later years, after many hours of couch time spent in psychoanalytic training, he realized he had also left because Franco's dictatorship was ripping his family -- and him -- apart.
"It was hard for me to take sides. My temperament is one of compromise. You can convince me of almost -- not everything because that's going too far. But I'm the type that if you talk to me and express your views on something, chances are I will be able to see your side."
"But," he added, "you pay a price for that sometimes. Your body cannot take it, or even your mind. I used to suffer from terrible stomach pains all the time."
While that kind of personality always put him in a difficult position back home, it has usually served him well in a tumultuous hospital system and has helped him win compromises from an often uncompromising mayor.
"There are hundreds of ways to undermine the president of this corporation," he said. "Hundreds. And there's no way of surviving this place if the people don't believe in you."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
African Is Among 4 Named Trade Group Deputy Chiefs

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization's director general, Mike Moore, named four new deputies today, including the first African to hold such a high-level post, to help him run the 134-nation trade regulatory group.
Those selected were a former trade minister of Burkina Faso, Ablasse Ouedraogo, plus Andrew L. Stoler of the United States, Paul-Henri Ravier of France and Miguel Rodriguez Mendoza of Venezuela. Mr. Stoler has been deputy chief of the United States trade mission here since 1989; Mr. Ravier is a 20-year veteran of the French trade department, and Mr. Mendoza was chief trade adviser at the Organization of American States and his country's trade minister from 1991 to 1994. 
 The announcement, expected for some time, had been delayed by the large number of candidates and by efforts to attain regional balance, with at least one representative of the least-developed countries in a leadership post. In a statement today, Mr. Moore called the decision "an extremely tough call, given all the very good people who were nominated by their governments."
The choices were complicated by Mr. Moore's unusual tenure as chief -- a split term. He is to be succeeded in three years' time by Supachai Panitchpakdi, a Thai deputy prime minister, who had to be consulted on the timing of the appointments. It was agreed that the four deputies would serve for one month after Mr. Moore's incumbency ends on Aug. 31, 2002, to permit a smooth transition.
The main difficulty Mr. Moore faced in making the choices was satisfying the trade forum's fractured constituencies, whose ability to get along has been frayed during contentious talks leading to the start on Nov. 30 of a new round of international trade negotiations in Seattle.
Resentment among developing countries has been expressed in preparatory meetings, with many delegates insisting that they have more of a say in running the trade forum. Mr. Moore, a New Zealander, has committed himself to integrating emerging economies into the workings of the organization.

HEADLINE: Investors See Room for Profit In the Demand for Education

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
When Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, met last year with Michael Milken, the "fallen junk bond king turned education entrepreneur," it was more than a case of the old school meeting the new.
"The message was, 'You guys are in trouble and we're going to eat your lunch,' " Dr. Levine said, recalling what he considered not a direct threat but a kind of predatory challenge. 
 Mr. Milken, whose Knowledge Universe companies range from preschool to corporate training, is not the only one who is hungry. Businessmen like Paul Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, and Lamar Alexander, the former presidential hopeful and former governor of Tennessee, are flocking to education, bringing with them a flood of dollars. They say they will turn the $700 billion education sector into "the next health care" -- that is, transform large portions of a fragmented, cottage industry of independent, nonprofit institutions into a consolidated, professionally managed, money-making set of businesses that include all levels of education.
While the for-profit education business has been evolving for several years, with the establishment of Christopher C. Whittle's Edison Schools and the University of Phoenix's college for working adults, the transformation is now occurring on a far larger scale. The dissatisfaction with public schools of parents of school-age children and the demands of the economy are fueling a flow of billions of dollars from corporations, pension funds and the general public into for-profit educational ventures.
For-profit companies are setting up law schools and new elementary schools, training factory-floor employees to use computers and taking over the operations of existing junior high and high schools. Their motives, the companies say, are to wring the waste from a system built largely on public largess and nonprofit benevolence, turning it into an efficiently run and profitable machine -- using investors' money instead of tax dollars.
"Changes in education are coming as surely as the Berlin Wall went down," said William F. Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts who is part of a group that has raised $150 million to invest in for-profit education and training and which hopes to raise another $100 million by early next year.
Eight years ago, when he was governor, Mr. Weld encountered stiff opposition to the concept of schools managed by for-profit companies. This month, Edison Schools Inc., the Whittle brainchild that operates 79 new and existing elementary and secondary schools in 16 states, including Massachusetts, hopes to sell $170 million in stock to the public.
"These ideas would not have flown in 1991," Mr. Weld said. "People just couldn't wrap their minds around it. Now we can't put the genie back in the bottle."
Even institutions like New York University and the College Board have formed for-profit subsidiaries to produce and market online courses and other educational services, some of which might be the source of public stock offerings.
In many ways, the race to invest in education marks the triumph of a market mentality that has consumed the nation in the late 20th century. No longer is education, where institutions of learning grew out of religion, the route to spiritual enlightenment. For many students, it is the place to start a business or accelerate their movement up the career ladder.
Wall Street's interest is the result of big societal changes in the past generation. Nearly half of all students in higher education today are over age 25, up from 28 percent in 1970. Many of those students are seeking skills to change careers. Corporations, meanwhile, no longer view training as a cost to minimize but as a competitive advantage to exploit.
As in health care, entrepreneurs assume that they will be able to solve the intractable problems that have baffled government and nonprofit institutions.
"In the business world, we've seen a movement toward the hollowing out of the corporation to cut costs," said Guilbert C. Hentschke, dean of the Rossier School of Education at the University of Southern California. "Now, in a sense, you've got that same process in schools, where districts are entering agreements for outsourcing, contracting for services and chartering new schools."
But analysts warn that as Wall Street rushes in, investors might find that the education business does not open itself to the free market as willingly as did health care, utilities or other industries that operated under longtime government regulations that limited competition.
Where for-profit enterprises have been introduced in education, there is little evidence so far that students are performing better, that high school graduates are getting better jobs or that corporations are teaching skills that benefit the individual as well as the company.
"It's difficult to impossible to determine if a for-profit school is doing a better job than a comparable public school," said Henry M. Levin, a professor of economics and education who heads the National Center for the Study of Privatization in Education at Teachers College.
So far, at least, "private schools and those public schools that are run by for-profit management typically seek students that are not costly to educate," Dr. Levin said. "That's not cheating. They are playing by the rules of the game. They want to do a good job, but they also want to make a profit. But the result is that you can't really compare them with public schools."
In that sense, if for-profit schools wish to expand they will have to take in less capable students and investors might find themselves on the same road as investors in H.M.O.'s several years ago. Those organizations were initially able to cut costs by offering services to groups of relatively healthy people -- employees of big corporations, for example. But as H.M.O.'s began supplementing their growth by recruiting less healthy individuals, costs rose, profitability sank and investors faced big losses.
Companies like Apollo Group, parent of the University of Phoenix, the country's largest private university, have been profiting from education and raising money from the public for several years. In addition, companies like DeVry Inc., ITT Educational Services, Sylvan Learning Systems and General Physics have long offered educational and training services to individuals and corporations, and venture capital investors and companies like Intel and Microsoft have been pouring money into educational start-ups.
Newer investors, however, are viewing a much broader span of learning as potential profit centers. An example is Knowledge Universe, the conglomerate assembled by Mr. Milken. Among its companies are Leapfrog Toys, a maker of reading and language products; Knowledge Learning, a day-care chain; Teacher Universe, which supports the use of technology in the classroom; MindQ Publishing, which develops multimedia learning systems; and Productivity Point International, which offers technology training for corporations.
"Ten years ago this industry did not exist," said Scott L. Soffen, a financial analyst at Legg Mason Wood Walker, an investment firm in Baltimore. The success of some of the early players -- Apollo, DeVry, the Learning Company -- was so exceptional that Wall Street was captivated, Mr. Soffen said. "Nothing attracts interest more than an industry group with momentum on Wall Street."
The opportunity to make money in education certainly looks good. The education and training industry accounts for 10 percent of the United States economy, as measured by gross domestic product, according to "The Book of Knowledge," a report issued last spring by Michael T. Moe, director of global growth research at Merrill Lynch. But education and training account for less than two-tenths of 1 percent of the value of the domestic stock market -- $16 billion out of $10 trillion, so there is plenty of room for growth and for companies to find profits in the education sector. Health care, by comparison, represents 14 percent of G.D.P. and a similar percentage of the value of the United States stock market.
There are plenty of private companies ready to soak up investors' dollars, said Michael R. Sandler, chief executive of EduVentures, an investment and consulting firm in Boston. Roughly $6 billion has been invested in private education companies by venture capital firms and other investors, he said, "an enormous amount of untapped market value."
Edison, the much-publicized effort by Mr. Whittle to build a better public school, is a long way from profitability. In the year ended June 30, the company lost $50.5 million on revenues of $132 million. Since its inception, Edison's losses total $113 million.
By taking on the elementary and secondary school market, Edison was somewhat unusual among for-profit education companies. Most efforts are focused on areas where others have already forged for-profit businesses and where it is likely to be far easier to make money -- the sale of textbooks and school supplies, for example, publication of learning materials, operation of preschools and delivery of classes and test preparation services over the Internet.
Those are the areas where the partnership including Mr. Weld hopes to succeed. The group, known as Leeds Equity Partners III, will be managed by Jeffrey T. Leeds and Robert A. Bernstein, two former investment bankers at Lazard Freres & Company who were among the early investors in Edison Schools. On the group's board of advisers are Thomas F. McLarty 3rd, the former chief of staff for President Clinton, and Lamar Alexander, the former governor of Tennessee.
"We really like the post-secondary part of the education business," Mr. Leeds said. He said he believed that schools providing professional training and certification -- in business, law, psychology, even medicine -- could be operated for-profit. If that training could take place over the Internet, serving students who cannot take time off from work or travel to a central campus, all the better, he said.
Lately, education stocks have badly trailed the market. The best investments have been in companies that offered computer-based training -- companies like CBT Group and Learning Tree International.
If primary and secondary school makes for a tough market, however, the need to constantly upgrade the skills of workers means that the most promising for-profit sectors are those where people need more education, after they have finished high school or college and entered the work force, said Dr. Levine, the president of Teachers College.
"I don't know whether these companies can do a better job of educating people," Dr. Levine said. "But they are the most aggressive and creative actors in higher education today. Some of them have shown they can make a profit. And that means that much of this industry is up for grabs."

HEADLINE: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: THE ASSEMBLY;
Republicans Maintain Their Solid Majority

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
A healthy economy and foul weather on Election Day allowed Republicans to retain their solid majority in New Jersey's 80 General Assembly races, leaders of both parties said today.
Democrats picked up three seats over all on Tuesday, including the Fourth District seat in Camden and Gloucester counties, where the incumbent Republican, Gerald Luongo, had been dogged by allegations that he was involved in a questionable land deal. In Mercer County, Democrats captured the Hamilton Township mayor's office, which had been held by a Republican for 24 years. A strong Democratic turnout also helped topple two Republicans who held Assembly seats in the 14th District. 
 But Democrats' attempts to turn gun control and health care reform into inflammatory issues did not resonate with many voters, and they failed to recapture the nine seats needed to regain the majority they lost in 1991. Republicans still ended the night with a 45-to-35 advantage in the lower house of the legislature. The split had been 48-32.
Jack Collins, speaker of the Assembly, declared those results a vote of confidence for his leadership. Pat Torpey, campaign director for Republican Assembly candidates, said the electorate also vindicated Republicans for their decision to enact only modest gun control measures and oppose a Democratic plan to mandate smart guns, weapons equipped with electronic devices that prevent them from firing for anyone other than their owners.
"The seats we lost were because of local issues," Mr. Torpey said. "No one lost their seat because of anything they did in Trenton."
Democrats said they were still pleased at their marginal gains. Joseph Doria of Bayonne, the minority leader of the Assembly, said the heavy rain and driving winds that cut power to 38,000 New Jerseyans was "incumbent weather." Indeed, incumbents from both parties ran in 78 races and won 75.
Tom Giblin, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, said New Jersey voters were generally moderate on social issues and usually voted for drastic changes only when they were incensed about economic matters like property taxes, income taxes or high auto insurance rates. In a time of prosperity, he said, it was simply too hard to mobilize the public.
"I never felt that guns would swing people," he said. "People always vote on pocketbook issues. At a time like this, it's almost like the legislature is becoming Congressionalized, where incumbents are difficult to knock out once they're established."
Many analysts say that with the balance of power between the two parties essentially unchanged, the most interesting legislative battles during the next year might be the jousting between the state's three top Republicans: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the two men who might run to succeed her, Speaker Collins and Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate president. In the days before the legislature took its summer recess in June, Mr. Collins seized the agenda by blocking the smart gun legislation Mr. DiFrancesco had supported and forced Governor Whitman to sign a bill forbidding any girl under 18 from obtaining an abortion without a parent being notified.
When the new legislative session begins in January, lawmakers are likely to consider school financing. They must also find a way to finance the state's Transportation Trust Fund, which finances road projects, and could consider raising the state's gasoline tax to do it. Because any Republican gubernatorial primary would most likely be dominated by conservative voters, the legislature could also consider bills regarding several social issues, including further restrictions on abortion and a proposal to mandate that all public school students recite a passage from the Declaration of Independence at the start of each school day.
"I think what you'll start to see is a lot of the shifting political agendas and competing ideas," said Cliff Zukin, a professor of political science at Rutgers. "At a time like this, you would expect to see Republicans pulling in different directions."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Accuses Seven Utilities Of Violating Clean-Air Law
The federal government sued seven electric companies in the Midwest and South, accusing the utilities of defying anti-pollution regulations and illegally contaminating the air breathed by millions of Americans.
The defendants are American Electric Power, Cinergy, FirstEnergy, Illinois Power, Southern Indiana Gas and Electric, Southern, Tampa Electric. The government accused them of modernizing their generating plants without modernizing their pollution controls as required by the Clean Air Act. Page A1. 

Technology Shares Propel Market
Technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq composite index to a fifth consecutive advance and its first close above the 3,000 mark, gaining 46.88 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,028.51. The other main gauges edged up, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbing 7.19 points, to 1,354.93, and the Dow Jones industrial average rising 27.22 points, to 10,609.06. C14.
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly, with the yield on the 30-year issue declining to 6.13 percent from 6.14 percent. C13.
 
Tyco to Shift Acquisition Strategy
Tyco International, whose share price has declined in recent weeks over concern about its accounting practices, said that it was likely to refrain from all-stock acquisitions that use pooling-of-interests accounting. The company also said it would buy back up to 20 million of its shares, which rose $1.50, to $41. C2.
 
CNNfn Names a New President
CNNfn, the financial news cable channel operated by the Cable News Network, named Shelby Coffey III, the former editor of The Los Angeles Times and current executive vice president of ABC News, as its new president. He replaces Lou Dobbs, who was also the on-the-air anchor of "Moneyline" and left in June. C12.
 
Mexican Stocks in a Broad Rally
Investors bought heavily into Mexican stocks, reacting to polls predicting a stable outcome in the nation's first presidential primary election and to signs that Telefonos de Mexico is becoming an important Internet competitor. The benchmark Bolsa index rose 5.73 percent to its highest level in six months. C4.
 
Fed Detects Some Slower Growth
The economy remains strong with some evidence of slower growth, the Federal Reserve said in reporting the results of its latest regional economic survey, known as the beige book. The report suggested that Fed policy makers might not be in a rush to raise interest rates when they meet on Nov. 16. C8.
 
Indonesian Agency Vows Action
The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency says it is at last prepared to start seizing the assets of politically powerful debtors who have refused to repay loans they owe to the nation's banks. And with a democratically elected government in office giving legitimacy to politically difficult changes, Eko S. Budianto, the head of the agency's asset management division, says the time is right to speed up the sale of assets the agency has accumulated over two years. C4.
 
Fund to Spur Minority Ownership
Broadcasting executives led by Mel Karmazin of CBS and Lowry Mays of Clear Channel Communications announced an investment fund with at least $175 million intended to spur ownership of TV and radio stations by women and members of minority groups. C2.
 
Four Deputies Named at W.T.O.
The World Trade Organization's director general named four new deputies to help him run the 134-nation trade regulatory group. C4.
 
Two Initial Offerings Rise Sharply
The initial public offerings of Thomson Multimedia, the French maker of RCA televisions, and Be Free, an American provider of Internet marketing services for online merchants, were strong performers. Thomson Multimedia, which began trading in Paris, rose 35 percent, to 29.02 euros, or $30.53. Thomson Multimedia's American depository receipts jumped 45 percent, to $32.75. C8.

HEADLINE: Two U.S. Drug Giants Planning to Merge in a $70 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW and LAURA M. HOLSON

 BODY:
American Home Products and Warner-Lambert said early today that they had agreed to merge in a deal that would form the world's largest drug company.
The deal, valued at about $70 billion, would combine some of the world's best-known brands, including Warner-Lambert's Listerine mouthwash and American Home's Advil painkiller, and two New Jersey-based companies situated less than 10 miles from each other.
The new company, to be named AmericanWarner, would be based in Madison, N.J., the headquarters of American Home Products, and have a market capitalization of about $140 billion. 
 The boards of each company met last night and approved the deal.
AmericanWarner would have $23.7 billion in total sales and would have an enormous presence in consumer brands and agricultural products as well as prescription drugs.
With $13.8 billion in worldwide prescription sales, AmericanWarner would be the biggest company in its industry. Its nearest competitors -- Novartis, Astra/Zeneca and Merck -- each have about $11 billion in worldwide sales in a sector so fragmented that its leaders have single-digit percentile shares of the market, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant.
After the merger, AmericanWarner would have 5.5 percent of the world prescription drug market, compared with Astra/Zeneca's 4.2 percent, I.M.S. said.
Analysts insist that AmericanWarner's size would be an advantage. The combined company's research and development expenses last year totaled $2.5 billion, compared with just $877 million at Warner-Lambert. By comparison, Merck spent $1.8 billion.
"It is unlikely that there will be any significant antitrust issues with the merger," said Viren Mehta of Mehta Partners.
"There is very little obvious overlap in the products the two companies make," Mr. Mehta added. "The only noticeable problem is the sizable gap that would exist between the world's top drug maker and its nearest competitor."
If the deal is completed, the company would be a combination of equals. Investors in both companies would trade in their stock for shares in AmericanWarner, which is to be divided evenly between American Home and Warner-Lambert. The companies would each get 10 members on AmericanWarner's 20-member board.
Last year, American Home Products announced two huge mergers -- first with the British drug maker SmithKline Beecham and later with Monsanto -- that subsequently fell apart, primarily over who would run the combined company.
Executives at American Home and Warner-Lambert have been talking about a combination for several months, said one person close to the companies.
It is believed that American Home officials had approached Warner-Lambert as early as last year, but Warner-Lambert was not eager to merge until Lodewijk J. R. de Vink, Warner-Lambert's chairman, assumed control of the company in May.
Executive egos are unlikely to derail this deal, however. The companies said that John R. Stafford, the 62-year-old chairman and chief executive of American Home Products, would become chairman of AmericanWarner, but only for 18 months. He would then be succeeded by Mr. de Vink, who is to serve as the chief executive of AmericanWarner. Mr. de Vink is 54 years old.
Mr. Stafford has strong opinions as to how the executive office should be structured. One person close to the negotiations said that Mr. Stafford had insisted that AmericanWarner have no mandatory retirement age for its chairman or chief executive, a policy that is in place now at American Home Products.
A spokesman for American Home Products declined to comment on the management structure.
Analysts said yesterday that they still expect American Home to continue its plan to sell its troubled agricultural division, allowing the newly merged company to concentrate on its core prescription drug business.
Analysts also said yesterday that they were surprised at how quickly American Home Products has moved to correct its bad fortune.
Aside from American Home's two ill-fated mergers, the company had several product calamities, including a $54 million settlement over its Norplant contraception device and a $3.75 billion payout to settle claims over the fen-phen diet pill combination.
The product disasters had caused shares of American Home Products to tumble 45 percent from its 52-week high of $70.25 on April 13 to $38.50 on Sept. 9.
Analysts said yesterday that American Home executives feared the company could become prey to hostile competitors, notably Novartis, which has a sizable agricultural and consumer division, or Glaxo Wellcome, a company analysts believe is looking for a deal.
Investors reacted giddily to the possibility of an all-American merger. Shares of American Home Products jumped 11 percent, or $5.625 yesterday, to $56. Warner-Lambert's stock also rose $5.625, to $83.8125.
Most analysts believe the merger, the discussions of which were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, was necessary. In the last few years, the pharmaceutical industry has become so competitive that companies can hardly afford to not have blockbuster drugs on pharmacy shelves or others in their production pipelines.
Though Warner-Lambert has been one of the drug industry's hottest performers -- routinely reporting quarterly earnings gains of more than 30 percent -- analysts were concerned that its pipeline lacked the depth of those of some competitors.
AmericanWarner would have a strong presence in several drug categories. Sales of Lipitor, Warner-Lambert's cholesterol reduction drug, should near $5 billion next year, according to analysts, while American Home Products' Effexor antidepressant line and Premarin hormone replacement are projected to each top $1 billion in sales in 2000.
"Certainly, we like the deal between American Home Products and Warner-Lambert," said Neil Sweig, an analyst with Ryan, Beck & Company, said before the companies announced the merger. "It's not a done deal by any means. But it has some positives. Warner-Lambert is not so dependent on Lipitor and American Home has a good drug pipeline."
Both companies have potential top selling drugs under development. American Home Products is developing two vaccines -- one for flu and one for pediatric pneumonia -- that analysts project to notch sales of more than $250 million. Warner-Lambert is developing a treatment for neuropathic pain that could sell more than $600 million. All three drugs are expected to be released within the next two years.
Aside from a bounty of new products, the merger is expected to create $1 billion in synergies, according to people close to the negotiations. One target may be the two companies' home operations, which employ some 6,700 people in New Jersey alone.
Analysts could not project how many jobs could be eliminated, although some duplication could result in virtually all of the new company's prime businesses.
Even though some analysts were cautious that the deal could still fall through, others believed it would succeed and pointed to how well the two companies' chief executives appeared to be getting along.
Mr. Stafford has a reputation for being one of the industry's most aggressive bosses, to the point of throwing the occasional elbow on the company basketball court, according to a colleague.
But Mr. de Vink, while confident, does not need to be in the limelight, analysts said, making him the perfect executive-office companion to Mr. Stafford.
"It's going to be hard for an outside company to break this deal up," Mr. Mehta said. "Few management teams fit as neatly together as this one."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Ex-Publisher Assails Paper In Los Angeles

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Otis Chandler, the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and the former chairman of Times Mirror, its parent company, last night offered a sweeping denunciation of the newspaper's current management for its "unrealistic and impossible" circulation goals, its "unbelievably stupid and unprofessional" agreement to share profits with the management of a downtown arena, and its contribution to the decline in morale among the newspaper's staff.
Mr. Chandler made the comments in a letter to the newspaper's staff. In a frank repudiation of the policies of the current publisher, Kathryn M. Downing, and Times Mirror chief executive, Mark H. Willes, Mr. Chandler, an heir of the family that founded the newspaper, wrote, "One cannot successfully run a great newspaper like The Los Angeles Times with executives in the top two positions, both of whom have no newspaper experience at any level." 
 Mr. Chandler resigned from the board of Times Mirror last year after reaching the compulsory retirement age of 70 and has remained largely silent about the company's new direction under Mr. Willes. While Mr. Chandler remains a large stockholder, he has had no day-to-day role in the company in 19 years. Thus his statement was regarded as a powerful piece of symbolism, but its likely effect was unclear.
Reached at an automobile museum he runs in Ventura County, Calif., Mr. Chandler said he would not comment on the letter until he had had a chance to speak to reporters at The Los Angeles Times. The opening sentence of the letter is addressed to "the employees of The Los Angeles Times, particularly of the editorial department because they have been so abused and misused."
The statement came as The Times newsroom was still seething about last week's revelation that the newspaper had entered into an agreement with the new Staples sports center to share the profits of a special Oct. 10 issue of the Times Sunday magazine that was devoted solely to the center.
It came from a man who spent the deacdes of the 1960's and 1970's as publisher, pushing to make The Los Angeles Times a newspaper of national and international stature. In1980, Mr. Chandler bowed out of active management.
In the early 1990's, with the slumping Southern California economy sapping the newspaper's financial vitality, Mr. Chandler -- whose more liberal politics had been an irritant to his conservative cousins -- faded into the background. His fellow heirs' desire for management change and a better financial return resulted in the hiring of Mr. Willes, a General Mills executive, in 1995.
Mr. Chandler concluded his message with a reference to the members of his family who founded and ran The Times, saying: "When I think back and realize the history of this great newspaper under the hands of General Otis, Harry Chandler and my father Norman and succeeding publishers, I realize how fragile and irreplaceable public trust of a newspaper is. The trust and faith in a newspaper by its employees, its readers and the community, is dearer to me than life itself."
Ms. Downing, in an interview conducted shortly before Mr. Chandler's letter was read to the newsroom by the city editor, Bill Boyarsky, said she had not seen a copy of it. Mr. Willes could not be reached.
After taking over as Times Mirror's chief executive, Mr. Willes undertook cutbacks and economies at The Times and the company's other newspapers that resulted in a swift rise of the company's stock price.
The Chandler family, through a series of trusts, still holds a majority of the voting shares in the company.
Mr. Chandler's statement came as it was learned that the Staples Center not only had entered an agreement with the newspaper to share the profits from the magazine but encouraged one of its suppliers to buy advertising.
It is unusual for a newspaper to enter into any financial relationship with an institution that is the subject of continuing coverage.
The role of the arena in selling the advertising has become a bone of contention inside the newspaper, even after Ms. Downing moved last week to quell a fierce protest in the newsroom over the profit-sharing arrangement, apologizing to the staff and saying it reflected her "fundamental misunderstanding" of the role of a publisher.
In an interview last week, Michael Roth, a spokesman for the Staples Center, which is home to the Lakers and Clippers basketball teams and the hockey team the Kings, denied that the center had a role in selling ads in the magazine.
At a meeting attended by 200 staff members on Thursday, Ms. Downing was asked about the ad-selling issue, raised first in an article in the Los Angeles Business Journal, and left the impression among many editors and reporters that she had denied it.
"I think the answer was pretty categorically no," John Lindsay, a managing editor in charge of the magazine. "That's my recollection." But in two letters sent by the center to a subcontractor, Anthony Crane & Equipment, Staples urged that advertising be purchased. One was signed by Tim Leiweke, president of the center.
Copies of the two letters were faxed to The New York Times by Bob Burt, the marketing director of Anthony Crane's parent company in Pittsburgh.
Asked who was soliciting the advertisements, Mr. Burt said, "it was more a joint thing, and mostly the Staples Center." The company did purchase an advertisement.
In a June 11 letter, Kevin B. Murphy, the senior vice president for development of the L.A. Arena Company, wrote, "As an important part of the Staples Center development team, we expect and would appreciate your participation in this magazine by purchase of an advertisement of appropriate size to represent you."
The letter added, "I attach an information sheet with some statistics and rates for advertisements in this issue. A representative of the L.A. Times will be contacting your firm."
A second, similar letter, dated Aug. 24, was signed by Mr. Leiweke.
Told of the Staples letter last night, Ms. Downing said she had told the staff meeting that "to the best of my knowledge, Staples didn't sell any ads." She added: "They didn't. The Los Angeles Times sales force sold the ads for this issue."
Asked how she viewed the letters from the Staples management to its subcontracter, Ms. Downing said, "They are encouraging people to participate; they're not selling people the advertising."
Told of the letters to the crane company yesterday, Mr. Roth, of the Staples Center, said, "I wasn't aware" of them.
Earlier this week, dozens of the newspaper's top journalists, including its entire Washington bureau and bureau chief, demanded that the editor, Michael Parks, assign reporters to write an extensive reconstruction of what transpired in the Staples deal. At first, Mr. Parks refused.
But yesterday, in a meeting with the projects editor Kit Rachlis and several other senior journalists, Mr. Parks said he had changed his mind, according to Mr. Rachlis.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DONNA KARAN TO TRIM WORK FORCE, CLOSE SOME STORES

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Donna Karan International will slash 8 percent of its work force, close seven outlet stores and consolidate its women's divisions in its latest reorganization. The New York-based fashion company hopes to save $6 million a year through the reorganization, which was announced late on Tuesday. It will lay off 175 people and integrate its marketing and public relations departments into a single unit. It will also close seven underperforming outlet stores. The company said it was refining the merchandise selection and store format at its outlets in an attempt to return the division to profitability. The company will consolidate its Donna Karan New York and DKNY women's businesses, and Susan Sokol, president of Donna Karan New York, will leave.

HEADLINE: Democrat Wins in a Squeaker Election for Mayor of Philadelphia

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3

 BODY:
After a harrowing election night vigil in which he finally beat back his opponent by a hairbreadth margin, John F. Street wearily faced his city early this morning and claimed the mayoral prize with a humble plea: "Give us a chance."
Mindful of the historic upset he had barely avoided, Mr. Street, the 56-year-old former president of the City Council, paid tribute to Sam Katz, the Republican challenger who almost won this overwhelmingly Democratic city. 
 "He tested our capacity, our work ethic," said the exhausted mayor-elect, who saw his sizable front-runner's lead dwindle precipitously across months of hard competition.
"We have really earned this victory," Mr. Street said, surveying the election margin of 50.2 percent for himself and 48.5 percent for Mr. Katz -- a difference of fewer than 8,000 votes in about 425,000 cast.
The outcome was not settled until 1:30 this morning when Mr. Katz, having watched Mr. Street's margin in the running tally shrink to 2 points from 15 in little more than an hour, finally ran out of mathematical hope and conceded.
The result spared the Democrats the embarrassment of seeing Mr. Katz elected the first Republican mayor since 1947 in this city that is 4-to-1 Democratic by registration. But the narrow victory was hardly perceived as a mandate for Mr. Street, an insular, old-style precinct politician who must now succeed the ebullient, successful Edward G. Rendell as mayor of the nation's fifth-largest city.
Mr. Street, the second black mayor in the city's history, seemed mindful that the tight result means he will have to work hard to show he deserves the office. Much of the campaign was about school and safety problems that, despite impressive downtown renewal, have seen 150,000 middle- and working-class residents leave the city in the last decade. Beyond that, municipal unions that suffered with the city through fiscally thin years are preparing to bargain hard with the new mayor for larger benefits now that this city of 1.4 million is considered on the rebound.
"I have been in this business a long time," Mr. Street told supporters. "I have not been perfect. I'm just going to ask you to give us a chance."
Mr. Katz, a 49-year-old consultant on the public-private financing of sports stadiums, said, "My opponent learned a lot about himself and this city."
A former Democrat with political ties to the black community, Mr. Katz rarely mentioned he was a Republican. He ran as a supporter of coalition government, private school vouchers and deeper cuts in the city's wage tax.
Mr. Street ran on his record as the ally of Mayor Rendell in bringing the city back from bankruptcy, and as a veteran of 19 years on the City Council and a proven master of the city's Democratic machine.
Vote analyses showed a solid turnout by blacks, who voted better than 90 percent for Mr. Street. Mr. Katz drew strong crossover support from liberal Democrats in the Chestnut Hill and Center City areas while barely failing to get a large enough turnout in Northeast and South Philadelphia to turn the tide.
In this city of 40 percent black residency, race was a dynamic but not an issue in the struggle between Mr. Street and Mr. Katz, who is white. Both men were widely congratulated for avoiding a return to the polarizing politics of a generation ago in the era of Mayor Frank Rizzo. Both candidates, in fact, promised a joint appearance for civic unity eventually regardless of the election result.
Mr. Street, who first came to attention a generation ago as a young firebrand agitator for neighborhood improvement, attributed his victory to a combination of efforts, from union support to clergy's blessings, from ward captains who got out the party vote to President Clinton's personal endorsement at a rally here last Friday. He made open appeals to party loyalty in falling short of the broad-based support enjoyed by the city's first black mayor, W. Wilson Goode, in 1983.
As the Democrats celebrated their narrow escape, Mayor Rendell, not one to be upstaged in any crowd, let it be known in interviews on local television that "there's a decent likelihood" he will be running in the next race for governor of Pennsylvania, after he serves next year as the Democratic national chairman.
"John is going to have to rebuild some coalitions," said Mr. Rendell, who defended the mayor-elect as a gifted though "shy" politician.
The city's two major newspapers had shocked the Street camp by endorsing Mr. Katz, an affable campaigner who basically ran as a businessman with a less plodding vision of the city than Mr. Street.
"It's about experience," Mr. Street doggedly insisted in reaching for the Rendell mantle as he won the Democratic primary and, in the early morning, City Hall itself. "I've made a difference in this city."

HEADLINE: A Liberal Democrat Wins in Salt Lake City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Within the vast bastion of Republican conservatism around Utah, Ross Anderson struck a blow on Tuesday for liberal Democrats, winning election easily to become the next mayor of Salt Lake City.
A former lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union who had never held public office, Mr. Anderson, 48, won the nonpartisan campaign with 60 percent of the vote, defeating Stuart Reid, a moderate Democrat serving as director of the city's economic development agency under Mayor Deedee Corradini. 
 Mr. Anderson and Mr. Reid were the top finishers among 12 candidates in a primary last month.
"This will do so much to change people's mind-sets about so-called liberalism when people throughout the state see that I'm a competent administrator who can bring people together and solve the serious challenges that face us," Mr. Anderson said yesterday in an interview at his home. "Somehow, they think we're all out there just demonstrating, walking women to abortion clinics and performing same-sex marriages."
For nearly 30 years, Salt Lake City has remained an anomaly in Utah politics, a place where most of the state's Democrats and members of non-Mormon churches reside. They have steadily elected Democrats as mayor since E. J. Garn in 1971. Beyond city limits, virtually all meaningful elected posts are traditionally held by Republicans, a list that currently includes Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, most state legislators and all five members of the state's Congressional delegation.
But Mr. Anderson, who is known as Rocky, is even a slice apart from many other Salt Lake Democrats, an unabashed liberal and political outsider who considers his civil libertarian roots a badge of honor.
Political analysts here said his victory was achieved, in part, through voter discomfort with Mr. Reid as a protege of Ms. Corradini, whose second four-year term has been tainted by her involvement in the Olympic bribery scandal and other personal financial matters. They also said Mr. Anderson benefited from attacks late in the campaign that accused him of having four former wives -- he has two -- and owning two gay nightclubs, which he said he did not. The Reid campaign denied any role in the accusations.
Campaigning for mayor, Mr. Anderson promised to tackle several high-profile issues, not least making sure the city does not get stuck with a bill for the 2002 Winter Olympics. Mr. Reid said he believed the city was adequately protected.
Mr. Anderson also promised to dismiss the police chief, Reuben Ortega, restore morale in the police department and put into effect after-school and job-training programs for young people. Mr. Reid said he would retain Chief Ortega.
As for his nickname, Mr. Anderson said it had no romantic base or political symbolism as a fighter.
"My mother used to tease me about it," he said. "As a kid, I liked to be rocked." MICHAEL JANOFSKY

HEADLINE: President's Visit to Hartford Will Focus on Redevelopment

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton is expected to announce nearly $200 million in private investments in this slowly rebounding city on Thursday during a tour of inner city areas that have not felt the full effects of the current economic boom. He will also visit Newark on Thursday and Chicago and Hermitage, Ark., on Friday as part of his "new markets" tour.
The private financing for urban projects in Hartford will include $15.3 million from Citigroup and other partners, $15 million from Aetna and $5 million from Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company, an administration official said. Citigroup's commitment includes $7.4 million for a 70-unit housing project in the city's Frog Hollow area. That project takes advantage of a tax credit offered to businesses to encourage urban redevelopment, a company spokesman said. 
 Urban redevelopment has long been in the works here, and some of the projects that will receive the new commitments have been on the drawing board for years.
"I think the occasion for the President's visit is crystallizing the commitment and willingness of local companies," said Robert W. Fiondella, chairman and chief executive of Phoenix Home Life, which is based in Hartford.
In Hartford, the President will visit El Mercado, an indoor marketplace in the city's Latino business corridor. He will later be joined by Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, as well as local business and educational leaders. They will speak at the Artist's Collective, an arts education center.
Richard L. Huber, chairman and chief executive of Aetna, said he had been promoting Hartford as a site for the President's visit. "All these older cities have some fairly serious problems," he said. "I'm glad he's coming to highlight that, and see some of the things we in the business community have done to help break this vicious circle."
In connection with the President's visit, a Housing and Urban Development report will be released describing the disparity between the booming national economy and poorer cities. The report focuses on older, medium size cities in the northeast that lost manufacturing jobs in the 1980's and have not yet recovered.
The President is expected to announce three initiatives by the Housing agency: a $6.2 million loan to support the Cityscape/Learning Corridor project, including several schools and a Boys and Girls Club; a $497,505 grant to the Hartford Housing Authority to fight drugs, and $1.5 million in work-readiness programs, to be shared with four other cities.
