HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Air Rudy

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
No sooner had the polling booth curtains stopped twitching in New York this week than Rudolph Giuliani took to the air upstate, with the first commercial of the 2000 U.S. Senate campaign. (The race still has no official entrants. But Mr. Giuliani has bought TV time and Hillary Clinton has bought a $1.7 million house, either of which is as good as an announcement as far as I'm concerned.)
The ad is a basic 30-second rundown of the mayor's achievements as mayor -- fought crime, increased jobs, etc. -- with shots of Mr. Giuliani and lots of happy New Yorkers. It's notable for only one thing. His euphoric constituents -- smiling, waving, walking their babies across the extremely safe streets -- all appear to be white. Closer inspection reveals a man who is possibly African-American working on the roof of a building far up in the air. 
 Mr. Giuliani says there's one shot of the Puerto Rican Day parade. He and his aides were busy all day yesterday pointing out possible minority New Yorker sightings in the footage. "In the shot of the Staten Island ferry, if you look to my left there's a woman who appears to be Hispanic," the mayor said. It was sort of a political version of "Where's Waldo?"
Nevertheless, to the casual observer the ad really does look as if the mayor of the nation's most wildly heterogeneous city was taking a bow for making things safe in Des Moines. It's not the most critical lapse in the history of modern politics, but it is peculiar. Mr. Giuliani's biggest problem as a mayor has been deflecting charges of racial insensitivity. One of his biggest challenges as a Senate candidate is to mollify black voters, at least to the point that they don't turn out in record numbers to vote against him. Why, then, would he introduce himself as a Senate candidate in a commercial that seems to have turned New York monochromatic?
There are several possible explanations:
* Thanks to the mayor's efforts stimulating the economy, black New Yorkers were too busy working at construction jobs to come down to the ground and pose for the camera.
* The Giuliani camp thinks this is what upstate voters would like to think New York City looks like.
* Whoever made the piece was just sloppy.
* The ad is a perfectly fine portrait of New York in all its glorious diversity, and anybody who thinks otherwise is a dreadful person.
Guess which answer the mayor likes.
"That's got to be your problem," he said, to a suggestion that there seemed to be something missing in the ad. Alerted by my question to an aide, Mr. Giuliani had called to discuss the errors in my thought process and point out the Latino woman on the ferry. It was a brief conversation, although Mr. Giuliani managed to squeeze in the terms "truly absurd," "a reach" and "kind of sick."
Did I mention that the other common criticism of this mayor involves a problem with accepting criticism?
"It's really sad that people look at the world this way," he continued, declining to be distracted from his theme of racial hypersensitivity. Bringing up the whole issue, he added, is an example of "a tired old stereotypical attack on Republicans."
That was a low blow. We're immersed in a presidential campaign that documents every single interaction between George W. Bush and minority voters in breathless detail. (Look, everybody! He's going to another black church!) The media are so excited about this Republican inclusionism that we fall into a swoon every time Mr. Bush says "Hola!"
But Rudy Giuliani isn't Mr. Bush. He's also probably not a political figure who needs any introduction to the voters upstate. The ad actually seems like a waste of money, since you can walk into a cornfield in Iowa and get somebody to tell you that New York City is a much better place these days, and identify who's responsible.
According to a recent New York Times poll, practically all the state's voters not only feel they know Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Giuliani, they've already made up their minds whom they're going to vote for. The election's still a year away, and the undecided-voter pool is vanishing. The way we're going now, the entire election will hinge on a retired appliance repairman in Cooperstown who thinks Jimmy Carter is still President and a couple of unemployed survivalists living near the Canadian border.
If they watch television, there's already an ad coming their way.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Drug Giants' Merger Deal Prompts Offer From Pfizer
Hours after executives of American Home Products and Warner-Lambert announced a $70 billion merger agreement, Pfizer attempted to break the deal up with a $82.4 billion hostile bid for Warner-Lambert. 
 Analysts who follow the pharmaceutical industry cautioned that a higher offer could yet emerge for Warner-Lambert, either from American Home or Pfizer or another drug company. Page A1.
 
Congress Approves Financial Bill
Congress approved legislation that opens the door for a new era on Wall Street in which commercial banks, securities houses and insurers will find it easier and cheaper to enter one another's businesses. The wide-ranging measure now goes to President Clinton, who is expected to sign it. A1.
 
Disney Posts Decline in Earnings
Walt Disney said that profits for its fourth quarter and full year fell sharply, hurt by slumping sales of home videos and Disney merchandise, and that its profit for the next year would be flat. Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman, said that he was shifting the company's emphasis away from adding new businesses and properties. Disney stock is down about a third from its 1998 high. C7.
 
Nasdaq Leads Main Gauges Higher
The Nasdaq composite index pushed further into record territory, but stocks generally pulled back from early-session gains. The Nasdaq gained 27.44 points, to 3,055.95. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.51 points, to 10,639.57. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 7.71 points, to 1,362.64. C7.
 
Treasury prices gained for the third consecutive day as the yield on the 30-year issue fell to 6.10 percent from 6.13 percent. C7.
 
Web Registration Rules Approved
The Internet's governing board approved terms for opening the network's address-registration businesses to full-scale competition, ending the six-year monopoly that had enriched Network Solutions. C2.
 
Bell Atlantic and GTE Name Team
Bell Atlantic and GTE, which are merging, announced a tentative senior executive team that, at least numerically, is drawn equally from Bell Atlantic and GTE. Executives from Bell Atlantic appeared to win the top operational and financial jobs while senior GTE executives will largely control staff functions that have less effect on the combined company's quarter-to-quarter financial results. Last year, the companies announced that Charles R. Lee, GTE's chairman, and Ivan G. Seidenberg, above, Bell Atlantic's chairman, would split the job of chief executive. Mr. Seidenberg is set to become the sole chief executive in 2002. C5.
 
Big Investment Seen for Teligent
A group including Microsoft and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst is close to a deal to invest $500 million in Teligent, which uses wireless technology to provide business customers with communications services. C7.
 
Interest Rates Raised in Europe
The European Central Bank raised interest rates for the first time in its short history, to 3 percent from 2.5 percent. C4.
 
Organization for Blind Sues AOL
Arguing that online spaces must be as accessible as physical ones are to people with disabilities, a group representing the blind sued America Online, saying the online service is almost impossible for blind people to use. A25.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS PASSES WIDE-RANGING BILL EASING BANK LAWS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Congress approved landmark legislation today that opens the door for a new era on Wall Street in which commercial banks, securities houses and insurers will find it easier and cheaper to enter one another's businesses.
The measure, considered by many the most important banking legislation in 66 years, was approved in the Senate by a vote of 90 to 8 and in the House tonight by 362 to 57. The bill will now be sent to the president, who is expected to sign it, aides said. It would become one of the most significant achievements this year by the White House and the Republicans leading the 106th Congress. 
 "Today Congress voted to update the rules that have governed financial services since the Great Depression and replace them with a system for the 21st century," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said. "This historic legislation will better enable American companies to compete in the new economy."
The decision to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 provoked dire warnings from a handful of dissenters that the deregulation of Wall Street would someday wreak havoc on the nation's financial system. The original idea behind Glass-Steagall was that separation between bankers and brokers would reduce the potential conflicts of interest that were thought to have contributed to the speculative stock frenzy before the Depression.
Today's action followed a rich Congressional debate about the history of finance in America in this century, the causes of the banking crisis of the 1930's, the globalization of banking and the future of the nation's economy.
Administration officials and many Republicans and Democrats said the measure would save consumers billions of dollars and was necessary to keep up with trends in both domestic and international banking. Some institutions, like Citigroup, already have banking, insurance and securities arms but could have been forced to divest their insurance underwriting under existing law. Many foreign banks already enjoy the ability to enter the securities and insurance industries.
"The world changes, and we have to change with it," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who wrote the law that will bear his name along with the two other main Republican sponsors, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa and Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia. "We have a new century coming, and we have an opportunity to dominate that century the same way we dominated this century. Glass-Steagall, in the midst of the Great Depression, came at a time when the thinking was that the government was the answer. In this era of economic prosperity, we have decided that freedom is the answer."
In the House debate, Mr. Leach said, "This is a historic day. The landscape for delivery of financial services will now surely shift."
But consumer groups and civil rights advocates criticized the legislation for being a sop to the nation's biggest financial institutions. They say that it fails to protect the privacy interests of consumers and community lending standards for the disadvantaged and that it will create more problems than it solves.
The opponents of the measure gloomily predicted that by unshackling banks and enabling them to move more freely into new kinds of financial activities, the new law could lead to an economic crisis down the road when the marketplace is no longer growing briskly.
"I think we will look back in 10 years' time and say we should not have done this but we did because we forgot the lessons of the past, and that that which is true in the 1930's is true in 2010," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota. "I wasn't around during the 1930's or the debate over Glass-Steagall. But I was here in the early 1980's when it was decided to allow the expansion of savings and loans. We have now decided in the name of modernization to forget the lessons of the past, of safety and of soundness."
Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, said that Congress had "seemed determined to unlearn the lessons from our past mistakes."
"Scores of banks failed in the Great Depression as a result of unsound banking practices, and their failure only deepened the crisis," Mr. Wellstone said. "Glass-Steagall was intended to protect our financial system by insulating commercial banking from other forms of risk. It was one of several stabilizers designed to keep a similar tragedy from recurring. Now Congress is about to repeal that economic stabilizer without putting any comparable safeguard in its place."
Supporters of the legislation rejected those arguments. They responded that historians and economists have concluded that the Glass-Steagall Act was not the correct response to the banking crisis because it was the failure of the Federal Reserve in carrying out monetary policy, not speculation in the stock market, that caused the collapse of 11,000 banks. If anything, the supporters said, the new law will give financial companies the ability to diversify and therefore reduce their risks. The new law, they said, will also give regulators new tools to supervise shaky institutions.
"The concerns that we will have a meltdown like 1929 are dramatically overblown," said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska.
Others said the legislation was essential for the future leadership of the American banking system.
"If we don't pass this bill, we could find London or Frankfurt or years down the road Shanghai becoming the financial capital of the world," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. "There are many reasons for this bill, but first and foremost is to ensure that U.S. financial firms remain competitive."
But other lawmakers criticized the provisions of the legislation aimed at discouraging community groups from pressing banks to make more loans to the disadvantaged. Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, said during the House debate that the legislation was "mean-spirited in the way it had tried to undermine the Community Reinvestment Act." And Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said it was ironic that while the legislation was deregulating financial services, it had begun a new system of onerous regulation on community advocates.
Many experts predict that, even though the legislation has been trailing market trends that have begun to see the cross-ownership of banks, securities firms and insurers, the new law is certain to lead to a wave of large financial mergers.
The White House has estimated the legislation could save consumers as much as $18 billion a year as new financial conglomerates gain economies of scale and cut costs.
Other experts have disputed those estimates as overly optimistic, and said that the bulk of any profits seen from the deregulation of financial services would be returned not to customers but to shareholders.
These are some of the key provisions of the legislation:
*Banks will be able to affiliate with insurance companies and securities concerns with far fewer restrictions than in the past.
*The legislation preserves the regulatory structure in Washington and gives the Federal Reserve and the Office of Comptroller of the Currency roles in regulating new financial conglomerates. The Securities and Exchange Commission will oversee securities operations at any bank, and the states will continue to regulate insurance.
*It will be more difficult for industrial companies to control a bank. The measure closes a loophole that had permitted a number of commercial enterprises to open savings associations known as unitary thrifts.
One Republican Senator, Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, voted against the legislation. He was joined by seven Democrats: Barbara Boxer of California, Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, Mr. Dorgan and Mr. Wellstone.
In the House, 155 Democrats and 207 Republicans voted for the measure, while 51 Democrats, 5 Republicans and 1 independent opposed it. Fifteen members did not vote.
Tucked away in the legislation is a provision that some experts today warned could cost insurance policyholders as much as $50 billion. The provision would allow mutual insurance companies to move to other states to avoid payments they would otherwise owe policyholders as they reorganize their corporate structure. Many states, including New York and New Jersey, do not allow such relocations without the consent of the insurer's domicile state. But the legislation before Congress would pre-empt the states.
Both the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Prudential Life Insurance Company are in the midst of reorganizing into stock-based corporations that are requiring them to pay billions of dollars to policyholders from years of accumulated surplus. In exchange, the policyholders give up their ownership in the mutual insurance company.
The legislation would permit any mutual insurance company to avoid making surplus payments to policyholders by simply moving to states with more permissive laws and setting up a hybrid corporate structure known as a mutual holding company.
The provision was inserted by Representative Bliley at the urging of a trade association. It attracted little opposition because it was attached to a provision that forbids insurers from discriminating against domestic-violence victims.
In a letter sent to Congress this week, Mr. Summers said that the provision "could allow insurance companies to avoid state law protecting policyholders, enriching insiders at the expense of consumers."

HEADLINE: In Newark and Hartford, Clinton Says Cities Are Untapped Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 4

 BODY:
As President Clinton toured a struggling Newark high school and a slowly recovering Hartford neighborhood to announce a series of corporate investments in impoverished cities, the White House and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, reached a bipartisan agreement to merge their anti-poverty programs.
The agreement, described by Mr. Hastert in an interview and by Mr. Clinton's aides as he traveled the Northeast with executives, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and basketball stars, is expected to be announced by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert on Friday in a low-income Chicago neighborhood. But it is likely to yield little fruit until Mr. Clinton is out of office -- the two men agreed on a set of principles and left the specifics and the financing to next year's budget debates. 
 Nonetheless, in the bitter atmosphere prevailing in Washington, the pact may be remarkable simply for the fact that the two agreed on anything. Mr. Clinton's aides said they had little chance of getting corporate America to sign on to any program that did not have bipartisan support, and Mr. Hastert appeared to be trying to inoculate the Republicans against renewed charges by House Democrats who say the Congressional leaders are as extreme as the former speaker, Newt Gingrich, when he first led the Republican revolution in the House.
The agreement would essentially merge relatively small-scale proposals that differ in specifics but share the goal of spreading a remarkable era of prosperity more evenly. It is a delicate political problem: Both in Newark and Harford today, Mr. Clinton tried to walk the line between acknowledging that many Americans have been left out of the boom while promoting "New Markets" in some of the country's oldest cities. It proved a hard sell.
Mr. Clinton's audience of students this morning at Malcolm X Shabbazz High School in Newark gave the president a rousing cheer -- "No one comes here," one student said from the bleachers -- but they quickly appeared restless and more than a bit bored by the stream of announcements of investment projects and tax incentives for small businesses and entrepreneurs.
The students immediately perked up at the appearance of Jayson Williams and other stars of the New Jersey Nets, as Mr. Clinton hailed the team's decision to put 35 percent of its profits into scholarships, basketball leagues and programs to clean up parks.
Mr. Williams told the audience that the students who performed the most hours of community service could "come to my house and party hard," an incentive that drew far more rousing cheers than Mr. Clinton's efforts to urge Congress to pass a new tax credit.
The credit is one of a cocktail of modest government programs -- most of which are still tied up in Congressional budget battles -- that Mr. Clinton has argued are needed to bring down urban unemployment.
Several of Mr. Clinton's programs are based on modestly successful administration efforts to encourage American investment abroad, chiefly to open new export markets. Much as he did in July in visits to Indian reservations, the Mississippi Delta and Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton made the case that the last untapped markets are in poor urban areas.
"What I want to do in passing this program," Mr. Clinton said in Newark, "is nothing more or less than to give American business people and other investors the same incentives to invest in the poorer communities of American that we give them today to invest in the poorer communities of South America or Africa or Asia."
Later in the day in Hartford, he used the backdrop of a new arts education center to make the case that he is devoting the last year of his presidency to "keeping this magic economic moment going."
But so far the programs he has described are tiny by most economic measures. All the big numbers thrown around today have more to do with boardroom decisions than White House decisions. "That does not mean that government programs are useless," Mr. Clinton's chief economic adviser, Gene Sperling, said earlier this week. "Sometimes you need to give things a shove. The leverage comes from the kind of incentives we are creating here."
In Hartford, President Clinton toured El Mercado, an indoor Hispanic marketplace where he had campaigned in 1992, and then joined insurance executives and Connecticut's Republican governor, John G. Rowland, at the Artists Collective, the new arts center. There he announced that local corporations were spending nearly $200 million to redevelop the city. He called it "one of the most impressive commitments" to new markets in any city.
He singled out Citigroup for its $7.4 million commitment of equity and debt capital to build 70 homes in the Frog Hollow neighborhood (though he pronounced it "holler"). And he thanked Richard L. Huber, chairman and chief executive of Aetna, for joining him on both his July and November "new markets" tours of disadvantaged communities.
"It is the morally responsible thing to do for the business leaders of this community and this state and this nation to invest in these places," Mr. Clinton told a crowd of about 150 people. "It's also the economically smart thing to do. It is a magic moment, and we dare not let it pass us by."
Hartford is a classic example of a city that has seen prosperity pass it by: While Boston and New York have boomed, thousands of insurance and aerospace jobs have been wiped out here, and there has been relatively little new industry to replace it.
A portion of the new $200 million in private investments Mr. Clinton announced here today will go toward redeveloping the downtown, particularly through the $1.3 billion Adriaen's Landing project, which would include a domed stadium, a convention center and new retail stores adjacent to the newly refurbished banks of the Connecticut River. The state has pledged $455 million to the project, provided the project can attract $210 million in private investment.
Larry Charles Sr., executive director of One/Chance, a neighborhood economic development group, said he hoped that permanent jobs from the new initiatives would reach residents of struggling neighborhoods.
"I have some concerns about how the table is set in this process," he said. "I am concerned about the extent to which neighborhood voices are part of the overall planning process."
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, was working to make sure this initiative did not suffer the fate of many others he has proposed: becoming grist for partisan warfare. In July, he first broached Mr. Hastert with a proposal to merge Democratic and Republican initiatives for cities.
In an interview on Capitol Hill today, Mr. Hastert said that he and President Clinton had agreed to work together to try to come up with a bipartisan strategy to bring new markets and new capital to the impoverished parts of the nation. And if the Congressional schedule allowed, Mr. Hastert said, he would fly to Chicago on Friday to join the president in the tour.
"It's something that I know needs to be worked on," Mr. Hastert said. "The president has an initiative fairly close to ours, so we made a commitment to work together." He said the two wanted to address environmental cleanup and "try to get people working together so that people can have some individual enterprise in these communities and try to build those communities back."
Mr. Hastert said the two men had not agreed to any legislation, only on goals. His aides said the White House and speaker's staff had worked out a five-point joint statement of "shared commitment to empower America's impoverished communities." In it the administration and Congress pledge to "work in a spirit of good faith to develop a bipartisan effort" to bring capital to impoverished areas of the country.
The draft says that since solutions need to come from within the communities "both political parties need to put aside politics and ideological constraints and participate in a process that focuses on solutions that can work in those communities without being subject to waste or abuse."
The Republican plan was first sponsored by Representative J. C. Watts, an Oklahoma Republican, and James M. Talent, a Missouri Republican, for up to 100 "renewal communities."
It is essentially a tax reduction plan under which there is zero capital gains tax for the sale of any business or partnership inside a renewal community -- a portion of the program White House officials still oppose -- and a wage credit for companies hiring workers from the community and a commercial revitalization credit for those who renovate nonresidential buildings in such communities.

HEADLINE: Giving In on Foreign Aid Bill, G.O.P. Finds an Election Issue

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The White House and Congress agreed tonight to cut a deal on a foreign aid bill, adding $799 million more than Republicans wanted to spend, Congressional aides said.
But in the battle, Republican leaders see a golden opportunity to paint Democrats as more concerned about helping foreigners than protecting Social Security. 
 For two days, the Republicans held up the foreign aid bill -- and with it, the battle over the budget, in which 5 of the year's 13 spending bills remain unsigned -- arguing over the desire of the White House to spend $370 million to ease the debts of 41 impoverished nations, mostly in Africa.
Mr. Clinton has said the aid will "enable the world's poorest and most heavily indebted countries to finance health, education and opportunity programs."
The House majority whip, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, calls it an effort to "rob the Social Security surplus to underwrite the national debt of Nepal."
And aides to Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Mr. DeLay say Democrats want to spend money on foreign aid that would come from the Social Security surplus, which both parties have sworn to protect. The aides said the Republican leaders thought that argument could be instrumental in helping Republicans keep control of Congress in the 2000 elections.
One aide said it boiled down to this: "Ghana versus Grandma."
The aides said the Republicans would paint the Democrats as willing to put foreign potentates before aging Americans. "All they want," Representative Harold Rogers, Republican of Kentucky, said on the House floor today, "is to give the taxpayers' money away to foreign countries and be damned what happens at home."
The Republicans' tactics became clear during tense talks between Congress and the White House.
The bill passed by the Republican Congress contained $12.7 billion, 14 percent less than Mr. Clinton's request. On Oct. 18, he vetoed it, calling it "another sign of the new isolationism that would have America bury its head in the sand at the height of our power and prosperity."
The negotiators went into closed-door conference in Mr. Hastert's office on Wednesday night thinking they might make a deal. They did not. A serious sticking point developed: debt relief for foreign nations.
The President wanted $370 million, about $1.20 per American, to help the 41 nations identified by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as "heavily indebted" lighten the burden of their poverty. Thirty-three of those nations, including Ghana, are in Africa.
But the Republicans held the line on debt relief at $123 million. This quarter-billion dollar difference was the biggest barrier to completing the bill. Tonight, a senior Republican aide said they had won that argument.
In the end, the Republicans agreed to a White House proposal to add $799 million to their $12.7 billion bill. The major increases were $170 million in economic support funds, $150 million for international development assistance, $104 million for nuclear-security programs in the former Soviet Union, and $75 million for peacekeeping operations in Kosovo. They earlier agreed to spend $1.8 billion over three years to underwrite Israeli-Palestinian peace accords.
Now the White House and Congress will move on to negotiations over four more bills, financing the Departments of Commerce, Justice, State, Interior, and Housing and Urban Development and federal money for the District of Columbia. They set a new deadline tonight: Wednesday.
The Republican leaders, including Mr. Hastert, voiced unhappiness at having had to add nearly $2.6 billion to the foreign aid bill, which will now have to pass the House and Senate. And Republicans said the argument over foreign aid versus Social Security would be a main campaign theme in 2000.
There will be rebuttals. For example, it could be said that the Republican-written spending bills dip by more than $17 million into Social Security. Since money comes from the same pot, any program can be identified as the one that used Social Security money. Opponents of more military spending, for example, point out that Congress increased Pentagon spending by $17 billion.
Mr. DeLay's view of debt relief -- he calls it "American taxpayer dollars sent overseas to subsidize the corruption and mismanagement of foreign countries" -- resonates with many Republicans.
But not all. Pat Robertson, the founder of the Christian Coalition and a former Republican presidential candidate, supports debt relief. So do Pope John Paul II, the World Bank and most of the world's aid agencies.
"The debt-relief initiative sends our tax dollars to make sure children are educated and vaccinated, and there are roads to get farmers' goods to markets," said Seth Amgott, spokesman for Oxfam, a worldwide antipoverty agency. "An American contribution to that effort is entirely worthy and eminently affordable."

HEADLINE: Freight Strike a Test of Hoffa's Mettle

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: MOONACHIE, N.J., Nov. 4

 BODY:
At daybreak today, Ernie Soehl, a gruff-voiced fireplug of a man, was already yelling orders to the picket line of teamsters just north of Giants Stadium.
Wearing black nylon teamster jackets that glowed in the passing headlights, the pickets had massed, placards in hand, outside the Overnite Transportation Company's truck terminal, to further James P. Hoffa's crusade to stop the decline in the teamsters' freight division, which his father once built into a swaggering symbol of union might. 
 Mr. Soehl, vice president of a New Jersey local, told the assembled protesters to fan out in twos and threes, follow Overnite trucks throughout North Jersey and set up picket lines wherever they made deliveries, to pressure Overnite's customers to turn to other trucking companies.
For 12 days now, since the International Brotherhood of Teamsters began a nationwide strike against Overnite, the union and the company, one of the nation's largest nonunion shipping concerns, have played cat and mouse.
The confrontation is far more than a game. It is an effort by Mr. Hoffa, who assumed the union's presidency last spring, to step out of his father's shadow and prove his mettle as a union leader. In addition, the walkout, supported by unions across the nation, has become a high-stakes effort to show that it is possible to win union recognition and a contract from one of the country's most vehemently antiunion companies.
"Hoffa has staked his future on winning this fight," said John Schulz, associate editor of Trucking World, a trade magazine. "The teamsters have not organized a freight company of any magnitude since 1980. This would be a crown jewel. This one dwarfs them all."
Mr. Hoffa says he is standing up to the nation's worst labor-law violator, a company against which the teamsters have filed more than 1,000 charges with the National Labor Relations Board, accusing Overnite of illegally firing and retaliating against scores of union supporters. One of the strike's chief goals, Mr. Hoffa said, is to force Overnite, with 8,200 drivers and loading-dock workers, to stop such unfair labor practices. The company denies engaging in any illegal practices.
So far, in what looks as if it could become a war of attrition, both sides are claiming the upper hand. The union insists that Overnite will surrender, saying the strike has cut its business by 30 percent at a time the industry is booming. Overnite officials say the company is making deliveries on schedule and that business is down just 3 percent.
Teamster officials say they have pickets at 140 of Overnite's 166 terminals; many of the pickets are teamsters who do not work for Overnite. The company says there are pickets at just 30 terminals.
Ira Rosenfeld, an Overnite spokesman, said, "As far as we're concerned it's a normal situation."
Mr. Soehl called the company's assertions poppycock, saying workers in Overnight's Moonachie terminal had told them shipments were down by at least one-third.
"We're going to keep up this fight until it's done, whether it lasts a week or a year," Mr. Soehl said.
Teamster officials acknowledge that the stakes are high. It is the union's biggest showdown since the 1997 United Parcel Service strike, and it is an effort by Mr. Hoffa to succeed in a fight in which the predecessor he detested, Ron Carey, failed.
After five years of trying, the union says it represents 3,600 workers at 37 of Overnite's terminals, although the company argues that because of legal challenges, the union represents only 1,800 at 22 places. The union says it has made so little headway because of intimidation, while Overnite executives offer another reason: most workers do not want a union. Overnite will soon pay its drivers $17.75 an hour, up from $17. Unionized drivers earn $19 an hour, and their fringe benefits are considerably better than Overnite's.
Mr. Hoffa's father, James R. Hoffa, the teamsters' president from 1957 to 1971, built the union's freight division to more than 400,000 workers, representing more than 60 percent of the nation's truck drivers. But after deregulation sent many unionized companies into bankruptcy, only 20 percent of the nation's truck drivers are now unionized.
With this strike, the younger Hoffa is trying to turn that around.
"If teamster market share in trucking continues to fall, we lose power, the bargaining power to win the contracts our members deserve and expect," Mr. Hoffa said in a recent speech to Overnite workers.
Mr. Hoffa's hard-line stance has surprised many labor experts.
"The Hoffa administration has been rather militant when a lot of people expected it to roll over and play dead or roll over and make deals with the bosses," said Michael Belzer, a trucking industry expert at the University of Michigan.
Some industry experts predict that Overnite will win because a company information campaign has turned many workers against the union and because so few of Overnite's workers are on strike. The union says nearly one-fourth are on strike, while the company says just one-tenth.
But other experts predict that the union can outlast the company because the strike will cut into Overnite's important Christmas business and because a low unemployment rate will make it easy for strikers to find jobs during the walkout.
Shortly after 7 a.m. today, Pete Brown, the president of Teamsters Local 560, was following Mr. Soehl's instructions and driving along North Jersey roads, tailing an Overnite truck that eventually stopped at a Samsung warehouse in Secaucus. Mr. Brown stood outside, holding a picket sign..
The driver whom Mr. Brown followed, Robert Link, was pro-union.
"Overnite is a romper room with favoritism galore," Mr. Link said, adding that union supporters often faced retaliation. "The question is, why don't they want to sit down and sign a contract instead of spending millions on overpriced lawyers to fight the union?"
Mr. Rosenfeld, the Overnite spokesman, later responded: "We have been bargaining in good faith. We've told the union all along we can not sign a contract that makes us noncompetitive."

HEADLINE: Looking for the Senator From All of New York

BYLINE: By George Gates; George Gates is a former editorial writer for The Buffalo News.

DATELINE: BUFFALO

 BODY:
In a New York Times/CBS News poll reported this week, 4 out of 10 New Yorkers said they didn't think Hillary Rodham Clinton knew New York well enough to represent it effectively. But if Mrs. Clinton comes to the Senate race as a carpetbagger, can her likely opponent claim that his career in New York City makes him any more representative of a state that isn't all skyscrapers and investment bankers? From upstate, Rudolph Giuliani looks like a carpetbagger, too.
The mayor's new upstate advertising, filled with metropolitan scenes, shows no awareness that from Buffalo to Plattsburgh and Binghamton to Massena, people seldom forget that New York is really two states, welded together by circumstances long forgotten. There's a widely held suspicion up here that metropolitan New Yorkers consider upstaters -- when they consider us at all -- a bunch of small-timers perpetually behind the curve. And for many upstaters, New York City is too busy, too noisy, too dirty, too much. 
 There is a good deal of parochialism in both camps. And a big campaign test for both Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton will be how nimbly they can move between them.
In politics, the greater population in New York City and its suburbs weighs against upstate. The 1990 Census counted 1.2 million people in the Buffalo-Niagara Falls region, more than the population of 11 states. But the last governor from the region was Grover Cleveland, and the last United States senator was James M. Mead, elected in 1938.
All too often, statewide elections offer upstaters only a selection of politicians from New York City and environs. Some of them seem lost when they arrive here to campaign. One gubernatorial hopeful babbled in Buffalo about "your airport" in Albany, more than 300 miles to the east. Pierre Rinfret, the loser to Mario Cuomo in the 1990 gubernatorial race, showed up talking about the high tolls on the Triborough Bridge.
Mayor Giuliani can talk about his successes against crime and corruption, but his city's violence and scandals seem as distant here as Chicago's or Houston's. What people will most want to hear are plans for stimulating a long-stagnant economy locked in a depressing pattern of business decline and shrinking population -- the famous boom never made it upstate. Just this week vows of revitalization, the perennial No. 1 campaign promise here, helped a Republican challenger defeat Erie County's three-term Democratic executive.
Mayor Giuliani may feel he's created a lot of exciting jobs in new industries in New York City, but this may only sharpen our unhappiness that our young people often have little choice but to leave for better opportunities elsewhere.
Mr. Giuliani has discovered one upstate issue. In August, while visiting near Binghamton, he let it be known that he had changed his mind and would support federal legislation letting New York into the Northeast dairy compact. Supporters see this pricing arrangement as a way to bring more money into the hands of the state's many dairy farmers, thereby aiding rural economies that need every nickel they can get.
Another issue may be harder for the mayor to maneuver around. He has set 2002 as the time to close the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. Several small upstate communities fear the landfill proposals they have been fighting could be pushed into reality by all that suddenly homeless garbage. One of the places is called -- sure enough -- Farmersville. A landfill there would forever scar its quiet and beautiful hills.
Mrs. Clinton's "listening tour" west of the Hudson, though it was criticized downstate as flaunting her ignorance, was shrewd packaging. For upstaters, it was a welcome contrast to the visits from politicians who don't even know they are out of touch. Mr. Giuliani can listen, too, and a significant segment of next year's vote may depend on which of these adversaries has the best listening skills.
So let Mr. Giuliani of Manhattan and Mrs. Clinton of Little Rock make their visits and give us their sales pitches. Apparently we'll have to buy from one of them, carpetbags notwithstanding.

HEADLINE: Pace of U.S. Consumer Borrowing Slows

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
United States consumers slowed their pace of borrowing in September, ringing up credit-card debt at less than half the pace they did in the previous month, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Borrowing rose by $5.9 billion in September to a total of $1.37 trillion. The increase was slower than the $6.8 billion expected by analysts and follows an increase of $7.1 billion in August. The Fed originally reported August borrowing had risen $10.8 billion, a seven-month high. 
 Debt from credit cards and revolving charge accounts rose $1.1 billion after a gain of $2.3 billion in August. The September increase in revolving credit was at the slowest pace since March. The increase in overall debt was the smallest since it rose $5.6 billion in June.
Analysts said people may have spent at a slower pace to prepare for Christmas spending.
The September increase in borrowing means debt grew at an annual rate of 5.2 percent, compared with 6.3 percent in August and 5.4 percent for all of 1998.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Overseas Money Flows In, Lifting Latin Stock Markets

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Buoyed by fresh inflows of overseas investment money, stock markets in Latin America are staging a rally that could presage a return to economic growth in many of the region's countries next year.
Over the last few weeks, market indexes in the region have soared. The Bovespa on the Sao Paulo stock exchange, Latin America's largest stock market, has soared to a six-month high. In Mexico, the bolsa index reached a three-month high. On the coattails of these markets, stocks in Argentina, Chile and Colombia registered healthy gains. 
 Much of the rally has been fueled by relief over potential interest rate increases in the United States, as recent economic reports have led some investors to believe that only one increase in rates, instead of several, is likely in coming months. Lower interest rates in the United States, Latin America's biggest source of investment, translates into more money available for purchases of stocks in the region.
A growing consensus that Latin America is positioned for a revival of economic growth next year is also encouraging investors to increase their stock holdings.
The recovery of some commodities prices, healthy demand for Latin American exports in rich industrialized nations and political and economic developments in countries like Mexico have led analysts like Geoffrey Dennis of Salomon Smith Barney to predict 3.2 percent growth for the region as a whole next year, compared with a four-tenths of 1 percent contraction in 1999.
"Investors are lifting the veil from a period in which Latin America was oversold," said Edmar Bacha, the New York-based strategist for Banco BBA Creditanstalt. "What they're seeing, minus the threat of higher Fed rates, is a region looking a lot better next year than this year."
One of the best examples of this is Chile, a nation that was hit hard by the economic crisis suffered by some of its trading partners.
Helped by lower domestic interest rates and a recovery in the price of copper, Chile's economy is expected to grow 5.5 percent in 2000, compared with a shrinkage of half a percent this year. And coming presidential elections are not viewed as risky, since the two leading candidates are pledging a similar blend of centrist economic policies, said Neil Dougall of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
In Mexico, politics is also generating optimism, with concern easing over possible disruptions resulting from primary presidential elections. And strong growth in the United States, Mexico's main export market, contributes to positive sentiment over the economy, which is increasingly viewed by economists as more linked to its northern neighbors than to the rest of Latin America.
Yet while prospects look better in countries like Chile and Mexico, it is in Brazil, Latin America's biggest economy, where most attention is focused. So perhaps it is no small wonder that the rally lifting most Latin markets is nowhere as significant as it is here.
Two weeks ago, Brazil's currency, the real, was being hammered as speculators who had been betting on weakness pushed it beyond two to the dollar for the first time in eight months. As alarm grew over the real's decline, Brazil successfully sought greater flexibility to defend the currency by using money from the International Monetary Fund, which has oversight over such matters because it is financing an economic aid package to the country. The real began to strengthen.
"All of a sudden there was much less pressure on the bank to raise rates to attract foreign capital," said Carlos Novis Guimaraes, head of Latin American investment banking at Lehman Brothers.
With the likelihood larger that Brazil might lower rates rather than raise them, a fresh assessment emerged.
Corporate profits, like those from eucalyptus producers benefiting from higher pulp prices and banks prospering from prescient investment strategies, suggested an economic recovery stronger than once thought. Most analysts are predicting Brazil's economy will grow 3 percent in 2000, compared with zero percent expected this year.
Still, investors remain cautious about the potential for rebound in Brazil and the rest of Latin America.
While shocks such as Ecuador's moratorium on foreign bonds seem to have been absorbed without causing much damage to investor sentiment, other factors lead some investors to remain wary.
For instance, interest rate increases abroad, like those announced on Thursday by the European Central Bank and the Bank of England, could undermine Latin America's stock rally. Reticence by Brazil's Congress to approve Government proposals to simplify the tax system and trim pension spending may also raise a red flag.
Nevertheless, an important shift in sentiment seems to be taking place. "It appears that global risk aversion is lowering after the collapses predicted by some people never materialized," said Ernest Brown, senior Latin America economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Trade Group's Leader Says Discord Threatens Talks

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Frustrated by the World Trade Organization's apparent inability to agree on an agenda for its meeting barely three weeks away, the leader of the group has warned the 134 member countries that the meeting could end in failure.
In a surprisingly blunt letter released today, Mike Moore, director general of the organization, said the preparations for the meeting in Seattle were caught in a "vicious circle." 
 Success of the talks in helping break down resilient barriers to global commerce is critical to the credibility of Mr. Moore, a New Zealander who took over as the group's top official only two months ago.
Mr. Moore said in the letter that whatever progress had been made on an agenda was "far from sufficient." He urged member countries to give their representatives more flexibility to compromise on disputes delaying the agenda for the four-day meeting that starts on Nov. 30.
The letter, dated Thursday, was written on the eve of the trade group's deadline of today to complete the agenda. That deadline was not met, and another had not been set by tonight.
"The very short time remaining before the Seattle conference, and the magnitude of the continuing divergences in positions, means the preparatory process is at a critical point," Mr. Moore wrote to Ali Said Mchumo, Tanzania's trade ambassador, who is chairman of the trade group's decision-making council.
Negotiations have bogged down in serious differences among countries, particularly on the issue of agricultural subsidies that protect farmers from foreign competition.
The disputes over agricultural issues have boiled down to a test of wills pitting one bloc composed of the 15-nation European Union and Japan, South Korea, Norway and Switzerland, all of which have highly subsidized farming, against a second bloc comprising the big farm produce-exporting countries, including the United States.
Besides the disagreement over agriculture, the agenda negotiations are stalled by disputes over whether the fulfillment of some previous trade agreements should be on the agenda. Developing nations want delays in carrying these out, contending they need more time to fulfill complex agreements like those on safeguards for intellectual property rights. Developed countries oppose putting such requests on the agenda, saying they reopen issues that have already been resolved.
In the letter, Mr. Moore said he strongly believed "that unless governments give their delegations in Geneva additional flexibility necessary to reach acceptable and balanced compromises, we risk not being able to progress significantly." A 32-page draft of the agenda has not been changed since a high-level meeting of trade group representatives last week.
In his letter, Mr. Moore said he was appealing "through you to member governments to undertake without delay a review of their instructions to their negotiators in Geneva in order to break out of what could otherwise become a vicious circle."
Mr. Moore released the letter, his spokesman said, because "once you hand it over to delegates, it will get around."

LENGTH: 580 words

HEADLINE: House Passes Compromise Bill for $13.5 Billion in Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The House overwhelmingly approved a compromise foreign aid bill today, but some allied governments and international aid workers expressed disappointment at the debt relief for poor countries.
By a vote of 316 to 100, lawmakers agreed to an aid package negotiated by the White House and Congress on Thursday that added $799 million more than Republicans wanted to spend on matters like peacekeeping in Kosovo, nuclear security in Russia and cancellation of poor nations' debts, mostly in Africa. 
 The $13.5 billion measure will advance next week to the Senate, where approval is expected.
President Clinton said the bill "meets our commitments" in key policy areas. But some European diplomats here and international aid workers were more skeptical.
In debt relief, the Group of Seven industrial nations agreed in Cologne, Germany, in June to cut the debt burden of the poorest countries to ease poverty. To help pay the American share, President Clinton requested $370 million this year to help the 41 countries identified by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as "heavily indebted."
But Republicans, who included $33 million in their spending bill, agreed to only $123 million in the compromise. They said that to spend more would force a raid on the Social Security surplus, which both parties vow to protect.
"The real danger today is not American hegemony, but American disengagement," said one diplomat from a European country involved in the debt fund set up at Cologne.
Aid workers said the United States could well afford to cancel loans to let poor countries focus their resources on needed services like education and health care. "We don't think a farmer in Mali should be selling some of his crop to go into the U.S. Treasury when they need to get children into school," said Seth Amgott, a spokesman for Oxfam, a worldwide anti-poverty agency.
The initial foreign aid bill passed by the Republican-controlled Congress last month contained $12.7 billion and was vetoed by President Clinton as inadequate. The administration asked for $14.4 billion but compromised on $13.5 billion.
The compromise restored some administration priorities, including an additional $170 million in economic support funds and $150 million for development aid.
The deal also increased financing for peacekeeping operations in Kosovo, including a new police force and assistance to neighboring countries. The administration originally requested $130 million, and Congress first approved $78 million, but in the end, they agreed to $153 million. The allies are to hold a donors' conference later this month to work out the cost-sharing. Financing for the American troops in Kosovo will be handled in separate legislation.
Republicans also restored $104 million for nuclear security programs and other aid to the former Soviet republics, but the $839 million total fell far short of the administration's request for $1.32 billion.
The United States has worked hard to prevent nuclear material in Russia from falling into the hands of terrorists. Even some proponents of safeguards have grown frustrated as the Russians have restricted access to some sensitive nuclear sites. But Kenneth Luongo, the head of the Russian-American Nuclear Security Advisory Council, a private group, said, "Given the problems in Russia, the thought that devoting less money is going to give them incentive to be more cooperative, or solve the problem faster, is inaccurate."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Drops to 4.1% As Wages Rise By 1 cents an Hour

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The American economy demonstrated once again last month its remarkable ability to absorb nearly all the people seeking jobs and yet not pay more to hire them.
The unemployment rate fell to 4.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly 30 years, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But the average wages of workers below the rank of supervisor went up just one cent an hour last month. 
 Despite a strong economy and nearly full employment, the inflationary pressures that usually foreshadow the end of an economic expansion have not yet emerged.
"The American economy is turning out to be more flexible and dynamic than anyone had thought possible," said James Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Manhattan Bank.
Stock prices rose smartly in response to the employment news. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 10,704.48, up 64.91 points. The mild wage number and an equally mild inflation report earlier this week suggested to investors that the Federal Reserve's policymakers may be less inclined to raise interest rates at their next meeting, on Nov. 16, and more likely to be restrained in the future even if they push up rates modestly this month in an attempt to slow the economy.
The Clinton administration hailed the latest employment figures as evidence of the success of administration policies. "We are drawing more and more people into jobs by making work pay," said the Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman.
Still, the Labor Department report suggested that the economy may be slowing gradually. The nation's employers added 310,000 jobs to their payrolls in October, the most for a single month since July. But employment growth averaged only 160,000 a month for August through October, down from 210,000 in the first half of the year. In recent weeks, retailers and auto dealers have reported that sales gains are slowing. Home sales and new construction have fallen from their summer peaks. And the consumer confidence polls show a gradual drop since mid-summer.
"No forecaster sees a recession ahead, but most do see more modest growth in the Year 2000 than in 1999," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, an investment firm.
Job growth was strongest last month among temporary workers, who accounted for 45,000 of the 215,000 service sector jobs added to the rolls. Government employment, particularly in education, also grew strongly, while jobs disappeared in retailing and, once again, in manufacturing.
Still, many companies scrambled to recruit enough workers from among the 5.8 million people who seek work. They represented an unemployment rate of 4.1 percent, down from 4.2 percent in September and the lowest since January 1970, when it was 3.9 percent.
The steady decline in unemployment over the last five years has spread across every group, bringing jobless levels to their lowest levels in years for Hispanics, whites, blacks, adult men and teenagers. The unemployment rate for adult women fell to 3.5 percent in October from 3.7 percent the month before -- the lowest level since 1953, the Labor Department said.
What is amazing in all these numbers is the failure of wages to rise, flatly contradicting established economic theory. Most economists expected, as unemployment fell below 5 percent, that the scramble to find enough workers would force employers to bid up wages at an accelerating rate. But the 5 percent line was breached in mid-1997 and nothing has happened.
"It is perplexing that the economy can persist at such low unemployment without wage inflation," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
Many economists argue that American corporations, through new technologies that improve efficiency, have managed to obtain a lot more output from employees for the same number of hours worked. The additional revenue from this output of merchandise and services helps to explain how companies have managed to remain profitable without raising prices. And indeed, the Commerce Department reported on Tuesday that as the economy expanded briskly in the third quarter, its inflation index rose at an annual rate of only 1.3 percent.
But productivity fails to explain why companies don't find themselves forced to raise wage scales to attract enough workers. And they have resisted doing so, according to Labor Department data. The average wage for production workers -- now $13.37 an hour -- was up only 3.6 percent for the last 12 months, a pace that is actually slower than earlier in the year.
A broader measure, covering benefits as well as wages, has been similarly mild. Only when income from stock options and recruiting bonuses are included does compensation begin to accelerate.
"I think there are nascent indications that we will see stronger wage gains going forward," said Mark Zandi, chief economist for RFA Dismal Sciences, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
But others argue that wages no longer respond as they once did to a scarce supply of workers. The work force, for example, is aging and unemployment among older, settled workers is always lower than among young people. Then, too, the rising number of temporary workers give jobs quickly to the unemployed and give employers a pool of people to draw from without having to bid for permanent hires.
Reflecting this demand, temporary workers now total 3.1 million, or 2.4 percent of the 129.3 million people employed in October. Few other groups of workers have grown as rapidly in the 1990's.
The decline in union membership and bargaining power has softened wage demands. So has the decline in the inflation rate, which has made workers more willing to accept smaller raises, many economists say. Then, too, immigrants are feeding many more people into the work force than the Government's numbers now capture, Mr. Gordon says. And the failure of the minimum wage to rise in step with inflation has taken pressure off wages.
"Rarely do we have a single explanation for a major change in the economy," Mr. Gordon said. "We never came up with one bullet to explain the productivity slowdown that came upon us in the 1970's, or the Great Depression."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
The Education of George W. Bush, and the Voter

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 5

 BODY:
One afternoon last week, flying high above northern Texas, Gov. George W. Bush eagerly displayed the tome he was reading, "Titan," a 774-page biography of John D. Rockefeller.
Mr. Bush pronounced himself a serious history buff as he toyed with the ribbon-like marker that tracked his progress -- a souvenir, he said, from one of his favorite events, the annual book fair here. 
 But a day later, standing with his wife, Laura, near the front porch of the Governor's Mansion, he hit a decidedly different note. Someone congratulated Mrs. Bush for an award that she had just been given by her alma mater, Southern Methodist University, and asked the couple if Mr. Bush had ever received a similar distinction from one of the schools that he attended.
"If they honored me," Mr. Bush said, with a touch of mischievous pride, "the teachers might boycott."
Cerebral or simply sensible? Intellectual or visceral? Closet bibliophile or class clown? As Mr. Bush, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, presents himself ever more fully to American voters, he often seems uncertain about which image to underscore, which card to play.
In this respect, more than any other, Mr. Bush comes across as a work in progress, a balancing act that has yet to find its equilibrium. Perhaps that reflects his own genuinely split personality. Or perhaps it anticipates the ambivalence of American voters and their appetite for candidates who stake some vague middle ground between uncommon erudition and common knowledge.
Precisely where on that spectrum Mr. Bush falls -- a determination with potentially important consequences for his candidacy -- was the subject of considerable attention this week.
For starters, the New Yorker magazine published Mr. Bush's academic transcript from his undergraduate years at Yale University, a document that Mr. Bush and his advisers had previously declined to release. The report card showed him to be a solid C student.
Then a Boston television reporter surprised Mr. Bush during an interview on Wednesday with a pop quiz on foreign leaders. Mr. Bush got just one of four questions right.
Mr. Bush shrugged it off today. "People can trick me with, trip me up with questions," he said in an interview with ABC News, adding that the American people simply "want somebody who they trust to lead the world to peace."
President Clinton pretty much echoed that sentiment and, in remarks that seemed at least somewhat sympathetic to Mr. Bush, said that the Texas governor would probably learn soon enough the names he should know.
Political analysts said that most voters would probably see the situation that way as well, but that Mr. Bush ran a serious risk if he seemed too cavalier about what he did and did not know, and if questions about the seriousness of his engagement with substantive matters became a theme so dominant in discussions of him that they eclipsed his affability and his agenda.
"Packaged by the right opponents, repeated the right number of times and the right ways, that issue might take on real momentum," said Bruce Buchanan, a professor of presidential politics at the University of Texas who has closely monitored Mr. Bush's political ascent.
Mr. Buchanan said that while Mr. Bush's performance on the pop quiz itself seemed irrelevant, and the quiz itself was arguably inappropriate, "I think there are some legitimate questions about whether Bush is truly up to speed yet."
But Mr. Buchanan added: "Can he get sufficiently well prepared to be ready for a Bush inauguration? In principle, I think yes."
Mr. Bush's refrain in the past has been that there are blind spots in his experience and familiarity with some issues, but that those could be corrected by the right advice from the right advisers.
And yet, Mr. Bush and his aides have been quick to show that he is catching up, filling in the blanks, cramming for the exam. They have been forthcoming about the parade of out-of-town experts -- from former Secretary of State George P. Shultz to Condoleezza Rice, the former provost of Stanford University -- who have traveled to the Governor's Mansion, where Mr. Bush gets private tutorials.
In public comments, particularly in regard to foreign policy, Mr. Bush has zestfully volunteered long answers to voters' questions, taking his audience around the world in 80 phrases that assert his geopolitical command.
"I'd love to, love to," he said to a man in Meredith, N.H., this week who asked him if he would care to share any of his thoughts on foreign policy. Mr. Bush started with China: "As opposed to being a strategic partner, China is a competitor."
He proceeded to Russia: "We should not be putting good money after bad into the country of Russia."
He landed briefly in Israel: "It is important for us to honor our commitment to the sole democracy in the Middle East."
Then he dwelled for a while in Mexico, saying that a way to stem illegal immigration was to foster economic development there.
"While we've got to do a better job of enforcing our border," Mr. Bush said, "it's important for people in this country to understand that people come here to work, to put food on the table."
But Mr. Bush takes this kind of thing only so far.
"There's a defiant streak in him," Mr. Buchanan said, "and I think he still has contradictory impulses. He knows he needs to study, but there's something in him that doesn't care for the earnestness or fussiness of that expectation."
And that, Mr. Buchanan and other political scientists said, may be one of his most appealing attributes to American voters.
"They want somebody who can understand the issues, but they also want somebody who can relate to them," said Darrell West, a professor of political science at Brown University.
While there are times when Mr. Bush conspicuously bucks any perception that he lacks intellectual curiosity, there are at least as many times when he acknowledges, and indulges, any impression that he is more salesman than scholar, and engaged in details only to a point.
Outside the Governor's Mansion last week, he was asked if he was ready for an education speech that he was scheduled to deliver four days later.
"I still have to write it," Mr. Bush said with a twinkle, a smile and the clear implication that he was not the one holding the pen.
It was reminiscent of a moment on the campaign trail months earlier when Mr. Bush jokingly told reporters that he was lingering with them to avoid another policy briefing from his advisers.
Those advisers send their own mixed signals. Frequently, they portray Mr. Bush as someone who is intricately involved in the operation of his campaign and even an unheralded policy maven. But they conversely praise him as someone smart and trusting enough to carve out a general vision and let others sweat the small stuff.
And in this regard, unlike most others, they are not always on the same page. After one adviser said that Mr. Bush can frequently be found with his nose deep in a book, another offered, only half jokingly, "Maybe the Bible."

HEADLINE: Republican Leaders Engage President in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Eager to adjourn with a spending deal that allows them to claim a partial political victory, Republican leaders in Congress are bargaining directly with President Clinton, White House and Congressional officials said today.
The officials said a compromise was discussed in three conversations over the last three days among Mr. Clinton, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate majority leader. 
 Nevertheless, much remains to be done. The two sides are still billions of dollars apart on spending, and there are significant policy disputes, like the Republicans' unwillingness to agree to pay $1 billion in dues that the United States owes to the United Nations. As a result, neither side expects a grand bargain before Congress reconvenes on Monday.
"We feel that the only way to conduct these kind of negotiations is detail by detail, and line by line," said Gene Sperling, the top White House economic adviser.
The deal Republicans are seeking would require the White House to pay for new spending it wants by cutting other programs, cuts known as offsets. These real cuts would allow the Republicans to stop using the creative accounting they have relied on to mask tens of billions of dollars in spending over the limits set by Congress.
White House officials said tonight that they had a long list of such cuts in their pocket. They have not shown Republicans that list.
Republicans also want Mr. Clinton to agree to a small across-the-board reduction in federal spending, significantly smaller than the 1 percent cut that he denounced as "mindless" and that he vetoed on Wednesday.
Mr. Hastert raised the matter directly on Wednesday, but "the President indicated opposition and said offsets were a far better solution," a White House official said.
Tonight they spoke again and agreed to try to cooperate, but Mr. Hastert did not bring up the across-the-board cuts, the official said.
Any deal would be intended to allow both sides to claim that this year's budget will not dip into Social Security surpluses to finance federal spending. This would defuse accusations that the Republican spending bills, or White House demands for spending increases, would require tapping into the retirement funds.
The White House and the Republicans would have to agree on using bookkeeping devices that make the spending look as low as possible. "I have no objection to that," President Clinton said last week.
Mr. Clinton has already signaled his willingness to compromise with the Republicans.
"We need to sit down like grown ups, go out and tell the American people the truth, and work through this," he said on Monday, two days before he vetoed the bill that included the across-the-board cuts. "We can find the offsets. We don't have to spend the Social Security surplus. We can do this. And I hope they will work with me to do it."
If a deal with the president falls through, senior Republican aides said, their leaders would prepare a package of billions of dollars in mandatory spending reductions that Mr. Clinton could not easily block.
The Republicans desperately want to complete the year's four remaining spending bills before Wednesday, the deadline set by the year's fourth continuing resolution, passed by Congress on Thursday night, that allows the Government to keep operating without a real budget. That budget was due 35 days ago, on Oct. 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year.
Many members of Congress are tired and grumpy and want to go home, said the Republican chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative C. W. (Bill) Young of Florida. More than any struggle over principle, power or penny-pinching, the desire to leave town seems likely to push them to the finish line next week, in what most hope will be the last days of a desultory year.
"That certainly is the mood and the hopes of all the members," Mr. Young said.
When Mr. Hastert and other Republican leaders emerged from his office on Thursday night, after a marathon bargaining session with the White House over spending on foreign aid, they looked spent. Mr. Hastert wore a mask of exhaustion. He had just been beaten in a debate with the White House, and had agreed to spend about $800 million more on foreign aid than his conservative colleagues wanted.
Mr. Young said he was just plain beat. "The days have been long," he said. "The hours have been long. Lots of 15-, 16-hour days."
Another reason to wrap up a deal is that nearly two dozen senators have planned official trips in the coming three weeks. They include Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, which governs spending; William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Finance Committee, which governs taxes, and Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
Congress must accomplish a great deal if it truly wants to leave town on Wednesday, the end of the fourth overtime period in what has thus far been a contest with few stars and fewer highlights.
The House passed the $15.2 billion foreign aid bill by a 316-to-100 vote today, with 84 Republicans in dissent. Four other spending bills remain to be negotiated; Mr. Clinton has either vetoed or refused to sign each one over issues of spending and policy.
The bill covering the Interior Department is being held up by two disagreements. One is President Clinton's request for $550 million more to buy wilderness areas to protect them from developers. The Republicans are willing to offer $300 million, but want to spend it in different ways, Mr. Young said. The second disagreement is over Republican amendments benefiting the oil, gas, mining and ranching industries.
The bill covering the Commerce, Justice and State Departments has two problems, as well. One is the demand by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, that the United States refuse to pay $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations until the White House agrees that no federal money can go to groups trying to liberalize abortion abroad. The other is Mr. Clinton's demand that Congress fully finance his program to add 50,000 officers to local police forces.
The bill covering the Education Department is stymied by a dispute involving Mr. Clinton's $1.4 billion program to reduce class sizes in public schools by hiring 100,000 new teachers. And the bill providing federal funds for the District of Columbia has been hamstrung by Republican refusals to finance an AIDS program and other local measures.

HEADLINE: Fighting Poverty, President and Speaker Find a Moment of Unity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Near the end of a bitterly partisan Congressional session, President Clinton and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert appeared together here tonight to celebrate a rare moment of accord: a pledge to merge their plans to alleviate inner-city and rural poverty.
The announcement came on the second and last day of Mr. Clinton's latest antipoverty tour, which began this morning on a tomato farm in a rural Arkansas town of 700 people and ended in one of Chicago's most blighted neighborhoods. 
 While the agreement they announced amounted to a set of goals rather than any specific legislation, the accord reflected a concern by Republican leaders that they not let Mr. Clinton dominate the debate over how to spread a remarkable era of prosperity to corners of the country where unemployment remains high and incomes are far below average.
The accord announced today pledges that the two parties will "work in a spirit of good faith to develop a bipartisan effort" to bring capital to impoverished areas of the country. But all the hard bargaining -- over what kind of tax incentives will be established, what kind of equity and loan guarantees to extend to small businesses and entrepreneurs -- are put off until next year.
"America can't ignore the people who have been left behind," Mr. Hastert said this evening.
Acknowledging that he was somewhat out of place in a staunchly Democratic neighborhood, he said, "I don't think I'm going to make Republicans out of anyone" in the audience. "But this isn't about politics," he said.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert both used the event tonight, in a technical preparatory school in the struggling Englewood neighborhood, to make the case that partisanship must stop at the inner-city's edge.
"They are used to writing in Washington about how we all fight all the time," Mr. Clinton said, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and several politicians behind him. "In Reverend Jackson's famous phrase, we have decided to reach common ground and higher ground."
Mr. Hastert, who introduced Mr. Jackson at the end of his comments, sounded much like Mr. Clinton in describing his goals.
"Sometimes Democrats and Republicans do agree," Mr. Hastert said. "And it's time to come together and make things happen."
Noting that the Democratic and Republican proposals even went by different names, Mr. Hastert said, "I don't care what we call it."
The written principles released by Mr. Hastert and the White House said there were "significant untapped new markets" in both rural and urban poor areas. They said their goal was to empower communities "with new equity capital, tax incentives and other tools" and to provide "private sector and government resources."
The Republican plan that Mr. Hastert alluded to this evening was sponsored by Representatives J. C. Watts of Oklahoma and James M. Talent of Missouri, for up to 100 "renewal communities."
It is essentially a tax reduction plan under which there is no capital gains tax on the sale of a business or partnership inside a renewal community, a proposal the White House opposes; a wage credit for companies that hire workers from the community and a commercial revitalization credit for those who renovate nonresidential buildings in such communities.
The second day of Mr. Clinton's "new markets" tour began in familiar territory for the president: a tomato farming cooperative in Hermitage, Ark., a town not far from the area where Mr. Clinton grew up. Mr. Clinton's first encounter with the town came more than 20 years ago, when as attorney general of Arkansas he went there to deal with labor problems stemming from the arrival of farm workers from Mexico.
"I just came down here one night and sat and listened for three or four hours and learned more about tomato farmers than I had ever known in my life -- and than I've ever heard since."
It could not have been a more welcoming crowd: in state elections, Mr. Clinton won overwhelming victories in the area, and today he stayed to shake hands with the crowds for more than half an hour. It resembled a campaign rally more than a celebration of the opening of new economic markets, and it was laced with the announcement of some old-fashioned road projects by Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater.
Another member of the cabinet, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, could not resist noting that Mr. Slater's tenure had been marked by "perhaps a disproportionate share of roads to Arkansas."
The ostensible purpose of the visit was to see the Hermitage Tomato Cooperative Association, founded by 15 farmers who were barely surviving and could not afford the kind of processing equipment needed to become a major supplier of tomatoes. Today they sell to Burger King and the Kroger Company, but they did so with existing government aid programs -- rather than what Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hastert were pressing today.
