HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge Contends Microsoft Stifled Tech Innovation
The judge in the government's antitrust trial against Microsoft issued a broad denunciation of the software giant as the first part of his verdict in the case. The judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court, said that the company used its monopoly power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers. 
 "Most harmful of all is the message that Microsoft's actions have conveyed to every enterprise with the potential to innovate in the computer industry," Judge Jackson wrote in his 207-page findings of fact. "Through its conduct," he added, "Microsoft has demonstrated that it will use its prodigious market power and immense profits to harm any firm" that gets in its way. Page A1.
 
Nasdaq Index Continues Its Climb
The Nasdaq composite index closed above the 3,000 level for the first time on Wednesday and recorded its sixth consecutive record high yesterday. It closed up 46.34 points, or 1.5 percent, at 3,102.29, and is up 41.48 percent so far this year.
The Dow Jones industrial average is up only 16.59 percent so far this year. It closed up 64.84 points, or 0.61 percent, to 10,704.48. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.59, or 0.56 percent, to 1,370.23. C3.
 
Employers Find It Hard to Fill Jobs
With the nation's unemployment rate at the lowest level in nearly 30 years, employees are no longer afraid to go job hunting in search of better benefits, more flexible hours and other perks, while employers are having a hard time attracting candidates to fill openings. A1.
 
Shares of Cobalt Soar on First Day
Shares of Cobalt Networks, a maker of no-frills network computers, soared in their first day of trading, to $128.50 from their initial price of $22, as investors bestowed yet another staggering valuation on a small, money-losing Internet company. C3.
 
Appeals Court Hands Intel a Victory
Intel won a key victory in an antitrust case when a federal appeals court lifted an order that required the computer chip maker to share patented microprocessor technology with another company, Intergraph. C2.
 
Latin American Stocks Rally
Latin America's biggest stock markets are booming, as investors from other countries take advantage of lower borrowing costs in the United States to gain a stake in what they expect will be a region of growing economies next year. In the last few weeks, indexes such as the Bovespa on the Sao Paulo stock exchange, Latin America's largest stock market, have soared to a six-month high. Healthy gains were also registered by the exchanges in Mexico, Argentina, Chile and Colombia. C2.
 
Disputes Threaten Trade Summit
Mike Moore, the director general of the World Trade Organization, warned in a letter to the chairman of the trade group's decision-making council that preparations for this month's summit meeting in Seattle are caught in a vicious circle. His letter warned that the meeting may end in failure unless its 134 members agree to compromise on disputes, notably one over agricultural subsidies, standing in the way of setting the agenda. C2.
 
Webvan Shares Make Fast Start
Shares in Webvan Group, an online grocer that is expected to lose $65 million this year, jumped 65 percent in their first day of trading, to $24.875 from the offering price of $15 a share. C6.
 
Amoco Agrees to Concessions
BP Amoco agreed to a number of concessions, including the sale of 13 percent of its oil production from Alaska's North Slope, in return for the blessing of Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska for its proposed merger with Arco. C3.

HEADLINE: Help Wanted, Meaning Help Can Be Fussy

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: ROANOKE, Va.

 BODY:
Not so long ago, most people were wary of leaving a job. Whatever its faults, they had too much at risk, like their seniority, security and benefits. But these times of prosperity and low unemployment have changed all that. Now, for the most part, people do not lose jobs. Jobs lose them.
For three and a half years, Joya Patsel, who is 19, worked for a Hardee's restaurant here. "They kept me at $5.50 the whole time," she said. "I quit." Now, she said, "I've been at McDonald's about five weeks. They started me at $6.25 and worked me up to $6.75." 
 Scott Marshall, 22, earns $11 an hour, or about $22,000 a year, installing heating and air-conditioning systems. He wants a higher wage, a shorter drive to work and a more empathetic boss. In late October, he called four companies like his own, and all were encouraging. "They all said just come in and fill out an application," he said.
Businesses are desperate for workers, and workers know it. Emboldened by that knowledge, they often bolt for nothing more than a shorter drive, more flexible hours, a marginal increase in pay or an employer's latest lure: the sign-on bonus. At the Roanoke office of the Virginia Employment Commission, for example, counselors originally trained to help the unemployed are busiest now helping fully employed workers find better jobs.
The bravest among them create their own jobs, striking out to start their own businesses, knowing they can still get a job if they fail.
"Workers seem fearless, and they ought to," said Gary Burtless, labor economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
At the heart of this new empowerment is the low national unemployment rate, which has been hovering around 4 percent. Employers in virtually every sector of the economy are experiencing a shortage of workers unlike any in recent history.
The scarcity runs through the ranks of the labor force from the construction trades to service-sector jobs to the high-technology Internet world. Needs that go unmet include those for doctors, engineers, mid level managers and even senior executives. But the severest shortages are in the lower pay ranges, for sales clerks, short-order cooks, food-store workers and data-entry clerks.
The trend has spread throughout rural areas and big cities and can be especially vexing in places like Roanoke, where the unemployment rate is 2 percent, considerably below the national rate.
Describing the situation here, Beth Doughty, president of the Roanoke Regional Chamber of Commerce, said: "It is most acute at lower wage levels, in jobs paying $6 to $10 or $11 an hour. But it's across the board, in all categories."
Carol Day, owner of an employment agency here, said 20 years ago she would have had 10 applicants for a secretarial job. "Now we might be able to come up with one or two people," she said.
Stanley Boatwright, a principal in the Lucas & Boatwright accounting firm, is beating the bushes for accountants with two to five years of experience, whom he would pay around $35,000 a year, and newly minted accountants, whom he would pay $25,000.
"What we see is what all employers see," Mr. Boatwright said.
Even in the professions, job seekers no longer look for lifelong careers with one firm. At the same time, he said, "the pipeline of qualified candidates is slowing down."
This market condition cannot last, some economists warn. They say it violates the age-old economic cycle. Any day now, they say, employers will have to respond by raising wages to lure and hold workers.
But other economists suspect that new forces are calming the old cycle. Once, said Lawrence Chimerine, a consultant and economist at the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, industry could raise prices because it controlled them. With the growth of foreign trade, particularly, Mr. Chimerine said, customers have taken control. If American prices rise, customers will shop elsewhere.
"The process these days is backwards," Mr. Chimerine said.
Economists also say technology has raised productivity, letting workers and industry produce more goods and services per hour. That gives employers some leeway to raise wages, though not by much.
With malls, hospitals and businesses that serve rural communities far beyond it, Roanoke is a sponge of job creation that soaks up hourly workers. Periodically, manufacturers in the area, especially fading textile companies, lay people off. But other businesses are creating far more jobs, enough to absorb laid off workers and thousands of new workers who pour into the area year by year and to still leave employers begging.
"What we're telling employers is, you're going to have to steal people" from one another, said Jerry Barnett, assistant manager of the employment commission office.
Mr. Barnett said: "People are very fluid. They will move for a minimal increase in pay. In this area, instead of talking about unemployment, we talk about underemployment, people working in jobs that they feel are beneath them."
Last week, RKG Associates Inc., a consulting firm in Alexandria, Va., released the results of a survey it did of the Roanoke area job market for the employment commission.
"Thirty-three percent of respondents would quit their current job to take another job that paid the same but better met their personal needs," the report said.
"Nearly 40 percent would change jobs for less than a 15 percent increase in pay," it said. And "nearly 20 percent of respondents were working in jobs with educational requirements that were at least two levels below their educational attainment level."
Unable or reluctant to raise prices for their goods and services so they can then raise wages, employers are trying everything else. One device is the bonus, for agreeing to take a job, for staying on it or for performance.
"Will match existing pay or exceed," a roofing company advertises. "$100 sign-up bonus." Kentucky Fried Chicken promises sandwich makers and cooks the "possibility of three raises within six months," a "gift certificate program for high performers" and "opportunity for employee bonus."
Temporary staffing agencies go to extraordinary lengths to locate and retain workers for their clients, especially those willing to take low-paid jobs. Adecco, a large agency with more than 3,200 offices worldwide, is searching for 250 workers to dispatch to Hanover Direct, a distributor for eight mail-order catalog companies. The company needs them to work the pre-Christmas rush.
But finding them will not be easy. Adecco is combing rural communities 30 to 40 miles from Roanoke, searching for housewives who are willing to work but do not have cars, and for the first time, it has hired a bus company to transport them.
Then to retain the workers, the agency is offering bonuses just for showing up. In addition to the $6.75 hourly pay for Hanover Direct's day shift and $7.75 for the night shift, Adecco will pay $20 for each week of perfect attendance and $40 more for a month of perfect attendance.
"We're trying to head off people from leaving," said Beth Pinson, the agency's senior area manager. Besides the boon to workers, the economy's mix of prosperity and fraying workplace bonds has stimulated a burst of entrepreneurship here.
Terry Kidman, 40, has started a business doing what he did for someone else for 20 years, fitting out gasoline stations. His wife, Linda Kidman, 39, was once a nurse. Now, she said, she earns $50,000 a year selling newly prosperous homeowners decorating accessories -- figurines, pictures, candles, sconces, mirrors -- as a door-to-door agent for Home Interiors and Gifts, a company in Dallas.
"People want their homes to be beautiful," Mrs. Kidman said. "They want something good to look at when they get up. Even a child. It likes to look at a picture of a teddy bear on the wall." Decorating "makes them feel a little more important about their home and their stuff."
Prosperity also created an opportunity for Jeff Miller, 35, who went no further than high school. He loathes the thought of "a job," meaning working for someone else. "You don't get the residual income if you have a job," he said.
Mr. Miller determined that Roanoke's bustling retail stores could use a package delivery service, so he started one that last year earned him $62,000. That, in turn, has let him resurrect an artifact of the era before prosperity, the breadwinner father. His wife, Susan, stays home with their three children -- her preference, he said, as well as his.
To other families, the abundance of jobs spells opportunity for all. Miles White, 51, has two jobs. He is a vocational rehabilitation counselor for the blind and works weekends counseling troubled teenage girls.
His wife, Chris Lambruscati, 50, quadriplegic since a skydiving accident, is a psychotherapist. One daughter, Shawn, 17, works part time at a McDonald's, and another, Arren, 14, works part time at a Kroger's supermarket.
"It gives them structure, money, self-esteem," Mr. White said.
But real work can be hazardous to homework, he said, "so we make sure they make reasonably good grades, or their work is cut back."

HEADLINE: Tennessee Debates Governor's Appeal for an Income Tax

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Nov. 5

 BODY:
In these flush economic times when many states have budget surpluses, Gov. Don Sundquist has had to grapple with revenue problems so severe that he has proposed the first income tax in Tennessee history, despite a lack of support from many of his Republican colleagues.
It has been an uphill battle for Mr. Sundquist, a second-term governor who had opposed an income tax for years. And on Thursday, as the Tennessee Legislature ended the first week of a special session here to consider tax reform but did not act on the governor's plan, the Republican leader in the Senate declared the income tax proposal all but dead. 
 Still, there is some bipartisan support for addressing a revenue shortfall that the governor's office has estimated will be about $383 million in the fiscal year that begins in July, unless new revenue sources can be found. That shortfall constitutes about 5 percent of the total revenue the state must raise.
Lawmakers are set to hold more hearings next week on the governor's proposal, and others.
Tennessee is one of eight states that do not have an income tax. The state relies heavily on revenue from its 6 percent sales tax. That rate together with local sales taxes gives Tennessee a higher combined sales tax rate than that of any of its eight neighboring states.
Economic analysts, including the governor's advisers, say that because of changes in consumer spending in recent years the state has not been able to benefit as much as it once did from its sales tax revenue.
"Sales taxes have not kept pace with economic growth," said William Fox, professor of economics at the University of Tennessee and an adviser to the governor.
The tax is on goods, but not services, and spending on services has overtaken spending on goods since the 1970's. To keep up, Professor Fox said, the state has increased sales taxes 61 times since 1971.
"The state has created a tax structure that is not competitive," he said.
Arturo Perez, a senior policy specialist at the fiscal affairs program of the National Conference for State Legislatures, said: "Tennessee has not been in a position to capture its share of the great economic growth in the last decade. Perhaps that indicates that Tennessee's current tax structure is out of kilter with today's economy."
Governor Sundquist's proposal would add a 3.5 percent tax on income, reduce the state's general sales tax rate to 3.75 percent from 6 percent and eliminate the sales tax on groceries.
"The failure of our tax structure occurred on my watch," Mr. Sundquist said in an interview today. "So I feel a responsibility to fix the system."
In a speech to the Legislature this week, the governor said the kind of long-term solution he had proposed was necessary to finance education and health care for the next generation, even if that meant the state would shift places in its ranking among states with the very lowest tax levels in the nation.
"I'm not going to tell our citizens that it is so important that we remain 50th in taxes that we're prepared to settle for 50th in everything else," he said.
But not everyone in Tennessee is convinced there is even a problem, much less that an income tax is the way to solve it.
"The wolf is not at the door," said Senator Michael R. Williams, a Republican.
"We're fully funded through July of next year," Mr. Williams said. "And I have not seen anything so far that would make me support the governor's plan."
One radio talk show host here, Dave Ramsey, has encouraged his listeners to send tea bags to Tennessee legislators in protest of an income tax. And a conservative research center called the Tennessee Family Institute has campaigned against the income tax as well, publicizing a report by the Cato Institute critical of a Tennessee income tax.
The Republican leader in the Senate, Ben Atchley of Knoxville, is against the income tax, as are some Democrats. Mr. Atchley said he did not believe there were enough votes in the Senate to pass the governor's bill. He agreed that Tennessee's tax system had a structural problem, but said that many taxpayers did not perceive it as an immediate problem.
"In last year's election everything was rosy," he said. "And then all of a sudden we've got a problem."
Mr. Atchley and others are looking for alternatives to an income tax, and ideas about taxes on services and personal property as well as spending cuts are beginning to be floated. The state's Medicaid replacement program, Tenncare, is a likely target when cuts are proposed. But no comprehensive alternatives to an income tax have yet been presented.
"The kind of sweeping reform that Tennessee is considering is rare, especially in recent years," said Mr. Perez of the state legislatures group. "It is always very difficult to enact any significant tax changes in the states. It usually does not always happen in the first year."

HEADLINE: By the Way, a Mayor-Elect Is Gay

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

 BODY:
The winning platform was what you might expect from a man eager to be mayor of Plattsburgh, a small, once-industrial border town upstate: more police officers, after-school programs, and a plan to revitalize the economy by drawing tourists to the town's War of 1812 battle sites. (A diorama of the war, he likes to point out, is inside City Hall.)
Earlier this week, that platform helped Daniel Stewart, a Republican, narrowly defeat Plattsburgh's five-term mayor, Clyde Rabideau. 
 And it made Mr. Stewart, 37, a former Air Force sergeant and tractor-trailer driver who now works as a financial clerk at a local car dealership, the first openly gay person to be elected mayor in New York State.
Mr. Stewart, who described himself as having been "in the closet" during his eight years of service in the Air Force, had served on the Plattsburgh City Council since 1993.
Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of the mayor's race, he said, was that his sexual orientation did not come up for discussion. "The mayor never used anything about that; I never mentioned anything about that," Mr. Stewart said.
Nor did gay and lesbian concerns, like nondiscrimination statutes or domestic partnership benefits, enter the race. (Plattsburgh, population 20,000, has a nondiscrimination law but not partnership benefits.) Gay political activists saw the lack of gay themes as a cause for celebration.
"One great thing about this race was that sexual orientation was not an issue," said Matt Foreman, executive director of Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay and lesbian lobbying group.
Instead, Mr. Stewart pledged to hire more police officers in Plattsburgh, where, he said, crime had increased in the last two years, bucking a national trend. He also pledged to attract more tourists to the town, which was home to an Air Force Base until 1995, by playing up its historical attractions.
"I want to capitalize on the War of 1812," he said, noting his plans to place a cannon, circa 1812, atop City Hall.
Mr. Stewart also vowed to increase financing for youth programs and to lure companies that could take advantage of Plattsburgh's electricity rates -- the cheapest in the country, he said -- and abundant water.
He was endorsed by the town's police union and by Gov. George E. Pataki. According to unofficial results from the Clinton County clerk's office, Mr. Stewart won by 68 votes. About 100 absentee ballots have yet to be counted.
Gay political activists hailed Mr. Stewart's victory as evidence of an increasingly level political playing field.
"Not only is it the first ever of its kind in New York State, but it happened in a small middle-America type of city way upstate," said Sloan C. Wiesen, a spokesman for the Gay and Lesbian Victory Fund, a Washington-based group that supports gay candidates.
During this week's races, nine lesbians and gay men -- a record number -- ran for office across New York, most notably in rural and suburban areas.
On Long Island, Jonathan Cooper, a Democrat, was elected to the Suffolk County Legislature. Two incumbents, New York City Councilwoman Christine Quinn and a Nyack village trustee, John Shields, also Democrats, held on to their seats. Several gay and lesbian candidates lost, including Judy Green, a Democratic mayoral candidate in Poughkeepsie, Mary Mendola, who ran for the Ulster County Legislature, and Brian Cafferty, who ran for supervisor of Rosendale, a Catskills town of river bridges and antiques shops.
The election of Mr. Cooper and Mr. Stewart brought the statewide total of openly gay and lesbian elected officials to 27, including a half-dozen elected school board members in New York City.
In Plattsburgh, interestingly enough, Mr. Stewart faced an opponent known for positions favored by gay people on issues like domestic partnership benefits and same-sex marriage. Mr. Rabideau, who unsuccessfully ran for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor last year, had long enjoyed the support of the state's major gay and lesbian lobby group, Empire State. This year, Mr. Stewart earned its endorsement.
"There is something uniquely important about electing openly lesbian and gay people to office," Mr. Foreman said. "It is a role model for young people. It dispels stereotypes very quickly."
The group has also actively sought out Republicans to press a its agenda within the state Republican Party.
Mr. Stewart will be one of five openly gay mayors in the country, according to the Gay & Lesbian Victory Fund. The others are in Arizona, Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina.
Among the roughly 500,000 elected officeholders nationwide, "from dog-catcher to Congress," as Mr. Wiesen put it, about 180 are gays and lesbians. Most are Democrats, he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Favorable News on Jobs and Inflation Lifts Equity Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Financial markets applauded a government report released yesterday that portrayed a slowing economy with no discernible increase in inflationary pressure.
After hearing that the unemployment rate for October fell to 4.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly 30 years, traders pushed bond yields, which had been falling all week, even lower. And stock prices, especially technology and financial service company shares, made a broad advance. 
 Analysts said the jobs report provided more evidence that the economy, which barreled ahead in the summer, is slowing down, reducing the need for the Federal Reserve Board to raise short-term interest rates later this month.
"The odds have certainly tilted against any action" by the Fed, said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "There is not a very compelling case to do anything right now."
Bond yields moved lower within minutes after the employment report was released, continuing a dramatic downward spiral that began less than two weeks ago.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.05 percent from 6.10 percent Thursday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, rose 19/32, to 101 1/32.
Stock prices moved sharply higher early in the session, but gave up some of the gains later in the day. Despite the selling, the closing numbers remained impressive.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 46.34 points, or 1.5 percent, to 3,102.29. It was the sixth consecutive record high for the Nasdaq, which closed above the 3,000 level for the first time on Wednesday.
Gains of more than 2 points in American Express and J. P. Morgan helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average by 64.84 points, or 0.61 percent, to 10,704.48. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.59, or 0.56 percent, to 1,370.23. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks gained 2.51, or 0.57 percent, to 442.41.
Since the start of the bond market rally on Oct. 26, the Dow average has gained just under 4 percent, the S.& P. 500 is up nearly 7 percent, and the Nasdaq has risen 10 percent.
The gains were recorded on heavy trading. Just over a billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Nasdaq was 1.33 billion shares, the sixth busiest session in its history.
The decline in interest rates has measurably improved the mood of investors in the stock market. For the week, the Nasdaq composite index rose 4.6 percent. Elsewhere, the S.& P. 500 managed only a half a percent increase. And the Dow Jones industrial average, which added four new stocks this week, lost ground, falling 25.38 points, or two-tenths of a percent.
The data this week appear to make it less likely that Fed policy makers will vote to raise short-term interest rates at a meeting scheduled for Nov. 16. But some economists said there is still a chance that the central bank could tighten monetary policy. And traders said that at this point, stocks could be vulnerable to such a move.
"You can make a case that with the weakening in housing indicators, the decline in car sales and the October employment data, things are slowing down," said Stephen Slifer, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "But we are still looking for a tightening."
Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company, said that if the stock market "gets the news we expect, which is that the Fed is standing pat, we are poised to go back through 11,000" on the Dow industrial average.
"But if we get too far ahead of ourselves and get a disappointment in the form of a rate hike," Mr. Hogan added, "we have set ourselves up for a fall."
Telecommunications equipment makers, financial service companies and retailers were among the biggest winners in the stock market. But it was a bad day for big oil stocks.
Qualcomm, the cell phone technology developer, jumped 30 3/8, to a record 294 5/16. For the week, the stock gained 32 percent.
Motorola rose 7 13/16, to 114 5/16, after telling analysts in a conference call that it would be cutting costs over the next five years.
Among retailers, Wal-Mart and Home Depot, two Dow components, were particularly strong. Wal-Mart gained 2 1/16, to 58 1/16, and Home Depot was up 2, at 78.
A negative report on oil companies from Goldman, Sachs sent oil stocks lower. Exxon fell 2 3/8, to 70 5/8; Royal Dutch Shell shed 1 3/8, to 55 5/8; and BP Amoco dropped 1 1/4, to 52 5/16.
Worries about the damaging finding by the presiding judge in the government's antitrust case against Microsoft were not evident in the company's stock price yesterday. Microsoft closed at 91 5/8, down 1/8.

LENGTH: 436 words

HEADLINE: The Microsoft Findings

 BODY:
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's long-awaited conclusions in the Microsoft antitrust case were labeled as simple "findings of fact." But by declaring that the software giant built by Bill Gates had ruthlessly stifled competition and harmed consumers, Judge Jackson went further than most experts expected in declaring Microsoft guilty of misconduct as a monopoly. Mr. Gates and his stunned aides indicated that they intended to appeal the decision. But the sweeping nature of the finding suggests that Judge Jackson wants to provoke settlement talks between Microsoft and the government on possible remedies. A settlement would let the court avoid ordering a breakup of a company that has helped drive the growth of the American economy.
The long Microsoft trial yielded some riveting moments. But nothing in the trial was as dramatic as Judge Jackson's 207-page document. The case began as a Justice Department accusation that Microsoft's tying of its own browser to its Windows operating system was an attempt to stifle the rival browser produced by Netscape. Then Justice broadened the case by bringing in what it said was misconduct by Microsoft against other rivals and competitors. The most striking aspect of Judge Jackson's decision was that he accepted these other examples, declaring that the company had, as a factual matter, engaged in anti-competitive conduct against Netscape, I.B.M., Compaq and other giants in the computer and software business. 
 It remains now for Judge Jackson to lay out his findings as to possible violations of the law by Microsoft. These particulars should suggest whether the misconduct found by the judge requires a limited remedy of sanctions against the company, directives that it stop certain of its business practices, a much more radical restructuring or even breakup of the company.
As a practical matter, the task of drawing a sensible road map toward achieving a fully competitive playing field in the computer software business, one that encourages fair competition and rewards innovation, requires the cooperation of the best minds from Microsoft itself. That is why Mr. Gates must now ponder whether it is in the interest of his shareholders to fight the Justice Department with more appeals or enter into discussions that achieve these goals and also enhance the owners' investment in the company. Microsoft should fight for its rights under the law, but it should also recognize the sweeping nature of the government's victory. Certain facts about its behavior have now been established, and it is in everyone's best interest to achieve a solution.

HEADLINE: U.S. VERSUS MICROSOFT: NEW ANALYSIS;
Clear Finding in Blunt Language

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
With a 207-page legal document, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has fashioned a club and wielded it against the Microsoft Corporation.
In findings of fact that echo almost every one of the Government's accusations in its sweeping antitrust suit against the big software maker, Judge Jackson has concluded that Microsoft is a monopolist that time and again bullied other companies in the computer industry, harming consumers and hindering innovation. 
 "It's a bad day for Microsoft," observed William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school. "The judge relentlessly accepted the Government's story of what happened."
At times, Judge Jackson used carefully calibrated legal prose, but at the end of his findings he shifted to uncommonly blunt language.
Microsoft's actions, he said, conveyed the message that the company would use "its prodigious market power and immense profits to harm any firm" that chooses to compete with the company's mainstay products -- especially its corporate crown jewel, the Windows operating system, which acts as the equivalent of the central nervous system in more than 85 percent of personal computers sold today.
Before the findings of fact were released yesterday evening, legal experts had expected that Judge Jackson would generally favor the Government but also nod on occasion in Microsoft's direction. He had suggested in the past that he would prefer to broker an out-of-court settlement between Microsoft and the Government. Such an outcome would relieve the Federal courts of the burden of having to make fine-tuned decisions about products and business practices in the Internet economy.
A settlement is still a possibility -- but only, it seems, if William H. Gates, the company chairman, and his top lieutenants decide that Judge Jackson has done what no industry competitor ever accomplished: brought Microsoft to its knees.
Yet with these findings, antitrust experts say it is more likely that Microsoft will persevere, hoping that Judge Jackson's final ruling is not such a one-sided rout as yesterday's document might seem to portend. The company's next step might then be to appeal his decision to a federal appeals court and then perhaps the Supreme Court.
"If the judge's goal was settlement, he would have to leave enough ambiguity in the findings of fact so that neither side sees it as in its self interest to fight this to the bitter end," observed Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school, who is a leading antitrust scholar and is advising the Government.
There seems little that is ambiguous in Judge Jackson's document. "Having gone this far, I don't see Microsoft settling," said Andrew Gavil, a professor at the Howard University law school.
The judge's findings of fact are preliminary step and not a final ruling. But they form the all-but-unshakable foundation and framework for the outcome of the case -- either a legal judgment or a settlement. A court's legal judgment can be routinely overruled by a higher court on appeal. But findings of fact can be overturned only in the rare instance when the higher court finds a "blatant contradiction" between the written record of the case and a judge's finding.
"Judge Jackson has poured a lot of concrete here," said Mr. Kovacic of George Washington University.
The scope of the defeat that Microsoft suffered yesterday is illustrated by the way Judge Jackson dealt with one of the Government's main allegations: that Microsoft had tied its Web-browser software to its industry-standard Windows operating system merely to thwart the challenge posed by Internet software makers, especially the Netscape Communications Corporation, the commercial pioneer in software used for browsing the World Wide Web.
Microsoft had replied that it simply made a product-design decision to include browsing software in Windows, rather than make it a separate product. The company noted that it had added new features to Windows over the years, a strategy that it said had helped consumers by making computers easier to use.
Indeed, this product-tying claim by the Justice Department and 19 states who jointly sued Microsoft had appeared to suffer a sharp setback shortly after the suit was filed in May 1998. A month later, a federal appeals court ruled in a related case that Microsoft should be free to blend its browser into Windows as long as it can make a "plausible claim" of business efficiency or consumer benefit from doing so.
Despite the very high hurdle the appeals court had put in the way of a product-tying claim, Judge Jackson proceeded to find one. "In conclusion," he wrote on that subject, "the preferences of consumers and the responsive behavior of software firms demonstrate that Web browsers and operating systems are separate products." After reviewing Microsoft internal E-mail and licensing deals, he concluded that Microsoft had decided to "bind" its browser to Windows and give it away free mainly to hobble its rival Netscape "rather than for any pro-competitive purpose."
As his product-tying finding showed, Judge Jackson has accepted not only the Government's version of events but also its theory of the case. The Justice Department had consistently argued that while Microsoft operated in the high-technology economy, it was an old-fashioned monopolist. The practices at issue, the Government charged, are similar to those used since the turn-of-the-century days of smoke-filled railroad cars -- threats and restrictive business contracts forced on other companies.
Microsoft argued that the Government was launching an assault on the company's right to make its own product decisions, protect its own intellectual property and innovate as it saw fit. And the Government, Microsoft insisted, simply did not understand how the fast-paced software business worked.
But Judge Jackson agreed with the Government, and found Microsoft to be an old-fashioned monopolist.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: U.S. VERSUS MICROSOFT: THE REACTION;
Conceding Nothing, Gates Sees Finding As Only One Step

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Nov. 5

 BODY:
Smiling stiffly, conceding no predatory behavior whatsoever and insisting that Microsoft's actions had in fact "brought tremendous benefits to millions of consumers," William H. Gates defiantly took issue this evening with a federal judge's finding that the company had engaged in monopolistic behavior.
With the company he co-founded in 1975 under siege from the government, Mr. Gates appeared at a news conference at Microsoft headquarters here barely an hour after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued his finding. 
 While repeating assertions that Microsoft has always "wanted nothing more than to resolve this case," Mr. Gates, the chairman of the company, yielded no apparent ground on which a settlement might be reached.
"Microsoft competes vigorously and fairly," Mr. Gates said. "Americans should wish that every business was as competitive as the personal computer business."
There was little attempt to put a good face on the judge's findings, which Justice Department officials in Washington were hailing as a smashing victory for their side and for consumers across the country and even around the world.
Instead, the word throughout Microsoft was that this was simply a step in a process that is far from being resolved.
"To try to pick a winner, I think, is a dangerous business in any lawsuit, just like it is in a 9-inning ballgame or a 12-round championship fight," said William H. Neukom, Microsoft's general counsel and the architect of the company's legal strategy.
Anyone with even glancing knowledge of what the judge found would have the sense, here on the Microsoft campus, that Mr. Gates and other officials were looking at the same situation and seeing it in almost diametrically opposite terms.
Asked what the ruling would do to the company's stock when it resumes trading on Monday, Mr. Gates smiled and said: "Microsoft is not a prognosticator of the stock market -- not up, not down, not sideways. We're in the business of creating software."
Mr. Gates said he had spent the past several days in the midst of one of his so-called "think weeks," in which he typically retreats to a remote location and contemplates long-term strategy for improving existing products and developing new ones.
Mr. Gates seemed to make a point of saying that that would remain his main focus. "What we get excited about is building great software."
Microsoft's chief operating officer, Bob Herbold, asked whether the company was developing any contingency plans in case it ultimately faced drastic judicial remedies such as a forced breakup, vigorously shook his head no. He declined to speculate on any such remedies.
Said Mr. Neukom: "We continue to be fully confident that the law is favorable to the defense we have organized. We expect that at the end of the judicial process, Microsoft's position will be fully vindicated."
He also described the company as "not anti-competitive but pro-competitive," and added: "Microsoft does not live the so-called quiet life of a monopolist."
Mr. Gates, in a statement to reporters, said: "This lawsuit is fundamentally about one question: can a successful American company continue to improve its products for the benefit of consumers? That is precisely what Microsoft did by developing new versions of the Windows operating system with built-in support for the Internet.
"Paul Allen and I started Microsoft with the simple idea that technology can improve people's lives," he continued. "Over the past 25 years, Microsoft has helped create a broad industry of literally thousands of companies."
Microsoft's response was part of the prolonged and sometimes controversial public-relations offensive that the company has been conducting since the Justice Department started pursuing an antitrust action.
The company has repeatedly defended its actions. While government lawyers have portrayed the software maker as a rapacious monopolist, charging among other things that Microsoft has bundled its Internet browser to the Windows operating system as part of a predatory pricing scheme, the company said it was simply trying to make its products as user-friendly as possible. Windows is the dominant operating system, found in almost 9 of every 10 computers.
"There's a central principle in this lawsuit, and we have stood up for our ability to integrate new functionality, new capability into our products," Greg Shaw, a Microsoft spokesman, said today.
Microsoft has moved aggressively in advertising and lobbying blitzes, and even on its Web site, to rebut the government's case. The main page of the Web site, for instance, has a description of its "Freedom to Innovate Network," which it describes as a "nonpartisan, grass-roots network of citizens and business who have a stake in the success of Microsoft and the high-tech industry."
The pitch continues: "If you support the Freedom to Innovate, Sign up today! (Click here)"
In the company's depiction, "freedom" involves being able to do things like bundle a Web browser with Windows.
In addition, Microsoft has been lobbying Congress to enact laws that could protect the company in some of the very areas in which it is being sued. In its annual report issued in September, sent to two million shareholders, Mr. Herbold urged shareholders to join the lobbying effort.
Today's findings amount to another step in what is expected to be a fight that could end before the United States Supreme Court.
For Mr. Gates, the battle has taken no small personal toll, as he has watched his reputation as an innovator and business icon become sullied by charges that he is a bully and corporate predator, bent on destroying his competition.
In public, Mr. Gates has been fairly restrained, parsing out all the ways in which he believes the government's case is legally unwarranted and, in fact, most of the message he has tried to project was an optimistic one.
At a hearing in June before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee in Washington,, Mr. Gates waxed enthusiastically about the company's role in wireless networks and electronic commerce, which he said would turn "consumers into big winners."
Asked about the country's antitrust statutes, he said at the hearing that "the laws as they are currently written are fine," but he passed up the opportunity to blast the government, only stating his belief that "things like integration of new features are one of the freedoms companies have" under those laws.
He has also stepped up other activities that have put him in a favorable public light, including huge philanthropic donations for scholarships, libraries and international medical assistance and even an appearance late last year on the "Rosie O'Donnell Show," in which he discussed the intricacies of his then 2 1/2-year-old daughter's experience with potty training.
"She watches 'Once Upon a Potty,' " Mr. Gates told Ms. O'Donnell. "She's getting the concepts down but she's not quite there."
In private, friends have said, Mr. Gates is deeply angry about the government's antitrust action and has portrayed himself as the victim of a vendetta by disgruntled competitors who could not keep up with him and his company.

HEADLINE: The Gnomes of Santa Fe

BYLINE: By John Rothchild; John Rothchild, the author of "A Fool and His Money," writes frequently on financial matters.

 BODY:

THE PREDICTORS
 By Thomas A. Bass.
 309 pp. New York:
 Henry Holt & Company. $25. 
 THOMAS A. BASS has written an engaging account of the short life (so far) of the Prediction Company, owned and operated by maverick physicists in rafting sandals and T-shirts, who baby-sit a computer in Santa Fe, N.M. The computer is programmed to make serious financial bets, with cash provided by a large and once stodgy Swiss bank. That bankers in pinstripes and wingtips have risked sizable sums on this quirky enterprise in the desert says a lot about what's happening on the frontier of finance.
The central characters, Doyne Farmer and Norman Packard, abandoned comfortable jobs (Packard at a university, Farmer at a research lab) to start Prediction in 1991. Both in their 40's, they had few personal assets to draw on. Packard had never owned a house or a new car. Before they could incorporate, they held agonized discussions with the staff about the morality of capitalism. At one strategy session, Packard remarked, "Talking about cash flow, how are we going to pay for our sandwiches?"
They knew next to nothing about the stock and bond markets, but they knew a great deal about chaos theory. Part of an avant-garde of physicists called the Chaos Cabal, Farmer and Packard had studied the helter-skelter of cascading rapids, falling snowflakes, measles epidemics -- even Italian politics. Where traditional scientists saw random turbulence, beyond the scope of "linear" Newtonian analysis, the Chaos Cabal saw intriguing patterns. They could stick a probe into running water at the top end of a pipe and predict the spatter of droplets and spume farther down.
This was interesting to hydraulic engineers, but it wasn't making anybody rich. Then sometime in the mid-1980's, when computers had linked banks, trading floors and investment houses on six continents, and billions of dollars sloshed through cyberspace around the clock, it occurred to Farmer that money flow was a lot like fluid flow. If he and Packard could find patterns in running water, why couldn't they find patterns in the crests, eddies and sinkholes of the Dow Jones industrials, Treasury bonds or Japanese yen? Eureka!
Bass, the author of several books, including "The Eudaemonic Pie" (about Farmer and Packard's scheme to beat the odds in Las Vegas), takes a cue from his subjects and tells the story in nonlinear fashion. With frequent and informative digressions, he moves back and forth from Prediction headquarters to the trading pits of Chicago to recent and ancient attempts to foretell the future ups and downs of markets. Isaac Newton himself, who lost much of his wealth in the London crash of 1720, lamented the inability of his beloved science to predict it. "I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of crowds."
Bass takes us forward again to three meetings held in Santa Fe in the late 1980's, where chaos physicists and traditional economists debated theories. The physicists chided the economists for continuing to rely on shopworn Newtonian concepts, the source of rotten forecasting of financial turbulence for nearly three centuries. Farmer gave a speech at the first gathering that intrigued the Citicorp chief executive, John Reed, who was in attendance. Reed's bank was choking on sour third-world loans, and his well-paid economists hadn't warned of this deadbeat debacle.
A long middle stretch of the narrative is devoted to the physicists' search for a partner with a bankroll. Though Reed's Citicorp is an obvious choice, Farmer and Packard decide to knock on other doors. They get serious interest, if not outright offers, from the Bank of America, PaineWebber, Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Meanwhile, back at Prediction headquarters, the staff tweaks and twiddles the computer, force-feeding it endless bytes of data, hoping it will regurgitate a betting system that wins. So far, it has made brilliant mock trades in various anachronistic simulations, but as soon as it starts trading in the present, it loses.
A lot of commentators have said Wall Street is like a casino, but "The Predictors" is the best description yet of how futures, options and more esoteric derivatives have turned world finance into a casino. Moreover, the financial casino is attracting the same players who tried to outsmart Las Vegas 25 years ago. Back then, Farmer and Packard stuffed tiny computers into their shoes and began a high-tech attack on the blackjack tables and roulette wheels. Glitches undid them, and they returned to salaried employment. Now, in their search for a bankroll, they reconnect with cronies from the "beat the dealer" days who manage billion-dollar hedge funds. They end up in a partnership with a Chicago trading house, O'Connor & Associates. The boss there, David Weinberger, had earlier used chaos theory to bet on football.
In 1992, as the Prediction Company is absorbed into O'Connor, O'Connor is absorbed into the Swiss Bank Corporation. Conservative bankers are caught up in the casino along with everybody else: betting on blips can be more profitable than banking. Weinberger's minions at O'Connor, mostly 20-something traders, take over top positions in the firm that just bought them, and within a year they've helped turn Swiss Bank into one of the top players in derivatives worldwide. Soon thereafter, Swiss Bank swallows the Union Bank of Switzerland, that nation's largest. Union has got in trouble, proving that betting on blips can also be more dangerous than banking.
At this point, Prediction's computer is making big bets with the Swiss bankers' money. On the most important point -- results -- Bass is ambiguous. After his exciting buildup, we want to know how much the chaos system has won or lost, and whether it is doing better or worse than George Soros, the Dow Jones industrials or the dartboard. All we learn is that it went on a losing streak and then a hot streak, and that after 1995 it met its quarterly objectives. We never find out what those objectives were. Since Bass got full access to almost everything (he's on the scene through countless meetings, getting long quotations, describing what the physicists think and feel and eat for lunch), perhaps he had to agree in advance not to reveal the bottom line. No matter. I suspect that if the Prediction people have found what Bass calls the holy grail of market forecasting, we'll see Farmer and Packard on the Forbes magazine list of richest Americans. So far, they haven't appeared there. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: 'Stiffed'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To state, as Judith Shulevitz does in her review of Susan Faludi's "Stiffed" (Oct. 3), that "you would never know from 'Stiffed' that American economic growth is the highest it's been in a quarter-century and unemployment the lowest" is to miss entirely the key feature of the postindustrial economy. Aggregate economic indicators tell us very little about the lives of working people today. In the global economy, national economic growth and high corporate profits are often built upon a lean and mean workplace with no job security and weakened benefits packages. Unemployment statistics tell us even less. Postindustrial economic fear is not driven by the availability of jobs so much as the nature of the jobs available. People fear that if they get laid off, their next job will not provide adequate wages or benefits. 
 Also, in arguing that addressing "the plight of the male blue-collar worker" requires him "to change, to develop qualities he might not have thought of as masculine, like the ability to communicate effectively, as well as . . . entrepreneurial skill," Shulevitz serves only to blame the victim. The basic underlying issue is that employers in the postindustrial economy have discovered a way to rid themselves of that pesky social contract America once had in the postwar period.
 
Nancy Wiefek
State College, Pa.

HEADLINE: Development In Chelsea

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I am a former member of Manhattan Community Board No. 5 and my current duties directly impact upon more than 1 million rent-regulated units housing nearly 3 million New York City tenants. As such I was astounded by the statement by Kevin A. Finnegan, co-chairman of Community Board No. 5's land-use and zoning committee "In the Flower District, a Crop of High-Rises, Oct. 10 that the 2,000 apartments planned for Chelsea will cause rents to rise and thus accelerate the pressure on existing Chelsea tenants. This statement exemplifies the muddled reasoning that has afflicted this city's urban planning for far too long. 
 Residential/commercial development certainly may raise quality of life concerns. It may increase vehicular and pedestrian traffic, generate more noise and garbage due to ancillary services, strain existing schools and subway stations, block sunlight, etc. Still, the one thing that masses of additional apartments will not do is to cause demand/prices for existing units to rise. Indeed, it is elemental (and instinctive to those familiar with New York City's tight housing market) that thousands and thousands of new units are needed to relieve competition for existing ones.
The demand for housing south of 96th Street in Manhattan arguably is more acute than ever before. Unless Mr. Finnegan and others intend to insist that only they have a right to live in those highly desirable neighborhoods, I suggest he welcome such development rather than condemn it with proclamations that can't withstand even the most mild economic analysis.
 
EDWARD S. HOCHMAN
Chairman
New York City
Rent Guidelines Board
Manhattan

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Altered Itineraries As the World Heats Up

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
IT probably isn't necessary to cancel or change vacation plans just yet, but global warming -- if it develops as forecast -- promises in time to revise travelers' lists of preferred destinations.
A warmer, more pleasant England, for instance, might replace an extremely hot Greece as a summer vacation spot of choice. Beachgoers, skiers, scuba divers, autumn leaf-peepers, anglers and just plain sightseers all may have to find new places to go, and some of today's prized destinations may wither as new ones blossom. 
 Or so says a recent study conducted for the World Wildlife Fund by the Climatic Research Unit of the University of East Anglia in England.
The average annual surface temperature of the globe has already risen by about 1 degree or a little more over the last century; in many parts of the Northern Hemisphere, the warming has been much greater.
Computer models of the atmosphere forecast a further rise of 2 to 6 degrees over the next century, with a best estimate of about 3.5 degrees, if industry and motor vehicles continue to spew heat-trapping carbon dioxide into the air at today's rates. By comparison, the world is 5 to 9 degrees warmer now than in the depths of the last ice age 18,000 to 20,000 years ago.
Some regions would warm more, some less, and some may actually cool. But in any region where the average annual temperature rises, climate experts say, high summer temperatures are expected to become even higher. In general, climatic zones would shift northward in the Northern Hemisphere, southward in the Southern, and from lower to higher altitudes globally. And everywhere, the sea level would rise -- by about 20 inches globally over the century, according to best estimates -- with potentially grave consequences for beach resorts.
Projections of this sort are inherently chancy, but they are all that scientists have to go on. So the climate experts at East Anglia used computer models to look at the possible effect of global warming on 10 of the world's favorite tourist destinations over the next century. And while the study was geared toward Britons, it has relevance for Americans, as well.
Some of the findings:
* Rising seas and a subsequent increase in beach erosion could eliminate many beaches and even submerge large parts of some popular islands, like the Maldives. Florida could be particularly vulnerable to beach erosion, the study said. Some Caribbean islands could be similarly affected, said David Viner, a co-author of the study.
* Higher temperatures could kill coral ecosystems, eliminating scuba-diving meccas from the Caribbean to the Maldives.
* Ski resorts at lower elevations, like those at Garmisch in Germany and Kitz buhel in Austria, might suffer from less snow, causing skiers to crowd higher-elevation resorts. Similar shifts could take place in North America.
* Rising temperatures could encourage the spread of malaria from North Africa to southern Spain.
* Hotter summers in the eastern Mediterranean, where the number of days with temperatures higher than 100 degrees would increase, may discourage summer visits to Greece and Turkey. But summer weather in England should become warmer and more reliable, encouraging many Britons to stay home and attracting more foreign visitors.
In many tourist areas, the study said, warmer temperatures might stimulate disease outbreaks, more forest fires and more air pollution.
A warming climate, Mr. Viner said, could shift the range of some sport fish; in the United States, anglers pursuing these fish make major contributions to local economies. Trout and salmon, for instance, are cold-water fish, and previous studies have shown that their habitat and range could be substantially reduced as streams warm up. On the other hand, the range of warm-water species like bass could expand.
Studies have also suggested that in New England, trees with relatively dull fall colors, like oaks and hickories, could eventually move up from the Middle Atlantic and replace the brilliant maples that draw crowds of foliage admirers every autumn.
How soon might these consequences be felt? Assuming the forecasts are reasonably accurate, it depends largely on whether climate change proceeds smoothly or in abrupt temperature jumps.
One example of how global warming might be a mixed blessing: In Alaska, where substantial warming has already taken place, the tourist season has been lengthened. But if it gets warm enough, the thawing of Alaska could eliminate many of the subarctic charms that make it so attractive. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 2339 words

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Chicago's New Fare: French, Mexican, Flamboyant

BYLINE: By DENNIS RAY WHEATON; DENNIS RAY WHEATON is the chief dining critic at Chicago magazine.

 BODY:
IN a thriving local economy punctuated by the clamor of new construction near the Loop, Chicago is enjoying a surge in fine restaurants. French food or cuisine with strong French underpinnings is in the vanguard. In neighborhoods where Italian trattorias have long been as regularly spaced as mailboxes, everyday-priced bistros now also dot the landscape.
The chefs at five of the best new places also own their establishments. They represent a generation of local talent that has been enormously influenced by Chicago's culinary pioneers -- Charlie Trotter, Rick Bayless, Gordon Sinclair and Jean Joho among them -- in whose kitchens they honed their skills. 

Tru
The most acclaimed, spectacular -- and expensive -- restaurant to hit Chicago in years, Tru has further energized the already flourishing dining scene in the affluent Streeterville neighborhood downtown. The soaring white room boasts large, well-spaced tables and original art (with works by Mapplethorpe and Warhol, among others). Museum-style glass cases display seasonal produce, on one visit an abundance of late-season Tuscan black truffles. Other notable design touches include padded stools for resting purses tableside and frosted-glass automatic sliding doors muffling the bustle from the huge high-tech kitchen. Yet the atmosphere is lighthearted, and the staff couldn't be more accommodating.
What is most captivating about Tru is the irrepressible creative energy of Rick Tramonto and Gale Gand, the married couple who own the restaurant in partnership with deep-pocketed Rich Melman of the Lettuce Entertain You restaurant empire. After winning accolades for their work in London and New York, Ms. Gand and Mr. Tramonto joined forces at a number of establishments in the Chicago area, opening Tru this year. Mr. Tramanto oversees the savory side of the menu, while Ms. Gand handles desserts; both create delicious original dishes that look as if they belong in an art museum.
Steeped in French technique, Mr. Tramonto also knows his way around Italian and Asian cuisines. A good example is his seared hamachi (yellowtail) served in a little pool of tomato reduction and topped with sweated onions and bracing freshly grated wasabi.
Ingenious creations illustrate the playful, sensuous luxury of Tru's multiple-course a la carte and tasting menus -- often in startling juxtapositions that show more than a bit of the prankster. On one visit, a trio of cleverly garnished fish tartares were served on a polished mirror; another time they were in a large martini glass positioned in a bowl of water around which swam a flamboyant blue Siamese fighting fish. A theatrical curved glass staircase holds on each step one of four different caviars or traditional garnishes. Mr. Tramonte likes to serve frothy "cappuccino" soups, on one visit an ethereal creamless cauliflower and truffle blend, in exquisite Versace cups.
Mr. Tramonto also thinks up new ways to boost foie gras; a recent stunner was an aspic-coated terrine of foie gras with truffle butter and peppered pineapple relish. Venison with chocolate sauce and a robust rutabaga puree is an adventure for meat lovers. A rare off-note was a black truffle risotto studded with diced lobster and fava beans; the rice was several stirs shy of perfection in texture.
Tru's broadly priced 450-bottle list is impressive for such a new restaurant, but our party of four let the sommelier, R. Scott Tyree, recommend wines by the glass.
Ms. Gand's seasonal fruit creations are excellent, and she revels in humorous plays on American sweets. Pairing a gooey chocolate fudge tart and caramelized banana with cabernet caramel sauce and peanut butter ice cream to evoke peanut butter and jelly, she elevates quintessential childhood flavors to a high-wire act. But then, the whole experience at Tru is a culinary Cirque du Soleil.
 
Grace
Yes, that's a halo on the logo of Grace, the latest entry in the flowering of upscale restaurants in the Market District just west of Chicago's Loop. It's a softly lighted, sleek space done in grays and browns with exposed brick muted by sheer curtains. Some tables, butcher paper-topped over a white cloth, are shoehorned in so tightly that they require a contortionist's skill to navigate.
Grace is packed nightly with a stylish crowd in dark suits or cool casual attire savoring the robustly flavored food of Ted Cizma, the chef and owner. Mr. Cizma offers several game dishes nightly; they are typically served with well-balanced, fruit and herb flavored sauces, as are the appealing seafood choices. A recent gratis opener was cold smoked boar finished with white peach relish and red pepper coulis.
On a recent evening, an appetizer of crisp lamb sweetbread nuggets with lamb jus was terrific on its bed of wilted bitter greens dotted with Maytag blue goat cheese. A warm lobster salad offered big morsels of the tender crustacean along with baby beet tops and lotus root accented with shellfish oil. For the main course, sliced wood-grilled saddle of rabbit garnished with fresh figs and sauteed spinach was brightened with a fragrant parsley puree. Juicy, mellow wild boar showed up again, this time herb-crusted, grilled and set over polenta seasoned with cheddar, cinnamon, and chilies surrounded by nectarine compote. Tuna grilled rare came on whole wheat noodles with a zingy crushed peanut and horseradish vinaigrette.
For dessert, a satiny huckleberry goat's-milk cheesecake answered a berry lover's prayers, but a strawberry-mint mascarpone tart was burdened by a soggy crust. The 100-selection list includes good half bottles, such as a brisk, toasty Murphy-Goode Fume Blanc Alexander Valley Reserve ($15) that perfectly graced the lobster and tuna.
 
Ixcapuzalco
An English speaker's tongue tangles trying to pronounce the name (EEKS-cah-pu-SAL-co), but this restaurant offers terrific regional Mexican food. It's a lively storefront with a yellow awning in the Logan Square neighborhood northwest of the Loop, which is still gritty but gradually being gentrified. Geno Bahena, formerly of Frontera Grill, has now set up his own shop.
Mr. Bahena's cooking and presentation fall somewhere between the casual air of Rick Bayless's Frontera Grill and the more refined style of his adjoining Topolobampo. The aroma of the earthy herb epazote filled the air as my wife and I entered the bouncing cedar-paneled 40-seat room, which once housed a gyro joint. Dramatic Mexican masks look out from over the tiny open red-tiled kitchen; the walls are adorned by vivid original paintings by Oscar Romero and reproductions of Frida Kahlo's works, with a backing of romantic Mexican ballads. Flowers, copper plates and big carved wooden chairs add to the charm. A shot of premium mescal and a fine margarita, shaken tableside, made perfect openers.
Mr. Bahena hails from the Pacific Mexican state of Guerrero, one of the most purely Indian regions of Mexico. Ixcapuzalco is his hometown, where he was raised on his family's ranch and orchard; a number of the cooks are also from there.
Oaxaca is known as the "Land of the Seven Moles," and Ixcapuzalco features each on a different day. Mr. Bahena sends out his moles bathing a choice of chicken or duck breast, and sometimes also quail or fish.
We tried Sunday's mole negro with medium rare duck breast; the deeply fragrant complexity of the sauce, which is almost black and spicy-sweet, is explained by 20 different ingredients, including several kinds of dried chilies, sesame seeds, plantains and cinnamon-flavored Mexican chocolate. That black mole was so good that I decided to work my way eventually through all seven, including Friday's dark red mole made from Mr. Bahena's grandmother's recipe.
In his other dishes, Mr. Bahena also favors poultry. Pheasant marinated in adobo spices is served with roasted tomato sauce and red-chili enchiladas. The leg was tough but the breast was perfect.
Mr. Bahena knows his way around seafood. A scintillating grilled cactus salad featured smoked tuna with roasted poblano and smoky chipotle chilies, and splendid Guerrero-style ceviche made with lime-marinated marlin arrived atop crisp tortilla triangles along with manzanilla olives, tomato, cilantro and serrano chilies.
A warm individual pineapple upside cake was lovely with brown butter caramel, mango ice cream and a generous scattering of blueberries. From the brief but well-matched wine list, we chose a fresh red Italian Barbera d'Alba Grasso ($24) from the great 1997 vintage.
 
MK The Restaurant
 Michael Kornick was a pioneer in revitalizing the old Market District before going to the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston and other top posts. Now he is luring a fashionable food-loving crowd to the still rather bleak but up-and-coming far north end of River North with his new restaurant, MK. Once a paint warehouse, the interior has been done in soothing shades of tan, cream and charcoal with exposed brick and original wood trusses under angled skylights.
Mr. Kornick likes artisanal cheeses and incorporates them into several appetizers. Rich ravioli, filled with melted chevre produced by Laura Chenel in Sonoma County, had a buttery sauce with rosemary and organic tomatoes; a zesty Belgian endive and French bean salad with toasted pecans and apples featured Carles brand Roquefort. I also savored coarsely minced tuna tartare on tangy celery root remoulade, accompanied with anchovies, capers and oil-cured olives.
While slabs of foie gras seem as common as exposed bricks these days in fine restaurants, not so old-fashioned calf's liver. But Mr. Kornick handles it masterfully, sauteing thin slices and serving them in a explosively pungent sauce of stone-ground mustard and 25-year-old balsamic vinegar under crisp applewood-smoked bacon and savory "burnt" Vidalia onions. I'm seeing a lot of guinea hens on Chicago menus, few better than MK's herbal pan-roasted beauty served with a Tuscan bread salad flavored with Lucini olive oil, basil and garlic.
A full-bodied 1995 Gigondas by Aline Bonfils ($38) stood up to both entrees.
Michael Kornick wisely brought over his pastry chef, Mindy Segal, from Marche, where he worked previously. She makes for a stellar ending with her cleverly fashioned desserts, such as the petite banana cream pie in a chocolate shell accompanied by a little banana-mascarpone cake with banana sherbet.
 
Savarin
The best new explicitly French restaurant to open lately in Chicago is the year-old Savarin, named for the celebrated French gastronome Anthelme Brillat-Savarin. It is a serious restaurant that focuses the mind on what's on the plate, helped along by a decor of gilt-frame mirrors on forest green walls, white pillars and woodwork, as well as an excellent service staff.
John Hogan has for years been among the finest French-oriented chefs in the city. Savarin moves from lovingly executed bistro classics -- onion soup, salade lyonnaise, braised rabbit, poulet grand-mere -- to more elevated and original French cuisine.
Satiny chicken liver pate is often a complimentary opener. Still, we always carefully consider the daily foie gras preparation -- perhaps stuffed with cabbage into a ballotine of boned pheasant and served with a slab of seared foie gras in an intense port-truffle sauce; or seared with French butter pears, caramelized pepper and a Gewurztraminer reduction. Another favorite is the triangle of delicate crab mousse wrapped in slices of smoked sturgeon.
For the main course we always look at the plat du jour; on a recent Wednesday I lucked into duck breast roasted medium rare paired with mahogany-brown braised leg and thigh and served with turnips and prunes in an Armagnac sauce. My companion enjoyed peerless bistro steak frites, the steak topped with parsley butter and buried in a haystack of thin crisp fries. Among daily fish offerings in the past year were whole turbotin (small turbot) braised with vermouth and fine herbs and seared sea scallops in a truffled broth with chanterelles and baby spinach leaves.
From a large, well-chosen wine list we selected a fine light 1997 Morgon DuBoeuf Beaujolais ($25).
When it is available, I order Wendy Kaplan's sauteed pear napoleon with goat cheese ice cream. As with most everything on the menu at Savarin, it's a real chore to find a disappointment.
 
Bill of fare
All these restaurants accept major credit cards. At Grace, MK and Savarin, smoking is allowed only in the bar or lounge. Tru permits no smoking at all; Ixcapuzalco is planning to open a separate room for smokers on Tuesday.
Reservations are essential at Tru -- two months ahead is not too soon for weekends and for the kitchen table -- and strongly recommended at the others.
Except for Tru, dinner prices are for two with a modest bottle of wine, but not tax or tip.
Grace, 623 West Randolph Street, (312) 928-9200. Dinner Monday through Saturday, lunch Monday through Friday. Valet parking ($7). Dinner for two, about $100.
Ixcapuzalco, 2919 North Milwaukee Avenue, (773) 486-7340. Lunch and dinner daily except Tuesday. Parking is usually available on the street. Dinner for two, about $80.
MK The Restaurant, 868 North Franklin Street, (312) 482-9179. Lunch Monday through Friday; dinner daily. Dinner for two, about $110.
Savarin, 713 North Wells Street, (312) 255-9520. Dinner daily, about $100.
Tru, 676 North St. Clair Street, (312) 202-0001. Dinner Monday through Saturday. Valet parking. Tru has several menus. A three-course prix fixe menu costs $70 a person. Four tasting menus, called "collections," of six to nine courses range from $75 (all vegetable) to $125 for a spontaneous chef's collection "designed to create sensory overload." The kitchen table, seating four to six, costs $150 a person. Wines start around $45 a bottle. Jackets are required. For parking in this dense urban area, valets will have your name in their own reservation book; the cost is a steep $8, but your car will be curbside when you leave.
