HEADLINE: Commercial Property /The Market;
Office Space Is Scarce, and Getting More Expensive

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
WE are already seeing triple-digit rents at the upper end of the midtown market," said an ebullient Steven Swerdlow, the senior managing director of CB Richard Ellis's New York office, referring to the $100 a square foot annual rents reported for the buildings at 712 and 767 Fifth Avenue.
Mr. Swerdlow cautions that stratospheric rent levels are likely to be confined to a few trophy buildings on Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, but he said the figure expresses the tone of the office market in Manhattan: space is scarce and it is getting more expensive. 
 The strength of the market is such that some real estate executives say it may prompt something not seen in this decade, new construction without a government subsidy.
The situation is the result of a booming economy that has produced nearly 79,000 private sector jobs in the city over the last 12 months. Unlike past expansions that were largely fueled by the financial services industry, much of the current growth is the result of industries that did not exist in previous cycles, such as new media and other Internet-related activities.
The importance of these companies, and the telecommunications firms that are also multiplying, cannot be underestimated, said John Powers, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company. Through the end of September, he said, these companies accounted for 35 percent of the space leased this year in Midtown South and 12 percent of the space downtown.
William G. Cohen, an executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, said the new computer-based companies are transforming whole neighborhoods. Many are lumped together under the rubric of "dot com" after the last part of their Internet addresses.
"The dot com's are driving the Park Avenue South and Garment District markets," he said. "They are all out there looking for 10,000 square feet in move-in condition." Examples of these transactions include Media Matrix, which took 10,000 square feet at 250 Park Avenue South at 20th Street; Fortune City.com, which signed up for 22,600 square feet at 500 Seventh Avenue at 37th Street, and Screaming Media, which took 26,000 square feet in the Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street.
These companies are largely selling the skills of their highly educated, generally younger employees, and they go to considerable effort to recruit and retain them. Many are attracted to the culture and nightlife of big cities, a bonus for New York. A recent national survey commissioned by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company, found that "computer services professionals chose New York more frequently than any other city when asked where they would most like to work."
Broader measures of leasing activity showed the strength of the market as well. "The Manhattan office market posted strong results in the third quarter and is now poised to end the decade with the lowest vacancy rates and highest asking rents since the early 1980's," according to the Cushman & Wakefield report.
And because there has been little new building in Manhattan in the last decade, the report noted that the upward part of the real estate cycle is likely to be extended.
The overall vacancy rate in Manhattan fell to 7.4 percent in the third quarter, the lowest rate in the decade, with space in Class A buildings even tighter at 5 percent, according to the report. The average asking rent increased to $39.44 a square foot annually from $32.89 at the comparable time in 1998.
Average asking rents in midtown broke the $40-a-foot barrier, increasing to $41.57, while those in Midtown South -- once not considered a prime office district -- are expected to top $30 a square foot before the end of the year. Average asking rents downtown are already over $30 a square foot, reaching $32.95 in the third quarter.
ASKING rents only tell part of the story, since other lease terms have an effect on the total cost of a deal. Funds provided by landlords for the construction of interior space -- called work letters -- have been shrinking and the period of free rent growing steadily shorter, brokers say.
"Work letters have been declining from $50 a square foot a few years ago to $30 and under now," Mr. Powers said. "That adds to rent," he said, because tenants have to bear more of the cost of building their space. In the early 90's, when landlords were almost desperate to lure tenants, a year to a year and a half of free rent on a 10-year lease was common. Now. he said, "tenants are lucky to get the time of construction" during which they are not actually occupying the space and are paying rent somewhere else.
Although office rents seem lofty compared to those in the mid-1990's, they have just recovered the losses of the early part of the decade, real estate executives say. "Nominal rents are back to the 1980 level," said Mr. Swerdlow. "Adjusted for inflation, we are still not back to that level."
Averages are useful for tracking trends in the market, but they also obscure localized developments by blending the highs and lows of a market. More important, some real estate executives say, is the fact that rents in some parts of Manhattan have reached the level where nonsubsidized new construction is economically feasible.
"It takes rent of about $65 a square foot to justify new construction without a subsidy and we have just gotten there in some parts of town," said Thomas Falus, president of Cushman & Wakefield's New York metropolitan area operations.
He noted that the new buildings in the Times Square area and the ones planned at Columbus Circle all involved assistance from government entities.
"We have over a dozen clients who are looking to do something with land that is dormant or underutilized," he said. "There is a lot of land in the pipeline and the question is whether it will be developed in an orderly fashion over the next 24 to 36 months or come out in a rush."
He said it would be useful if 4 million to 5 million square feet of office space were built over the next few years, noting that it would add only about 1 percent to Manhattan's inventory.
The capital markets are prepared to finance new construction as long as certain conditions are met, said John D. Lyons, the executive managing director of Granite Partners, a real estate finance company. "The capital is there to finance new construction as long as it is a quality project with ample preleasing," he said.
Unlike the early 1980's, when lenders were willing to finance new construction on a purely speculative basis, today's investors want a high level of assurance that the buildings will be occupied once completed, he said.
And while real estate investment trusts have diminished as a factor in the market, another class of investors, known as opportunity funds, has arisen to take their place. "Opportunity funds have raised $29 billion in capital in the first three quarters of this year," he said. "REIT's at their height in 1997 only raised $37 billion."
REIT investment in the city has declined by 12 percent since the third quarter of 1998 while private investors increased their presence in the city by 27 percent, accounting for almost half the total office transactions through the third quarter.
With the leasing market strong, buildings in Manhattan have held their value or increased in price. According to Granite, buildings in Midtown South increased 7 percent to an average of $157 a square foot over the same time last year, while those in midtown held at $197 a square foot and those downtown remained at an average of $122 a square foot.
While declining vacancies and rising rental rates are good news for owners of property, the situation can be difficult for brokers whose business depends on finding space and making deals.
"This is a very frustrating market to work in," said Robert Emden, an executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis who specializes in midtown properties. "You have to canvass the market to find out where space is going to become available before it hits the market. Once it is on the market, it's old news."

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Going to School on Saturday, to Learn Things Hungarian

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
On a beautiful fall Saturday recently, most youngsters were enjoying the last of the good weather with their friends. But 61 young people traveled to New Brunswick, as they do every Saturday during the school year, to attend classes at the Szechenyi Hungarian Saturday School and Kindergarten.
In addition to learning the language -- most classes are taught in Hungarian --they learn about Hungarian history, culture, geography and literature. All of the children, from kindergartners to teenagers, either immigrated to the United States from Hungary with their families or are first-generation Americans. 
 Zoltan E. Koller, a civil engineer who teaches history at the school, recently talked about its mission.
Q. Why was the school formed?
A. A large number of Hungarians came to the United States at the turn of the century for economic reasons, and another large wave came after the 1956 revolution, which was the first organized, armed revolt against Communism. Many of the ones who came at the turn of the century were drawn to this area to work in the factories and mills. Then, within a few months after the 1956 revolution ended in November, 250,000 people left Hungary. At least 100,000 of them came to the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut-Pennsylvania region, and many of those came to New Brunswick, where there was already a large Hungarian community. The 1990 census counted 40,000 Hungarians in Middlesex County alone.
Now, some of the families have moved away from this immediate area, but the children still come here for classes. We have one family from Pennsylvania and one from Garden City, N.Y., who come every Saturday.
Q. Who is the school named after?
A. Istvan Szechenyi was a rich Hungarian born in 1791 who helped initiate reform movements in the 1820's and 30's. A writer, economist and politician, he helped finance a lot of the modernization of the country at that time, including building the first fixed bridge between Buda and Pest.
Q. What do you hope to accomplish through the school?
A. It is important for the children to learn the language, to know of their past and where they came from. They learn more about themselves, and they learn the American culture by being able to look at it from the vantage point of another culture. In addition to learning their heritage, I think it makes the children more tolerant of all people and of their differences.
We can all learn from the past and a knowledge of their history grounds them. The Hungarian Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Geza Jeszenszky, was here Oct. 23 to mark the 43rd anniversary of the 1956 revolution. He laid a wreath on a Hungarian memorial in New Brunswick. Until recently, any commemoration of the revolution was forbidden in Hungary, so this was an important event. The ceremony also marked the 10th anniversary of Hungary converting from a socialist country to a democratic republic.
Q. How do Hungarian children celebrate the holidays?
A. On the Monday after Easter, the tradition is for young boys to sprinkle the girls with water and in return the girls give the boys an egg. The tradition has its roots in an ancient pagan fertility rite. It is still practiced by families here. Also at Easter, the tradition is to color eggs, but with elaborate folk paintings. People familiar with the art can distinguish Hungarian painted eggs from Ukrainian ones, for instance.
The custom around Christmas is for youngsters dressed as shepherds to sing Hungarian Christmas songs at homes and to get cake in return as thanks. St. Nicholas Day is Dec. 6 and is a gift-giving day separate from Christmas. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: Silicon Island, Wired but Underpopulated

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
FAYYAZ YOUNAS, a 26-year-old software engineer and SUNY Stony Brook graduate, was explaining how his penchant for risk had taken him from Long Island to Northern California's Silicon Valley when, as if on cue, an earthquake shook his Palo Alto, Calif., office.
"People here have a pretty healthy appetite for risk," Mr. Younas said as the mild tremor rattled sports equipment in the corner of his cubicle. His own career illustrates the claim. When his first Silicon Valley job, at the industry giant Sun Microsystems, became too routine, he left for Informatica, a younger, less established company. 
 Mr. Younas is just the kind of employee that many Long Island companies would love to lure back to the Island. Matthew Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, the area's largest business organization, estimates that as many as 10,000 technical jobs -- more than one in eight such jobs on the Island -- are unfilled for lack of qualified applicants. Business leaders say the severe shortage of high-tech workers threatens to derail efforts to turn the Island's tech sector into an economic cornerstone and could stunt the region's economic growth.
The flight of Long Island talent to better-known tech hot spots is only half of the problem, business leaders say. Even if every Long Island tech grad stayed on the Island, it still wouldn't close the gap. Many college-level technology classes at Long Island universities are underenrolled. Many young Long Islanders are leery of technical careers, having seen their parents or their friends' families fall victim to the layoffs of the late 1980's and early 1990's, when the region's defense industry imploded. Sixty thousand jobs, many of them in the high-tech sector, were lost.
Long Island's major universities annually produce only about 250 of the 1,000 engineers and about 350 of the 2,000 computer science majors the Island needs, said Yacov Shamash, acting vice president of economic development and dean of the College of Engineering and Applied Science at SUNY Stony Brook. Those numbers will be cut, at least in the short term, by Polytechnic University's recent decision to shut down its undergraduate program in Farmingdale, which annually produced more than 60 tech grads.
Virtually all industries on Long Island are suffering from a labor shortage as the region's economic boom continues Page 14 . But the situation is most critical in high-tech disciplines, and not just at companies like Computer Associates or Symbol Technologies. The crunch affects any company big enough to have a systems manager, a category that includes an ever-broader swath of Island businesses. In an increasingly computer- and Internet-driven economy, not having enough tech help can be a crippling disadvantage.
Mr. Crosson said there was no easy fix. "The fact that Long Island is not unique in this respect is one of the problems we have," he said. "We are in the midst of a very intense competition that is only going to become more pronounced as the years go by."
Economic developers, high-tech companies and educators are searching for creative initiatives to fill the deficit. One program sponsored by the Long Island Works Coalition, a nonprofit group established by the Long Island Association that includes businesses, other nonprofit groups, schools and universities, is intended to reach out to the best of the Island's scientifically oriented high school graduates, most of whom leave the area to pursue their technical degrees, Mr. Crosson said.
Early next year, Long Island high school teachers will be sent around the country to appeal to former students who are pursuing technical degrees out of state, Mr. Crosson said. With recruiters from local high-tech companies in tow, the teachers will try to encourage the students to return for jobs.
Details are still being worked out, but Mr. Crosson said he expects the Long Island tech companies that send the recruiters to foot the bill.
"The cost of relocating people unfamiliar with Long Island is even higher, so on balance, targeted recruitment of that kind could be very cost-effective," Mr. Crosson said. "The idea, of course, is that the kids who have gone off to college are recruited not just by a stranger from companies they've barely heard of, but by a teacher whom they know and trust."
On the success of such programs ride regional planners' hopes of achieving some kind of critical mass and distinct identity for the Island's high-tech industries. Forty percent of Long Island's 50 fastest-growing tech companies are in software and information technology, according to the consultancy Deloitte & Touche, and the various tech industries have replaced about a third of the lost defense jobs, according to the Long Island Association. But the Island lacks the labor-drawing power that a single strong identity gives high-tech regions such as Denver (communications), lower Manhattan (the Internet), Boston (electronics) or South San Francisco (biotechnology).
In recent years, the Long Island Association has focused on five technology industries -- biotechnology, medical imaging and health care information systems, graphic communications, computer software and emerging electronics. Now the coalition is narrowing its focus, Mr. Crosson said, in an effort to identify a blend of tech industries as the Island's own high-tech niche.
Planners and businesses are discussing at least a dozen combinations of tech industries. Among these is genomics, applying data from gene identification to develop new treatments against disease. Another is biocomputing, simulating biological processes to similarly develop new medicines and devices, in orthopedics, for instance.
While the search for a viable hybrid tech industry proceeds, efforts to shore up the Island's core tech industries continue. Weary of the departure of more than half a dozen biotechnology companies to hubs around the country, Huntington and Babylon are trying to create a 10-mile biotech corridor along Route 110, said Donald Middleton, the Town of Huntington deputy director of planning and environment.
"If there can be a Miracle Mile, there can be a golden 10-mile biotechnology center between Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory at the north end and the Broadhollow Bioscience Park that's being built at SUNY Farmingdale," Mr. Middleton said. "We're about 20 years behind what's been done in San Francisco, where the university system has served as an incubator, a catalyst, and that should have been done here a long time ago. I think the 110 corridor should be the hub of the biotechnology industry."
With SUNY Farmingdale and the private sector as partners, and the Long Island Regional Planning Board consulting, the two-month-old Route 110 Redevelopment Corporation is studying anticipated infrastructure challenges, Mr. Middleton said. About 110,000, or 20 percent of Suffolk's 550,000 jobs, are along Route 110, he said. To ease congestion, the project is considering a light rail system along the roadway and is recommending that more area businesses provide on-site day care.
Peter Goldsmith, chairman of the Long Island Software and Technology Network, is optimistic that word is spreading about Long Island's viability as a technology hub. As evidence he points to the sponsorship of the Great River-based Long Island Technology Center in recent weeks by Microsoft and Oracle, the largest software companies in the country. They signal the first time such large sponsors from outside the region have signed on, he said.
But developers will need more than real estate and a label, said John Putzier, president of the technology group at the Society of Human Resource Managers. "I hate to burst the balloon, but every community I go to today wants to put up this aura that they are technologically driven and they are the place to be, the destination of choice," Mr. Putzier said. "I went through an area this week called the Technology Corridor in West Virginia and it was nothing but open fields. It's becoming almost a cliche."
As local private- and public-sector groups wrestle with the labor shortages, the Island's high-tech companies are offering more perks and incentives to lure prospective employees and keep the workers they already have.
Islandia-based Computer Associates can feel more like a cruise ship than the third largest software company in the country. Workers can begin their day with free Continental breakfast and move on to aerobic step exercises in the fitness center, visit their children at the on-site day-care center, unwind with a little tennis or basketball and treat themselves to free dinner buffet.
This year the software giant revised its employee referral bonus, awarding $1,000 to $5,000 to employees who recruit talent versus the flat $600 it had paid, said Deborah Coughlin, senior vice president of human resources. As of late September, 311 referrals had turned into jobs compared with 145 for all of last year at the company's Islandia headquarters, where the company employs more than 3,000.
Jody O'Donnell, president of Relocation Solutions, a 10-year-old Northport company that advises clients on home purchases and other aspects of moving workers, said tech companies on Long Island and elsewhere were going to unprecedented lengths to bring talent on board.
More than ever, Ms. O'Donnell said, companies have been willing to pay the relocation penalties imposed when an employee abandons another company soon after the moving van leaves. One Long Island technology company recently paid the visa costs incurred by an out-of-state company whose recent hire changed his mind and accepted the Long Island post, Ms. O'Donnell said.
But the salaries paid to Long Island tech employees are not going to reverse the California Gold Rush. A computer engineer working on Long Island earns an average salary slightly higher than the national mean, though slightly lower than average salaries in such high-tech hotbeds as Austin, San Jose and Boston, according to the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. But Long Island computer programmers, to cite another example, don't fare as well.
Because high-tech companies in other regions are also raising salaries to stem their labor shortages, the Island's tech companies are hard-pressed to make their salaries stand out, Ms. O'Donnell said.
"Everyone is reacting to the same situation," she said. "They're all competing for the same employees."
The intense shortage is prompting the Long Island Association to enter the debate brewing in the United States Senate over whether to open the doors to more foreign high-tech labor, Mr. Crosson said. The association is likely to support a loosening of restrictions on foreign workers, he added.
In large measure, Mr. Crosson blames Long Island's technology companies for the flight of local talent. Local corporations are not awarding internships early enough or scholarships large enough to compete with other companies around the country, he asserted.
"In Silicon Valley, for example, companies are recruiting high school students as summer interns and then once they have identified kids who are potential employees and talent, they are paying all or most of their college tuition," Mr. Crosson said. "By way of contrast it's sometimes difficult to persuade high-tech companies here to bring on additional college students as summer interns even though they may be only as little as a year or two away from graduation or employment. What is frustrating is the same companies will pay a relocation fee of $75,000 or more to bring a young person from another part of the country."
But Ms. Coughlin, the Computer Associates human resources executive, said her company had committed to help SUNY Stony Brook double the size of its computer science department in the next several years. The company has plans to work with the school on its curriculum, train professors "and maybe even loan some of our own people as professors," she said. The problem is "you just don't have enough new bodies coming out of the schools," she said.
Last month, the company agreed to participate in Suffolk County's affordable housing program, a pivotal issue in attracting talent, by providing a subsidy to new homeowners.
Many business leaders agree that the short-term prospects are dim for attracting large numbers of high-tech workers. But they are just as confident of some kind of payoff farther down the road.
H. Michael Boyd, a human resources analyst at International Data Corp. of Framingham, Mass., said that Long Island planners might be onto something by playing up the bonds the Island's homegrown talent have with the area. Dr. Boyd recounted the difficulty recruiting Long Islanders away from the region even during the height of the defense layoffs.
"There was a strong, I don't want to say emotional attachment, but cultural attachment about various parts of the Island that people didn't want to leave," he said.
John Hoctor, 25, a Centereach native, said that local planners would need more than high school teachers and memories of home to bring them back.
"I think it would be kind of funny to have my high school teacher come out and recruit me," said Mr. Hoctor, who earned his bachelor's and master's in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last year. He has started a venture capital fund in Manhattan and did not foresee a return to the Island.
"I owe a lot to my high school teachers," he said. "I got a very good education at Centereach High School, but I wouldn't feel they would have recruiting power over me. It would be nice to see them again, but they wouldn't draw me back to Long Island."
But Mr. Younas, the Palo Alto-based software engineer and SUNY Stony Brook graduate, said that he and some of his Stony Brook friends who also left after graduating could return. Mr. Younas and his best friends from college, Mohamed Abdelsadek, 24, and Kwasi Mireku, 32, excelled at the university, graduated at the top of their 1996 class and heartily embraced all that the school offered.
They worked together on a complex senior project that translated data into 3-D images. And together they built a cardboard catamaran that stayed afloat for a regatta on a university pond. The three now meet weekly via an Internet chat room, where Mr. Younas said he has been talking up the idea of launching their own tech startup.
"One of the places we were considering was Long Island," Mr. Younas said. "It's close to the financial world and has low real estate costs. It has some strategic value. Maybe one fine day we'll end up there."

HEADLINE: In Nassau, the Millennium Comes Early;
The Budget Triggered One Voter Revolt, and There May be More in Store

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
THE key to the revolution that took place in Nassau County's voting booths last week -- and the key to much of the political maneuvering likely to captivate county government for the next two years -- can be found at a storefront office a couple doors away from the Dunkin Donuts on Merrick Road in Bellmore.
There, in the headquarters of David W. Denenberg's Democratic campaign for the County Legislature's 19th District, three big computer printouts adorn a wall. In bold capital letters, they all say the same thing: 
 "IT'S THE BUDGET, STUPID!"
Indeed, the county government's fiscal crisis under County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and his fellow Republicans in the Legislature's majority was the overriding issue that led to the unparalleled election upset. Propelled by voter rebellion over the county's $300 million deficit and its tax increases, the Democrats won control of the legislature for the first time in Nassau's 100-year history.
And the county's lingering budget problem will continue to be the overriding issue that the Democrats face when they take office, political experts say.
"It will not go away," said Arthur J. Kremer, who was the Democratic chairman of the State Assembly's Ways and Means Committee and is now in the private practice of law. "It will be continuing throughout their tenure. It's a difficult challenge, but if they can solve the budget and stabilize the county, they can be in power a long time.'
Besides capturing the county Legislature, the Democrats also retained their hold on North Hempstead Town and the cities of Glen Cove and Long Beach. Moreover, they gained two seats on the Oyster Bay Town Board, where they had never had more than one. Most astonishing of all, the Democrats took two seats on the town board of Hempstead -- the most populous town in America and the citadel of the Nassau Republican organization. Historians had to go back to 1907 to find the last Democrat to hold public office in that town.
Democratic leaders themselves were surprised by the extent of their inroads. Now they seek to parlay their victories into permanent gains instead of a one-term fluke. It will not be easy, say politicians on both sides.
"For them, the good news -- and the bad news -- is that they won," said Frederick E. Parola, who as the Republican county comptroller has been critiquing Mr. Gulotta's budgets for years. "They're the party in control now, and it's their responsibility to make the hard decisions."
The Legislature's departing Republican majority claims that the budget it adopted three days before the election largely solved the county's fiscal problems, by imposing a combination of cuts and unpopular revenue increases that included a 10.5 percent raise in county property taxes, a new 1 percent tax on real estate sales and various surcharges in fees.
"We made a lot of progress governmentally," said the Legislature's presiding officer and Republican majority leader, Bruce A. Blakeman. "The '99 deficit will be closed out in a few days, we've gone a long way toward creating structural balance into the future, and I believe fiscal year 2000 is structurally balanced. We went so far that we had to inflict a lot of pain, not popular things to do in an election year."
Mr. Blakeman learned first-hand just how unpopular the budget was. A promising political career suffered a heavy blow when he became the biggest casualty of the Democratic sweep, losing his own seat.
"The key person out front was Bruce, selling the Republican plan and making TV commercials," Mr. Parola said, "and that's who paid the price, along with some of his colleagues."
Despite Mr. Blakeman's claims of solving most of the fiscal crisis, critics say that crucial elements of the new $2 billion-plus budget have yet to be seen -- even the total figures remain unknown. The critics also say that the budget is based on various revenue estimates and cost reductions that are doubtful and one-shot deals that need to be replaced by something else to plug budget gaps in future years. Some critics already predict more deficits.
"The issue continues to be the budget, and if we don't cure the budget problem, voters will turn back away from the Democrats," said Mr. Denenberg. "We're inheriting an awful problem. We have a unique opportunity that only lasts two years, unless we can prove that we can handle it and handle it correctly. The hard work begins now."
His motto on the importance of the budget was modeled on the theme that President Clinton's political operative, James Carville, drummed into his campaign workers: "It's the economy, stupid."
Mr. Denenberg was one of five Democratic challengers who upset incumbent Republican legislators. Added to the five Democrats already in the Legislature, the 10 will form a narrow majority when the new body takes office on Jan. 1. The nine Republican legislators who survived the election will become the new minority. They all come up for election in 2001 -- along with Nassau's top countywide officials, the county executive, comptroller and district attorney.
"Obviously the overarching issue is getting the fiscal ship back in order -- that's really going to be the test for the Democratic majority," said the Nassau Democratic Party chairman, Thomas P. DiNapoli. Desmond Ryan, a former Republican aide in Suffolk who is now the executive director of a developers' group called the Association for a Better Long Island, said: "They've been given an enormous vote of confidence. The public is trusting them to make a change, and they must deliver."
Whatever problems may be hidden in the hundreds of pages of budget lines yet to be published and scrutinized, the Democrats' task is made all the more difficult by their own campaign platform. Notably, they promised to oppose any renewal of the 1 percent tax on real estate sales -- a measure that the Republicans say will yield $55 million annually -- when it expires at the end of next year.
"That's laudable," said Comptroller Parola, "but now they're stuck with reality. We're over the silly season now, and they've got to come up with $120 million" to make up for the real estate transfer tax and other budget shortages, he said.
"The Blakeman plan did not totally address the structural imbalance created by the administration," he said, meaning that the basic cost of county operations exceeds the recurring revenues. "The Democrats, I assume, will do more cutting."
One specific problem the comptroller cited is his staff's estimate that police costs are running $15 million above the budgeted figures.
Even after the election, the new budget adopted by the Republicans remained a mystery. "We haven't been able to decipher very much from what they did," said Mr. Gulotta's budget consultant, William R. Marshall. "It's long on rhetoric and short on details. I'm going on guesstimates on my part, because at the end of the day we threw our hands up. Last night I started making a spreadsheet myself, trying to see if I can make heads or tails of it."
Because Mr. Gulotta faces a deadline this week on whether to veto any parts of the budget, Mr. Marshall said, "we're behind the eight ball" in figuring out what is in it. He complained that the Republicans "substituted a lot of one-shot revenues," a tactic for which Mr. Gulotta's own budgets have been repeatedly attacked. He also asserted that the Legislature's budget restored some cuts that Mr. Gulotta made and added more taxes.
The director of the watchdog Nassau Citizens Budget Committee, Phoebe Goodman, said: "I don't know what's in the budget any more than other people, but I do know it's a terrible way to make a budget. I hope I'm wrong. I hope they knew exactly what they were doing. I'm doing this blindfolded, but I'm assuming they just narrowed the deficit somewhat. They couldn't close it; it's just too big."
Mr. Ryan prdicted: "The question this time next year will not be if we have a deficit, but how much."
Major parts of the budget include paying off most of last year's $193 million deficit by using $82 million from the sale of the county medical center and nursing home, $12 million from the sale of county land in Plainview, the $19 million settlement from a disastrous attempt to switch to a private health insurer for county workers and getting $3 million in appealed Medicaid reimbursements.
An advance payment from Nassau's share of the national settlement of the lawsuit against the tobacco industry will be used to close deficits and to pay for the next five years of $18 million annual subsidies due to the new public benefit corporation that is running the medical center and nursing home.
The Republican budget also listed $45 million in spending cuts, including 250 jobs, some through layoffs and others through attrition and the elimination of vacant positions. New revenues included various increases in state aid, reimbursements for housing inmates who should have been in state prisons and a $5 million reduction in subsidies for the public buses.
But the Legislature's Democratic leader, Judith Jacobs, said that the budget documents so far "are nothing more than a glorified press release." Many of the added revenues, she said, are far from guaranteed.
Comptroller Parola said that the Legislature "went halfway or maybe a quarter of the way" in solving the budget problems, "but obviously to the electorate, did not go far enough." His office has always acted impartially, he said, adding that "I look forward to working with the Democrats and with my guys" on the Republican side ins seeking to balance the books. Referring to the Legislature's term of office, he said: "It's going to be a fun two years."

HEADLINE: Little Ambassadors With Hearts In Need of Repair

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
TWO Siberian toddlers have arrived in the United States on an adult-size mission: to serve as emissaries of Russia and symbols of an effort to improve relations between the two countries.
Because they were born with potentially fatal heart defects and faced limited prospects for reaching adulthood in Russia, Sophia Ovchinnikova and Sergei Yurinski are at the Westchester Medical Center here to undergo surgery not available in Russia. 
 Some political and business leaders are want the two babies, handpicked from among thousands of others suffering from congenital heart defects in Russia, will serve as symbols of healing between nations -- particularly in the area of nuclear disarmament.
"The children show the real human side of the work we're doing in Russia's nuclear cities," Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said last week. "Everyone -- Russians and Americans -- want what's best for kids."
The United States Department of Energy has been working in the remote Siberian regions of Tomsk, where Sophia lives, and Krasnoyarsk, Sergei's home, on a nonproliferation program aimed at reducing the availability of nuclear material for weapons.
Sophia, 13 months old, and Sergei, 22 months old, arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Oct. 6 to a red-carpet welcome and were taken with their mothers to the Children's Hospital of the 1,100-bed Westchester Medical Center. A motorcade including the New York City Police and Fire Departments, the Westchester County police and dignitaries and businessmen, accompanied them. Those present included Kirill Speransky, senior counselor of the Russian Mission to the United Nations, Edward Mastal, director of the Highly Enriched Uranium Transparancy Program of the United States Department of Energy, and Edward A. Stolzenberg, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester Medical Center.
The children's visit is sponsored by the Forum Club's Children of the World Foundation, a New York-based organization established by William Denis Fugazy, a limousine magnate and lobbyist, to give ailing youngsters in different parts of the world access to the most advanced medical techniques. The Forum Club, an organization of business and civic leaders, counts among its members Lee A. Iaccoca, the former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.
The Siberian babies are the sixth and seventh to receive heart surgery in the United States under the sponsorship of Mr. Fugazy's foundation, which was formed last year.
Both Mr. Fugazy and Secretary Richardson said that because of the mutual humanitarian, economic and political benefits to both sides, American offers of medical assistance have been well received. The United States selected the two Russian children through the medical department of the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy.
In many cases, care at American hospitals specializing in pediatric heart surgery is the only opportunity for sick children like Sophia and Sergei to live normal lives, said Dr. Lester C. Permut, the surgeon in charge of Sophia and Sergei's cases. The Westchester Medical Center is providing its services without charge to the children's families.
Dr. Permut said that Sophia and Sergei suffer from two of the most common heart disorders in children and that in the United States, the prognosis for such cases is excellent: a 95 percent percent survival rate after surgery.
"In this country, we consider these kinds of pediatric heart surgeries very routine operations," he said.
But in Russia, children having surgery to correct congenital heart defects have only a 5 percent chance of survival because advanced pediatric heart care is not available there. As Olga Victorovna Ovchinnikova, Sophia's mother, explained through an interpreter: "I was told my child could have surgery in Novosibirsk, but that it was highly experimental and there were no guarantees. Then we heard about this. It was like a miracle."
It is the first time that the Children's Hospital at the Westchester Medical Center -- one of only about 10 hospitals in the state licensed for pediatric heart surgery -- is taking part in the Children's Foundation program. More than 100 children each day are cared for at the center here, which has the region's only pediatric intensive care and neonatal intensive care centers. Next year, the Medical Center plans to complete construction of its new 257,500-square-foot, four-story Children's Hospital.
At the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York earlier this year, Anton Kozhedub, 3, of Ukraine and Maria Lucia Miller and Merolyn Roario, infants from the Dominican Republic, underwent heart surgery. Mr. Fugazy said those medical procedures, like the others that have been performed, "have opened avenues not there before and created new friendships."
In particular, Police Commissioner Howard Safir of New York City and law enforcement officials from the Dominican Republic have since exchanged information that has aided in arresting criminals. And pharmaceutical companies are exploring new business venues in the Dominican Republic. Also, George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, helped finance a hospital in the Dominican Republic, a country that is a rich source for American baseball teams.
In the latest partnership with Siberia, the most immediate and palpable gain is Sergei's speedy recovery. A hole in his heart has been repaired and he is making satisfactory progress, Carin Grossman, a hospital spokeswoman, said.
Dr. Permut, who performs about 150 open-heart procedures a year, explained that the wall that should have formed between the lower left and right chambers of Sergei's heart did not completely close when Sergei was in the womb -- resulting in an abnormal blood flow and increased pressure in the artery that goes through his lungs.
Before the operation, the blood pressure in the artery to Sergei's lungs was the same as that in his aorta, when it should have been one-fourth of the pressure. It has, however, finally begun to drop, but not to the level it should be.
Under ideal circumstances, the surgery should have been performed before Sergei reached 6 months. "It is already late to start fixing the problem," Dr. Permut said.
Sergei's lungs have suffered, although the damage is probably reversible, Dr. Permut said. Without the surgery, or a heart-lung transplant later on, Sergei would have lived only into his teenage years or perhaps until he was 20.
In contrast, Sophia is undergoing a correction of a hole between the two upper chambers of her heart at precisely the correct time in her life, Dr. Permut said. Her medical problem is less complex than Sergei's, although the mitral valve in her heart needs to be repaired as well. Without surgery, she might not have lived past her 20's, he said.
In interviews last week, Sophia's mother, Mrs. Ovchinnikova, and Sergei's mother, Yulia Sergeevna Yurinskaya, said they had been overwhelmed by the kindness New Yorkers have shown to them and their children.
"They've treated us like family," Mrs. Yurinskaya, a housekeeper at a Siberian factory said, speaking through Dr. Gregory Rozenblit, a director of the department that performs angioplasties at the Medical Center. Sergei's bed is littered with toy trucks and other presents from well-wishers.
Mrs. Yurinskaya is able to talk by phone every day to her husband Mikhail, who also works in a factory in Siberia, and to her parents and in-laws. "They were going out of their minds waiting," she said. "They were very worried about the baby, and at first they were crying because everything was so bad. But now they are crying because they're so happy."
Sophia lives with her mother, aunts and grandmother in a small town in Siberia. Ms. Ovchinnikova, a single mother who works as a housekeeper in a gym, said she talks to her relatives only about once a week at a pre-arranged time and place from the United States, because there is no phone in their apartment in Siberia.
When they do talk (the news from Siberia is that the snow has already begun to fall) the women discuss their new hopes for Sophia and changing relations between the two countries.
"We can't believe what is happening," Ms. Ovchinnikova said, "that after all these years of cold war tensions, there is now so much friendliness."
Sophia is awaiting surgery, and since their arrival in the United States, Sophia and her mother have lived in a small apartment here provided by the hospital, so that Sophia can recuperate from a cold and ear infection.

HEADLINE: Bursting Schools Go on a Building Spree

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
AN unprecedented spurt of public school construction is under way in Connecticut. State records show that the total cost of construction projects approved by local districts in 1999 is three times what it averaged in previous years.
David Wedge, manager of the school facilities unit of the State Department of Education, said that local public school districts have submitted requests for partial reimbursement in state school building grants for 200 projects totaling $1.5 billion. During the last few years, he said, the total cost of school construction projects in Connecticut that have been submitted for reimbursement has been between $475 million and $736 million annually.
 "We expected an increase, but we didn't expect an increase of that magnitude," he said. 
 Mr. Wedge said that the favorable economy and the decaying conditions of many public schools, which were detailed in a State Department of Education report last year, combined with rising school enrollments, have resulted in the construction increase.
This isn't just happening in Connecticut, either. "School construction is a national phenomenon right now," he said.
School districts are not building the same kinds of schools that were built during the last great pulse of school construction, the baby boom years of the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's. There are some important differences that appear to be trends.
New schools are architecturally more interesting than those built 30 years ago. They are designed for growth and for use by the community when school is not in session. They accommodate a broader range of academic, athletic, artistic, and technological offerings than ever before. And their libraries have been reborn as media centers that have taken a more central, important role than previously.
Typical of the new schools is Ansonia High School, which opened just after Labor Day on a hilltop overlooking a wooded area with a man-made lake. The $23 million high school was described by Douglas Rudig, the Ansonia school superintendent, as the "centerpiece" of a $50.5 million restructuring of Ansonia's educational system that, he said, eliminated inequities between what students were offered in different parts of the city.
State reimbursement grants vary with the relative wealth of the school district, ranging from 80 percent for the poorest to 20 percent for the wealthiest. Ansonia received 76 percent reimbursement from the state.
Ansonia invested in technology in the high school. The entire school is linked with networked computers; there are foreign language, writing and mathematics computer labs, and a computer-assisted drafting lab; there are capabilities for distance learning, through which courses can be taught for students in other buildings, allowing Ansonia and neighboring municipalities to share specialized instruction courses. The school also has a television production studio, which students in Ansonia never had available to them before. Specialists in the media center can beam videotape recordings into classrooms.
The new high school also has expanded program accommodations for the arts. There is a new ceramics studio. The 450-seat auditorium has sophisticated sound and lighting equipment for student performances and there is a new suite of music rooms.
"This is the third year we've had music in the high school in over 20 years," said Maria Tangredi, a music teacher. "It just died away."
Building a new high school was an opportunity to expand and improve the city's educational offerings for students, said Wilhemenia Christon, the high school's principal.
"It is not the physical plant that is going to make this school," she said. "It's the programs. You can be in a castle, but if you don't do anything with it, then nothing is going to happen."
Curiously, Ansonia's school construction reversed the usual course of cause and effect. In most districts, the need for more school space to accommodate rapidly rising school enrollment has been the justification for improving the schools as well. But Ansonia's school enrollment had been projected to stay level, or even decline slightly for the next few years. Its decision to build and renovate schools was to improve them, and that seems to be the reason, Mr. Rudig said, for an unexpected increase of 130 students, more than 5 percent, in its school population in the last year. A few of those students transferred from a local state vocational school, but most were from families that had moved into Ansonia, attracted by the new schools, he said.
Not so for Ridgefield, where school enrollment is increasing 28.8 percent and growing. School Superintendent Ralph Wallace said school enrollment hit a peak in Ridgefield in 1979 at 4,910 pupils, and then declined to 3,293 in 1989. But it has been climbing for a decade, now standing at 4,806, and is projected to hit 5,846 in 2008.
But that's not all. As the State Department of Education's report on the condition of the state's schools noted, there has also been a decrease in class size, and furthermore, school enrollment increases are not distributed evenly across all cities and towns. So the fact that the state has about 550,000 public school students in schools built for 600,000 disguises the reality that most schools are either nearly full or overflowing.
To address its enrollment problem, Mr. Wallace said Ridgefield has begun a vigorous school building program, beginning with the construction of a $34 million middle school scheduled for completion in September 2001. It has three school projects included among those being considered for state reimbursement grants this year: the construction of a new elementary school, the enlargement and renovation of another elementary school, and the renovation of the old middle school. In the future, officials also hope to renovate and enlarge Ridgefield High School. Mr. Wallace said all of this will cost, conservatively, $72 million.
"People have held off and held off, making do with portable classrooms and using unconventional spaces like nurses rooms and faculty lounges as classrooms," Mr. Wallace said. There is no more spare space to use, and taxpayers in his town realized that waiting further merely meant paying more later on, he said.
As in Ansonia and many other communities, Ridgefield's school construction projects had to win approval in a voter referendum. "Community use was a big selling point," Mr. Wallace said.
So was technology, which is very popular with parents and the public. Like Ansonia High School, Ridgefield's new middle school will be fully wired for computer networks.
"We're emphasizing science," he said. That is because 96 percent of the town's graduates go to college, double the percentage of 40 or 50 years ago. Science labs will have classrooms built into them, and the woods adjacent to the school will feature trails for nature studies. The school will also have accommodations for a music performing arts program.
That makes Glastonbury's school construction a familiar story.
"We've had a 30 percent population growth in the middle schools in the 1990's," said Jacqueline Jacoby, the school superintendent.
Only two years ago, Glastonbury renovated all five of its elementary schools. The district is building a $38 million middle school that will also use woods on its grounds for an environmental studies program, will also be equipped with computers, will have a media center and will be designed for use by community groups. The middle school is scheduled to be opened for students in January 2001.
In June, she said, Glastonbury submitted requests for state reimbursement of 33.7 percent, its reimbursement rate, for a new $22 million elementary school and additions and renovations at its high school costing $38 million.
"Our schools are very heavily used by our community," Ms. Jacoby said. About 60 organizations and the local Parks and Recreation Department keep the town's schools booked every evening, she said.
Prominently located along busy Route 7, New Milford's new $48 million high school is scheduled for completion next summer.
Fully air-conditioned (another common feature of new schools in the state), the town's school superintendent, Raymond E. Avery, said the school is designed into three parts: the academic and administration portion in the center that includes the media center, the gym and athletic facilities at the south end, and the auditorium and performing arts rooms at the north end. Those three parts can be locked off from each other and used independently by students or the community, Mr. Avery said.
Besides all of the high-tech equipment, the performance arts rooms, and the glitter and drama of something new, some Ansonia High School students said there is a psychological benefit to their new school.
When the old Ansonia High School was opened in 1937, it made the cover of Life Magazine as an example of the most modern high school in the country. But over the following six decades, the school wore out and grew dingy and crowded, and that was embarrassing, some students said.
"People looked at us like we weren't good students because of the way our school looked," said Rebecca Judach, who was helping prepare the school's lobby for its public open house recently.
She and her friends, most of whom were cheerleaders and members of the student government, said the new school was academically inspiring both to students and teachers.
"I don't think anything's different," said Tiffany Goldson. "It's that we're different, in our minds."

HEADLINE: An Important Fish Becomes Scarce

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
SINCE Squanto taught the Pilgrims to fertilize their crops with menhaden, the abundance of the oily, pungent fish has been taken for granted along the Northeast coast. But during the last 10 years, adult menhaden, generally known as bunkers, have become scarce in the Northeast, affecting the food chain and causing a debate about the regulation of the menhaden fishing industry.
The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, a federal agency that monitors migratory fish along the Atlantic coast, reported that in 1998, the latest year for which statistics are available, 1 billion juvenile menhaden survived their first year, down from 2 billion in 1997. In 1990, the number was 6 billion and there were 7 billion in 1980. 
 "For years I haven't seen bunker," said Thomas Fitzgerald, a recreational fishermen from Madison. "When there's no big bunkers, there's no big blue fish. I always say the bunkers will come back next year and the blue fishing will be what it use to be. But it never happens. Something is wrong."
Biologists agree, but what exactly is causing the decline remains a mystery. Some experts said the bunker population has always been cyclical and the current numbers may just be a natural down cycle. Others said the bunker, which are used in fertilizer, livestock feed and food additives, are simply being overfished and may never recover if the industry doesn't cut back.
Menhaden range as far north as Nova Scotia and as far south as Florida. Among the things they eat are plankton. They are a vital food source for ospreys, bald eagles, seals and other marine mammals. Adult menhaden is the favored bait for blue fish, striped bass, king mackerel, red drum, sharks, tuna, crabs and lobster.
Because of the lack of adult bunkers in Long Island Sound, blue fish and striped bass are feeding more on river shad in the early spring, which is reducing their numbers, said David Simpson, a State Department of Environmental Protection supervisory fisheries biologist.
During a September public hearing in Old Lyme on the menhaden issue, recreational fishermen and environmentalists blamed the problem and the consequent decrease in Long Island Sound of large blue fish on overfishing by the industry.
Statistics from the fisheries commission show that the industry takes at least 90 percent of the annual catch. The remaining 10 percent of the commercial catch is used as bait for recreational fisheries or for lobster and crab commercial fisheries. The fisheries commission reported that the industry caught about 587 million pounds of menhaden off the Atlantic and Gulf coasts in 1997, down from 630 million pounds in 1996. In 1990, the catch was 877 million pounds.
"I'm bemused by the attention this issue is getting in Connecticut, said Barney White, vice president of the Omega Protein Corporation, a Hammond, La., company that makes food supplements, and chairman of the National Fish Meal and Oil Association. "The industry hasn't commercially fished Long Island Sound for the last three years, and has no plans to ever go back there."
It didn't always used to be that way.
"There use to be about eight bunker boats that operated out of New London in the late 1940's and 1950's," said Lawrence Malloy, 81, a second-generation Long Island Sound fishermen. "Many still had tall smoke stacks and coal burning steam engines. There were boats named Amagansett, Pocahontas, and Promised Land," Mr. Malloy said.
Now, according to fishery experts, most of the commercial bunker fishing is done in the southern half of the Chesapeake Bay in Virginia, where one of the menhaden rendering plants is located. Another is in North Carolina. The Virginia plant is owned by Zapata Protein, the parent company of Omega Protein.
Some environmentalists said the industry needs to be better regulated.
"Menhaden's enormous economic value to the public requires that they not be managed as a commercial fishery for the benefit of a narrow, commercial special interest," said Richard J. Weisburg of the Coastal Conservation Association, a national environmental organization focused on the preservation of fishery stocks.
Although commercial boats no longer fish in Long Island Sound, a moratorium in Connecticut prohibiting bunker fishing by the industry has been in effect for the last three years and has been extended two years to 2001, said Ernie Beckwith, manager of the state D.E.P.'s fisheries division. He said many states on the Atlantic coast have imposed moratoriums or increased regulations on the industries' fishing boats.
"The intent of fishery regulation is to preserve enough adult fish able to spawn and maintain the natural abundance of the species," Mr. Beckwith said.
Mr. White of Omega Protein said the industry is not causing the menhaden problem.
"Accusations that the industry is causing the decline of the menhaden population are just flat wrong," Mr. White said. "In a perfect year for commercial menhaden fishing, perhaps as much as 20 to 25 percent of the bio-mass of menhaden will be taken. But according to the scientific literature, as little as 3 percent of the menhaden bio-mass is needed to maintain the fish's population." He noted that a single female will produce 200,000 to 300,000 eggs.
Mr. White said another reason the menhaden population may be falling is because of the rebound of the striped bass, which feed on menhaden and have come back because commercial fishing has been prohibited on that species for the last three years.
Mr. Beckwith said there is no evidence that menhaden are being overfished.
"Commercial fishing is nowhere near what fishery biologists believe to be the maximum sustainable yield," Mr. Beckwith said. However, he said, as much as 70 percent of the fish being taken by the industry are three years old or younger. Because the fish commonly don't begin to reproduce until they are three, Mr. Beckwith said he is concerned that over the long-term catching those fish could further reduce the menhaden population.
Biologists believe the fall off in the numbers of menhaden is being caused by natural environmental conditions, such as wind and waves that move the fish away from areas where the juvenile menhaden can mature. According to fishery statistics, the same unfavorable conditions existed in the 1960's causing a comparable menhaden shortage in Long Island Sound.
Another theory about the scarcity of menhaden and blue fish in Long Island Sound is that these fish are simply remaining in the Atlantic and not entering the Sound. Biologists don't know why.
Because menhaden eat large amounts of plankton, which contribute to hypoxia or dissolved oxygen deficiencies in Long Island Sound and the Chesapeake, the Coastal Conservation Agency is calling for a moratorium on commercial fishing in the Chesapeake until the menhaden's role in maintaining water quality and possibly preventing hypoxia is studied, Mr. Weisburg said.

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
For Newark's Central Ward, 206 Town Houses

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
BY next summer 206 town houses for low- and moderate-income families are expected to be completed on two 6.5-acre sites on either side of Irvine Turner Boulevard between West Kinney and Prince Streets in Newark's Central Ward. The sites are a block from where the 1967 racial riots erupted, pushing the city into decline.
Instead of being built with traditional techniques the wall panels and roof trusses for the homes are being manufactured in a factory elsewhere in the city and will be assembled on the site, where the rest of the construction will be completed. 
 Foundations for the first 92 homes of the project, called Community Hills, are under way, as is the assemblage of the wall panels for the 1,000- to 1,100-square-foot two-story houses. They will be sold for $20,000 to $50,475 to families earning $18,000 to $25,000 a year, depending on family size. The $25 million project will also include an 18,000 square foot day care and community center and three vest-pocket parks.
The housing components are being manufactured by NCC Technologies, an affiliate of New Community Corporation of Newark, the developer. The nonprofit developer, which builds 300 residences a year, most of them in Newark, opened its factory last year on one 40,000 square foot floor of the three-story, long-dormant former Borden's milk processing plant at Orange and Nesbitt Streets, near Route 280.
On the other two floors, said Raymond M. Codey, director of development for New Community, will be office space for start-up companies and support services on running a small business and securing loans and grants.
On part of the site New Community also has city approval to build a 40,000 square foot, single level factory with a 50 foot high ceiling, which will start to rise by year's end and, using wall panels, be completed four months later. There, the group envisions manufacturing modules for entire houses, underscoring its resolve to turn the operation into a long-term business venture like other businesses it runs.
New Community, for example, owns the land under a 57,000 square foot retail center on Bergen Street and South Orange Avenue in Newark and is part owner of its 45,000 square foot Pathmark Supermarket, which Pathmark operates. The group also owns and operates the center's 12,000 square feet of smaller stores.
New Community's enterprise will be the latest to test factory-built housing in New Jersey. The concept is considered an effective way to produce housing for lower income buyers or renters, but few factories have survived in the state.
Explaining the reason for opening the factory and planning a second one, Mr. Codey said: "It's a way for us not only to do affordable housing projects for ourselves and others, but to create jobs."
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark described the venture as "a win-win" situation. "For the last 15 years housing has been trucked into Newark from factories in Pennsylvania and Virginia and it made no sense," he said. "We should have a factory to build housing in and employ people from the city."
NEW COMMUNITY tested the current factory, which employs 12 people, by manufacturing 2,500 wall panels for the builder of 200 town houses on Avon Avenue and Irvine Turner Boulevard. That project is part of the Newark Public Housing Authority's program to create 1,777 such residences to replace rentals in 12 of the city's bleak public housing towers.
Community Hills is not part of the authority's replacement program, which is the result of a 1989 settlement of a federal lawsuit filed by tenant and housing groups. But it is part of the larger effort to change the face of housing for low-income people in the city, said Harry Robinson, a spokesman for the housing authority.
The authority is under contract to sell New Community the two sites for its project for about $250,000. The group is building the project using a $24.8 million grant it initially received from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to take over and renovate two vacant public housing towers. But last year H.U.D. permitted the group to build the current project, the second phase of which will go up across the street from the first on a site where four high-rises once stood and a fifth will soon be razed.
Below-market-rate mortgages will be available to buyers at the project from the New Jersey Mortgage Finance Agency and conventional lenders. Buyers will be required to make no more than a 5 percent down payment for the house.
The two projects, said Mr. Codey, jump-started the first factory and convinced New Community that operating it as well as the planned modular plant would enable "us to fill a market niche." The group bought the old Borden's plant for $10,000 at a bankruptcy auction and paid $600,000 in back takes owed to the city by the former owner. NCC Technologies, the nonprofit group's manufacturing affiliate, is run by Rudy Faust and Mark Flesher, who have backgrounds in residential construction in New Jersey.
Using factory-built components can lower the cost of producing a home by 15 percent over traditional houses and shave off six months from the production schedule, largely because of greater operating efficiencies, Mr. Codey said. Those figures, he added, rise to a savings of 20 to 30 percent when entire homes are made in a factory.
In such a setting the quality of the homes can be improved because they can be made year-round and under closer supervision, Mr. Codey said, adding that in terms of shipping "we can also offer a quicker turnaround" than out-of-state factories.
As of August, 467 manufactured homes were produced in New Jersey, up from 349 the same time in 1998, according to the New Jersey Manufactured Housing Association, a nonprofit trade group in Trenton. The state "has not been a big user of manufactured homes, but the use is growing," said Judith A. Thornton, the group's executive director, adding that "more and more builders are using prefabricated parts in home construction."
Ms. Thornton said factories "never lasted the test of time" because of, among other things, the high cost of operating in the state, finding workers and union resistance to nonunion manufacturers.
New Community has addressed those issues. Through its Workforce Development Center it has trained unemployed city residents to work in the factory at lower than prevailing wages. Mr. Codey said unions supported this endeavor because it would ultimately provide jobs for union members in completing the housing.
He said his corporation had received $3.5 million in federal grants, as well as $2 million in grants and low-interest loans from the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark, to set up the existing factory and build the new one, helping to reduce costs. The city also granted a tax abatement for the factory site, insuring the project's long-term financial viability, Mr. Codey said.
In addition to using the factories to produce its own low cost housing projects, Mr. Codey said New Community was in discussions with private and nonprofit developers to manufacture components and houses for projects in the state and, of course, in Newark. Mayor James predicted that the city, which plans to build 1,000 homes by the end of next year, and the housing authority would be "big users."
Since the authority's housing replacement program began in 1993, 959 of the planned 1,777 low-rise homes have been built and the remaining 818 are in various stages of planning, said Mr. Robinson, its spokesman. He said the authority also recently received a $35 million federal grant to raze additional high-rises and replace them with more low-rise residences beyond those required under the 1989 settlement. The hope is to build 800 mixed-income rental and for-sale units, he said.
While Newark's program is the largest in the state, five other cities -- Elizabeth, New Brunswick, Paterson, Jersey City and Atlantic City -- are involved in similar efforts, which is a market Mr. Codey said he intended to tap. But to guard against downturns in the residential market, he added, the factories will also turn out prefabricated parts and building modules for commercial and institutional uses such as charter schools and day care centers, for which there is a "built-up demand in urban areas, particularly Newark."
For the first 92-unit phase of Community Hills, to be completed by February, New Community's existing factory will produce 1,200 wall panels for the two- and three-bedroom houses. Each of the vinyl- and brick-faced homes, designed by Mikesell & Associates of Newark, will have a washer and dryer and one parking space.
Construction of the remaining 114 homes will begin once the last public housing tower on the second site is razed by year's end, said Mr. Codey. They are to be completed by the summer, he said.
"This is an effort to rebuild Newark one house, one job and one family at a time," he added.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Sensing Room for Growth, Home Depot Thinks Small

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
Elizabeth Bacorn was in a hurry. After selecting paint to touch up the fireplace in her Old Bridge home, Ms. Bacorn scoured the aisles of the new Villager's Hardware here for her next purchase.
Christine and Jack Godowski of Sayerville were checking front doors, reviewing the prices as well as the merits of a free installation. And Kay Mirando was looking for new miniblinds for her kitchen but was determined not to spend a fortune. 
 It was a typical Saturday at Villager's, the latest retail experiment from Home Depot, the Atlanta-based home-improvement giant. The shoppers came for bargains, convenience, service -- and out of curiosity.
Indeed, when Villager's opened here in June, it was the first hardware store the chain opened in its gamble to capture part of the $50 billion a year home-decorating and remodeling business not served by big box retailers. Not surprisingly, Home Depot, which viewed New Jersey as fertile ground, decided to test its concept here. Three more are expected to open in central New Jersey by the end of the year.
Villager's is a baby big box store intended to appeal to both the Martha Stewarts and the Bob Vilas of the do-it-yourself crowd and to provide an updated version of the mom-and-pop hardware store.
Robert J. Wittman, Home Depot's senior vice president for business development, said the decision to make New Jersey a testing ground was a simple one.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Wittman recited New Jersey's retail vital statistics: the second most densely populated state in the nation with 8.1 million residents; an average per capita income of $33,937, second only to Connecticut's, and an aging housing stock.
Translation: Baby boomers with discretionary money to spend on sprucing up their charming but troublesome old homes.
Mr. Wittman said other factors included the state's diverse economy, a qualified labor pool and the Whitman administration's pro-business attitude.
Moreover, he said Home Depot's Northeast headquarters is in South Plainfield, and the chain has 30 stores in the state.
"The reception here has been terrific," Mr. Wittman said.
He declined to give any specific figures, but added that Villager's "is doing better than expected" in terms of customer traffic and sales.
John M. Harris, a research analyst at Schroder & Company in Manhattan, who follows Home Depot, said the concept "showed that the company was planning for future growth and to enter different market segments before it was absolutely necessary."
Mr. Harris added that Home Depot had five years of growth left to open its typical big box stores, and that Villager's was a "kind of contingency planning for the future because we all realize all big boxes will run out of room sometime."
For now, he said, "it fills a niche big boxes don't in terms of convenience."
Cynthia A. Nelson, director of real estate at PricewaterhouseCoopers, agreed that the choice made sense because given its presence in New Jersey, the chain "will be able to leverage off its brand name."
Ted Kraus, a retail consultant in Mercerville, added that despite the state's seemingly endless shopping outlets, "we are under-retailed."
Mr. Kraus said that while there is likely to be some carnage as a result of the Villager stores, the brunt of the new hardwares will be felt by linen and houseware stores.
"Don't get me wrong," he added. "Some of the little hardware stores will be impacted, but those that survived Home Depot probably will again."
That's how Timothy Verasca -- the third generation in his family to run Spotswood Hardware -- sees it.
"So far there hasn't been any impact" on his family's hardware store, which has operated on Main Street in Spotswood -- two miles from the new Villager's -- for the last 58 years, Mr. Verasca said. "Business is up."
What is in his favor, he said, is that "Villager's is on a highway and the locals don't want to deal with traffic. People also know me, know I live in the community and have the same problems they do."
For instance, he said, his store carries copper wiring because most houses in the area were built before the 1970's, when aluminum wiring became common.
Service is also what Raymond Cappella feels insulates his store, Milltown Hardware on North Main Street in Milltown, a half-mile from Villager's. Though he and his two brothers bought the business three years ago, Mr. Capella said they grew up in the community, where the store has been in the same location for more than 100 years.
"We sell service," he said before cutting the conversation short to wait on customers. "They can hire all the people they want, but they will never be able to duplicate it."
Interestingly, the Villager's here was carved from a Rickles, the hardware chain that went bankrupt, losing out to Home Depot. Channel was another casualty.
The 40,000-square-foot Villager's here, like the others on the drawing board, is smaller than the typical 120,000-square-foot Home Depot. And it has neither the look nor the incessant beeping of the fork lift trucks of the larger stores.
Huge items like lumber, large appliances and sheet rock for big home improvement jobs cannot be found. Instead, Villager's is meant to be a place where men can feel as comfortable picking out dinner plates as women can choosing power tools.
Convenience is the idea behind the concept, said Mr. Wittman, which could be rolled out nationally based on the performance of the test stores.
"We want to get customers in and out quickly," he said.

HEADLINE: Marla Nierenberg, Michael Hanan

Marla Sue Nierenberg, a daughter of Claire Nierenberg and Dr. Aaron Nierenberg of South Orange, N.J., is to be married today to Michael Scott Hanan, a son of Linda A. Hanan of Parsippany, N.J., and Nathaniel Hanan of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein will perform the ceremony at Congregation Beth El in South Orange.
The bride, 31, is the director of education policy and new initiatives at the New York City Partnership, a business organization that is concerned with education, economic development issues and the building of affordable housing. His father is a business development consultant in Cliffside Park for the American Power Conversion Corporation, a manufacturer of backup power supply sources for computers.
