HEADLINE: DESTINATIONS;
Farms Where Turkeys Are Raised to Be Gobbled

BYLINE: By JOSEPH D'AGNESE 

 BODY:
"HELP WANTED" reads the sign hanging outside Ronny Lee's farm market in Hightstown. This is the time of year when Mr. Lee anxiously seeks extra hands to help him perform an unsavory but necessary seasonal chore. "We hang the sign up, but we don't say what it's for," he said. "People come in and inquire, and then we'll break it to them."
Mr. Lee raises apples, peaches, pumpkins, corn and a host of other crops on his 54-acre farm in Mercer County. But his farm, built circa 1868 and his family's home for six generations, is famous for its Jersey-grown turkeys, fat, corn-fed gobblers that sell for $1.49 a pound, plucked, dressed and ready for the oven. Last year, Lee's Turkey Farm filled 2,000 orders for customers wanting freshly killed birds for Thanksgiving. Mr. Lee expects about the same number this year, but as always, he'll need a little help. 
 Meanwhile, Larison's Turkey Farm Inn and at Hinck's Turkey Farm, two of the state's other major turkey purveyors, are also gearing up for the gobbler season. Each caters to a slightly different market.
At Larison's, a 53-year-old restaurant ensconced in a farmhouse in Chester, patrons dine amid antiques, Tiffany lamps and stuffed-animal trophies. "We get a lot of comments from people who say they came here as a kids," said Louise Blaine, whose cousin, Arthur McGreevy, has owned Larison's for 27 years. "They like being able to bring their kids now."
You could just let Larison's do the cooking for your dinner and swing by to pick up the bird in time for the meal. A ready-to-serve turkey, fresh from the oven, is $3.50 a pound and comes with two quarts of gravy. But you must order a 28- to 30-pounder.
That kind of takeout meal -- not to mention sandwiches, salads and trimmings -- is the year-round specialty of Hinck's, a four-store, family-run chain, which has raised its own birds on a farm in Wall Township since 1938. Hinck's, too, roasts whole turkeys for customers' tables but limits the number of orders. (Dinner for 10 runs $61; for 15, $83, and for 20, $123.) "We're going to be careful about taking too many orders," said Bob Longo, whose father-in-law, Richard Hinck, started the business. "I could probably take more orders and make more money, but I don't want to stress the system."
No other holiday calls upon one's ability to pull together a flawless meal, and turkey houses feel the pressure, too. "It's such a traditional meal," Mr. Longo said. "Everyone knows how it's supposed to be." All those expectations come to roost at the dinner table. And that has dictated how much business Mr. Longo accepts on this day. "When a customer sits down with one of our birds, we want it to be perfect," he says. "Therein lies our future."
And as he says, the meal itself has ties to the past. Historians are far more certain that eels and venison were served at the first Thanksgiving in 1621 at the Plymouth Colony than that turkey made an appearance. Gov. William Bradford's official record of the holiday menu notes only that he sent out four men hunting and they returned home with numerous "fowles." What those were is anybody's guess.
The tom turkey we all grew up drawing in grade school is at once vain and wily. To attract a mate, he flares his bronze-brown feathers like a peacock. Stalked by hunters, he uses those same feathers to camouflage himself in the woods. "One of the common misconceptions is that these birds are stupid," Mr. Lee said. "They are not. Well, my guys are not as swift as wild turkeys. They think I'm their mama because I raised them since they were a day old. But hunters need to be pretty skillful to catch a wild turkey."
For Mr. Lee and his family, turkey season starts in June, when they begin to receive day-old poults, as the babies are called, from a hatchery in Ohio. Not one of those turkeys will ever resemble the one emblazoned on the bottom of your serving platter. "These all have white feathers," Janet Lee said. The Lees' birds occupy comfortable quarters in the family barn.
All summer long they gorge themselves on corn, but these animals are clever diners. "We feed them once a week," Mr. Lee said. "We literally put all their food for a week right in front of them. If you did that to a dog, he'd eat it all and make himself sick. But turkeys know enough to eat and give it a rest."
When people -- the Lees, their visitors or children on class trips -- to visit the barn, the curious turkeys flutter en masse to the front of their barn fence to greet them. And as they go about their work, the Lees hear their occasional telltale calls. Toms make the traditional gobble; hens utter a different sound. "It doesn't really sound like a gobble, gobble to me," Mrs. Lee says. "They make a barking sound like a seal."
The silence of the birds comes in the two weekends and the week before the holiday, when Mr. Lee and his $8-an-hour hired hands -- men with regular jobs as varied as accountants, jet mechanics and stock car designers -- go to work filling orders. Customers from Texas, Florida, Georgia and California have been known to arrange business trips to drop by the farm and pick up their birds.
The attraction is taste, which is enhanced by proper storage and handling. Freshly killed birds are sold only by special order, but many are also frozen. Once a bird meets its maker, its cleaned carcass is aged 48 hours in a refrigerator, then flash-frozen at minus-10 degrees Fahrenheit. Mr. Lee insists there is no difference between the two, provided his system is strictly followed. Supermarkets, he maintains, handle birds poorly, dumping them into freezers just barely under 32 degrees. This is why he does not sell to supermarkets. When a customer arrives asking for a fresh kill but has not placed an order, "I say: 'Try one of my frozen birds. I'll stake my reputation on it.' Once they try it, they're hooked."
Besides being a stickler for quality, Mr. Lee subscribes to an odd but convincing notion that turkeys can act as an economic indicator. "You can literally follow the economy by the average size of the turkeys people are ordering," he said. "I can tell if it's going to be a winning year for stores for Christmas shopping based on sizes. The average turkey was 16, 17 pounds in the Carter years, and when Reagan got in, they averaged 27, 28, 29 pounds. Bush started at 25 pounds and ended at 22 pounds. Clinton boosted it to 25, 26 pounds, but I think it fluctuates every time he screws up. You can tell the economy's going strong right now. Sizes are even bigger this year than last."
But optimism may well flee earnest home chefs when they get the turkey home. Every Lee bird leaves with cooking instructions and a phone number, which customers are not shy about using. "We might get calls at 6 A.M. asking, 'How do you cook this thing?' Mr. Lee said. "One year, someone called as they were sitting down to eat. 'It's really bony,' they said. 'I can't cut it.' I told 'em, 'Turn it over.' "
Then there's the zealous chef who remembers only that Mom used to get up early, stick the bird in the oven and cook it all day. They're a little fuzzy on details like cooking times and temperatures. When their relatively small 15-pounder is ready by 9 A.M., Mr. Lee, a one-man Thanksgiving hot line, fields the call: "I tell them, 'O.K., you want to keep it warm until dinner time, and you're going to need a lot of gravy.' "
It could be worse. They could be cooking the Pilgrims' traditional Thanksgiving eel.
Hinck's Turkey Farm (limited seating, bakery and takeout meals year-round). Four locations:
 1414 Atlantic Avenue, Wall Township, off Manasquan Circle; (732) 223-5622.

LENGTH: 1005 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Even the Mayor Is Not Immune

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
Mayor Sara Bost had not repaired the wall where car thieves had slammed into her house on Eastern Parkway when it was riddled with bullets from a drive-by shooting.
She said last week she thought the shooting on Oct. 14 -- in which no one was hurt and no suspects were charged -- was in retaliation for her effort to crack down on the drug trade by putting more police officers on the streets at night. 
 But privately, some officers said the mayor's home -- up the street from an exit of the Garden State Parkway -- might simply have been a victim of the random gunfire that seems all too common these days in this crowded corner of Essex County.
Only days after the mayor's house was peppered with bullets, a 16-year-old mother of two was shot to death in her home on Highland Terrace. And last week, at Oak Street and 15th Avenue, a block from the mayor's house, a wreath was hung in memory of a young Irvington man who was shot to death there in July.
The recent violence highlights a much more gradual but no less dramatic decline in the fortunes of Irvington, a 2.8-square-mile township of 61,000 residents sandwiched roughly between Newark to the south and east and suburban Essex and Union counties to the north and west. Once a bedroom community of one- and two-family houses more akin to its suburban neighbors in affluence, racial and ethnic composition, Irvington over the last several decades has more closely reflected the deficits of its looming neighbor: violent crime, poverty, a decaying physical appearance.
"We're a suburban community with urban problems," said Mayor Bost, whose challenge since being elected in 1994 has been to reverse the trend.
As if the city cannot generate enough crime on its own, officials here said a crackdown on drugs in Newark had had the unforeseen consequence of pushing business over the boarder.
"On one side of 20th Street is Newark, on the other side of 20th Street is Irvington, so when they increase their effort, the drug dealers just come over," Mayor Bost said.
It was a gloomy Election Day at the Fire Department's Station No. 4 firehouse, an East Ward polling place and sturdy brick reminder of the township's past as a middle-class suburb of Newark. But inside, the brass polls were gone; across the street, two houses were boarded up.
The Rev. Theodore Backman, an associate minister at the Zion Baptist Church in Newark, had just cast his vote when he paused to list some of the problems that infest the town.
"One's a drug problem, one's a housing problem, the other's a rat problem," Rev. Backman said. "All these abandoned buildings, if they can't sell them, they should tear them down."
He lamented that Irvington had changed since he moved here 31 years ago from Newark. "People were more up to par," he said. "It was a more quiet area. It's become more transient. They're moving in, moving out. Plus, you've got landlords who don't live here, so people say, 'I don't care.' "
To help combat crime, there are plans to enroll about 40 cadets in the Essex County Police Academy in January and add them to the 172-member force in the spring with the help of $6 million federal grant.
For now, the town does what it can. "We're putting pressure on the dealers," Chief Steven Palamara of the Irvington Police Department said one recent day as a yellow front-end loader uprooted an illegal telephone from its concrete base; the phone was suspected of being used for drug deals.
Charles Henderson, 40, a firefighter for 13 years who grew up here, said it had pained him to move his family into a condominium in Basking Ridge five years ago. "I've got a son, and the education system is not what it should be," said Mr. Henderson. "In Basking Ridge, they still sing Christmas carols."
The departure of middle-class residents and the abandonment of property are factors in what Mayor Bost said is the local government's most fundamental problem: a low 88 percent tax collection rate that has forced the city to cut services and raise taxes for property owners who do pay.
It is that inadequate tax collection rate, Mayor Bost said, that forced her to declare the city in distress and to open its books to auditors to receive additional funds from the state's Aid to Distressed Cities Program. She said the city received $6.7 million toward a $61 million budget for the current fiscal year. Next week, the state will announce next year's aid for Irvington as well as for East Orange, Jersey City, Paterson and Camden.
To be sure, there are breaks in the gloom enveloping the township. The West Ward, for instance, is lined with well-kept homes owned and occupied by professionals. Just off Eastern Parkway, Maple Gardens is a private gated complex of spotless brick high-rise apartment buildings set off by flower beds and manicured lawns.
In addition, Mayor Bost said the city is condemning 140 properties to clear the land for residential development that will provide housing and tax revenue.
In terms of business, Springfield Avenue, which divides the 2.8-square mile city, is a bustling commercial strip, with hardly a vacant storefront in sight. The city's largest employers, including Revlon, Standard X-Ray and American Aluminum, have remained steadfast. Businesses participating in the state-chartered urban enterprise zone alone have invested more than $40 million and hired 316 residents since May 1996, said Lorelei Mottesse, director of the town's urban enterprise program.
Ms. Mottese said the city recently formed a district to assess retail businesses for improvement projects along Springfield Avenue. A similar program is being formed for industries, she said. The city has also received a $114,000 grant from the state Department of Environmental Protection to study redevelopment of its mildly contaminated industrial sites, called brownfields.
"Everyone is working very, very hard," said Ms. Mottese, a former mayor of Lincoln Park, "to bring Irvington back as the Newark suburb that people remember so fondly."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 12; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1021 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
Rocking the Foundations Of American Life

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
LITTLE STEVEN VAN ZANDT has always been "a band kind of guy." Having said that for the first time many years ago, he left his role as a guitarist in Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, which many fans consider one of the best rock-and-roll bands in the world, to start a solo career in 1984.
That career has now brought him back to being a member of the hottest rock band to hit the stage in years while also releasing his fifth solo album this fall. 
 Some music industry watchers may consider the term release a misnomer when applied to the new album, "Born Again Savage," on his own Renegade Nation label, since the album has been available only through the artist's Web site (www.LittleSteven.com) since early September.
Until Mr. Van Zandt, 49, reconnected with his longtime friend when Mr. Springsteen recreated the E Street Band for a reunion and "rededication tour," he had done little musically that was in the public eye for a decade. He acknowledged that only his dedicated fans were aware of the Web site or the album until recently.
"Born Again Savage" is the last installment of a five-part concept Mr. Van Zandt conceived in 1982. He set out to explore the meaning of the individual, the family, the state, the economy and religion, all weighty topics to deal with in rock-and-roll songs. He did not shy away from the controversial side of any of his topics and produced two albums with decidedly anti-American government themes.
His current effort, which he described in a telephone interview from the road as the only pure rock-and-roll album he has ever made, is just as hard-hitting as the first four albums, both in musical style and in its judgment of American life, this time as it relates to religion. Musically, the album sounds like an update of the 1960's, complete with psychedelic overtones on some tracks, plus a sprinkling of punk and alternative rock to liven things up.
Mr. Van Zandt, who grew up in Middletown and now lives in Manhattan, was born into a Catholic family but grew up as a Baptist. He says he now accepts a mixture of many religions.
"I think people are a little lazy when it comes to religion," he said. "Religion should make you dig deep inside and think. Then you can make up your mind."
The songs on "Born Again Savage" deal with the hypocrisy that Mr. Van Zandt feels is rampant in religion, as well as many people's muddled and shallow thinking about heaven, hell and God. Although the album is considered a solo effort (Mr. Van Zandt plays all the numerous, hard-driving lead and rhythm guitar parts), he is backed by an old friend, Adam Clayton of U2, on bass and Jason Bonham, son of the Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham, on drums.
On each of his albums, Mr. Van Zandt put together a talented but temporary backing band, which is different from the kind that defines a "band guy." That kind of band generates lifelong friendships, personal commitment and people who will always be there for one another -- like the E Street Band, which has claimed his loyalties from the early 1970's on.
Despite the talent he displays on his albums, Mr. Van Zandt has never had an easy relationship with recording companies. His fourth album, "Revolution," was released only in Europe and is now almost impossible to find. His newest effort is to be available in some independent record stores starting Nov. 30.
"We wanted to put it out there for the fans first," he said. "I've had the Web site since the beginning of the year, so it seemed like a good way to go. Record companies have a lot of reasons to not like me, in addition to the fact that I deal with controversial subjects. I'm old; I've never had a hit; many of my songs are not particularly radio-friendly, and true rock-and-roll is very much out of favor right now."
He has a sixth album of nonpolitical songs written but said he did not know when he might release it.
Mr. Van Zandt acknowledges that he is lucky to have the money and the fame from the E Street Band to allow him to market his own recording, something many independent artists do not have the option to do.
"But I think I've earned it, too," said Mr. Van Zandt, whose speaking voice is a far cry from the drawn-out, gravelly growl heard on his songs. "I've learned the harder you work, the luckier you are."
Much of the music on his albums is derived from the years of research he did on everything from the meaning of human existence to apartheid in South Africa to the involvement of the United States government in the politics of South American countries.
Once again, Mr. Van Zandt's celebrity status contributed to his ability to do things most people could not do. He spent much of the 1980's globe-trotting into any country that had a war or oppression going on, and when he felt he knew enough about a situation, he would take a stand and try to effect change.
"Sun City," a 1985 song that united more than 50 artists in a fight against apartheid, was one of the results of this personal obsession with world politics. It is also one of the few songs he has ever written that did not make it onto his or someone else's album because, he said, he writes only the songs he needs.
"Voice of America" and "Freedom, No Compromise," his second and third albums, were also direct outgrowths of his travels and include African and South American rhythms.
"Helping to end apartheid in South Africa was the most satisfying,' he said. "You very seldom have clear-cut victories like that. It is usually a process of chipping away at something."
The United Nations has twice honored Mr. Van Zandt for his humanitarian efforts. He is no longer caught up in a missionary zeal to politicize the world, as he says he once was, in part because he now has three careers going at the same time. In addition to the world tour with the E Street Band and his solo work, he plays Silvio Dante, a Jersey street guy and mob enforcer on HBO's critically acclaimed series "The Sopranos."
"Unfortunately," he said, "learning the truth about what is going on in the world, and even learning about oneself, is a luxury because it is a full-time job."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
GreenspanCranes His Neck Over Stock and Home Prices

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve, as everyone knows, is always trying to keep inflation down without sacrificing too much economic growth. The public debate that accompanies this process focuses on the behavior of the real economy. The booming stock market has stretched that focus, of course. But even so, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is expressing greater concern lately about the dangers of a high stock market and rising home prices.
Far more than in the 1970's or 1980's, the wealth embedded in stocks and home ownership generates spending, and thus raises the odds that consumer demand will exceed the nation's supply of labor, materials and services. Inflation would then accelerate. Mr. Greenspan and his fellow policymakers have argued that case in the past. And now the chairman has underscored his concern in three speeches since mid-October. 
 "The frequency with which he makes this point means that his not-terribly-successful campaign to talk down the stock market continues," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist and a former Fed vice chairman. "He has not given up."
And if his jawboning doesn't work? If stock prices fail to decline from present levels, or even resume their climb? Would he want to raise rates at the next Fed policy meeting, on Nov. 16, fulfilling an expectation that unsettles the stock market?
Mr. Greenspan himself has probably not decided yet. The Fed tries to control inflation, or the threat of it, by raising interest rates. But the target is inflation itself, Fed officials insist, not any one of the contributors to it, like stock prices. In his recent speeches, Mr. Greenspan has not changed that message. But his remarks have heightened the profile of stock prices and home prices as potential contributors to inflation.
The economy once drove the stock market; now the opposite is true. Raising rates is one way to discourage stock buying and nullify the market's inflationary potential.
"There is no question that the stock market has become an important component" of our discussions, said Edward M. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor.
Mr. Greenspan's recent speeches outline these discussions, or at least his decisive contribution to them. New technologies, he argues, have made corporate management more efficient, and have raised the level of labor productivity, or the amount of goods, services and revenue that an average worker produces in an hour. All this adds to Corporate America's capacity to increase supply and thus satisfy rising demand.
Rising stock prices reflect this improvement, Mr. Greenspan says. They also reflect a view that stocks are less risky an investment than in the past and therefore worth more. Both factors, however, may be unsustainable. Stock prices, in short, may be unjustifiably high, in bubble territory.
A financial crisis could restore the old risk factor. A stock that now seems worth $10 may, a few months from now, be fairly valued at only $8 to a more nervous investor. The "equity premium" will have risen, or, as Mr. Greenspan puts it, "The key question is whether the recent decline in equity premiums is permanent or temporary." If the improvement is temporary, then stocks will eventually plunge in some crisis, damaging the economy and also creditors who have loaned tens of millions of dollars for the purchase of stocks.
THE productivity-growth trend presents another danger. While it certainly is at a higher level than in the recent past, that level cannot keep on rising. When the inevitable plateau comes, Mr. Greenspan warned in one of his speeches, then consumer demand, still driven by market wealth, "can accelerate so much that total demand could rise above even the productivity-augmented" greater supply of goods and services. As demand exceeds supply, shortages develop and prices rise.
A speech on Tuesday added home prices to the mix, but in a subordinate role to stocks. For every dollar of stock market gain, consumer outlays are lifted by 3 to 4 cents, Mr. Greenspan said, while higher home prices yield 5 cents for each dollar of gain. But only "about a sixth of the so-called wealth effect -- that is, the impact of capital gains on consumer spending -- stems from equity extracted from the sale of existing homes," he said, or the refinancing of mortgages. The rest comes from the huge, booming stock market.
The distinction adds to the stock market's importance in the Fed's deliberations. "Greenspan is not targeting the stock market," said William C. Dudley, a chief economist at Goldman, Sachs, "but he is saying the market is an increasingly important factor in setting interest rates."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Blackmail Questions

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating whether contractors working on downtown renewal projects in New Rochelle were pressured into hiring minority workers, city Detective Lieut. Robert DeLeno said.
The investigation follows the October indictments of Darnell King and Clifford Lester, the detective said. The United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York has charged that Mr. King of Mount Vernon and Mr. Lester of New Rochelle tried to extort money and jobs at construction sites at the New Rochelle Public Library Plaza parking lot and at a nearby park. The indictment also charges that the defendants conspired to extort money, including salary payments and protection payments, from the construction companies, using threats of damage to the companies' machines and a threat to the owner of one of the companies to accomplish their goals. 
 They apparently posed as members of a coalition seeking minority employment, authorities said. Both defendants face federal extortion charges that carry a penalty of up to 20 years in prison.
Judge Charles Brieant of Federal District Court in White Plains ordered the two held in the County Jail in Valhalla without bail while they await trial. A bail hearing was set for Friday.

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER;
But Does It Work?

BYLINE: By ALAN B. KRUEGER; Alan B. Krueger, a former chief economist of the Department of Labor, is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University. He is writing a book entitled "Education Matters," to be published next year.

 BODY:
We run from one fad to another in education, from phonics to whole language and back to phonics, from subject-based to holistic learning, from curriculum-based to child-centered learning, from neighborhood to magnet to charter schools, from old to new to whole math, from English-only to bilingual education to language immersion.
With education growing as a voter concern, politicians have been quick to martial dueling remedies of their own. Republicans propose expanding charter schools and diverting funds from failing schools to finance vouchers. Democrats want to reduce class size and install computers in the classroom.
Indeed, how we teach our children shifts with the winds of philosophies and politics, leaving many observers dizzy and dismayed. 
 "The sad truth is," the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once lamented, "American schools, by and large, do not know how to teach. The ineffectiveness in teaching reading skills to many young people, whether white or black, poor or rich, strongly indicts foundations and government for not spending funds effectively to find out what different kinds of reading experiences are needed by youth with various learning styles at various points in their life."
Thirty years later, we still know little about the effectiveness of the tools in vogue: school vouchers, charter schools, school-to-work transition programs, summer school, year-round schooling, extended-day schooling, tracking, school uniforms and small schools.
Dr. King was correct to look to research to shed light on this darkness. But therein lies the problem: education suffers from a lack of scientifically sound studies.
The federal government spent $14 billion on space exploration last year, but less than $300 million on research to improve education. The primary research function of the Department of Education has been to administer tests and collect data. Less than 1 percent of its budget goes to research, with even less to conduct and evaluate studies.
Controlled experiments are especially rare. With insufficient funds and little tradition in experimental methods, most researchers rely only on observations in a handful of classrooms, without any concrete measure of results. Findings are weak or inconclusive.
Take, for example, the decades of seesawing over automatic promotion, the practice of passing students to the next grade so they can remain with their peers, whether or not they have mastered the material. The National Research Council and various studies have found that students who are held back, with little additional tutoring, continue their academic slide and are more likely to drop out. But those studies don't tell how those children would have fared if they had been promoted. They might have done even worse, justifying an end to the policy once and for all.
Or consider the nationwide rush to wire schools, despite the contradictory claims about the effectiveness of computer-based instruction. Should computers be a priority for inner-city fourth graders who read at the first-grade level? Or do they need more books and less software?
By randomly selecting some classrooms to receive computers and some to go without -- or some districts to practice automatic promotion and some to hold back failing students -- the effects could be measured under scientifically appropriate conditions. Random assignment ensures a balance in terms of variables like students' intelligence, motivation and parental involvement.
Such research is not unheard of. In the late 1980's, in a Tennessee study by a consortium of universities, 11,600 students in kindergarten through third grade were randomly assigned to regular-size classes of 22 to 25 students, to regular-size classes with teacher's aides or to smaller classes of 13 to 17 students. The results, gleaned from tracking the students for four years, showed that attending a smaller class increased average test scores. Students did not score higher when their classes had teacher's aides; and the teacher's experience and whether he or she had an advanced degree were also irrelevant to scores. Two recent follow-up studies showed that students assigned to smaller classes were more likely to graduate from high school and apply to college.
Although these results have made a case for reducing class size, leading to billions of dollars in additional federal, state and local spending, they shouldn't be the end of the story.
The largest improvement occurred the first year. The gain remained about the same for four years, while the students were in smaller classes, but the advantage shrank when they returned to regular classes. Think of it as that first aspirin that makes a headache go away; the second and third keep it at bay, and when you're off the aspirin, it comes back, but not as badly.
Further experiments might show that it isn't necessary to reduce class size for all grades -- an expensive proposition. One dose might suffice. And it may not be necessary to reduce them everywhere but to concentrate efforts in districts where the study found the most improvement -- areas with many low-income and minority students.
Another reform sweeping the country is just beginning to be tested. In 1997, Mathematica, a nonprofit research company in Princeton, N.J., conducted a lottery to randomly select 1,300 low-income public schoolchildren in New York City to receive vouchers to attend private elementary schools. After the first year, the students scored, on average, only 2 percentile points higher on math and reading tests than those who remained in public schools -- a difference that was just barely discernible statistically. By comparison, the gain for low-income Tennessee students after one year of small classes was 7 percentile points. The voucher experiment is to continue for another two years, and it will be interesting to see if the private school students ultimately show meaningful gains.
Naturally, experiments involving children raise a host of ethical dilemmas. Some fear that members of a control group are denied the advantages of a sound education. But without conducting a controlled study, it wouldn't be clear which students were harmed -- say, those who were given computers or those who weren't. And some students would be denied computers anyway, because they aren't being installed in all schools at once.
Enough progress has been made since Dr. King's day that we don't need to take radical, untested steps to try to improve education. American public schools have educated the most productive work force in the world, test scores are rising, and a higher proportion of students graduate from high school than ever. Educators should demand compelling evidence before making wholesale changes.
The Food and Drug Administration requires scientific testing before new drugs are prescribed. Why should we treat children's minds differently from their bodies? Just as that agency has created an impressive body of medical knowledge, the Education Department can lead the way to a greater understanding of what works and what doesn't by requiring experimental evaluations before federal dollars are thrown to the philosophical and political winds.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE & MONEY;
Financial Aid for the Bourgeoisie

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN; Andrew Ross Sorkin reports from London for the Business Day section of The Times.

 BODY:
CHRIS CORNISH has a solid annual income of $140,000 from his own software business. He and his wife, Sandra, own three cars, including a Jeep Grand Cherokee, and live in a four-bedroom house in New Canaan, Conn.
The Cornishes do not sound like naturals for financial aid. Nonetheless, their daughter Jordana, a sophomore at Vanderbilt University, got $22,150 in aid this semester in the form of a $13,950 grant and several low-interest loans. Their daughter Charissa, who took time off before entering her sophomore year at William and Mary College, received a $23,000 aid package, mostly in low-interest loans. 
 "We're thrilled we were able to get what we got and talk about it," said Sandra Cornish, referring to the stigma financial aid would once have had in her prosperous community. "I'm not sure it would always have been that way."
Financial aid is no longer strictly for paupers, at least not paupers by traditional standards. As the cost of higher education hovers between $20,000 and $30,000 a year at private institutions and $8,000 at public ones, even affluent families are finding their wallets too thin.
Aid officials say that some families receiving help this fall have incomes over $200,000, and some have assets that hit seven figures. About 14 percent of students from families with incomes of $100,000 or more received federal aid in the 1995-96 school year, according to the Department of Education's latest accounting. For those attending private colleges or universities, the figure was 45 percent.
"We have more people at higher levels of income getting financial aid," said Thomas C. Keane, the director of financial aid and student employment at Cornell University, where 508 families with incomes over $100,000, 79 of them earning more than $150,000, received need-based grants last year. At Princeton University, 126 freshmen were eligible last year despite household incomes in excess of $105,000.
"The costs are going up faster than families' income is going up," Mr. Keane said. "Now there are programs so that anybody can get money, at the very least through a loan."
Administrators advise that even families with seemingly little need should apply, since they may qualify for some help. Special considerations might include many dependents, more than one child in college, certain large debts or high medical expenses. Aid officers know that tending to a sick or an elderly parent can drain resources.
The most salient feature of the Cornishes' application was the fact that they support five young children in addition to their two college-age daughters; they also have a growing business with debt. Still, the Cornishes paid $1,400 for the services of a consultant to help both daughters enhance their financial aid eligibility as well as find the best deals.
Many private colleges are sweetening their financial aid packages not only because their endowments are swelling in a boom economy, but also to attract students with the grades, demographic profiles or special skills to balance their student bodies.
"There are so many ways to be eligible for aid these days," said Monique Thomas, the founder of Collegiate Financial Aid Services in Darien, Conn. She believes that qualifying for aid is as much an art as it is a science -- a philosophy that has spawned an industry of financial aid helpmates and, for those seeking lower sticker prices, shelves of self-help books.
"I go through a 72-point system, where I look through tax returns and examine income and assets," said Ms. Thomas, who recently helped a family with three children in college obtain about $55,000 a year in mostly grants and scholarships, despite their having assets close to $500,000.
Kalman A. Chany, the founder and president of Campus Consultants, in New York City, says that many potentially eligible families don't apply. "There are a significant number of households that could be eligible but just don't bother, or they're too intimidated by the process and throw up their hands in disgust," he said.
Just as the Internal Revenue Service allows certain deductions to be taken to lower one's tax bite, there are legal ways to lower a family's tuition bill by increasing its eligibility for financial aid. And the arguments for using loopholes are similar in both circumstances. "You should be able to get what you're entitled to," Mr. Chany insisted. "Parents don't create the formulas."
Saving for the long term, of course, is the best way to ensure that there will be enough money to pay for college.
"A poor family without the means to pay for college will find concerned financial aid officers ready to look in every corner of their coffers to come up with the aid necessary to send that family's child to college," writes Mr. Chany in his Princeton Review guide, "Paying for College Without Going Broke," whose year 2000 edition came out last month. Not so, he adds, for well-to-do families just looking for the college to pick up the bill. "An honest attempt to save money, and a willingness to make sacrifices, can make a large impression," he writes.
With that in mind, here are short-term strategies that can maximize a family's chances for aid.
 
The ABC's
Aid packages usually consist of a combination of grants, work-study programs and, most often, low-interest loans. The college's financial aid officers, who have considerable discretion in allotting aid, can arrange a package using the institution's own money and funds from numerous state and federal programs.
Perhaps the most well-known federal grant is the Pell, a gift of up to $3,125 a year per student. But households with incomes over $40,000 rarely qualify. The Perkins loan, which at 5 percent currently carries the lowest interest rate of any higher education loan, is also designed for the most needy.
For stretched middle- and upper-income families, the most accessible federal loan is the Stafford. This loan is either subsidized or unsubsidized. Families that can demonstrate need and qualify for the former don't pay interest while the student is in college. The unsubsidized version is available to virtually anyone, no matter what the household income. Because of the low interest rate, which cannot go above 8.25 percent, some families have even been known to take the loan just to invest the money. (The current rate is 6.32 percent while the student is enrolled, after which it rises slightly.)
Colleges' methods for determining a family's need can be subjective and confusing, especially for institutions doling out their own money. "There are a lot of different ways to view a family's income and assets," Mr. Keane conceded. Even if you do not receive government money, you may be eligible for thousands of dollars in grants from the school itself.
The formulas that are used to ascertain what is called the Expected Family Contribution, or E.F.C., are indeed long, complicated exercises. Applicants can get help with the federal formula at www.ifap.ed.gov, the Department of Education's Web site for financial aid professionals.
Interactive calculators for both the federal formula and the Institutional Methodology, a different formula used by many private colleges and some state universities, are available at www.collegeboard.org.
The formulas consider parent and student incomes and assets, as well as the number of dependents and other family circumstances. Financial aid officers at a student's chosen college compute the cost of attendance, including tuition and fees, room and board and allowances for books, transportation and personal expenses. That number, minus the E.F.C., is a family's need -- the amount of money the student is eligible to receive from the government and the college.
Say, for example, that a family of four has an annual household income of $85,000. Not considering assets or any other circumstances, such a family might be expected to contribute $13,508 toward a child's education, which would amount to 15.9 percent of its gross annual income. At a state university, $13,508 could cover the entire cost for a year. At a private university, it might cover only half the year's tuition. But the college could arrange a package of government grants and loans or its own aid to cover the balance.
In this situation, Mr. Chany writes, "Depending on how badly the college wants the student, parents won't pay a penny more for an exclusive private college than they would for a state school." In some cases, they may even pay less, he adds.
But families must first fit their financial picture into the formula.
"The E.F.C. is the key number," said Greg Phillips, the president of Phillips Financial Aid Services, a financial aid consulting company in Pittsburgh. "That's where income and asset planning comes into play to get that number as low as you can get it."
 
E-Z Aid
Juggling assets and income can be risky, so it's important to talk to an accountant before making any big changes.
In addition, "the process has to start early, not in December of a child's senior year when these high schools have their Financial Aid Nights," Ms. Thomas said. "It's just too late."
The reason is that eligibility for aid is based on the family's income from the tax year that began in January of the student's junior year. By December, parents will want to have minimized their discretionary income for that year's tax return by, say, avoiding capital gains, profits on stock sales or premature withdrawals from I.R.A.'s.
Consultants also tell families with modest incomes and substantial assets to file the short forms 1040A or 1040EZ, if they can. When adjusted gross income falls below $50,000, assets are not considered, no matter what their worth, when the data on the federal form, the Free Application for Federal Aid, is analyzed.
Mr. Phillips, for instance, has clients with more than $1.5 million in assets but a household income of $40,000. Because they could file a 1040A, the clients ended up with a Pell grant and a Perkins loan.
"That's crazy!" Mr. Keane said. "With a million dollars in assets, it is likely they would not have received any need-based aid from Cornell. That's why we use Profile."
He was referring to the College Scholarship Service's Profile form, which many private colleges require in addition to the federal application and sometimes their own forms. Profile is far more inquisitive, demanding more information on assets and income.
But Mr. Keane adds that he would still have been required to provide government money to Mr. Phillips's clients.
"We're not allowed to deny somebody money when they prove eligibility through the federal formula," he said.
 
Whose Money Is It, Anyway?
Accountants often suggest that parents put money in children's names because of the many tax benefits while the child is growing up. But that move works against applicants who are filing for aid. That's because in determining E.F.C., administrators using the federal formula figure that the student will pay 35 percent of his or her assets (25 percent according to the Institutional Methodology), and parents 5.65 percent of theirs (5 percent in the Institutional Methodology).
"Do I think they should move that money back into the parents' name before the kid applies for college?" Mr. Keane said. "Yeah, I do.
"It really isn't the kids' money," he added. "The students never earned that money. But if a parent is putting money away for their child, taking advantage of the tax law while the child is growing up, they should be able to move that money back to where it benefits them most for financial aid."
 
If It's a Very Good Year
Families can have an exceptional financial year.
Nice as that is, it distorts the picture when it comes to aid. If a given year's income is extraordinary, consultants recommend writing a letter of explanation to the college's financial aid office, and including a tax return from the previous year to demonstrate the point.
"You've got to hit them over the head with your special circumstance," Mr. Chany said. "You have to be short and brief, because they are overworked. Tell them your income just went up, or it's about to go way down. You have to give them real numbers."
Financial aid officers sympathize with big medical expenses. And if a special circumstance exists -- say, the parents are divorced, and the father has stopped making his child-support payments -- officers can consider that, too.
 
Grades vs. Need
No matter what the financial situation, the key to getting aid is being a good student.
"Grades, SAT's, the quality of the student and what they bring to the table is going to make a difference," Ms. Thomas said. "The admissions office is going to be a heck of a lot more generous with a kid who has done really well than with Johnny over there, who is just a C student, even though need-for-need, they may be the same."
 
Need Help?
Higher education may be hopelessly expensive, but there's at least one source of aid that's often free: advice. The SLM Holding Corporation, better known as Sallie Mae, the nation's largest financer of student loans, offers the following options for angst-filled (and debt-ridden) parents.
l College Answer Service, (800) 891-4599. Financial-aid counselors answer questions and provide details on grants, loans, scholarships, work-study programs and application procedures. You can also obtain a free guide, "Paying for College."
l Parent Answer Service, (800) 891-1410. Counselors discuss the federal Parent Loan for Undergraduate Students (PLUS); you can determine your eligibility and apply over the telephone.
l The Web site www.salliemae.com offers information on financial aid as well as online loan applications, loan tips, a glossary of terms and interactive calculators to estimate Expected Family Contribution.
l If all else fails, the commercial Web site www.ECollegebid.org gives parents a chance to bid for a tuition they're willing to pay. Participating colleges then decide if they're willing to accept the bid. The site, which becomes active this month, works much like Priceline.com, the electronic discount-travel service.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Bidding War To Uncork Drug Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
REDD FOXX, the comedian, once observed that health nuts were going to feel stupid someday, lying in the hospital dying of nothing.
It is difficult to call a business with more than $130 billion in sales worldwide dead, but until the end of September drug stocks did not have much life: as measured by the Amex Pharmaceuticals Index, from the start of the year through Sept. 29 the group was down more than 14 percent. The stocks started to wake up in October. Last week, investors became even more interested when Pfizer made an $82.4 billion bid for Warner-Lambert, casting doubt on Warner's friendly merger agreement, worth more than $70 billion, with American Home Products. 
 Until recently, Larry N. Feinberg, managing partner of Oracle Investment Management, which manages about $600 million in hedge funds and private equity exclusively in health care companies, was not buying drug stocks. He is now. Mr. Feinberg took some time last week to talk about the industry's problems and prospects. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
 
Q. In the mid-1990's drug stocks were crushed by fears about the Clinton health plan and then roared back. What has ailed them this year?
 
A. Drug stocks have lagged this year because of economics, politics and the Internet.
From an economic point of view, fears of rising inflation have not helped, because if interest rates are backing up, then price-earnings multiples are suspect.
A political issue is the biggest cloud over the industry, and one of the keys there is the Medicare prescription drug benefit. There is a big political push to get the elderly covered for prescription drugs. This fear of government regulation implies possible price controls by the government.
The Internet has caused concerns about drug utilization and benefit management. Historically, the thing that has been really striking about the health care industry is the lack of information flow.
Now we are entering a period where a number of companies are hooking up health information systems with doctors. The net impact of that is that drug utilization will get controlled more, and cheaper drugs, where applicable, will be used more often.
 
Q. It seems these are real concerns. Yet you are positive on drug stocks. Why?
 
A. We are past the bottom and are beginning to turn up. For demographic and technological reasons, the health care industry will be the world's great growth industry.
I believe we have entered a tremendous new product cycle. At the moment we have new drug categories like osteoporosis, breakthrough drugs for certain cancers. The first two flu drugs have just been approved. These are huge new markets that are opening up, and we are just at the tip of the iceberg.
The next big wave will be based on genomics, as we get more answers to what genes turn on and off and why that happens. That will lead to customized drug therapy.
Even if the effort to curb costs intensifies, expensive drugs are not going to go away. If they are better than generics, paying for them is still better than putting people in the hospital.
 
Q. What is your sense of the struggle for Warner-Lambert?
 
A. Both Pfizer and American Home Products are good fits with Warner-Lambert.
American Home Products has a great drug pipeline. Warner-Lambert doesn't have much of a pipeline, but it has good products. The Pfizer bid, which will be hard for American Home Products to match, is more of a strategic combination in that it gives Pfizer a better position in the cardiovascular business.
But the real key to this is that this is the trigger that will open the floodgate to further mergers.
 
Q. Which companies are more likely to combine than others?
 
A. Anybody who wants to get bigger is a candidate, so you could include everybody in the industry. There are tremendous cost savings to be realized.
The most obvious merger candidates are those that need help, a list that includes Novartis, SmithKline Beecham and Pharmacia Upjohn. I wouldn't put it past Merck to do a deal. In the next five years there will be fewer, bigger players.
 
Q. So which stocks do you like?
 
A. We own Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has a great drug pipeline, American Home Products and biotechnology companies like Amgen, which is selling at a multiple comparable to the drug companies but is spending twice as much on research and development.
Aside from the drug companies, the big opportunity for investors is business-to-business commerce in health care.
Companies in this area include Medical Manager, CareInsite, which has the former management team from Medco Containment; Healtheon; and IDX Corporation.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Dividends Are Fading As Market Signals, Too

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT 

 BODY:
OF all the market-timing models that failed to anticipate the extraordinary stock bull market of this decade, the most spectacular failure has been the one that is based on dividend yields.
According to that model, the stock market is overvalued whenever the average dividend yield of stocks drops to historically low levels. Between 1871 and 1990, the stock market was in danger whenever its dividend yield dropped to below 3 percent; stocks lost 3.2 percent, on average, over the subsequent year. 
 Often, such a yield portended a bear market. At the market top before the bear market of 1973-74, for example, the dividend yield of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was at 2.7 percent, then a record low.
But the signal hasn't worked in the 1990's. The S. & P. 500 last traded at a 3 percent dividend yield in October 1992, when the index itself was around 420. As of Friday, with the S.& P. 500 more than three times as high, its dividend yield is near its record low of 1.18 percent. At that rate, the S. & P. 500 would have to decline by more than half just to bring it back to the level that has signaled a major market top.
Clues to the model's failure are seen in a new study that examines the role of dividends in the United States economy all the way back to 1926. The study, by two finance professors -- Eugene F. Fama of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business and Kenneth R. French of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management -- concludes that the role of dividends has diminished.
Today, for example, just 20.7 percent of all publicly traded American companies even pay a dividend. As recently as 1978, that share was 66.5 percent. And even during the Depression, the number never dropped below 33 percent.
The professors discovered, first of all, that the universe of publicly-traded companies has changed significantly over the years. Relatively more and more companies are either unprofitable or so in need of cash that they must invest their earnings into their businesses. Often such companies are relatively young and have small market capitalizations. This class of companies rarely pays dividends, the professors said, and has seldom done so in the past.
CONSIDER the growing proportion of American public companies that are unprofitable. In any given year before 1980, that figure was rarely above 10 percent. At the end of 1997, however, it was more than 30 percent.
Even when small-cap companies have earnings, however, they rarely pay dividends. That is because they are often growing so fast that it makes far more sense to put their cash to work themselves. From 1963 until 1997, according to the study, the assets of companies that have never paid a dividend have grown 15.7 percent a year, on average, versus 8.7 percent for dividend-paying companies.
According to the professors, only about half the decline in the percentage of companies that pay dividends can be explained by the increased prevalence of this class of companies that are often fast-growing, small-cap or both. They attribute the other half of the decline to an increasing reluctance to pay dividends on the part of established, profitable and often large-cap companies -- a class that has made payouts in the past.
Many Wall Street analysts believe that this parsimony has been caused by the increasing popularity -- since the mid-1980's -- of companies' share repurchase programs. These stock buybacks are really just another way for management to distribute profits to shareholders..
But Professors Fama and French dismiss that view. They found that buyback plans have, almost exclusively, been the province of dividend-paying large-cap companies.
Furthermore, such companies are distributing a greater percentage of their earnings as dividends today than they were before repurchase programs became so popular. So share buybacks cannot explain why fewer large-cap companies are paying dividends today than in the past.
Regardless of the causes, it is clear that dividends don't play the role they used to in corporate America.
Of course, that reduced relevance doesn't mean that stocks aren't overvalued. But if a bear market does begin from today's levels, it won't be because the market's dividend yield is too low.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

(Source: Disappearing Dividends: Changing Firm Characteristics or Increased Reluctance to Pay?, by Eugene F. Fama and Kenneth R. French)

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
In Convertibles, a Path To Technology Stocks

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY has been the undisputed champ of the bull market. But investors seeking a slightly less risky way to jump into the sector may want to consider convertible bonds.
Technology companies have long tapped investor enthusiasm by issuing convertibles and preferred stock to finance the next stage of their growth. Of the $26 billion of convertibles issued year to date, more than 30 percent were from technology companies, according to the Value Line Convertible Survey. 
 Technology convertibles make up 41 percent of the market value of the Merrill Lynch All U.S. Convertibles Index, versus 26 percent one year ago. (Even a relatively technology-heavy index like the Standard & Poor's 500 has a technology weighting of just 24 percent.) The Merrill index has returned 17.8 percent so far this year, nearly keeping pace with the 19.0 percent return of the underlying stocks, according to Preston Harrington III, a convertible bond strategist at Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Harrington says technology convertibles may be an attractive alternative for investors who worry about the high valuations of the sector's stocks. "It's a more conservative way for investors to play technology," he said.
Convertibles are hybrid securities that can be exchanged for a specific number of shares in the issuer's underlying common stock. They offer much of the upside of a stock if prices are rising -- investors can sell the appreciated bond or convert it to stock. At the same time, the fixed interest rate paid on them provides some of the protection of a bond.
The hook for investors is that a fairly priced convertible usually rises more on an increase in the price of the underlying stock than it falls if the shares tumble.
"There is no question investors can sometimes do better with a tech convert" than with the common stock of the same issuer, said Michael Shamosh, bond strategist at Tucker Anthony. But, he added, there is still plenty of risk.
Hedge funds, for example, often profit by selling short the shares of technology companies, betting that they will decline, while holding the convertibles, so they can profit from a steeper decline in the stock while collecting the convertible's yield. That creates volatility when the hedge funds unwind the positions.
On their own, however, individual investors face big hurdles in buying convertibles, which are often rated below investment grade. Experts say sophisticated skills are needed to analyze the complex risks of both the stock and the bond. And because most of the technology convertibles are issued on an unregistered basis, only institutions can buy them initially. Individuals cannot trade the bonds until they are registered, usually 90 to 180 days later.
Convertible funds offer one solution. These have returned 12.6 percent a year to date through October, versus 10.2 percent for the average United States diversified fund, according to Lipper Inc., the research firm.
A clutch of such funds had heavy investments in technology as of Sept. 30. The $70 million Value Line Convertible fund had a 40 percent technology weighting, which includes the bonds of Internet companies like Doubleclick, Mindspring Enterprises and CNET. It has an average credit quality of BB.
The $47.4 million TCW Galileo Convertible Securities fund, with 37 percent of its assets in technology, has stakes in STMicroelectronics, Intel and Conexant Systems, and has an average credit quality of BBB-, higher than the average convertible fund.
The $449 million Van Kampen Harbor fund, with 36 percent of its holdings in technology, holds big positions in Comverse Technology and Conextant. Its average credit rating is BB+.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH -- EUGENE E. PERONI JR.;
John Nuveen & Company

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WHO'S in charge of the stock market? The little guy, says Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of equity research for defined portfolios at John Nuveen & Company, the money management firm based in Chicago.
"Institutional investors dominate the market only in terms of trading volume," Mr. Peroni said from his office in Radnor, Pa. "The turning points in the market, the more reliable and sustainable moves, are led by individual investors." 
 And so he scans the ticker tape, looking for heavy and consistent buying in particular stocks by investors trading in relatively small lots of 10,000 shares or less, almost your average mom and pop.
Following small investors is key to Mr. Peroni's craft. Each year since 1995, he has picked 10 stocks to be packaged into a unit investment trust, or U.I.T., an unmanaged portfolio of securities that are held for a set period -- 13 months. (Investors usually have the chance to roll over their investment into a new U.I.T. the following year.)
Previously, Mr. Peroni's U.I.T.'s were available only to clients of Janney Montgomery Scott, a brokerage firm in Philadelphia where he was director of technical research. In May, he joined Nuveen, and on June 15 he started the $40 million Peroni Growth Portfolio: Summer Series 1999, which holds 20 stocks. Starting on Dec. 6, Nuveen will offer a U.I.T. called the Peroni Top 10 Picks Portfolio: 2000, consisting of 10 stocks.
At Janney Montgomery, Mr. Peroni's 10-stock portfolios combined to produce an impressive record, returning 24.7 percent a year before commissions and fees, on average, for the 10 years through December 1998, compared with 16.6 percent for the Dow Jones industrial average. Through Oct. 29, the $138 million Janney Montgomery Peroni Top 10 Growth Trust 1999 portfolio, which started Dec. 4, 1998, returned 35.6 percent, versus 19.0 percent for the Dow Jones index, Nuveen said.
U.I.T. investors can buy shares only during a brief window (through January, for example, for the Peroni Top 10 Picks portfolio to be offered next month). The portfolio almost never changes over the life of the U.I.T.
Investors pay a 2.95 percent commission to their brokers the first year and 1.95 percent if they decide to roll it over -- so this is not a low-cost alternative to a mutual fund. The new Nuveen U.I.T., which has a minimum investment of $1,000, also carries expenses of 0.20 percent.
Mr. Peroni's stock-picking system was designed by his father, Eugene E. Peroni Sr., 89, an architect who became PaineWebber's head of technical research in 1971.
The younger Mr. Peroni, who describes his investing style as moderately aggressive, looks for mid- or large-capitalization growth stocks that have been trading for at least two years.
Mr. Peroni doesn't have much use for computers.
"We rely on the tools that were available at the turn of the century," he said: "ticker tape, a quote machine and point-and-figure graphs, which are drawn by hand."
The point-and-figure charts illustrate a stock's price movements of $1 or more.
"The graphs give us a good overall look at pricing patterns," Mr. Peroni said, "and let us quickly identify departures from a stock's historical price trend."
MR. PERONI ignores trades of 10,000 shares or more, which are usually institutional. Why? "We find that institutional traders react to news, like rumors or changes in analysts' direction," he said. "Individual investors are intuitive and anticipate positive change.
"I'm not talking about the CNBC couch potato or the day traders," he said, but rather "astute individuals who may have spent their careers at a particular company and know the business, the technology or the service intimately."
Hence the ticker tape, which shows all trades, rather than computer programs that typically highlight only high-volume trades. Patterns are sometimes visible in a day, but typically take several weeks to identify, he added. He takes special note of companies when he is satisfied that individual investors are making a strong commitment to the stock. Institutions follow sooner or later, Mr. Peroni says.
He whittles his list to 40 or 50 stocks by focusing on strong sectors where investors are buying steadily, typically choosing market leaders in each group. Currently, he likes technology, drug and telecommunications stocks.
By design, his 10-stock list generally includes just three or four industry groups. "For many years, the market has been driven by a few key industries and stocks," he explained.
Mr. Peroni gives minor consideration to nontechnical factors, including company news, economic events and Nuveen research reports. And he pays no attention to typical valuation measures like price-to-earnings ratios or book value.
One of his favorite stocks is Solectron, in Milpitas, Calif., a contract manufacturer of high-technology products like computer motherboards. Solectron is in his 1999 Janney Montgomery U.I.T. and the Nuveen summer U.I.T.
"The question is whether we're moving to a new generation of chips that would require retooling of equipment companies," Mr. Peroni said.
The stock could advance, he said, not only because of rising earnings expectations but because of the prospects for technological advances. Shares closed at $81.50 on Friday.
He also likes Commscope, a Hickory, N.C., manufacturer of cable that transfers data and voice more efficiently than copper lines. The cable is used in telecommunications links and in computer line hookups. Mr. Peroni said the stock, which is in the Nuveen summer U.I.T., had consistently outperformed earnings expectations. It closed at $42.50 last week.
ANOTHER favorite is Texas Instruments, which finished last week at $93.4375. He is bullish on the semicondutor business in general, but he also likes the company for its pursuit of higher-growth areas of the sector.
"The company has refocused away from calculators and semiconductor chips, and focuses on digital signal processing as a way to put data into digital format," he said. Texas Instruments is in the summer U.I.T.

HEADLINE: A U.S. Study Of Embassies Says Updating Is Urgent Need

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
American embassies are "perilously close to the point of system failure" because of antiquated buildings and grossly inefficient computer networks, an independent commission reported on Friday.
Few American diplomats can send e-mail messages to each other, even within the same embassy, but continue to depend on the slow and hierarchical "cable culture" of traditional diplomacy, said the independent commission, the Overseas Presence Advisory Panel. 
 In some embassies, including those in Ukraine and Angola, embassy staff members work in trailers or freight containers because spending on buildings has not kept pace with changing demands and staff levels, the panel said.
The solution is to spend at least $200 million on information technology, to rethink the size and shape of embassies, to perform some administrative functions regionally or in Washington and to set up a new corporation to manage government property abroad, the report added.
"The status quo is not acceptable," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said of the report. "We need more resources to support our people, operations and programs. These are investments that will pay large dividends rapidly."
The commission also backed an earlier recommendation that the United States spend about $1.3 billion a year for the next 10 years to protect embassies from attack.
Dr. Albright set up the panel in April, partly in response to the bombings in August 1998 at the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
The panel also said staff cuts at embassies could lead to significant savings. "We should have a leaner, more agile, better functioning, better trained force representing the 30 agencies who do work overseas," the panel's chairman, Lewis Kaden, a New York corporate lawyer, said at a news conference on Friday.
The United States has more than 14,000 citizens stationed overseas in 252 diplomatic posts in 160 countries. The State Department employs about 38 percent of them, followed by the Pentagon (37 percent) and the Agency for International Development and the Justice Department (6 percent each).
