LENGTH: 3059 words

HEADLINE: Can G.M. Return to the Passing Lane?

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
A JOKE making the rounds of car dealers offers this solution to America's drug problem: "Turn the marketing over to G.M. and demand will go away."
The chief executive of one auto maker said he no longer bothered to pay attention to G.M. And John P. Wolkonowicz, an industry consultant at Buhlin Group, summed it up this way: "They've fallen and they can't get up." 
 General Motors may be the world's biggest company, and it may be enjoying record sales and profits, but it still doesn't get much respect.
Just last week, G.M. took the first step toward an expected management reshuffling that would be its biggest in seven years. But while its current leaders can point proudly to vast improvements in the balance sheet, there are doubts throughout the industry about whether a new team can solve the company's giant, persistent problem: a failure to plug a steady leak in market share. If the economy sours, the company -- as well as its work force -- faces enormous problems.
It is bad enough now. In October, G.M.'s market share, 28 percent, was smaller than the combined share of Asian auto makers, 28.4 percent. In some ways, that marks the end of an era. While G.M.'s market power has been eroding for three decades, sinking below the Asians was inconceivable a generation ago.
Decades ago, when G.M. built more than half the cars on the road, when designers expressed America's postwar exuberance with soaring tail fins, when marketers captured the imagination of millions by telling them to "see the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet," G.M. was held in awe. But for years it has built take-no-chances vehicles, usually a step behind the competition. G.M.'s design triumphs are now found not in garages but in museums.
"The company continues to run behind the curve," said Gerald C. Meyers, a former American Motors chairman who is now a professor of organizational behavior at the University of Michigan. "They have got to get out and lead the market in design."
G.M. knows it needs flashier cars, and is attacking that problem. "To get market share you need great products," said John F. Smith Jr., 61, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive. He is expected to retire in May, along with the director who helped install him in a palace coup in 1992, John G. Smale. "We've got a lot of strength coming in the marketplace," Mr. Smith said.
The changing of the guard is likely to amount to different men wearing the same uniforms and marching with the same methodical steps, according to interviews with directors, executives and others close to the company.
In the expected succession, several executives close to Mr. Smith would simply move up the ladder. Harry J. Pearce, 57, now vice chairman, would become chairman, while G. Richard Wagoner Jr., 46, now president and chief operating officer, would become chief executive. Mr. Smith said in a recent interview that he had no plans to retire soon, but people close to the company said that he is ready to step down and that the board planned to announce those changes in January, effective when Mr. Smale retires in May.
G.M.'s leaders said in a series of interviews that the company would be hitting on all cylinders within a few years -- that it had redefined each brand and was developing cars and trucks that meet its sharpened marketing goals. In an effort to win back buyers, G.M. plans to introduce 20 new car models and 40 light-truck models worldwide in the next four years.
IF it works, G.M. will have a sizable edge over its rivals. As other car makers scramble to become big enough to sell cars worldwide -- in the last year, Daimler-Benz bought Chrysler, Ford bought Volvo and Renault took a big stake in Nissan -- G.M. is already global in a way that they only dream of being.
Some experts said great designs could indeed jump-start G.M. "You can't expect to get much change in market share when you are just me-tooing," said David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. He noted that Chrysler -- the poster child of car company turnarounds -- "was very damaged and they turned it around remarkably fast."
Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's retired president and vice chairman, agreed: "If they really came up with blockbuster cars and trucks as opposed to me-too vehicles or O.K. vehicles, they could turn things around in a hurry."
G.M. has a long way to go. Because its market-share decline has been so steady, it is hard to grasp its severity. At its peak, in 1962, G.M. sold 51 percent of the nation's sets of wheels -- with its Chevrolet division alone selling 31 percent.
In the 1999 model year, the whole company sold just 29.7 percent in an industry where executives claw like alley cats for every tenth of a point. G.M.'s market share even ticked down a tenth of a point from the 1998 model year, when a strike shut down production and essentially erased a month's worth of sales. In the 1997 model year, a fairer comparison, G.M.'s share stood at 31 percent.
The October 1999 number was G.M.'s lowest ever, with the exception of strikes.
The global picture is also grim: At its postwar peak in 1950, G.M., which peddles cars and trucks in 170 countries, sold 39.6 percent of the world's vehicles. By 1992, when Mr. Smith took over, that was down to 17.6 percent. In the first nine months of this year, it was 15.9 percent.
Starting next year, the board will add worldwide market share to the criteria that determine executive compensation.
"We need to grow market share; there is no question about it," Mr. Pearce said. "Our necks are on the line."
Car companies in trouble typically focus first on fixing what is closest to the consumer -- their cars and trucks. That is what Nissan is trying to do now, and what Chrysler already has done.
In the 1980's, Chrysler was best known for its boxy K-cars. But in 1989, it unveiled the Dodge Viper, a flashy muscle car. "An automobile company doesn't even have to be very good to look great if they have blockbuster products," said Mr. Lutz, now chief executive of Exide, the world's largest battery maker. "The Viper was the key to revitalizing the whole Dodge brand and possibly the whole Chrysler Corporation."
But that hasn't been G.M.'s way. It lost $2 billion in 1990 and $4.5 billion in 1991. Since Mr. Smith took over in 1992, G.M. has made money every year -- and has fixed everything but its cars.
Today's cars, of course, are better than yesteryear's, but the improvements haven't been enough to pass the competition. However, executives have managed to lift profits by improving productivity, quality, time to market, manufacturing, operating efficiency and, most recently, labor relations.
"We have systematically changed most things at General Motors," Mr. Smith said. "We're not a troubled company."
G.M. has set quarterly earnings records for four quarters in a row. Its high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickups are so popular that it cannot build them fast enough. Most analysts urge clients to buy G.M. stock. And despite its shrinking market share, G.M. is poised to set sales records this year because overall sales levels are so high.
BUT these achievements, to some extent, are the products of a sizzling economy. On closer inspection, G.M.'s financial picture is mixed. On the upside, it has already surpassed next year's goal of an average 12.5 percent return on net assets for four quarters in a row.
On the other hand, Mr. Smith had set a quarterly 5 percent net profit margin goal. But in the third quarter, G.M. missed that by a mile, managing just 2 percent, with its Latin American and Asia operations losing money. For the first nine months of the year, the overall margin was 3.4 percent. By comparison, Ford's margin was 6.3 percent.
And while G.M. has vastly improved its manufacturing efficiency, so have its competitors. Two decades ago, the Japanese could build cars for about $1,000 less than America's Big Three, according to Harbour & Associates, an auto industry research firm. Its latest study showed that G.M., along with DaimlerChrysler, still operates with roughly the same gap, while Ford has cut it in half.
G.M. has gone to great lengths, meanwhile, to impress shareholders. Between January 1997 and Oct. 13 of this year, it spent $7.5 billion to buy back 15.6 percent of its shares. It has sold or spun off to shareholders its Electronic Data Systems, Hughes Defense and Delphi Automotive Systems subsidiaries. And it is evaluating whether to spin off part of Hughes Electronics.
G.M. stock, having started the year at $58, ran up to a high of about $77 in April, but has since dropped to about $68.875, following the general trading pattern of Ford's stock. Most analysts rate the stock a buy, in part because it trades at just 8.12 times earnings.
But many rate it a buy for another reason. As John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch, put it in a recent report, the possibility of a Hughes Electronics spinoff "is the key attraction."
And while outsiders applaud G.M.'s efforts to improve its lineup, many are skeptical about the ability of G.M. executives to predict which cars and trucks will attract customers, given the company's track record of turning out dull designs. G.M.'s rivals are rushing out new models, too.
Robert J. Eaton, a former G.M. executive who is now co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler, said the thought of competing with G.M.'s future offerings didn't exactly make his knees knock. G.M. has not proved a force to worry about for some time and, he said, "I don't expect it will in the future either."
But Ronald L. Zarrella, president of G.M.'s North American operations and its marketing chief, countered: "I hope our competitors are writing us off. I think they are making a huge mistake."
Others hope so, too. G.M. stock can be found in the portfolios or pension plans of at least 1.2 million Americans, and nearly 400,000 workers around the world depend on G.M. for a livelihood. So while "What's good for G.M. is good for America" may be an outdated saying, the company remains awesome in size and impact.
The market share question is important not only because it symbolizes the decline of a once-great American company. Its answer may also be essential to the well-being of G.M.'s 143,200 factory workers in the United States. Mr. Zarrella said one reason the company's share had not increased this year was that G.M. is already building as many cars and trucks as it can. But in a weaker economy, workers now pulling overtime would probably face layoffs.
"In a lower market, we've got to increase our market share," Mr. Pearce said. "You would have excess capacity, and excess capacity means higher costs and less profitability and that's not the way we are going."
G.M. executives can explain their market share problems. "When we had the difficulties in the early 90's, we had to stop a lot of product programs," Mr. Smith said. "That hurt us."
When G.M. started making money again, it concentrated on replacing its biggest sellers with fresh products -- primarily midsized cars and minivans in a market craving sport utility vehicles and pickups. And because the money those cars brought in was keeping the rest of the company afloat, managers were loath to take design chances.
THAT is no longer the case. By 2004, G.M. wants half of its lineup to be made up of innovative products -- cars and trucks that are daringly designed, that do something other auto makers haven't thought of or that sharply improve on what others have done. The bulk would be vehicles that mix and match attributes of cars, pickups and minivans.
That is a big change. Three years ago, G.M. looked five years into the future and classified fewer than 5 percent of its products as innovative, said Lawrence D. Burns, G.M.'s vice president for research and development and planning.
Mr. Wagoner added: "I think people would like to see a little more spice in the mix -- maybe products, frankly, that may not be that critical from our volume and pricing and profitability perspective, but might liven up the overall car portfolio. And I think that's a fair criticism, and I think you are going to see more of those."
Some question whether G.M. can pull it off. Industry leaders say top G.M. executives are not "car guys" but financial wizards who seem out of place at car races, where many industry executives seem at home. As a result, those leaders said, they do not trust their gut instincts for what will prove popular with buyers, and instead rely heavily on research. Mr. Smale, retired chairman of Procter & Gamble, is as happy selling soap as cars, and so are many of the marketers G.M. has hired in recent years to sharpen the image of its vehicles. Mr. Pearce is a lawyer.
"G.M. is betting its future on getting the science of predicting what will work versus what won't work to levels which nobody has achieved before," said Mr. Lutz, the retired Chrysler executive. "It is possible that the science will prevail, but it would be the only area of creative expression where a scientific formula will determine the hits."
Indeed, in 10 separate interviews, G.M. executives mentioned the "R.D.B.'s" of various cars and trucks -- the "relative differentiated benefits" they give customers.
To be sure, the research effort is awesome in scope. G.M. has 40 full-time people who search the world for social, economic, environmental and political trends that might influence buyers. The sophisticated, ambitious forecasting and planning projects are intended to ensure that G.M. can be ready for whatever the future holds. One "what if" situation is that people will someday travel in flying cars, just as portrayed on "The Jetsons."
Despite G.M.'s Herculean research efforts, outsiders are skeptical. Just three years ago, G.M. introduced 15 cars and trucks that executives insisted would end the company's slide in market share. But those models only increased share slightly in some segments, while the overall decline continued.
As for G.M.'s latest assertions, "we've heard that song before," said Nissan's president of North American design, Gerald P. Hirshberg.
But G.M.'s rivals are hardly standing still. DaimlerChrysler is investing about $47 billion to develop 64 new cars and commercial vehicles by 2004. Toyota plans to introduce 11 models in the United States in the next 18 months. The much smaller BMW plans about a dozen in the United States in the next two years. And all auto makers are rushing to add new crossover products -- vehicles that combine car and truck attributes -- to the American market.
While G.M. said it had been focusing intensely on styling for the last 18 months -- and vehicles take up to five years to develop -- the company's latest styling attempts have been mere evolutions of existing designs. A year ago, G.M. replaced its full-sized pickups -- the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra -- and in January it will bring out sport utility vehicles based on those designs, new versions of the Chevrolet Suburban and GMC Yukon XL.
G.M. executives argue that customers who are likely to buy those vehicles don't want radical styling changes. And they point out that the new trucks are handily outselling the old ones. '
'The new truck, some would say, is in terms of its styling, incremental," Mr. Pearce said. "That's what our marketing research said was warranted." While other companies are rushing out expressive designs for their sport utility vehicles, G.M.'s will look much like those that have been on the street for nine years.
G.M.'s newest design efforts -- the Chevrolet Impala and its two-door cousin, the Monte Carlo -- have also turned out bland, according to competing designers. But Mr. Pearce said "an Impala is very exciting in its own market segment," arguing that buyers of midsized sedans are more concerned about safety features and interior space than styling.
While some reviewers have given the cars high marks for handling, others are less generous in their praise. Automobile Magazine called the Monte Carlo "inoffensive but hardly exciting" and wrote, "We hope that by the next redesign, Chevrolet might wake up and make the Monte Carlo great as opposed to just O.K."
Mr. Wagoner shrugged. "Beauty is a little bit in the eye of beholder," he said.
OF course, styling isn't the most important attribute for some buyers. Legions of baby boomers have grown to trust Consumer Reports, but G.M. vehicles seldom excel there either. "Generally, the G.M. products have not done well," said David A. Champion, the magazine's director of auto testing. "In terms of reliability, they've always been below average, so we haven't been able to recommend them."
"They're getting better," Mr. Champion said. But he could only think of two the magazine had recommended in recent years: the Chevrolet Lumina, which he said was reliable but had sloppy handling, and the Oldsmobile Intrigue, which recently was dropped from the recommended list because of reliability problems.
Even if the skeptics are wrong and customers fall in love with the cars and trucks that flow out of G.M.'s new efforts, it will be years before most make it from designers' drawing boards to dealers' lots. Mr. Zarrella said market share should gradually increase because of new models like the Saturn LS and the Chevrolet Silverado and Suburban.
"The truth will be told over the next five years," Mr. Wagoner said. "I don't deny there are a lot of challenges for us, but I would have to say I like our deck of cards."
As Mr. Wagoner and Mr. Pearce prepare to take the reins at G.M., and as Mr. Smith and Mr. Smale prepare to retire, there is another striking change from 1992. The board is no longer clamoring for anyone's head. In fact, Mr. Smale is defending current management against outside critics instead of leading the charge to throw it out. "This is a cup half full, not half empty," Mr. Smale said.
And while market share is so important that it is now discussed at every board meeting, it is not done in a scolding manner.
"This is not the board shaking its finger at a complacent management, saying, 'Why don't you get your market share up?' " Mr. Smale said in a recent interview in his Cincinnati office. "The board agrees with management that the market share ought to be higher."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Coaching Entrepreneurs for Profit

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
IN his years in Congress and in his career as a professional football player, Jack Kemp gained fame but little fortune. Now, Washington's champion of entrepreneurship and the free market is turning his preaching into practice, embracing capitalism in a more personal way: He owns high-technology stocks worth millions, he's on the boards of nine public companies, he's an adviser to two Silicon Valley venture capital firms and he's raised capital for fledgling Internet ventures.
"I'm a Nasdaq kind of guy," said Mr. Kemp, co-director of Empower America, a Washington nonprofit corporation he helped found to promote the free market. "I want to see the little guy grow up to be a big guy -- and take me with him." 
 And what a ride it is for Mr. Kemp, who at 64 is being rewarded handsomely for connecting Washington with Silicon Valley. For starters, his Empower America board is filled with top names in private equity: The Forstmann brothers, Ted and Nicholas; Julian H. Robertson Jr., chairman of Tiger Management; and West Coast venture players like Thomas W. Weisel, who heads his own firm, and E. Floyd Kvamme, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers.
With such gold-plated connections, Mr. Kemp has become a strategic adviser, an indefatigable networker and a man who can meld ideas, people and money. "Jack really sees the value of entrepreneurial capital and now he's in it up to his waist," said Mr. Kvamme of Kleiner Perkins.
For instance, Mr. Kemp introduced Mr. Kvamme to the management of SeeItFirst.Com, an Internet streaming video company that plans to go public one day. Kleiner Perkins backed the company, and Mr. Kemp is a board member and investor.
"I played football when there was no money in it, and I was in Congress when there was not a great deal of income from it," Mr. Kemp said in a telephone interview. "I believe in capitalism and I paid my dues. Now I'm doing very well."
A look at his diversified portfolio of corporate board memberships shows how well: Carson Inc., an ethnic hair care company; JumpMusic.Com, an Internet music retailer; Proxicom, an Internet networker; Oracle, the software giant; ZapMe, an educational networking company; the Hawk Corporation, an industrial components maker; Realmed, a health care company; Speedway Motorsports, car racing sponsors; and Sports Authority Inc., a sporting goods retailer. The latter two seats came about through his friendship with Nick Buoniconti, the former Miami Dolphin.
Mr. Kemp is also on the advisory boards of two venture capital firms, Thayer Capital Partners in Washington and Thomas Weisel partners in San Francisco. He is also a professional speaker and is on the board of nonprofits like Howard University, Habitat for Humanity and Opportunity Industrial Centers, an urban business development group, pursuing his belief that entrepreneurism can help minorities and the poor, too.
"I introduce companies to people who have access to capital," said Mr. Kemp, the vice-presidential candidate on the 1996 Republican ticket. "I introduced Proxicom to Tom Weisel and he did the secondary stock offering. I'm involved in start-ups, in speed-ups. While I don't consider myself an expert, I can open doors and make introductions."
Financiers say Mr. Kemp's advice is invaluable. "Only recently has Silicon Valley realized government exercises a big role," said Joseph G. Fogg 3rd, a venture capitalist and Empower America board member.
The boards of these companies generally pay Mr. Kemp an annual retainer of $10,000 to $30,000, plus around $1,000 for each meeting he attends, along with fees for other activities. And he can buy stock at a discount.
While Mr. Kemp will not say how much he earns, Securities and Exchange Commission filings indicate he owns around $2.3 million in Proxicom shares and has 63,000 options in Oracle, a company whose stock closed last week at $58.6875. He met Lawrence J. Ellison, the Oracle chief executive, through a leading Bush administration economic adviser, Michael Boskin. "Sixty-three thousand Oracle options," Mr. Kemp said. "I got a lot more than that. It's a great company. I jumped at the opportunity to be on that board because it's one of the most dynamic software companies on the face of the globe."
How Mr. Kemp ended up making millions from Proxicom, based in Reston, Va., is a tale of politics paying off in unexpected ways. Proxicom's chief executive, Raul Fernandez, 33, with a net worth of at least $287 million, once worked for Mr. Kemp on Capitol Hill. "Raul's a brilliant guy, did all my computer work for me when he was 19 years old," Mr. Kemp said. "He's just a neat, neat guy and he came to me one day and said 'Mr. Kemp, I think I want to start my own business.' And, here I am the champion of capitalism and I say to him 'stay with me and I can get you a $10,000 raise in the Bush administration.'
"Well, now he put me on his board," Mr. Kemp said, "and I put him him in touch with some venture capital guys and he went public five months ago and today the stock hits 83 and Raul's worth like a half-billion dollars."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: Next to Mom and Dad;
It's a Hard Life (or Not)

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
MONEY doesn't buy happiness -- and among teenagers, it may actually make life feel harder.
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll last month, 1,038 young people aged 13 to 17 were asked to compare their lives with what their parents experienced growing up. Over all, 43 percent said they were having a harder time, 33 percent said they were having an easier time and 23 percent said it was about the same. At the same time, there was a divide along economic lines, with the upper-income children saying they were feeling more burdened. 
 In fact, the affluent teenagers, whatever their race or gender, were substantially more likely than those from more modest homes to report that their lives were harder and subject to more stress: Among those with household incomes of $75,000 or more, 50 percent said their lives were harder, 28 percent said easier and 21 percent said they were about the same.
Among those from families where the household income was less than $30,000, only 38 percent said their lives were harder than their parents', compared to 41 percent who said their lives were easier and 18 percent who said they were about the same. Among those with household incomes of $30,000 to $50,000, 41 percent said their lives were harder, 33 percent said easier and 26 percent said about the same.
Some social scientists believe the gap is a measure of what parents tell their children, and how the information is conveyed.
"It's a really interesting class issue," said Gina Bria, an anthropologist at the Institute for Family Development in New York City. "In families living close to the bone, parents are more likely to pass on family stories about how people survived, and in the process to pass on skills for living. Wealthy kids often have less of a perspective on the struggles of life. And in some strata, there is a lot of pressure to keep the family's new-found status, and children feel the pressure to get into elite schools, to be sure they don't slide back. Everything's about going forward, about prosperity. Falling back is the American nightmare."
In later interviews with some of the teenagers who took part in the poll, the more affluent said that higher parental expectations, more pressure for good grades, a faster pace of life and a more dangerous world made their teen years more stressful than those of their parents.
It may come as a surprise to parents who came of age in the druggy 1960's and 1970's, with the Vietnam war raging, but many of their teenagers sound wistful describing their parents' childhood as care free, leisurely and safe.
"My parents both said they felt safe growing up, my dad in Long Island and my mom in California," said Ashley Nielsen, 14, of Alta Loma, Calif. "They could do a lot of things we can't do today, like I don't think they had to worry about things like hitch-hiking. Sometimes at football games, or when there's a whole bunch of teenagers around, I feel a little nervous, like something could happen. My world is pretty safe, but I know there's a real world out there. I think there's more peer pressure now than there was in their time, and more expectations to get good grades. Grades are the biggest stress for most kids I know."
Several teenagers who said their lives were harder described a steady anxiety about peer pressure and living up to their parents' academic expectations.
"Life was just a lot easier when my parents were growing up," said Tommy Shipp, 15, of Houston. "They didn't have as much peer pressure to do drugs and all that. There's a lot more pressure to be popular, and to drink. I've heard my parents talk. My dad's parents didn't really care what he did, he got kicked out of the house at 15."
But now that his father is a highly successful businessman, Tommy says: "I'm definitely going to go to college, and they care about how I'm doing in school."
Several of the more affluent teenagers who said life has gotten harder attributed it to a sense of too-muchness: too many activities, too many consumer choices, too much to learn.
"I think everything's gotten harder since my parents were growing up," said Molly Wilhelm, 15, of Lakeville, Minn. "Back then, I think everyone was more equal, but now, because there's so much more offered in styles of clothes and stuff, we all want to fit in. I think my parents had more free time, and the world isn't as safe as it was in their day. It's more common for kids to do drugs and all that stuff. Education gets progressively harder as people learn more, and there's more to cover. And now that there's more technology, they expect more out of us."
MANY teenagers from more modest backgrounds view the new technologies and new opportunities as making their lives easier than their parents' were.
"I think it's easier now, because of technology," said Ariel Garcia of Opa-Locka, Fla. "When you want to do a report, you just look at the Internet, you don't have to go to the library. Cars have air-conditioning now, so you're comfortable. There's microwaves, so it's easy to cook. My dad had it much harder. He's Dominican, and he was in the Navy. That's tough. I would never go into the Navy. Those rich kids, they don't appreciate what their parents do for them. The money just goes through their hands."
While the more affluent teenagers portray their parents' upbringing as easier, and more idyllic, the lower-income youngsters talk more of the difficulties their parents had to overcome.
"There were 13 in my mom's family, and there's only four of us, and without so many brothers and sisters, my mom can take care of all of us," said Rae-chelle Nunn, 17, of Columbia, Tenn. "Like my mom drives me to school, but when she was a kid, she had to walk."
Asked why the richest teenagers might see their lives as harder, Ms. Nunn has a quick answer "They're just spoiled brats," she said, laughing. "But I am too. My mom spoils all of us."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1272 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: GILT COMPLEX;
It's No Longer Just the Economy, Stupid

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE median size of a new house in the United States just passed 2,000 square feet, 25 percent bigger than two decades ago. Ford's new Excursion, a $37,000 behemoth of a sport utility vehicle, is selling out as soon as it reaches dealers. Half of all households now invest in the stock market. Unemployment is at a nearly 30-year low.
America is doing well by any material measure, and for the most part is thoroughly enjoying the experience. But there are also signs amid the prosperity that people are asking whether this is all there is, whether driving cars the size of tanks and parking them in garages the size of gymnasiums is truly the national purpose. 
 Polling shows that most Americans view themselves as less cynical and more compassionate than even a few years ago, and that they are inclined to do more for the less fortunate now that they have taken care of themselves. There has been a surge in volunteerism. Charitable giving is up across income levels.
At the same time, sociologists and commentators report that people feel more stressed, that they do not have enough time for their families, that they sometimes see their quality of life failing to keep up with their improved finances.
Restless searches for spiritual fulfillment and backlashes against consumerism are longstanding features of American society, and are magnified during periods of affluence, when people have the luxury of looking beyond the next paycheck.
Culture warriors, especially on the right, have long warned of a dangerous emptiness in the national soul. And it may be that the whole phenomenon this time around is nothing more than an attempt by self-absorbed baby boomers to feel better about themselves, especially given the persistence of the gap between rich and poor and the unforgiving nature of the global economy.
But the country also seems to be grappling genuinely with the question of how it can best put its prosperity to use.
THERE may never be a single or clear answer. But the issues behind the question are bouncing around Washington and on the campaign trail with increasing prominence.
In the aftermath of a bitterly partisan presidential scandal, it is perhaps not surprising that Washington has not yet reached any consensus. Presented with the opportunity this year to allocate huge projected surpluses, Congress and the Clinton administration gridlocked, shunting big ideas from both parties to the sidelines for now.
Still, there seems little doubt of a renewed willingness on the part of politicians across the ideological spectrum to focus more on those who have not benefited from the current boom. Less clear is how big an effort the country is prepared to mount to deal with such problems.
President Clinton, who twice won office by appealing to the middle class, spent two days last week touring inner cities, using some of his dwindling reserves of political capital to draw attention to ways in which a little bit of public money can encourage private enterprise to bring jobs and hope to the country's most blighted neighborhoods.
Not to be outdone, Republicans accepted an invitation for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to join Mr. Clinton in promoting the approach, which as much as any program illustrates a trend toward small-scale solutions that look to market forces and individuals rather than big government.
IN his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, Bill Bradley is bucking the trend to some degree. He is suggesting that government can tackle a few big problems with big programs and lots of taxpayer money, although even he looks to the private sector and markets in his plans to alleviate child poverty and improve access to health care.
Vice President Al Gore has positioned himself somewhere in the center. He has blasted Mr. Bradley for proposing to spend so much that the nation's newfound fiscal health would be endangered, and talks mostly about "working families," but has his own plans for issues like providing health care to poor children.
"Whether you believe that the federal government should do it or the state government or your church, there is a general feeling that we can now as a country look beyond our driveway and say, who in my town needs help?" said Rich Galen, a Republican consultant. "If somebody can tap into that, it can be a powerful political force."
In fact, the front-runner for the Republican nomination, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, seemed to recognize the opportunity particularly early, and built his campaign around the theme "Prosperity With a Purpose."
That purpose, it seems, is as broad and vague as it is indisputably admirable: that nobody gets left behind. And if the main beneficiaries are meant to be the poor and the poorly educated, the act of addressing their needs is intended to make those in a position to help feel more fulfilled as well.
IT has not escaped Mr. Bush's team that the approach could help neutralize the strong economy as an issue favoring the vice president by shifting the focus from whether voters are better off than they were four or eight years ago to how to capitalize on the good times. But they say the slogan only resonates because the country is looking for a moral dimension to its happiness.
"There's a sense out there in America that for years people strived for prosperity, and now they've achieved it but feel incomplete," said Mark McKinnon, Mr. Bush's media consultant. "Governor Bush has articulated a message that many Americans feel, which is that it's not enough for our wallets to be full if our hearts are empty."
Mr. Bush's ideas on how to achieve such a transformation -- like supporting faith-based charities, giving tax breaks to the working poor and improving underperforming school systems -- would not put any big new burdens on the middle class and would by no means rule out a broad-based tax cut.
And even in the context of a middle class that is looking for more than material gain, the middle class is still likely to demand attention for its problems.
Both parties are acutely conscious of a vague but persistent sense among many relatively well-off families that their children are not getting the attention they deserve, that they hardly know their neighbors anymore, that their lives are getting harder, not easier.
In some cases, the government can respond with specific policies, like requiring employers to provide leave for births, deaths or family emergencies. In other cases, politicians are struggling with how to respond.
"It's really a new agenda, and a lot of times leaders don't know what the solutions are or even what the questions are," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "Leaders who speak to it and come up with new approaches will be received well."
Ruminating last week on the new politics of prosperity, a senior member of the Clinton administration said that while the revived focus on poverty fighting was well established, there would also be a greater focus on what he called "trans-economic" issues.
"There's a kind of inner angst, beyond-materialism kind of dynamic that's emerging," he said. "It's 'Tipper Gore was right' kind of stuff: Is there a movie you can take your kids to? Are we raising a nation of Nintendo zombies?"
WHAT may be new is the degree to which such social and family concerns are no longer articulated un-self-consciously just by the religious right, which claimed them as its own during the 1980's.
Instead, they have become part of what Amitai Etzioni, a sociologist at George Washington University, called the "new, more moderate language of the moral center."

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Leaving the Farm for the Other Real World

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: FARGO, N.D.

 BODY:
TO Scott Halley, there was never any question that he was meant to be a farmer, his life forever set to the rhythms of planting and harvesting wheat.
But the balance sheet told another story. 
 "You look at the numbers at the end of the pencil," said Mr. Halley, 44, "and you realize it's time to try something different."
With a heavy heart, but a clear head, Mr. Halley recently joined a growing trend of American farmers who are voluntarily leaving agriculture rather than lose money year after year. But what has surprised many of them is that the transition to urban life has been so successful. Businesses are eager to hire farmers, who are often well educated and highly skilled as managers. And their families often relish the social and cultural offerings in places where the lights shine brighter.
A century ago, nearly half of all Americans lived on farms and ranches. Now fewer than 1 in 100 people farm. The winnowing of their numbers has been chiefly a matter of the food supply exceeding demand; technological advances, from tractors to computers, have allowed each acre of land to produce more and more bushels of grain.
While the resulting decrease in crop prices benefits consumers, farmers are struggling to survive. Operating on slim margins, only the largest farms stand a chance of turning a reasonable profit. Thousands of small farmers sell out every week, typically to a much larger agricultural enterprise.
Since leaving their farm in remote Bisbee a year ago to work as a soil scientist at North Dakota State University here, Mr. Halley has seen the family's income double to more than $40,000. And the Halleys' three children, who feared leaving rural life and starting over in suburban West Fargo, have thrived academically and socially in their new surroundings.
"The kids would never want to go back now," said Mr. Halley."The telephone never stops ringing."
A recent study at Iowa State University found that former farmers have largely succeeded in building satisfying new lives and sound financial foundations.
"The good news is that there is life after farming," said Fred Lorenz, a sociologist who worked on the study, which is to be published in the journal Rural Sociology.
Iowa State has begun a program that helps farmers move into other jobs. While farmers often walk away from the fields with deep feelings of dejection and failure, they have highly marketable skills, including working on computers, dealing with financial markets and running a business. Many farmers under age 50 are college graduates.
"Farmers underestimate their market potential," said Bruce Babcock, an agricultural economist at Iowa State. "They have a skill package that's in demand. It's just a matter of convincing them."
BUT even for those who found good jobs, leaving farming exacts a profound emotional toll, made all the more keen since farmers are surrendering a way of life that has often been carried on for generations.
"It's not just about making money, but about having a life that is meaningful," said Dr. Michael Rosmann, a farmer and psychologist who counsels farmers. "For most of them, that grieving lasts for the rest of their lives. To make the decision to quit farming, to do what's best for the family, takes an awful lot of courage."
Mr. Halley, who tended land that had been homesteaded by his wife's grandfather, feels the pull of the land every day. Once a week he drives eight hours to work a portion of the farm that has not been rented to other farmers, just to sustain the bond for a day. Mr. Halley, who earned an economics degree in 1978, is working on completing a master's degree. His wife, Denise, works for a catalog company in Fargo.
To succeed on their farm, the Halleys needed to get about $100 from an acre. Nearly 70 percent of that cost was tied to planting -- buying the crop, paying for fertilizer, maintaining machines; another 10 percent went for overhead and interest payments on the $130,000 debt for machinery. But with wheat selling for $2.40 a bushel, with 30 bushels an acre, the Halleys were falling far short.
Professor Babcock said farmers often succumb to a crisis mode of thinking -- "If I can just hang on for one more year, maybe things will get better." Too often the result is a draining of resources until nothing is left, he said.
Today grain prices are at their lowest levels in more than 10 years, even without adjusting for inflation. Farm aid packages enacted by Congress in the last two years have helped some farmers stave off failure. Despite the hard times, farmers have not been whipsawed by the terrible conditions of the 1980's, when land values fell sharply, interest rates soared and many banks called in their loans.
THE number of full-time farmers in the country has been falling since the 1930's, to less than one million. Iowa alone is losing some 1,500 farmers a year, Professor Babcock said. The typical Iowa farmer earns between $25,000 and $50,000 a year.
More than half of Iowa's farmers commute to jobs in offices or factories. It has become unusual for any farm to survive without some non-farm paycheck, often provided by a wife.
In the Iowa State study of farmers who left the land, incomes rose, and measures of stress and symptoms of depression declined, among children as well as parents.
Megan Halley, 13, who transferred from a class of 30 at Rock Lake School to a class of 400 at West Fargo Middle School, spoke with excitement about the courses in her new school. She especially likes art, which was not offered at Rock Lake, and computer technology. Back on the farm, she said, the antiquated phone system took five minutes or more just to dial up to the Internet.
"It's cool here," said Megan, who now shops at a nearby Gap, rollerblades at Skateland and finds the latest releases of one of her favorite band, Savage Gardens, at the record outlet. The closest store to the Halleys' Bisbee farm is a 10-mile drive.
Megan worried she might not fit in with the young people in her new surroundings.
"The boys here aren't any different than back in the country," she said. "There's just a lot more of them."

HEADLINE: A Dying Neighborhood Has Many Executioners

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article "Swept Away," a sympathetic image of the White Sands community (Oct. 10) reports (prematurely, I hope) on the "death of a neighborhood." If this comes to pass, then the executioners will be the Home Depot Corporation, the top administration officials and the local politicians.
White Sands's history is colorful but this is no more an obsolete neighborhood or an unhealthy slum than Broad Channel or Rockaway Point or Clason Point or many older waterfront communities. 
 But the economic impact of the proposed 171,000-square-foot Home Depot will devastate more than the immediate White Sands area. It would threaten at least 85 local businesses, by my count, employing more than 420 people and located in the major shopping and service streets: Coney Island and McDonald Avenues, Avenue U, 86th Street, Kings Highway and many others. The loss of these businesses could undermine the value of these streets, then the surrounding communities.
I call on responsible politicians to turn thumbs down on Home Depot.
 
IRWIN FRUCHTMAN
Gravesend, Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Nothing Behind The Wall

BYLINE: By David Fromkin; David Fromkin is the author, most recently, of "Kosovo Crossing: American Ideals Meet Reality on the Balkan Battlefields."

 BODY:
When the Berlin Wall came down 10 years ago this week, it made a lot of very smart people look very foolish.
The failed rebellions of East Germany in 1953 and Hungary in 1956 had convinced most Westerners that the Eastern Europeans could not overthrow their Soviet masters by themselves -- and also that America, the only country that could stand up to the Soviet Union, would not run the risks inherent in doing so. And everything we knew about Russia, and about human nature in politics, disposed us to believe that the Kremlin would not relinquish its empire voluntarily. 
 Only a handful of thinkers, ranging from Charles de Gaulle to the Soviet dissident Andrei Amalrik, foretold the eventual dissolution of the Soviet Union itself, and even they saw it as likely to happen as a result of disastrous wars with China or pressures from the Muslim Soviet states of Central Asia.
I know of only one person who came close to getting it right: Raymond Aron, the French philosopher and liberal anti-Communist. In a talk on the Soviet threat that I heard him give in the 1980's at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, he reminded the audience of Machiavelli's observation in "The Prince" that "all armed prophets have conquered and all unarmed ones failed." But what happens, Aron asked, if the prophet, having conquered and then ruled by force of arms, loses faith in his own prophecy? In the answer to that question, Aron suggested, lay the key to understanding the future of the Soviet Union.
The Berlin Wall -- and other Soviet walls, both real and metaphorical -- came tumbling down because nobody believed in them strongly enough to man them anymore. Not even the Soviet elites, the prime beneficiaries of the collapsing system, were disposed to call out the police or armed forces in defense of their fiefdoms. The armed prophets, having lost faith in their religion, surrendered their arms.
Anniversaries provide the occasion for looking back, and for re-evaluating. Perhaps the most curious thing about the events of 10 years ago is that just as Westerners were utterly surprised by what happened, we also overestimated what it signified. Caught up in high hopes for what freedom would bring to the former Soviet bloc, we confused the collapse of a failed ideology with a victory of our own system. Thus we are puzzled and disappointed that in the intervening decade the results have been uneven, with progress (in our meaning of the word) visible in some countries but barely apparent in others.
Might the explanation for these struggles date back to the crumbling of the wall? The rot in the Communist world set in long before the revolution of 1989 -- for years, the landscape of the Soviet empire had been dotted with Potemkin villages. Professors went through the motions of teaching students what both knew to be untrue. The economy was in large part make-believe: factories pretended to produce, employers pretended to pay and workers pretended to work.
So if the loss of faith that Aron posited occurred years before the wall fell, then the Soviet experience was a life of all-embracing fraud, in which people believed neither in themselves nor in others, nor in the institutions, policies and philosophies they all purported to serve. As law and government fell into disrepute, crime and corruption thrived. Marxist idealism vanished, creating a vacuum that was quickly filled by a lingering cynicism that stood much stronger than the Berlin Wall.
Is it any wonder, then, that the events of a decade ago did not usher in, uniformly and everywhere, the rule-of-law idealism that a liberal democracy with a free-market economy requires? All societies need certain amounts of coercion, but Aron was right in saying that coercion is not enough. Belief in the system is essential, too. What happened in 1989 was that our enemies gave up their own faith without necessarily acquiring ours.
The continuing electoral success of formerly Communist candidates and parties in Eastern Europe provides evidence of how hard it has been to convert the people of the former Soviet bloc to the Western liberal faith. Yet precisely such a positive belief in our values is required in order for these countries to build successful societies.
The paradox is that the loss of faith, the cynicism, the lawlessness and the corruption that enfeebled and then brought down the wall in 1989 have kept us from fully achieving our own goals in the decade that followed, and still block the road to a more promising future.

HEADLINE: France Presses For a Power Independent Of the U.S.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
In a Europe that is increasingly concerned about unilateralism and resurgent isolationism in the United States, France seized the moment this week to urge the European allies to develop a more independent defense and foreign policy.
President Jacques Chirac, speaking Thursday at an international conference, warned that a world with only one superpower is not as secure and safe as a multipolar world in which Europe is one of the strongest poles. 
 Mr. Chirac said he believes this "because the present situation is causing difficulties in numerous countries, including the most powerful among them, the United States, where Congress too often gives in to the temptations of unilateralism and isolationism."
Another reason, he added, was "because the forerunners of what could someday become a new bipolar tension are already arising" between the United States and China.
French officials close to Mr. Chirac said that one of the main causes for concern in both China and France was the possible deployment by the United States of a limited missile defense shield to protect against attack by "rogue states" like Iraq or North Korea. Such a shield in the eastern Pacific region might also make China think it had to build more missiles to keep its own nuclear forces from being marginalized.
France, Germany and Britain all have strong reservations about amending the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with Moscow to permit more anti-missile defenses, and Russia has said that changing the treaty could destabilize the global strategic balance.
That is also the view of the European allies. "President Chirac has told President Clinton that it could open a Pandora's box that is in none of the allies' interest," one French official said.
In the view of French leaders since Charles de Gaulle in the early 1960's, the best insurance against both American isolationism and the capriciousness of heavy dependence on the United States has always been an independent French or European strategic power.
Now Mr. Chirac and other French officials are capitalizing on the Senate's rejection last month of a global treaty banning nuclear tests to urge Europeans not to defer to American leadership but to go ahead and build something that Americans have long been calling for: stronger European defenses.
The world needs "responsible involvement" by the United States in international affairs, Mr. Chirac said in his remarks, which were warmly received by many other Europeans present.
"He spoke for me and for all Europeans on that," said Karl Kaiser, a German foreign policy expert who was an adviser to Gerhard Schroder, the German chancellor.
Mr. Chirac singled out the United States for only one moment of praise: "I salute their impressive economic and technological dynamism," he said at a gathering organized by the French International Relations Institute. "I deplore the present American diffidence in several major areas as a result of decisions by Congress. I wish the United States would once more take on all its responsibilities on the international scene, and as soon as possible. But the world is a fragile place. It won't wait."
The Socialist ministers of defense and foreign affairs also took a strongly Gaullist line this week. "For my part, I believe that since 1992 the word 'superpower' is no longer sufficient to describe the United States," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine told the same audience on Wednesday. "That's why I use the term 'hyperpower,' which American media think is aggressive.
"Supposing Europeans really do want to become a power," Mr. Vedrine added, "the willingness of the United States to accept with anybody, and particularly with Europe, partnership that is anything but momentary or limited, and to move from unilateralism to multilateral ism, remains to be demonstrated. We would like to believe it. This question underlies the whole question of the European common foreign and defense policy.
"We cannot accept either a politically unipolar world, nor a culturally uniform world, nor the unilateralism of a single hyperpower," he added. "And that is why we are fighting for a multipolar, diversified and multilateral world."
Defense Minister Alain Richard, speaking of lessons the Europeans learned from Kosovo, where only the United States was quickly able to mass the sophisticated precision-guided weapons needed for the NATO bombing campaign, urged Europeans to cooperate and build forces for similar missions.
He and some other Europeans complain that the United States has been warning Europe against trying to build multilateral defenses that would duplicate the alliance's.

HEADLINE: Last Stand in Defense Of a Hollow's History

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: BLAIR, W.Va., Nov. 4

 BODY:
Jim Weekley, the last litigious man in Pigeon Roost hollow, warily awaited word from Washington about how the politicians were trying to get around his big court victory, which has put this state's coal mining industry and government establishment in a state of shock.
"Now, Senator Bobby Byrd's done a whole lot for this state, but Bobby Byrd's just like all our politicians here -- they're coal company men," said Mr. Weekley, a retired miner who chain-smoked watchfully in the autumnal glow of the hollow where his mother was born. 
 The hollow is a gentle valley containing 200 years of his family history. It is set amid a series of mountaintops that the coal industry targeted for decapitation with mammoth mining machinery -- "mountaintop removal" is the technical term. It is a technique of dynamiting and bulldozing that Senator Robert C. Byrd and the rest of the state Congressional delegation are now furiously defending in the name of the state's economic health. They are pressuring the Clinton administration and fighting to undo the stunning court victory over this high-tech strip-mining practice recently won by Mr. Weekley and a group of other homesteaders and environmentalists.
Unlike tens of thousands of others in hollows across Appalachia, Jim Weekley decided to rebuff the mining company's offers and cling to his seven-tenths-of-an-acre homestead as he saw this backwoods hamlet about 40 miles from Charleston shrink to 60 families from 200 when the mountaintops and hollows were bought for removal. In the face of gargantuan removal machinery that juts 20 stories above the horizon, Mr. Weekley became the holdout among his now departed hollow neighbors. He joined a public interest lawsuit to block the common mining practice of dumping the vast tons of dynamited waste from the obliterated mountaintops down into valleys just like his beloved Pigeon Roost hollow, where streams and woodland vistas are choked off and buried.
"I ran free in this hollow all my life," said Mr. Weekley, citing values different from the rich low-sulfur coal lying all about him up in the mountaintops. "The memories and the footsteps and the happiness we have had in the hollow. The six children we raised, the love tree where I courted my wife. This fight is not about money. It's about being for the future."
Chief Judge Charles H. Haden 2nd of United States District Court, a veteran Charleston jurist with a reputation for being conservative Republican in his outlook, shocked the state last month when he ruled for Mr. Weekley, the West Virginia Highlands Conservancy and a half-dozen other landholders. He found that the state had violated federal mining and clean water laws for years by permitting the blockage of hundreds of miles of vital valley streams with the mountaintop rubble.
"That judge came down my hollow to see what it was all about," Mr. Weekley proudly recalled even as he awaited word from Washington on the efforts to undo the ruling, which environmental lobbying groups have hailed as a landmark defense of antipollution law. As Mr. Weekley spoke, that lobby was in a tooth-and-claw struggle against the storied powers of Senator Byrd, the dean of Senate constitutionalists and leader of the state Congressional delegation.
The senator, who loves to revel in such home state glories as mountain fiddling, is alarmed that the state's mining economy and jobs are under threat from the court ruling. He is planning to block the decision by attaching a legislative rider to some final bill in the Congressional rush to end the session. "We have taken some reasoned steps toward ensuring the viability of the coal mining industry in our state," the delegation declared in an opinion essay prepared for Sunday newspapers.
But Joe Lovett, the lawyer who won the court decision in behalf of Mountain State Justice Inc., said that he had seen the rider and that it would plainly gut the court decision by eliminating the current laws' valley fill standards and buffer zone requirements for protecting streams -- strictures that Judge Haden found had clearly been ignored. The state delegation, which has declined to release details of its rider to the public, is insisting a way can be found to repair the problem while protecting both jobs and the environment.
"The White House is hedging," said Mr. Lovett, noting that under pressure from Senator Byrd, the administration has declined to repeat in this case its earlier unqualified warnings that the president will veto any late session bills that include anti-environmental riders. "My guess after eight years of watching this president is that he's not going to veto it," Mr. Lovett said pessimistically. He is concerned as well that any last-minute effort to compromise may also mean a weakened environmental law.
Environmental groups are watching Vice President Al Gore in particular because he is running for president on his pro-environment credentials. He has contended that the urgency of the issue was eased by Judge Haden's subsequent decision to stay the ruling pending an appeal. But environmental lobbyists, noting that the delegation is pursuing a rider to trump the appeals process, are dissatisfied that Mr. Gore has not explicitly guaranteed a presidential veto if the Byrd rider is passed.
"Gore's resolve does not seem so great," said Courtney Cuff, Washington legislative director for Friends of the Earth. "We fear they're going to talk the talk, but not walk the walk."
Here in the state, the coal industry, the miners union and virtually all government officials have attacked the court ruling as economically ruinous. Gov. Cecil H. Underwood, a Republican, ordered a hiring freeze and a 10 percent budget cut, steps that environmentalists say was part of a pro-industry panic scenario to help passage of the Byrd rider.
Ken Hechler, a Democrat who is West Virginia's secretary of state, accuses the White House of trying to finesse politics over principle in this struggle. Long a crusader against mountaintop removal, Mr. Hechler asserted that both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore had been "oblivious to the utter devastation" left by this rapid form of strip mining. Precious mountains in four coal-rich states of Appalachia are being reduced to "moonscapes" by a technique increasingly on the rise, Mr. Hechler warns. The industry points to showcase reclamation projects, but Mr. Hechler, grieving for lost nature, dismisses them as "lipstick on a corpse."
As he patrols Pigeon Roost hollow, Jim Weekley is pleased that by defending his family roots and memories on seven-tenths of an acre he has managed so far to block a huge plan for a mountaintop mining swath of 3,100 acres, a project that needed his hollow to go forward. He is not against mining, he emphasizes, speaking as a veteran of the old deep-shaft mines where, he says, the work could be lethal but at least a man knew that his labors below were not literally erasing his place in the hollow.
Mr. Weekley is angry that the politicians so concerned now about the environmental laws never really told their constituents about their provisions in the first place.
"Why didn't they tell the little guy?" he asked, studying the horizon and Washington beyond. "The companies sure knew, but what about the little guy in the hollows?"

HEADLINE: Joined at the Stoop: Neighbors Till the End

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Mornings begin on West Hagert Street at 7, when Dorsha Mason, 80, crippled and bent by phlebitis and arthritis, rises from bed in the row house of the North Philadelphia neighborhood where she has lived for more than half a century, inches her way across her living room with her walker and opens her front door.
Her neighbors do not have to worry; the open door says she has made it through another night. 
 Up and down the block, neighbors echo the signal. Across from Mrs. Mason, Rachel Lockhart, 83, opens her door, and so does Mary Little, 80, next to her, and Amanda Riley, 89, two doors down. On the corner, Katherine Jones, 66, opens hers.
They have lived side by side on this short block of red and white row houses, most of them, for 40 and 50 years. They raised their children together, and paid off their mortgages by scrubbing other people's floors or working in the factories that brought tens of thousands of black families here from the South.
They went to church together, singing in the choir and cooking for the needy. Through it all, they always made time for the neighborhood, organizing meetings and voter registration drives, sweeping the streets, planting prize-winning gardens.
Now, with failing hearts and aching backs, they are negotiating old age together in a neighborhood like other urban neighborhoods in Philadelphia, burdened by poverty, crime and years of neglect by the city.
"We're all deteriorating," said Mrs. Mason, who has outlived two husbands. Wearing a flowered satin robe and receiving visitors on a hospital bed that she keeps in her dining room, she threw back her silvery hair and laughed. "And I'm the chief deteriorator."
Though West Hagert Street is considered relatively safe, many residents have installed triple locks and security bars. Mrs. Riley still takes a morning walk, but on the advice of a neighbor she has adjusted her route to avoid drug dealers on 20th Street.
"There's some rough spots," Mrs. Riley acknowledged. But she does not focus on the drug dealers any more than she does on the arthritis that racks her body. The neighborhood, she said, is not unlike her life: "I assume there's going to be rough spots."
Mrs. Riley and her neighbors, like most older Americans, are staying put, not moving to retirement communities. "Don't move me from this block," declared Mrs. Riley, who still recalls her elation when she and her husband and their two teenage sons moved in on May 20, 1950.
But unlike many retirees, Mrs. Riley and her elderly neighbors, with a few exceptions, could not move if they wanted to. As hard as they have worked to maintain their row houses, painting regularly and keeping up with repairs, they have, in a sense, outlived the neighborhood. They would be lucky to sell their homes for $20,000, they say. Where could they move with that?
"Our younger people don't want our houses," said Geraldine Cade, 74, who has spent 42 years on West Glenwood Avenue, a block over from West Hagert. "They don't want to live around the neighborhood. They want an apartment or a condo."
Mrs. Cade and her neighbors hang on in row houses that were not built for the old. The bathrooms are on the second floor, up 15 steps. They all know the number; after knee-replacement surgery, said Theodosia Golson, 73, "I crawled up those steps."
They make do with Social Security and modest pensions. They are sustained, they say, by their faith in God. The traveling they do is mostly to church and back. At night they stay home, listening to the radio, watching television and reading their Bibles.
And they look to each other. These neighbors were all specializing in assisted living -- the informal, unpaid kind -- long before developers began using the term to attract the affluent elderly.
At 83, Rachel Lockhart is still working, taking care of other people's children, but in her free time she bakes pound cakes and casseroles for people on the block.
Raymond Hodge, 79, who lives on Glenwood Street, is not giving rides the way he used to -- his car is too old, he says, and the windows have been broken and the tags stolen -- but he says he is available in a pinch.
Mrs. Riley, at 89 the oldest resident on the block, takes care of her 87-year-old brother, Arthur Hemphill, who had a stroke in June, and she still helps sweep the street.
Mrs. Mason, who worked as a procurement clerk, purchasing agent and negotiator for the Navy, says she retired as block captain and president of the neighborhood association, but she still does the jobs. She is too crippled to pick up cigarette butts on the street as she once did, but she pays a neighborhood man, Harry Gathers, a few dollars to do the job for her.
Mr. Gathers, 50, is one of Mrs. Mason's projects. "Harry has a problem with self-esteem," she said. "Mrs. Riley and I are working with Harry."
According to the 1990 census, nearly 20 percent of the neighborhood's residents were 60 or older, and 3 out of every 10 of those lived at the poverty level. Social workers say some residents make do on Social Security checks of $500 a month. It is not the easiest neighborhood to live in at any age.
The grocery on the corner is gone, in its place a vacant lot. There is a new Pathmark grocery, part of a rebuilding effort, but it is eight long blocks away, along a busy avenue, past abandoned buildings and more vacant lots.
A nearby drugstore also closed, and residents complain that a chain drugstore five blocks up the hill is expensive. One benefit to living in the city, though, is that a bus line passes through the neighborhood, and people 65 and older ride free.
To outsiders, the landscape of vacant lots and abandoned buildings define one vast North Philadelphia zone.
But Mrs. Mason said of her neighborhood, once so well tended that even after whites left and factories began to close, it was known as Upper Society Hill: "This is not a ghetto. This is a place where people worked hard to build a community."
Unemployment is high, but the neighborhood is home to nurses, teachers and accountants. Mrs. Mason does not have children, but she does have plenty of nieces, nephews and cousins who visit regularly. Mrs. Riley's son Charles, 67, a retired machinery painter, has moved back home to help his mother.
A block away, James Golson Jr., a high school principal in New Jersey, has returned to Boston Avenue with his wife and their 6-year-old daughter so he can keep an eye on his parents, James and Theodosia, who live four doors away in the house where they raised their five children.
Mr. Golson Sr., 84, a retired Navy cook, is a rarity in the neighborhood. "Most of the husbands have died," Mrs. Mason said.
Half of the members of the neighborhood association's board have also died. Mrs. Little had to give up her post as secretary because of palsy in her hands. The remaining members do not meet nearly as often as they used to, but when Mrs. Mason gets on the phone and calls them together, as she did the other week, they are at her door promptly at the appointed hour, bringing chairs and homemade cakes.
"It's not where you live," Mrs. Mason said, directing the meeting from her bed, "it's how you live where you live."
Mrs. Mason moved to the block with her husband in 1943, and when Mrs. Riley arrived seven years later, Mrs. Mason was one of the first people at her door.
"She introduced herself as the block captain," Mrs. Riley said. "She said what we all were expected to do. Meetings were going to be at her house, and we're going to keep the block clean."
They didn't just keep the block clean; with help from Philadelphia Green, a nonprofit gardening program, they planted trees and gardens. "Everywhere you had a pot, or a tire, or whatever would hold dirt, it would have flowers in it," recalled Mrs. Riley, who grew up on a farm in Rock Hill, S.C.
Mrs. Mason's scrapbooks are filled with photographs of the flowers that year after year won top prizes from the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society. There is also a 1972 newspaper clipping describing West Hagert Street, with its gardens and community pride, as "the essence of what urban living can be for the ordinary citizen who can't afford Society Hill."
Mrs. Mason organized children to help sweep the streets. She ran an after-school program in her living room. When drugs arrived in the late 80's, Mrs. Mason and her neighbors formed a community watch. Mrs. Mason patrolled the streets with an elderly neighbor, Ora Lee Camp, who lived on 20th Street.
"We came out at 11 p.m. and walked the block till 5 a.m.," Mrs. Mason recalled. "We had nerve. You had to have nerve to do this job."
Back then, Mrs. Mason was in her 70's and on crutches.
Despite all those efforts, the neighborhood declined. There were drug-related killings on Opal Street. Several houses burned. One morning Grace Skinner, 77, who lives in the row house where she was raised, found two bullet holes in her windshield. The flowers were stolen. Many residents and businesses fled.
Mrs. Mason and her aging neighbors stayed.
"They figured out how to survive with each other," said Kim Camp, the daughter of Ora Lee Camp, who died two years ago at age 74.
"Before direct deposit, they would rob people coming out of the bank," she said, so the neighbors would all go to the bank together.
The question now is how much longer these neighbors can carry on.
The other afternoon Mrs. Mason was maneuvering from Mrs. Carter's car to the sidewalk and up the five steps to her front door. Back from one of her regular hospital visits, she had neighborhood business to tend to. "Mrs. Dugue needs help," she said.
Dolores Dugue, 77, who lives across the street, had broken her ankle on her stairs the night before. And she could not afford to be laid up; she is taking care of three great-grandchildren. Her granddaughter, Mrs. Dugue said, died of a drug overdose last spring.
Mrs. Mason telephoned Mary Cook, the 70-year-old volunteer social worker at St. Martin de Porres, the neighborhood Catholic parish. Fifteen minutes later, Mrs. Cook was at Mrs. Dugue's bedside.
Mrs. Mason turns 81 on Nov. 17. "I retired in 1995," she keeps telling people. "I'm too old to keep doing this."
Mrs. Cook worried aloud: "Who's going to take over after Mrs. Mason?"
People in the neighborhood ask the same question. Mrs. Cade apologizes for not being able to keep up the community garden the way she used to; her arthritis makes bending over painful.
One of Mrs. Mason's protegees, Kim Camp, is trying to start her own business and it is hard to get to neighborhood meetings, said Ms. Camp, who is 43.
"I don't know how they did it," she said of her mother and Mrs. Mason and the others. "I sit in awe. I don't know where they got their energy."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk
