HEADLINE: Siblings' Lives Trace a U.S.-German Divide

SERIES: ONE EUROPE, 10 YEARS: Different Paths

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: WITTENBERG, Germany

 BODY:
On March 15, 1960, an 18-year-old German girl and her younger brother boarded a train here to escape East German Communism for the West. But the police were patrolling and the girl, convinced they could not make it together, pushed the boy off the train as it started to move.
"Police were asking me who I was, where I was going, why I was traveling, and I realized we were too suspicious as a pair," said Heidi Boettcher, now an American citizen. "My brother was just 16. I was sure he would join me later." 
 But the nudge that left the boy, Hans Schulz-Netzer, marooned at Wittenberg station 17 months before the Berlin Wall went up led to permanently divided lives. One has long lived in the Soviet bloc, the other in rural Missouri. By the time the wall fell a decade ago, Hans and Heidi stood at opposite poles in the basic post-cold-war debate of Western societies.
That debate no longer concerns the merits of capitalism, a system without ideological rival since Communism collapsed. Rather, it centers on the differing European and American views of how far capitalism should be regulated in order to cushion people from the harshness of market forces.
A German without job prospects, Hans favors enveloping social protection. An American with a convert's zeal, Heidi wants "the government out of my face." Hans sees his sister as "way over to the political right." Heidi views her brother as the victim of a German system "that still assumes people are so dumb they need to be taken care of."
German unification without German neutrality was a great Western achievement, but the economic toll was also great. Over the past decade, the decision to extend state pensions, unemployment benefits and all West Germany's social programs to 17 million new citizens has precipitated a crisis in Europe's largest welfare state.
Put simply, a once envied "social market" model is now carrying more weight than it can bear. Mr. Schulz-Netzer, 56, is part of the burden. He has been collecting about $825 a month in unemployment benefits for the past two years. His wife, Karin, 55, gets another $600. Karin's daughter, also unemployed, receives some more.
That money has to come from somewhere, free lunches being as scarce in Germany as anywhere else. The taxes and charges needed to finance all the social cushioning have pushed up wage costs and so deterred hiring. Long Europe's engine, Germany has stalled, unable to dent 10 percent unemployment.
This crisis does not surprise Mrs. Boettcher, 58, who is married to a farmer in Missouri, a state with a 4 percent unemployment rate. "If you want to work, I don't give a damn, you find work," she said, laughing. "But Germans are sheep. Why should my brother think for himself if money is being thrown at him?"
Having raised 11 children since arriving in the United States in 1961, she has now started a small business -- a day nursery for infants. Charging a daily rate of $11 a child and on the move from morning to night, she makes a little more than her brother's family receives from the German state for doing nothing.
It is tempting to see in Mrs. Boettcher's dynamism and her German brother's passivity facile symbols of American vitality and German self-doubt, of the vigor of the New World and late middle age of the Old. But the divisions of the post-cold-war era are more nuanced than that.
Germans in general reject unmitigated "Americanization"; if that is the sum of cold war victory, they tend to say, no thanks. To the millions of American jobs created this decade, some respond that Germany has free health care, free universities, smaller prison populations, no homeless: capitalism tempered by equity.
"We could benefit a lot by being more American," said Norbert Walter, chief economist for Deutsche Bank. "We should apply the market economy instead of being a museum of Western socialism. But Americans only need to take a look at their inner cities to see they might also learn a little from Europe."
A decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall, this debate is coming to a boil. Time has run out; Finance Minister Hans Eichel said recently that the German model was "finished." But a look at the lives of Heidi Boettcher, American immigrant, and her brother suggests that trans-Atlantic accord will prove elusive on how much state-directed compassion global capitalism needs.
 
The Right Qualities For Assimilation
Germans make good Americans. Between 1820 and 1996, 7.1 million Germans immigrated to the United States -- more than from any other nation. The desire to forget an often painful past, honesty and thoroughness, a practical bent -- many Germans share these qualities, and they have made absorption easier.
Certainly Mrs. Boettcher looks the part. With one infant on her back, another in her arms, she exudes a ready friendliness that speaks of 38 American years. Her manner is easygoing to the point that even 10 children under 4 in her new home in Altenburg, Mo. (population 256) seem manageable.
So the darkness of the story she tells -- punctuated by the contented squeals of little Americans -- is doubly shocking.
Like many Germans of her generation, Heidi grew up fatherless. Like most Germans, she suffered. Her father, Karl Schulz-Netzer, was captured by the Americans and held in St. Louis. On his return to Germany after the war, he filed for divorce.
Her parents and her country split at the same time. Age 4 when the war ended in 1945, Heidi fell into the Communist world. She recalls her mother cutting up a blanket to make pants for her and her brother. The garden yielded bare subsistence.
Living in a rural area, she saw Communist doctrine at work. Land was taken over by the state, farmers put to work eight hours a day and granted a month's vacation. But holidays were scant compensation for expropriation.
Wheat sometimes grew "to the ceiling" because nobody could be bothered to harvest it, she recalls. A first lesson in Communism's effect on motivation: nobody wants to herd the state's sheep.
Care packages sent from the United States by distant cousins, the Degenhardts, provided the only relief. The family had emigrated to Missouri in the 1870's. For the young girl, sweet Hershey bars and succulent lard constituted America's first lure.
A good athlete, Heidi was sent at 17 to the German high school of physical culture in Leipzig, training ground for many East German Olympic gold medalists. In this palace of high socialism, indoctrination moved into high gear. But Heidi was more marked by rationing than revolution. If the latter produced the former, how good could it be?
"When I turned 18," she said, "I was nominated to join the party. It was, of course, the greatest honor. The only problem was, I didn't believe in Communism. I'd already decided it works fine on paper, but in reality people need incentives."
Her own incentive became escape. With the Berlin Wall not yet built in 1960 -- it would go up the next year -- thousands were leaving every week. It was enough to get to Berlin and board a subway to a Western sector. But movement into the capital was tightly controlled.
At the end of a vacation at home in Teuchel, an outlying district of Wittenberg, Heidi feigned sickness to put off return to school and decided to take a train to Berlin, a little over an hour away. She went to the station with her little brother, Hans, who kept saying that he wanted to go with her.
They boarded the train; Hans, she recalls, clung to her. But he was only 16, without qualifications, and, seeing the police, she urged him to get off. In the end she had to prod him as the train lurched forward.
"I thought I'd never make it," she said, "and I was already wondering what prison would be like. The police cornered me between two cars and kept grilling me. And then, for the first time in a long time, I thought of my father."
A visit to her long-lost father: that was the reason for her journey to Berlin. An older policeman -- about her father's age -- listened to the girl's story of estrangement. How she wanted to see her dad now after so many years. Then, abruptly, after 45 minutes, he smiled and ordered the interrogation ended, saying, "Have a nice trip."
The voyage would be long. It took her, that night, to West Berlin: a first Coke, refugee camps, her first 10 West German marks for giving blood. On to Hanover, then Bavaria, and training as a nurse.
Freedom was real; it was also lonely. She wrote to the Degenhardts, who invited her to join them in Missouri. The Berlin Wall had gone up in August 1961. A few weeks later, on Sept. 22, she flew to the United States.
Her road took her from Wittenberg, Saxony-Anhalt, to Wittenberg, Mo., where the Degenhardts lived. It was one long traveled by Germans. The American Wittenberg was founded in 1839 by about 700 Lutherans who sailed to the United States after leaving the town where Martin Luther nailed his explosive theses to the church door.
Wittenberg, on the banks of the Mississippi, is now a ghost town, destroyed in the flood of 1993. But in Altenburg, a parish founded at the same time on higher ground, all is neatly ordered around the Lutheran church. Boxes contain pretty floral arrangements and American-flag pennants.
In this area, in a tightknit, church-dominated community, Heidi quickly felt at home. What struck her was the absence of fences, the unlocked doors, the friendliness, the positiveness. A place free of the shadow of bad German history.
 
Eleven Children, Without State Support
Soon she met Albert Boettcher, known as Junior, president of the Lutheran youth association, descendant of Germans who had moved to the area in the 1920's, proud owner of a 1960 Chevy. They were married in 1963.
"Heidi was always a wild one," Mr. Boettcher said. "That's why she got out and her brother stayed: a question of spirit. She swam the Mississippi twice, you know, and that's about a mile. Always she hated authority, regulations, doctors, hospitals, pills. So we just went right ahead and enjoyed nature."
To such effect that the Boettchers had 11 children between 1964 and 1984 on their 100-acre Altenburg farm. In Germany, this would have provided them with something close to a living. The state pays "Kindergeld," or child money, for every child regardless of parents' income, to encourage child-bearing and support families.
At a rate of 250 marks per child for the first two children, 300 for the third, and 350 for each subsequent one, the Boettchers would have been entitled to about $2,000 a month from German authorities.
In the United States they received nothing. "I never could bring myself to sit in a county office and ask for some handout like food stamps," Mrs. Boettcher said. "I know where that kind of thing leads."
All the family ever accepted was free school lunches during a two-year period. Like more than 15 percent of Americans, they never even had medical insurance. They did not want it, and the children were generally healthy. When one daughter was sick and hospitalized, they raised $3,000 through a collection in the church.
"We're not the German sheep yet," Mr. Boettcher said, "although we're trying to play catch-up with President Hillary's universal health care. More taxes and more programs will kill this country."
The hypothetical has scant value in history, but Mr. Schulz-Netzer dwells on it. The Berlin Wall went up on Aug. 13, 1961; he qualified as a mechanic 15 days later. That qualification was what he had been waiting for to join his sister in the West.
"My handicap was the wall," he said, sitting drinking a beer, his gaze distant. "If it had gone up three weeks later, I would be with Heidi. But fate wanted me here." And what of his sister's nudge on the train? "At that time, I don't think I was ready to go, anyway," he said.
For 16 years after his birth in 1943, the two grew up in the same Wittenberg home. But they are so different now, shaped by opposing cultures, that this shared past seems infinitely remote.
He is full of the caution, the fatalism, the unspoken fears of Germany; she seems to have been freed of them by a wide-open continent. "In God We Trust," says the dollar bill, but Germans have every reason to be suspicious of God's benevolence.
In a sense, its past explains the country's social safety net. In West Germany, after hyperinflation and Hitler, social cohesion was worth almost any price. In the East, free day care centers and visits by doctors and dentists to schools were billed as the gifts of socialism; they also helped secure compliance to a police state.
But the world has changed. Germany has ceased to be the treacherous epicenter of the cold war. It desperately needs more risk-taking: 8.4 percent of the American adult population has started a business, against 2.2 percent in Germany.
But the country's essential difficulty since 1989 has been in convincing people it might be worthwhile to trade some of the old and no-longer-affordable security for the rewards of risk.
Certainly Mr. Schulz-Netzer seems stuck with the old habits. Can-do is not his motto. For decades he worked in a state company repairing increasingly obsolete buses. It was dull, repetitive and secure.
"You'd roll up on Monday morning with a headful of alcohol and know nothing would happen," he said. "It was written right there in the East German Constitution: every man and woman has the right and obligation to work."
And, where possible, work the angles. From time to time, Mr. Schulz-Netzer would be called into his boss's office and some prominent Communist Party leader would be there needing his car repaired. On the black, for a quiet payment.
Mr. Schulz-Netzer was happy to oblige. Over the years they flocked to him: party officials, police, state security agents.
"They were all so stiff and formal in their official roles," he said, "and then they'd show up at my place and be quite sympathetic."
East Germans called such angles their "Lebenstrategie" -- "life strategy" for making a bad system bearable. And so, Mr. Schulz-Netzer said, people were lulled. "We get used to things," he said, shrugging. "We had movies, we had television, we had cars of a sort, and we even had our own little Florida on the Baltic."
Was anything missing? He pondered the question for some time. "Well, we had no incentive to be self-sufficient."
Through his acquaintances with party officials, he secured permission to use his moonlighting money to build a house on land next to his mother's home.
He had to request official approval for the purchase of each hinge, each doorknob, each tap -- but over a six-year period he got the job done. That bungalow, completed in 1982, is now his pride and security.
Other security evaporated when the wall fell in 1989. The car company struggled through various incarnations before closing in 1997, leaving Mr. Schulz-Netzer without a job -- like 21.7 percent of adults in Saxony-Anhalt, whose population of 2.7 million is about half that of Missouri (although in area Missouri, half the size of Germany itself, dwarfs Saxony-Anhalt).
"It's simple in this society," he said. "If you're over 40, nobody wants you." He has sent out hundreds of job applications, without luck. Garages, he says, do not want to hire a master mechanic when they can employ a youth for half the price.
Of course, when the wall came down, he had the option of turning his informal domestic workshop into a real enterprise. He thought seriously about it. "But I was 46, and I would have had to go into debt to be competitive," he said. "It seemed like too much risk, especially as I have no sons who could inherit the business."
So he has been living on handouts instead and awaiting a monthly pension of over $1,000, which begins at 60 if he opts for a slightly lower payment than he would receive at the official retirement age of 65. As of next month, he will be on a one-year state program that will put him to work at odd jobs like cleaning cemeteries.
A few years ago Karin Schulz-Netzer, who lost her seamstress job in 1991, got an early pension after convincing authorities that she was psychologically troubled.
"We live all right on our 2,400 marks a month," Mr. Schulz-Netzer said. "I garden, I potter around. I worked for 34 years. This money we get is money we have earned by paying taxes."
 
Strangers Too Scared 'To Do Anything'
In 1991, two years after the wall fell, Mr. and Mrs. Schulz-Netzer traveled to the United States for the first time. In New York they missed their connection, and spent one terrified night in a hotel, not daring to telephone or even urinate.
"American toilets are different," Mr. Schulz-Netzer explained. "The water level is higher, and so we were worried about a flood."
His sister could not believe it. "That is the fear the Communist system engendered," Mrs. Boettcher said. "They were scared to pee, to sleep, to phone, to do anything."
After this trauma, the reunion in Altenburg was a happy one. But there was no meeting of the minds. They visited Chicago, and Mr. Schulz-Netzer was appalled by the homeless people he saw. He was also troubled by the restlessness of Americans. "It's slower here in Germany, and I like that."
Mrs. Boettcher says that sometimes she feels she does not even recognize her brother. She cannot imagine not working and derives major satisfaction from baby-sitting. "I keep the kids happy, I am doing something," she said. "And I get paid."
Her husband, now 72, also works hard. Apart from the farm, he is active in bovine artificial insemination. His record, he said, is 2,600 cows bred in a single year. "It's great business," he said.
By almost any estimate, business is better in Missouri than Saxony-Anhalt. The discrepancy between a 4 percent and a 21.7 percent unemployment rate tells much of the story. In Missouri, wage costs are about half the German level.
But a central conundrum of European-American relations is that the American success story of the 1990's may not be exportable, any more than Mr. Schulz-Netzer can be convinced that his sister's active American life is better than his own state-supported existence.
As Mr. Walter of Deutsche Bank put it: "One thing about Germany today, and much of Europe, is that if you want to achieve something, change something, don't say it's the American way. There's an allergy to American triumphalism."
But a decade after unification, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has not yet found another way to convey a reform message that resonates. A united Germany continues to live beyond its means. There are 46 pensioners for every 100 active workers today; in 2030 there will be 96 pensioners for every 100.
But of course 2030 is still 30 years away. "We like the social line here," said Mr. Schulz-Netzer said. "In fact, in many ways, we thought of the old regime as good."
 
One Europe, 10 Years
This article is part of a series examining Europe a decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Previous articles have looked at Vaclav Havel, the Czech dissident who helped bring down the wall, as well as the troubles that unification has brought to Germany and the shifting relationships between East European countries 10 years after the fall of Communism.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1335 words

HEADLINE: U.S. VERSUS MICROSOFT: THE HORIZON;
Microsoft's Horizon

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
For more than a year, the Microsoft Corporation has been untarnished on Wall Street and on Main Street from the government's relentless antitrust assault on the company. But suddenly, it may begin feeling some pain as investors and the computer industry consider the likely impact of the blow delivered on Friday evening by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson.
The judge, who is deciding the antitrust case without a jury, took a defining first step toward a verdict, with findings of fact that concluded that Microsoft was a monopoly whose bullying tactics had hurt consumers and the economy by stifling innovation in the computer industry. 
 With that conclusion, Judge Jackson set the stage for an eventual ruling against the software giant and remedies that could be as extreme as a breakup of the company.
The Microsoft Corporation has not known this kind of threat to its business or public image in the 18 months since the government filed its antitrust suit.
At the trial in Washington, Microsoft was pummeled with harsh accusations of corporate misconduct and incriminating evidence. Its every embarrassing slip-up in the courtroom was chronicled daily in the news media.
Yet Wall Street shrugged it all off as an irrelevant sideshow. Microsoft's stock price kept climbing, minting more Microsoft millionaires and ensuring that William H. Gates 3rd continued to extend his lead as the world's richest person. And polls of public opinion have shown that the favorable reputation of Mr. Gates and his company have been untarnished by its antitrust battle with the government.
But on Friday night, in late after-hours trading after Judge Jackson's findings were made public, Microsoft's stock price fell sharply, down as much as $5 from $91.5625. David Readerman, an investment banker who studies the company, says he expects Microsoft's shares to drop early this week, though by no more than 10 percent. Still, a 10 percent decline would erase $47 billion in the wealth of Microsoft shareholders.
"It won't be a wipeout," said Mr. Readerman, a managing director at Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco. "Microsoft is still a great growth story. But not only the Department of Justice but also now a federal judge feel that some of that growth was acquired improperly."
Mr. Readerman added: "The findings of fact by a United States federal judge are a serious thing, and now it's out. It's new information, and it's not pretty reading."
A judge's findings of fact are not a ruling, but they set the framework for the outcome of the case -- a legal judgment or an out-of-court settlement.
And now, the industry and investors will begin thinking seriously about remedies the government might seek. With Judge Jackson's one-sided findings, even sanctions that had seemed extreme -- like breaking up the company -- now seem to be back on the table.
On Wall Street, Mr. Readerman noted, bankers will surely be doing spreadsheet calculations on the value of Microsoft if it is broken up into separate companies. The division most often mentioned would create three companies: one with Microsoft's industry-standard Windows operating systems, a second with its office productivity software and a third with its Internet and electronic commerce products. Many bankers have said they believe that if the court splits up Microsoft -- just as the government forced the breakup of Standard Oil earlier this century -- the company's value would actually increase.
Within the industry, there is a debate about the restraining influence, if any, that the antitrust case has already had on Microsoft. Any waning in Microsoft's power over the last year has resulted mainly from the evolution of technology, as the Internet gradually erodes the role of the personal computer as the center of gravity in computing.
The case has certainly not slowed Microsoft's aggressive investment program in new businesses -- especially its taking stakes in cable television and telecommunications companies, as their networks become increasingly important to the future of the computer industry. Microsoft made the latest such investment on Friday, announcing that it was putting $200 million in Teligent Inc., a supplier of wireless phone and data services.
Still, there is a sense in the industry that Microsoft has become more careful in its business dealings since the antitrust case began. Judge Jackson's powerful findings of fact, industry executives say, should bring further self-restraint.
"Before this case, Microsoft would make sure you lost," said William R. Hearst 3rd, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, a leading Silicon Valley venture capital firm. "Now, you have to lose on your own." In earlier rounds of settlement talks, Microsoft showed a willingness to loosen its contracts with personal computer makers, including opening up its secret "marketing development agreements." Judge Jackson found that these contracts provided price incentives for companies that favored Microsoft's software products and punished companies that did not. Microsoft, according to people close to the talks, also offered to publish the pricing lists, adjusted for volume sales, for its licensing agreements with personal computer makers like Compaq, Dell, Gateway and I.B.M.
But the company has fiercely resisted any suggestion that it must be forced to give companies wide-ranging access to its fundamental software technology or allow them to modify it.
"We take the simple-minded view that it is our intellectual property, we made it, it's our song, and you should play it our way," explained William Neukom, Microsoft's general counsel.
The government accused Microsoft of using access to its Windows technology as another tool to reward allies and punish rivals. Without that access, other software products will not run smoothly on Microsoft's Windows operating systems.
Regardless of the government accusations or the judge's findings, Microsoft believes that the case law protecting intellectual property strongly supports its stance. And while the company would find it difficult, if not impossible, to appeal Judge Jackson's findings of fact, an appeal can be built around legal precedents.
In any settlement talks, it is Microsoft's concept of intellectual property protection that is the biggest obstacle, according to antitrust scholars. "Anything that suggests compulsory access to its technology is poison to Microsoft," said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University Law School.
For Microsoft, the great incentive to settle would be to sidestep an actual verdict declaring the company a monopoly. That could open the floodgates to rounds of private antitrust suits because proving that a company is a monopoly is often the most costly, time-consuming hurdle. Being a monopoly is not illegal in itself. But if a federal court has ruled Microsoft to be a monopoly, that hurdle has been overcome for all subsequent antitrust litigation.
Since Judge Jackson's findings of fact are not a final ruling, a settlement would presumably erase the monopoly finding.
"Taking that off the table is the biggest carrot the government has to offer Microsoft," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa College of Law.
On the other hand, Judge Jackson's findings of fact come down so strongly on the government's side, it gives Microsoft little room to compromise and thus little incentive to settle. Instead, it may well hope to win the case on appeal, which could end up before the Supreme Court and last until 2002.
For the government, there is perhaps one incentive to try to reach a settlement.
"Despite the finding coming down strongly on the government's side," said David Yoffie, a Harvard Business School professor, "there is one additional reason for it to seek a settlement: we have a Presidential election next year. And a new administration in Washington could change a lot in its thinking and approach to the Microsoft case."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
In Hindsight, Mets Made the Best and Worst Trades of Last Off Season

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The off-season had hardly begun when the Texas Rangers traded Juan Gonzalez to the Detroit Tigers. Last off-season only one player of that magnitude, Roger Clemens, was traded. The Gonzalez deal last week could be the harbinger of a whole string of swaps involving major players.
With general managers convening today in Dana Point, Calif., for their annual week of meetings, five weeks ahead of baseball's winter meetings, talk will be plentiful. Some of it -- maybe much of it -- will be fanciful. The spiciest topics of conversation will be Ken Griffey Jr., Shawn Green, Carlos Delgado and maybe Alex Rodriguez and Manny Ramirez. 
 But before the general managers start tossing too many names and bodies around, this would be a good time to look back at their efforts a year ago and see which trades worked well and which failed.
Trades made during the winter of 1998-99 can be judged on the impact they had on the teams or on their one-sided nature. Obviously, when minor league prospects were included in a deal, it can't be judged on the long term until the prospects establish themselves or fail to make it.
On the basis of 1999 results, the Mets, the Cincinnati Reds and the Arizona Diamondbacks made the trades that had the greatest impact on their success. The Pittsburgh Pirates made the trade that produced the best performance in relation to what they gave up. The trade that produced the worst results for both sides involved the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The Dodgers were also on the wrong side of the most one-sided trade, as developments would show. It was made Dec. 1 and was a three-team transaction between the Mets, Dodgers and Orioles in which the Mets acquired Armando Benitez and Roger Cedeno and gave up Todd Hundley.
Cedeno was a revelation to the Mets, hitting .313 and stealing 66 bases. Benitez, firing his demon fastball past batters, assumed the closer's role after John Franco was injured and played a major role in the team's drive, albeit tortured, to the playoffs. Benitez finished with 22 saves, a 1.85 earned run average, a .148 opponents' batting average and 128 strikeouts in 78 innings.
Because the Mets had a $91 million catcher in Mike Piazza, they sought to shed Hundley. The Dodgers took him. In addition to Cedeno, they gave up Charles Johnson, a good defensive catcher, in the trade, and expected a productive catcher to play in his place. But Hundley batted .207 and struck out 113 times in 114 games. His 24 home runs were not enough to overcome the hitting deficiencies. His throwing still suffered from an elbow operation in September 1997: opponents stole 107 bases against him in 139 attempts.
The trade took just one week to put together, Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, said.
"We had talked to a number of teams about Todd," Phillips related. "It came down to just the Dodgers' and the Orioles' being interested in him. A few teams said they had interest but wanted to wait until spring training. We didn't want to wait until the spring, when we thought there could be a circus atmosphere."
As he talked with the Dodgers, Phillips knew they were talking to the Orioles about Johnson. Knowing the Orioles sought a catcher, he talked to them about Hundley. They came close to a deal, Phillips said; in fact, he said, they actually had a tentative deal. But it fell apart. Back to the Dodgers.
"We started to construct the three-way deal," Phillips related. "First we worked out our deal with the Dodgers, then turned around and began negotiations with the Orioles to see what they'd give us for Johnson. We knew we wanted Benitez. We concluded Hundley for Johnson and then turned Johnson around for Benitez."
The Reds' successful trade had its genesis two weeks before spring training. Jim Bowden, the Reds' general manager, gained permission to add a few dollars to his smallish payroll. He targeted Greg Vaughn and his $5.75 million salary ($850,000 deferred without interest) and acquired him from San Diego for Reggie Sanders, an outfielder not in the team's plans, and Damian Jackson, an infielder in the same situation.
Without Vaughn, the Reds would not have had the surprisingly good season that took them one victory short of the playoffs. He led he team with 45 home runs and 118 runs batted in.
The Diamondbacks' successful deal brought them Luis Gonzalez, who led the team with a .336 batting average and also contributed 26 home runs and 111 r.b.i. He epitomized the surprisingly strong Diamondbacks, and all he cost them in the trade with Detroit was a young outfielder, Karim Garcia, who batted .240 in 96 games.
For offensive production, though, the Pirates made the best deal. It brought them Brian Giles, and the Pirates got him from hitting-rich Cleveland for a reliever, Ricardo Rincon. Giles batted .315, clouted 39 home runs and drove in 115 runs, numbers that would have been higher had he not lost the last two weeks with a broken finger.
The Pirates made another trade that sent Jon Lieber, one of their starting pitchers, to the Cubs for Brant Brown, an outfielder. Brown was a disappointment for the Pirates, and Lieber compiled a mediocre 10-11 record for Chicago. But those 10 victories made Lieber the Cubs' No. 1 starter.
For absence of achievement, though, no trade came close to another swap the Mets and the Dodgers made. The Mets gave the Dodgers Mel Rojas, once a capable reliever; they received Bobby Bonilla, once a productive hitter. Rojas appeared in only five games for the Dodgers before they released him. Bonilla remains a member of the Mets, his .160 batting average testimony to a gamble gone wrong.
"It's something we talked about at the end of season," Phillips said, "the logic being we needed to add offense. To make it work within the confines of our payroll, we knew we had to shift Mel's contract and hope to catch lightning in a bottle. I'm not sure there was a dissenting voice in the entire group: the people on the field, in the front office and the owners."
 
Expensive Digs
For their meetings this week, the general managers are staying in $400-a-night hotel suites. "It doesn't make sense in our economy to meet where the rate is $400," one general manager said. Added another: "In baseball, we pay lots of money for pitchers and hotel rooms."
 
Passing the Torch
Richard Jacobs, who sold the Indians last week to Larry Dolan, will be remembered as the owner under whom the team underwent a stunning revival. He will also be remembered as an owner who wanted a more activist commissioner. When the Mets signed Dwight Gooden to a three-year contract for $13.45 million in 1991, Jacobs urged Fay Vincent, then the commissioner, to fine the Mets for giving Gooden so much money.
"I'm furious," Jacobs said when he telephoned Vincent. "How can you let that happen? You should fine them. We need a commissioner who will take action."
Less than a year and a half later, Jacobs was part of the ownership group that forced Vincent out.
 
Awkward Reunion
When Albert Belle left the Indians as a free agent after the 1996 season, there was no happier man in the Indians camp than their manager, Mike Hargrove. Mr. Hargrove, meet your right fielder in your new job as Baltimore manager. Yes, Mike and Albert are reunited.
 
Baseball Economics
Doug Melvin, the Texas general manager, who triggered the superstar trade action by sending Juan Gonzalez to Detroit last week, said agents don't want to name a price when they are negotiating a contract. " 'Market value,' they say," Melvin said.
So what is market value these days? Is it the $13 million a year of Mike Piazza, the $15 million a year of Kevin Brown, or the $12.5 million a year of Bernie Williams and Larry Walker? It's not the last figure, because Jim Bronner, Gonzalez's agent, indicated that wouldn't do the job, Melvin said.
Perhaps market value has been established by the Seattle Mariners' offers to Ken Griffey Jr. ($16 million a year for eight years) and Alex Rodriguez ($17.25 million a year for eight years). But neither player plans to accept the offers, so maybe they don't set the market either. Do we hear $20 million?
The Seattle Mariners' brain trust meets with Griffey and he tells them he wants to be traded to a team closer to his home. They meet with Rodriguez and he tells them he wants to stay, at least until his contract runs out after next season. That might work for Rodriguez, but it doesn't work for the Mariners.
This doesn't work for the Mariners either: Rodriguez says if they do trade him this off-season, he won't sign a new contract with his new team; he'll become a free agent next year. The shortstop's stance makes it more difficult for the Mariners to trade him, but they will most likely try.
Griffey has taken a different approach. "If a trade is worked out, he'll be open-minded," said Brian Goldberg, who is Griffey's agent. "He's not saying he'll sign right away or test free agency. But he'll look at it and see how he likes it."
The line forms to the left.
 
He Could Look It Up
If Pete Rose, as he has said recently, has really never seen the evidence baseball investigators compiled 10 years ago in their inquiry into allegations that he gambled on baseball games, the Internet has just what he's looking for. All Rose has to do is click on DowdReport.com, and he'll have before his eyes the very report compiled by John Dowd, the Washington lawyer who was baseball's chief investigator.
The report has all the evidence Rose would want to see. "Recently," Dowd writes, "there has been much renewed interest in the Dowd Report and in Pete Rose's lifetime banishment from baseball. I am making the Dowd Report and the agreement signed by Pete Rose and Commissioner Giamatti available in this forum so that the public may draw its own conclusions."
Dowd's Web site also includes a statement Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti read Aug. 24, 1989, the day he announced Rose's banishment. It undermines a contention Rose has made that he never had a hearing.
"By choosing not to come to a hearing before me," Giamatti said, "and by choosing not to proffer any testimony or evidence contrary to the evidence and information contained in the report of the Special Counsel to the Commissioner, Mr. Rose has accepted baseball's ultimate sanction, lifetime ineligibility."

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD: INNOVATIONS;
Made in the U's of A: Designs for Real Life

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Last spring, Allen Taflove, who teaches in the Engineering, Design and Communication Program at Northwestern University, posed this problem to his students: You're alone in the desert, you break a leg and you can't get any reception on your cell phone. So what do you do? The freshmen responded by designing an antenna that boosts reception in remote places.
The solution was a surprise to everyone. "Most people don't expect freshmen to come up with anything viable," Professor Taflove said. But they do. Dozens of colleges and universities are now offering programs in which undergraduates design functional products on their own or with local entrepreneurs or major corporations. 
 In Lehigh University's Integrated Product Development Program, students work with companies like Black & Decker and Lutron Electronics to develop or to improve products. The companies are charged $10,000. In return, they get access to university resources and bright young minds; students get experience and academic credit, and the college gets a stake in potentially lucrative products.
"For years, business leaders and recruiters have said that college students have the technical skills but are not used to working in teams and communicating in a cross-disciplinary manner," said Todd Watkins, an associate professor of economics at Lehigh who helps coordinate its projects. "These programs engage teams of undergraduates in collaborative, project-based problem-solving and decision-making for real products that in many cases do end up in the marketplace."
Which raises the tricky issue of ownership. Most institutions have patent policies for faculty and graduate students, and generally, if the inventor uses the university's labs and resources, it has some intellectual-property claim. Disputes, however, do erupt. For the past year, Vanu Bose, son of the founder of Bose sound systems, has been fighting the Massachusetts Institute of Technology over a wireless software radio he developed as a graduate student.
The issue of ownership becomes even murkier when it involves outside companies and undergraduates. "It's a new area," Professor Watkins said. "There's no well-established procedure. Right now it's a one-on-one discussion with each company we work with."
The question now being debated at Northwestern is: Who owns the antenna-for-the-desert?
"We think Professor Taflove and Northwestern will own the patent, and the students will get royalties if anyone chooses to manufacture it," said Prith Banerjee, the chairman of the electrical and computer engineering department at Northwestern, which oversees the program. "But we're still not sure." ABBY ELLIN
 
http://www.nytimes.com

The university hopes to market the ideas. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Giuliani Senate Bid Could Give Unions Negotiating Leverage

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Labor unions overwhelmingly backed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election in 1997, but now they are not only tilting strongly toward his likely Senate opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, but also hoping to use the Senate race to squeeze more out of the mayor in contract talks next year.
Political analysts said this labor backing could hurt the mayor and help the first lady in several traditional ways -- through union phone banks and get-out-the-vote efforts -- and in one unorthodox way. Warning that city workers are fuming about the modest wage increases in their current contract, several union leaders said labor tensions and protests were likely if Mr. Giuliani failed to be generous in contract talks. 
 "It's very hard to run a campaign when you have a lot of labor unrest in your own backyard," said Lee Saunders, director of District Council 37, the municipal employees' union that represents 125,000 workers.
Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine, who is the mayor's chief labor negotiator, vowed that Mr. Giuliani would be as tough as ever in the contract talks, which cover nearly 300,000 workers, including teachers, firefighters, police officers and social workers.
"There's nothing they can do that would make life difficult for him," Mr. Levine said. "Many of these unions need to get their own houses in order and start to represent their members' interests, rather than worry about politics."
Several labor experts said Mr. Giuliani faced a daunting challenge balancing a Senate run with contract negotiations. He might be tempted to impress conservatives by being tough on labor, these experts said, though doing so would only erode his union support in the city.
On the other hand, said Raymond D. Horton, a professor at Columbia University Business School who was president of the Citizens Budget Commission, the mayor's Senate ambitions might cause him to give away the store. "If past is prologue, electoral politics will certainly intrude on collective bargaining," Professor Horton said. "The general pattern is, it makes the mayor a patsy in collective bargaining."
Mr. Levine said the mayor would not bring politics to the negotiating table. "We do contracts that look to what benefits the city," he said.
For the Senate campaign, the mayor's relations with labor promise to be far testier than in his 1997 re-election bid. Two years ago, Mr. Giuliani and his aides strenuously sought labor endorsements, valuing union phone banks and donations and knowing that union endorsements of his Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, could have given momentum to her faltering campaign.
Several powerful unions that backed the mayor in 1997 are now leaning toward the first lady, among them the transit workers' union, a 50,000-member janitors' union and, most important of all, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
In addition, after staying on the sidelines in the mayoral race, the city's two most politically potent unions -- 1199, a health-care union with 150,000 members, and the United Federation of Teachers, with 90,000 -- are making plans to endorse and campaign hard for Mrs. Clinton.
Many political experts say the teachers' and 1199's all-out campaign efforts were pivotal to Senator Charles M. Schumer's narrow victory last year over the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.
With 2.3 million union members in the state, labor is often considered New York's most potent political force. Its political clout is smaller in statewide races, however, because union membership is not nearly as concentrated upstate and in the suburbs as in the city.
Still, some analysts say that with polls showing the mayor and the first lady neck and neck, labor's ability to get voters to the polls could push Mrs. Clinton over the top.
"Union endorsement and union engagement can make a significant difference, particularly if it's a tight race," said Ester Fuchs, director of the Center on Urban Research and Policy at Columbia University. "The candidate that can get out their base is going to win this race, and if unions turn out Democratic voters who haven't been turning out, then the race goes to Hillary."
Because neither Mr. Giuliani nor Mrs. Clinton has officially declared as a candidate, no union has made a formal endorsement. But several unions, most notably the Civil Service Employees Association, the state's largest public employee union, with 265,000 members, have indicated they would back Mrs. Clinton as soon as she announced.
In 1997, unions backed the mayor's re-election for various reasons, among them that they were pleased that the city had rebounded during his tenure, they were afraid of retribution if they opposed him, and his Democratic opponent, Ms. Messinger, had scant chance of winning.
But union leaders said the considerations that go into a Senate endorsement are different. Several labor leaders said Mr. Giuliani's forceful personality worked well in City Hall, but would probably flop in the Senate. These labor leaders also noted that senators, unlike mayors, focus on national issues like health care, education and the minimum wage, where Mrs. Clinton's views often parallel labor's.
In addition, several municipal union leaders said their members were fuming at Mr. Giuliani and unlikely to endorse him because their salaries have languished while the city's economy has soared.
"There is still tremendous anger in the city work force about the pay freeze in the first two years of our contract, particularly in light of the booming economy," said Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union.
Complicating matters for Mr. Giuliani, the city's contract negotiations are expected to begin early next year and could reach fever pitch during the Senate campaign.
"My members want to fix the shortcomings of the current contract," said Patrick Lynch, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. "There is a huge debt owed to the city's unions, because their sacrifices helped create the budget surplus."
Mr. Levine defended the current round of five-year contracts, saying they improved productivity among municipal workers while giving them a raise of nearly 13 percent over five years -- more than the inflation rate.
Mr. Giuliani has been hurt and Mrs. Clinton fortuitously helped by some turnover that parent unions in Washington brought about to clean house at two of the city's largest unions. As a result of his high salary and high living, Gus Bevona, a Giuliani supporter, was forced out as president of the city's largest janitors' union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union. The trustees named to replace him are liberals who share many of Mrs. Clinton's views.
District Council 37's former executive director, Stanley Hill, was closely allied with the mayor, and enthusiastically endorsed his re-election. But Mr. Hill was forced out last November for failing to stop embezzlement and vote fraud at the union.

HEADLINE: Office Tower Is Planned, Without Leases Set

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Jerry I. Speyer, the developer who owns Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building, wants to accomplish the real estate equivalent of reviving an endangered species: he plans to build a speculative office tower.
Since the recession in the early 1990's left Manhattan landlords with bankrupt skyscrapers and acres of vacant space, lenders have been loath to provide financing for any office building that did not already have a tenant. Office towers now under construction have already been designated as homes for Morgan Stanley, Bertelsmann, Ernst & Young or Bear Stearns & Company. 
 But Mr. Speyer is betting that the real estate market is now so robust that he and his partner, Travelers Insurance, will have no problem filling up his proposed 25-story, granite and teal-colored glass tower at 222 East 41st Street, near Third Avenue. He expects to begin construction early next year and to open 18 months later.
"We're putting up a new building, which I think is going to be the first of a new generation of buildings," Mr. Speyer said. "We've had enough inquiries already that lead us to believe that going forward is the prudent thing to do."
Some real estate executives expressed skepticism about Mr. Speyer's plans because space is available in nearby buildings, including 622 Third Avenue and the Chrysler Building. They also suggested that the building site is not the most desirable corporate location.
According to Newmark & Company, a real estate brokerage firm, the vacancy rate for prime office space in Midtown Manhattan is about 8.5 percent, and is slightly higher in the Grand Central district. However, there are few large blocks of space available.
Mr. Speyer said he would be offering modern office space in the 365,000-square-foot tower for rents of about $53 a square foot, including taxes and operating costs. Other developers concede that Mr. Speyer's rents would be $10 to $20 a square foot cheaper than other new buildings, including one in Times Square that has a steep subsidy from the city and state.
The key difference, Mr. Speyer said, is that his land costs were so low. The development rights for the site, which now serves as a parking lot, are owned by Travelers. He said the insurer had obtained the right to use the lot from the estate of Stanley Stahl, a real estate magnate.
Designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the building will be known as 222 East 41st Street. "By New York standards, it's not a huge building," Mr. Speyer said. "But I'm excited to be building in New York again."
Although Mr. Speyer has done extensive renovations of Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building in recent years, this tower would be his first new project since an office building at 375 Hudson Street in the mid-1980's.
Mr. Speyer would be building the first speculative office tower since the last real estate boom. Developers were still building new skyscrapers at a brisk pace in 1987, when the vacancy rate in Midtown hit double digits. But lenders continued to provide the financing for new projects until 1991, when vacancy rates soared to 18 percent in midtown and 25 percent downtown and the market collapsed. Many new office buildings sat empty for years.
The first new office tower since then was just completed by Douglas Durst at 4 Times Square. About half the towers now under construction have tax breaks and other incentives from the city.
"Lenders learned from their mistakes," said Ross Moskowitz, a real estate lawyer at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. "Now only a handful of developers have access to the kind of financing that will allow, for the first time in almost a decade, speculative buildings to be built." He said "demand currently exceeds supply."
Still, at least five developers, who have construction sites in hand, cannot move forward without a tenant. Brookfield Properties Corporation, for example, plans to build a 1.2-million-square-foot tower at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street if the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce agrees to a lease. Mr. Durst would like to build another skyscraper at 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas if he can find a tenant.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The 1893 Cable Building, Broadway and Houston Street;
Built for New Technology by McKim, Mead & White

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE 1893 Cable Building marked the sudden advent of a new technology, with giant basement rollers drawing cable cars along Broadway from the Battery to 36th Street -- a $12 million investment that became obsolete less than a decade later. Now the building at Broadway and Houston Street, designed by McKim, Mead & White, is on the line that divides SoHo and NoHo, as a new rush of technology allows the owner to return the building to its cable-era elegance.
Cable cars were first installed in New York in the mid-1880's, a promising advance over the slower and dirtier horse-drawn cars. But the city was divided into many surface-transit franchises, and the smaller companies did not have the financing to install cable mechanisms, so cable expansion lagged, especially in the congested city center, where construction issues also impeded progress. 
 So it took something like the giant Metropolitan Traction Company -- a syndicate that included a former city corporation counsel, William C. Whitney, a financier, Thomas Fortune Ryan, and a Tammany contractor, John D. Crimmins -- to raise the kind of money it took for a comprehensive change. In 1892 Metropolitan filed plans for a new eight-story office and loft building at the northwest corner of Houston and Broadway, stretching back to Mercer Street.
The upper floors were designed for offices, but the basement was given over to a series of steam engines and winding wheels -- 26 feet in diameter -- that moved one-and-a-half-inch steel cables just under the surface of Broadway from Bowling Green to 36th Street. Metropolitan spent more than $12 million on the cable system, designed by the engineer George W. McNulty.
The cables moved at a constant speed, reported as 30 miles an hour; car operators clamped on or off, and used ancillary brakes. The cables weighed 40 tons each and drew up to 60 cars at once. The company expanded the service as it bought more and more lines. By 1897 it controlled most surface transit lines in Manhattan.
According to Mosette Broderick, an architectural historian, the $750,000 Cable Building itself was designed by Stanford White, almost certainly because White and William C. Whitney had become friends and collaborators. "It was a nice, lucrative goody in a very bad economic time -- the McKim, Mead & White office was laying off people in the early 1890's," said Professor Broderick, who teaches at New York University's College of Arts and Sciences and has just finished writing a book on the architectural firm and its clients.
Although the large windows clearly denote a commercial space, the delicate terra cotta, light orange brick and elaborate copper cornice are characteristic of more monumental design. The sculptor J. Massey Rhind designed two colossal female figures flanking the doorway -- commissioned sculpture is also unusual on commercial buildings. The Real Estate Record and Guide called the new Cable Building "the highest achievement of the art" and remarked that, with its example, "no excuse remains for building cheaply or meanly on any New York City property." The building is part of the NoHo Historic District designated in June by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
The theory of cable power was not completely borne out. The cables moved at a constant speed, so conductors had to be careful to release the cable nearing a tight corner, like the one at 14th Street and Broadway. But conductors were forgetful, there were many accidents, and the bend earned the name "Dead Man's Curve."
IT took only one problem to interrupt service on the entire line -- in the rush hour on Oct. 9, 1900, a cable broke in the basement of the Cable Building, shutting the system down for four hours during a heavy rainstorm.
These shortcomings were magnified as Metropolitan expanded its system. Only two years after the building was completed The New York Tribune reported that, for its 18 million car-miles annually, the company could save $2 million a year if a good electric system could be developed. Electric propulsion was also much smoother.
So on May 25, 1901, the last cable car left Houston Street for the Battery, and the line switched to electricity. The Cable Building retained its name, but the machinery stood silent and was later removed. By the 1930's the building had tenants like National Pants, Hercules Shoe Lace and the Doll Parts Manufacturing Association.
In 1985, when Harry Feldman and Jules Demchick -- with a group of investors called Cable Building Associates -- bought the building, tenants included a mixture of small manufacturers and offices. The building was not in good shape, and the new owners have upgraded the elevators, lobby and corridors, made extensive roof repairs, and hired Apple Restoration to clean, repoint and repair the facade, a project that was completed last year and cost more than $1 million, said Evan Stein, who manages the building.
Ken Follett, the head of Apple, said that the building "had a depressing cast to it" -- before the cleaning, a prior owner had painted many of the building's elements brown, including the marble panels at the fourth and fifth floors.
Now the inside could be the set for a new workplace sitcom -- in plan it's a large doughnut ringing an interior court, which lets the visitor see into the offices of Web designers, software engineers and others. Recently, one employee in socks was taking a break by jogging around the doughnut, which looks like it might be 20 laps to the mile. The perimeter corridor is lit by broad expanses of oak-trimmed windows, which have been stripped and polished.
The firm of Allanbrook Benic Czajka Architects has the best view in the place, on the eighth-floor corner looking south down Broadway and east on Houston. "We walked in and started jumping up and down," said James V. Czajka, a partner; they pay $4,000 a month for a 1,500 square foot space.
Although some interior elements have been restored, the interior still has an atmospheric, battered quality, with traces of cheap 1950's work colliding with elegant 1890's details. Mr. Stein said the owner wants to bring back the lobby ceiling, which is concealed by drywall, and redo the doors, which are cheap aluminum replacements.
He said that almost all the offices are small, often just 900 or 1,000 square feet, so they often get start-up businesses. But as the Cable Building looks better and better, and the demand for such space increases, he said, they are losing their older tenant mix of artists and nonprofit organizations, which cannot match the annual rents of up to $35 a square foot paid by Internet companies and high-tech businesses.
"But we're doing our best to keep the variety," he said. "We try to keep all our renewals below the market level. This is the artistic pulse of the city."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
For Employers,Pitfalls in Treating Workplace Depression

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
ASK an experienced manager about the "reasonable accommodation" that employers must provide under the Americans With Disabilities Act, and you are likely to hear about wheelchair ramps, Braille signs in the elevator and other physical changes to assist workers with physical handicaps. 
 But what does "accommodation" mean for workers suffering from depression? The question nettles employers across the country.
Depression, of course, is not simply the blues. It is a clinically defined mental disorder that is estimated to affect roughly 1 in 10 Americans over the age of 18, sapping their energy, impairing their concentration and making them prone to mood swings and unexplained absences. Add up the work time lost to the illness and the medical bills for treating it, and by some estimates depression costs American employers $36.2 billion a year.
Yet in many a workplace, depression is regarded as a character flaw rather than a treatable illness, and some employers follow what amounts to a don't ask, don't tell policy, implicitly expecting workers to soldier on in silence or be stigmatized as "not up to the job," said Thomas W. Croghan, a research physician with Eli Lilly & Company and an associate professor at Indiana University.
Such attitudes are part of the reason that the government gets more disability-act complaints from workers with emotional or psychiatric impairments than from workers with any other kind of disability. In preliminary figures for the federal fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 2,681 of the 17,014 complaints filed with the Labor Department concerned emotional or psychiatric impairments, and almost half of those -- 1,278 -- involved depression.
For managers, failure to grapple with the problems of depressed employees is economically shortsighted, experts say. Several academic and corporate studies have found that getting depressed workers into treatment is cost-effective because the workers' restored productivity, even if not 100 percent, still outweighs the cost of treatment. "It'll probably cost you more if you don't address it," said Thomas J. O'Connor, director of PRS Disability Management, a Falls Church, Va., consulting firm that provides return-to-work assistance for professionals with depression.
Daniel J. Conti, director of the employee assistance program at Bank One in Chicago, related an example at his company: An information systems manager whose job kept him on the road almost constantly went on disability leave because of depression. When he wanted to return to work, he was told by his doctor that he would not be able to travel.
At first glance, there seems to be no solution, Dr. Conti said. But a disability coordinator in the program had been monitoring the manager's treatment during his leave and had kept in touch with both his physician and his work supervisor. The case manager was able to win agreement from both on a reduced-travel schedule for the employee, with an eye toward a gradual increase back to the pre-leave level.
"We got the person back to work earlier in an accommodated fashion" than would otherwise have been possible, Mr. Conti said, "and my bet right now is that this person will be able to stay at work."
In a tight labor market, retaining workers, disabled or not, is a high priority. "People can't afford, given their investment, to throw someone away and get someone new," Mr. O'Connor said.
But when it comes to depression, he said, the disabilities act has led employers to focus too much on the risks they face.
"They are walking on eggshells, so they look toward the safest way to deal with it, risk management and compliance," he said. "We want employers to embrace employee management."
In Bank One's case, integration of the employee assistance program with the company's human resources and benefits departments makes it easier for the program staff to help managers cope with difficult situations.
In the name of privacy protection, though, some companies prefer to keep more distance between employee assistance programs and other departments.
Still, applying the law to depression remains a problem for employers and employees alike. Attempts by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to clarify how depression fits in under the law have failed to resolve some important issues.
"As it is now applied, the A.D.A. only partially accommodates the needs of depressed workers," researchers concluded in a recent study published in the September-October issue of Health Affairs, a journal of health policy.
The study found that a growing number of employers believe that they should encourage a worker with depression to seek treatment, but that they often hesitate because of concerns about how to approach the employee. And they are not sure what the law requires, an uncertainty that employees share. Especially blurry is whether the act applies in cases where medication can keep symptoms of depression in check.
"The law is unclear as to where the need to accommodate ends," said Dr. Croghan, the Lilly research physician, who was an author of the Health Affairs article.
Experts point to a recent United States Supreme Court decision in which two airline workers whose impaired vision was correctable were found not to be protected under the law. The courts might apply the same reasoning, the experts say, to depressed workers.
"Depression is extremely treatable," said Peggy R. Mastroianni, associate legal counsel for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. "To the extent that these cases give them less protection, it is a concern."
But, Ms. Mastroianni said, depressed workers may find that they still have protection under the A.D.A. if they have a record of disability or if their medication creates side effects that hamper their performance.
Chai Feldblum, a law professor at Georgetown University Law Center who helped write the disabilities act, said the Supreme Court ruling meant that "greater attention will be given to the absurd Catch-22 created by this law."
Ms. Mastroianni said the commission expected to issue more guidelines on depression soon. Whether or not they turn out to be helpful -- some consultants say the commission's past efforts have only muddied the waters -- they are further evidence of heightened awareness.
"I think many companies are still struggling with the how-to of dealing with depression in a proactive way," said Gregg O. Lehman, president of the National Business Coalition, which provides information to employers on how to buy health care coverage for workers. "But increasingly, companies are embracing the fact that we have to do something."

HEADLINE: I Hear America Sighing

BYLINE: By Richard Rorty; Richard Rorty's "Philosophy and Social Hope" will be published in January.

 BODY:

THE REAL
 AMERICAN DREAM
 A Meditation on Hope.
 By Andrew Delbanco.
 143 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $19.95. 
 Andrew Delbanco, who teaches humanities at Columbia University, is one of America's most acute and perceptive cultural critics. Yet this "meditation on hope" (his Massey Lectures in American civilization, given at Harvard last year) ends on a note of hesitation. Delbanco is not sure whether the remedy for our country's "postmodern melancholy" is to get religion or, instead, to resacralize the United States, replacing hope for divine redemption with the secular hope for an ideally just America. In the last pages of his beautifully written book, he hints that the latter strategy will not work. But he never quite commits himself.
The three lectures in "The Real American Dream" are titled "God," "Nation" and "Self": three candidates for the central figure in a narrative that may, by providing hope, avert "the lurking suspicion that all our getting and spending amounts to nothing more than fidgeting while we wait for death." Such a sustaining narrative, as Delbanco says, is called a culture when it "establishes itself over time in the minds of a substantial number of people."
Delbanco thinks that the 19th-century American attempt to substitute the nation for God was, in its day, fairly successful. Lincoln, he says, "perhaps more through his death than through his life, contributed immeasurably to the sacralization of the state as the source of justice, mercy and hope." Whitman's "O Captain! My Captain!" and "When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd" helped Americans identify their country not as Zion, the place where the eternal would next intersect the temporal, but rather as the site of the great secular project that its martyred president had sketched at Gettysburg. Lincoln's nation, as Delbanco says, was "the political incarnation of the idea of universal rights" -- rights whose achievement can be embraced as a sacred mission, whether or not one believes that we are endowed with them by a divine being.
Delbanco doubts that many present-day Americans are buoyed up by the hopes that Lincoln and Whitman shared. "We live," he says, "in an age of unprecedented wealth, but in the realm of narrative and symbol, we are deprived." Neither God nor Nation works anymore. Yet the Self -- the consuming, narcissistic Self -- is a nonstarter, for the whole point of a sustaining narrative is to take one beyond self-involvement. Delbanco quotes Melville as saying, "We become sad in the first place because we have nothing stirring to do," and his third lecture argues that this sort of sadness has become pervasive among Americans at the end of the century.
Delbanco echoes many other recent accounts of what has happened to America when he says that "something died, or at least fell dormant, between the later 1960's, when the reform impulse subsided into solipsism, and the 1980's -- two phases of our history . . . that finally cooperated in installing instant gratification as the hallmark of the good life, and in repudiating the interventionist state as a source of hope." He admits that his "division of American history into two phases of coherent belief followed by a third phase of incoherence and nervous waiting" is "too neat." Nevertheless, his simplified sketch of our country's attempts to find sustaining narratives serves his purposes well. It helps him dramatize the alternatives he believes we now face: to go back to the secular project of Lincoln, Whitman, the Progressive movement, the New Deal and the Great Society, or to abandon secularism and return to the faith of our great-great-grandfathers, or to dream up some third, unprecedented source of hope.
The misleading word "real" in Delbanco's title suggests that he might have some proposals for a third sustaining narrative. He says at the end of his prologue that "in a brief conclusion, I shall propose a few thoughts about what new idea, if any, may be gathering form and strength . . . as the old forms of hope pass away." But it is hard to find these thoughts in his final pages. Instead, one gets references to Graham Greene, Walker Percy and others who believe both that only God will do and that only a consciousness of sin will get us back in touch with God. Delbanco keeps hinting that hope must be paid for with guilt; that Whitmanesque exuberance cannot last; that a merely secular project cannot, in the end, fend off melancholy.
Reading these pages, one is reminded that the first lecture, titled "God," was all about the Puritans -- guilt-ridden people about whom Delbanco has written a great deal in the past, and whom he takes very seriously indeed. Maybe he should take them less seriously. Harold Bloom, in "The American Religion," spoke for many when he wondered why American intellectual historians seem so obsessed with tracing our roots back to that particular little group of self-flagellating sickies: people who believed (as Delbanco says Jonathan Edwards did) that "if God should decide to pluck you from the fire . . . it would be for no reason other than his own inscrutable whim."
Bloom thinks that nobody who sadomasochistically relishes dependence on a higher power can qualify for the American pantheon, for America truly begins only when Emersonian self-reliance replaces Calvinist guilt. No real American, Bloom believes, takes himself to be younger than God. Even those unwilling to go quite that far will wonder if Delbanco picked the right sort of God to write about in his first chapter.
Perhaps the pre-Civil War religious movements that Delbanco briefly mentions in his second lecture -- Mormonism, Millerism and the like -- would have been more suitable subjects than Puritanism. Delbanco might have been well advised to follow Bloom's advice that we see Joseph Smith's as the right sort of response to Emerson's challenge -- his call for Americans to imagine a new relation to the divine. Had Delbanco been willing to forget, for once, about the Puritans, he might have devoted his first chapter to the period 1800-50, when, as he says, "every week seemed to mark the appearance of a fresh prophet determined (to use Melville's phrase) to 'gospelize the world anew.' "Doing so would have made the transition from the "God" chapter to the "Nation" chapter less abrupt.
In the latter chapter Delbanco shows that he fully understands and warmly admires Lincoln's attempt to transform Christian symbolism "into the symbol of a redeemer nation, and, thereby, into a new symbol of hope." But in his third and final chapter he keeps insinuating that late-20th-century America is evidence that such attempts are doomed to fail. One such suggestion is provided by a passage contrasting the way in which the Puritan self "expanded toward (and was sometimes overwhelmed by) the vastness of God" with "a national ideal lesser than God but larger and more enduring than any individual citizen."
"Lesser than God"? That phrase begs the central question Delbanco's book raises. Why, one can imagine Whitman asking, should we Americans take God's word for it that he is more vast than the free, just, utopian nation of our dreams? Whitman famously called the United States of America "the greatest poem." He took narratives that featured God to be lesser poems -- useful in their day, because suitable for the needs of a younger humanity. But now we are more grown up. For us, the tortured adolescent writhings of Augustine, Jonathan Edwards and Graham Greene should be subjects of commiseration, not models for imitation.
GRANTED that the present culture of instant gratification makes even the Puritans look good by comparison, Delbanco gives us little reason to treat that culture as the fated result of the secularist replacement of God by Nation. As he recognizes, this is not the first time that our country has indulged in an orgy of selfishness, or that it has, self-defeatingly, pinned all its hopes on Self. Back in 1929, George Babbitt's mindless bounciness was making Edwards's asceticism look good. But a few years later, Tom Joad and F.D.R. were making Whitman and Lincoln look much better.
Disgusted as we may now be by Babbitt's spoiled great-grandchildren, we have every reason to hope that once today's economic bubble bursts, once we start reinventing the interventionist state, Americans will relearn what Delbanco calls "the lesson of Lincoln's life . . . that the quest for prosperity is no remedy for melancholy, but that a passion to secure justice by erasing the line that divides those with hope from those without hope can be."
