HEADLINE: Dispute Over Plan To Use Jobless Aid For Parental Leave

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
A bitter struggle has erupted over a plan by President Clinton to allow states to pay unemployment benefits to workers who take time off to care for newborn infants.
White House officials said the change in policy, subsidizing unpaid leave for parents of newborns, could help millions of people struggling to balance the demands of work and family. 
 But employers and many state officials said Mr. Clinton was exceeding his legal authority, circumventing Congress and reversing six decades of government policy, which has held that people can get jobless benefits only if they are actively seeking work.
Just two years ago, the Labor Department told states they could not use the federal unemployment insurance trust fund to pay for maternity and paternity leave. Now, the administration is preparing new regulations that would allow the states to do so if they chose.
Employers said the president's policy would take money meant for jobless workers and give it to people who had jobs but chose to leave them temporarily.
Government data suggests that more than 650,000 people a year take parental leave under a 1993 law, the Family and Medical Leave Act. But the potential demand is much greater. The Labor Department says that 1.9 million working women have children under the age of 1.
Patrick J. Cleary, vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said of the president's plan: "This is the nuttiest idea we've seen in a long time. The administration is looking for a pile of cash to fulfill a political promise, and they found it in the unemployment trust fund. But that's an insurance fund, not a slush fund. It's for unemployed people. Workers on family leave are employed, not unemployed. We'll see bad times again some day, and when we go back to the trust fund, it'll be bust."
Legislators in several states, including Vermont and Massachusetts, have introduced bills to provide unemployment insurance to workers taking family leave. But officials who run the state programs are generally cool to the idea, fearing that it would change the focus of unemployment insurance and harm the trust fund.
James E. Finch, the unemployment insurance director in Utah, said: "President Clinton's plan represents a very substantial change in the bedrock core principles of the unemployment insurance program as it has been operated for 60 years. The foundation of the program is that benefits are paid to people who are unemployed through no fault of their own and who are actively seeking full-time work."
Under the 1993 law, people who work for a company with 50 or more employees are generally entitled to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newborn children or sick relatives or to tend to medical problems of their own. Workers who take leave are legally entitled to return to their jobs or to equivalent positions with equivalent pay.
Jobless benefits vary from state to state, but average $200 a week. Under the current system, state officials said, the cost of any additional benefit payments would be passed on to employers because they pay the taxes that finance the unemployment insurance program.
State officials estimate that paid leave for new parents could increase their unemployment insurance costs by 15 percent to 20 percent, depending on how many people seek benefits.
Advocates of paid family leave said the cost would be much lower. Moreover, they said, paid leave would benefit the economy by reducing absenteeism and the need for new parents to go on welfare.
Senior Republicans in Congress said the president should not make such a momentous change in policy by unilateral action. And they have sent letters to the White House urging him to reconsider.
In one such letter, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut told the president, "Your decision allowing states to use unemployment compensation to provide paid family leave pits out-of-work Americans against their neighbors who have jobs."
Mr. Clinton signaled his intention to rewrite federal policy in May, in a commencement address at Grambling State University in Louisiana, but he gave no details. Now the administration is preparing to announce the details, many of which have become known to experts in the field as the Labor Department writes new rules for the unemployment insurance program.
In announcing the rules, White House officials said, Mr. Clinton will present himself as the champion of a popular political cause, helping hard-pressed families while Congress sits on the sidelines.
Mr. Clinton is relying on an expansive view of executive authority. An analysis by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service raises questions about that authority. Under federal law, it says, money withdrawn from the trust fund must be used "solely in the payment of unemployment compensation." Conceivably, it says, states could define "unemployment compensation" to include family leave, but that would conflict with the "legislative history and historical interpretation" of the program.
Business groups said they would challenge the new policy in court if the president formally adopted it.
The federal unemployment insurance program was created in 1935 as part of the Social Security Act. Under longstanding interpretations of the law, people are eligible for jobless benefits only if they are involuntarily unemployed, able to work and available for work.
The Labor Department's Web site describes who is eligible: "You must be available for work. This means that you are ready to start a job immediately. It also means you have transportation and do not have to remain at home to care for children."
Supporters of paid family leave like Maurice Emsellem, a lawyer at the National Employment Law Project, said states could make exceptions to this requirement. Within the framework of federal law, those supporters said, states have wide latitude in setting eligibility standards, benefit levels and tax rates. Moreover, they said, since the New Deal, states have been allowed and even encouraged to experiment with unemployment compensation.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, an author of the 1993 family leave law, said it had been a boon to millions of new parents, allowing them to bond with their children before returning to work. But Mr. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said that many people who needed family leave did not take it because they could not afford to go without a paycheck.
Low-wage workers who take unpaid leave often "wind up on public assistance," he said.
Labor unions and women's groups, led by the National Partnership for Women and Families, are lobbying state legislators to provide some type of income, subsidies or tax breaks for workers who take family leave. The new federal policy clears the way for such state action.
Richard A. Hobbie of the Interstate Conference of Employment Security Agencies, a national organization of state labor officials, said: "In general, our members have been opposed to the president's proposal, not because they oppose the concept of paid family leave, but because they believe it's inappropriate to use the unemployment insurance system for that purpose. State officials would argue that workers on family leave ought to be able to get benefits under some other government program or from employers."
Thomas W. Douse, the unemployment insurance director for Vermont, said that paying jobless benefits to new parents "would lead to an automatic increase in employer taxes" because benefit payments in the state would probably increase by 20 percent, or $9 million a year.
"To be sure," Mr. Douse said, "we have a strong trust fund right now, but the whole purpose of the trust fund is that you raise money in good times so it will be available in bad economic times."
Employers said the president's proposal could deplete the trust fund. But Mr. Emsellem, from the National Employment Law Project, said that with the jobless rate at a 29-year low, many states had healthy surpluses in their trust fund accounts and could afford to expand unemployment insurance.
"Businesses criticize the president's proposal as a raid on the trust fund, even as they lobby successfully for cuts in state unemployment insurance taxes," Mr. Emsellem said. "That's hypocritical."
Thomas S. Whitaker, deputy chairman of the North Carolina Employment Security Commission, said he liked Mr. Clinton's initiative because it allowed states to decide for themselves whether to pay unemployment compensation to workers taking parental leave.
"If states don't want to do it, they don't have to," Mr. Whitaker said. "I hope the Labor Department takes that approach on other issues."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
How Vouchers Can Shift The Balance

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
ADVOCATES of school vouchers believe that public schools will improve if they're forced to compete for students, but what if that's wishful thinking? What if a voucher system merely allows the better students to escape, leaving the rest trapped in the same bad schools?
Thomas Nechyba has analyzed those questions by building computer models of school districts in New York and its suburbs. Dr. Nechyba, a professor of economics at Duke University, has used worst-case assumptions about vouchers to study their potential effect on schools and the balance between city and suburbs. 
 The research, published in The American Economic Review and The Journal of Public Economic Theory, imagines vouchers ranging from $1,000 to $5,000, aimed at students trapped in the worst schools. Once a school district in, say, the Bronx was declared an educational disaster area, anyone living there would get a voucher that could be applied toward tuition at a private school.
If, as feared by critics, private schools accepted only the best students with vouchers, then at first only some families in the Bronx would benefit. But gradually the neighborhood itself would change as more middle-class parents became willing to live there. A private school in the Bronx might start looking better than a public school in Yonkers or another suburb.
"I'm not assuming that lots of people from Westchester are suddenly going to move to the Bronx just to get a voucher," Dr. Nechyba said in an interview. "The effect would be more subtle. A person living in the Bronx who gets a raise at work, for instance, wouldn't be as quick to move to a suburb for its schools. The voucher would give the middle class an incentive to stay inside the city limit."
As more middle-class parents remained in urban school districts to take advantage of vouchers, property values would rise in the city and fall in the suburbs. Urban neighborhoods and suburbs wouldn't be segregated so sharply by class and race.
"Vouchers would help reverse the forces that stratified classes in the city and suburbs," Dr. Nechyba said. "When your children's school is determined strictly by where you live, people in good school districts try to protect their schools and their tax base by zoning out low-income people. Even when the poor aren't zoned out, they're priced out, because the price of a house includes a high premium for the schools."
Dr. Nechyba concludes that suburban public schools would be the chief victims of urban vouchers, because they would end up with a smaller share of the bright students and affluent parents. The chief beneficiaries would be the urban students using the vouchers.
AMONG students overall," Dr. Nechyba said, "the gains from the winners roughly offset the losses. So the effect of vouchers would be neutral even when you start out with worst-case assumptions."
It would probably be more realistic, he said, to assume that vouchers would stimulate at least some improvements in public schools. To keep students from fleeing to private schools, unionized teachers might adopt more flexible work rules, or administrators might create more small schools tailored to students' needs and parents' demands.
"If we factor in even a modest improvement in public schools," Dr. Nechyba said, "we see dramatic increases in the overall quality of education as well as a more even distribution of opportunities. Low-income kids in the city would have access to private schools and to better public schools in their neighborhood. They would also have easier access to better public schools elsewhere, because suburban property values wouldn't be as artificially inflated."
Dr. Nechyba sees one immediate application for the research: as a legal tool for redressing educational inequities. Advocates for New York City students are in court trying to force New York State to redress the disparities in what different school districts spend per pupil.
If the advocates prevail, Dr. Nechyba suggests that the money go directly to parents instead of to school districts. He and Michael Heise, a law professor at Case Western Reserve University, argue in a paper for the Manhattan Institute's Center for Civic Innovation that the money be used for vouchers.
"With targeted vouchers," Dr. Nechyba said, "you can not only improve the opportunities for disadvantaged students, you can also improve disadvantaged neighborhoods. You'll end up with a more integrated society."

HEADLINE: Expansion of Arts Center Touches a Nerve in Princeton

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6

 BODY:
When the colleagues of the architect Michael Graves strolled out of their first planning board meeting here last December, they thought they had reason to be pleased.
They were sure the project they were proposing -- a large addition to an arts center that would be Mr. Graves's first public commission in his hometown -- had been warmly received, with only a few caveats. 
 Not only was Mr. Graves donating his time and that of his employees, but the project -- almost doubling the size of the Arts Council of Princeton -- was no ordinary addition. The design was pure Graves: an industrial-looking round tower and a distinctive 12-sided entrance and reception hall, with wings for a 200-seat theater and more classroom space. If built, the addition would transform the original nondescript brick building.
"I remember saying that it really couldn't have gone much better," said Thomas P. Rowe, one of the architects.
Over the spring and summer, the architects worked away on the design, polishing and making small changes -- moving the building back two feet, knocking a few feet off the height of the tower and erasing a sawtooth roof detail -- while the Arts Council went ahead with its fund-raising, getting $3.6 million of the $4 million they needed for the project.
But then everything came to a halt.
In late September, the planning board called the architects back for another session, labeled a concept review. "They said we really didn't change it that much," Mr. Rowe said, "and they're right."
In what is generally described as a heated confrontation, the board, with a few new members, ripped the proposal apart. They also listened to angry complaints about the project's size and about the loss of parking spaces -- a precious commodity here -- from residents who live near the center, most of whom are black.
Within a month, the escalating debate over the proposal -- and over the politics behind the board's apparent flip-flop -- has divided the participants and endangered the Arts Council's commitment to downtown Princeton, a place that prides itself on both its economic and racial diversity.
Angry letters have been sent back and forth, between the Arts Council and public officials, including the Mayor of the Borough of Princeton, Marvin Reed, who was easily re-elected this month for his third term. Mr. Rowe, from Mr. Graves's office, said he had no plans to revise the building again, before the design is formally submitted for a vote, and Mr. Graves concurred.
On Friday, the well-known architect said he thought the design was "wonderful," and said his office was not "going to roll over and play dead." Several board members of the Arts Council have threatened to build a new building outside the borough if the planning board forces them to make the addition smaller.
And behind it all, seldom spoken, but recognized and feared by all sides, is the specter of racism.
"Many of the neighbors feel that the Arts Council is exclusionary, anyway," said Jim Floyd Sr., 77, a former mayor of the adjacent Township of Princeton. (The township, population 13,500, surrounds the borough, population 12,500; they are generally separate entities, but they have the same planning board.) Mr. Floyd's son and his sister-in-law live in clapboard houses two blocks away from the Arts Council's building, built by the Works Progress Administration in 1938 for an African-American Y.M.C.A., and he has been involved in the issue ever since the first planning board hearing.
"Look at their programs," the elder Mr. Floyd said: "There's a course on parenting at 10:30 in the morning, and you have to pay for it! Who's going to be able to go to it? The people in this neighborhood are off working. And those courses are expensive."
In addition, he said, many of the neighbors feel angry that they were not consulted about Mr. Graves's addition. Some testified that it would be incompatible with the scale of the four-corner intersection, which has a library, a graveyard and a bakery.
To Peter Bienstock, a board member of the Arts Council and its chosen spokesman, the racial overtone of the debate is a mischaracterization of the nature of the opposition. The dispute, he added, has crippled the Council's fund-raising. As a land developer for more than 25 years, he added, he has dealt with many development projects. "Close neighbors almost invariably object," he said.
(Mr. Bienstock has said publicly that if the addition were proposed for a site across the street from his own house, he, too, would be opposed.)
Today, he said that because of meetings over the last two weeks with leaders and congregants from several of the area's black churches -- meetings in which balloons were flown to show the height of the proposed addition -- the strength of the protest against the design now seemed to be dying away.
Mr. Bienstock dismissed the accusation from neighborhood opponents that the Arts Council is elitist and caters mainly to whites who drive in for the council's courses and presentations. Besides parenting classes, they include pottery workshops and music concerts. He said that many blacks, from nearby and farther away, support the addition. (And he said course scholarships were offered to local residents.)
The Arts Council bought the former Y.M.C.A. from the borough four years ago for $125,000. And at that time, there was controversy, and the same charges that the Council catered more to whites in the outskirts than to blacks next door. But since then, Mr. Bienstock said, the Council has recruited minorities for its advisory board -- there are now three blacks on the 28-member board -- and has listened to their suggestions about new programs to appeal to local residents.
One of the new board members back then was Jim Floyd Jr., who says he and two other minority board members "bailed out" after a couple of months, when, he says, the rest of the board "didn't seem interested in questions we raised about the way they did business."
But they were replaced by other minority members, including the Rev. John E. White, pastor of the Witherspoon Presbyterian Church, a few blocks away from the Arts Council building.
Mr. White questioned Mr. Bienstock's optimistic assessment that the Arts Council was past its greatest hurdles in his neighborhood.
"There are still some very mixed feelings in the community," he said. Some think the Arts Council's programming is positive, he said, and some feel it is elitist. Some are not in favor because of the history, he said, when the building housed a black Y.M.C.A., "and they have their memories; there's nowhere near as many African-Americans involved there now." There are concerns about the size of the addition: "Some people are worried about the overflow and worry that they and their friends won't have places to park."
For his part, Mayor Reed, who sits on the planning board, labeled the debate "your typical small-town development conflict," and produced an Oct. 5 letter from the planning board to the Arts Council asking for a public meeting to try to resolve the issue. A date has not yet been set.
Mr. White, who is African-American, was asked what he thought of the proposal. "I do share some of these concerns about parking -- and it is a big building," he said. But he agreed that making the addition smaller would not serve the Arts Council's needs for a bigger theater and more classrooms.
"If it has to be smaller, they would leave," he said, "and everyone's aware of that." He paused. "The Arts Council has been a good neighbor to us. But it's understandable that people don't want a behemoth next to them -- even Mr. Bienstock said he wouldn't want it across the street from his own house."
"And there's the history, too," he said, recalling when the building was a black Y.M.C.A. "It's hard to defeat history."

Jets Rally in 4th Quarter
The New York Jets overcame their own mistakes to defeat the Arizona Cardinals, 12-7. D1
 
Nets Now 1-3 for Season
The Nets beat the Washington Wizards, 112-87. D8
 
MARATHON F1-18
 
26.2 Miles, a Stride at a Time
Joseph Chebet of Kenya won the New York City Marathon in 2:09:14, and Adriana Fernandez of Mexico was the women's winner, finishing in 2:25:06. Chebet became the first man since Alberto Salazar in 1982 to win the Boston and New York City Marathons in the same year. F1
 
OBITUARIES B10-11
 
Primo Nebiolo
The man who brought track and field out of the amateur ranks as president of its world governing body for almost two decades was 76. B11
 
BUSINESS DAY C1-26
 
Mixed Reaction on Microsoft
Any satisfaction in Silicon Valley with a judge's findings in the Microsoft antitrust case is offset by concern that the court document is a step toward greater government intervention in the high-technology economy. The judge's findings are not a final ruling in the case, but they will almost certainly serve as the framework for its outcome. A1
 
Building Bigger Businesses
One legacy of the Clinton administration may be a return to economic empires, a result of merger approvals and deregulation. Some of the biggest changes have been or are expected to be in telecommunications, oil and, with the signing of a bill tomorrow, financial services. A22
 
The Thinking Behind the Deal
The chief executive of Warner-Lambert said his company was proceeding with its $72 billion proposed merger with American Home Products and spurning an $80 billion hostile bid from Pfizer because Warner-Lambert and American Home were better matched. C1
 
Surfing, Republican Style
The Republican National Committee plans to offer a "family friendly" Internet service that will deliver the party's messages directly to supporters. C1
 
Stocks Lower in Tokyo
Stocks were trading lower in Tokyo today. At midday, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 136.80 points, or 0.75 percent, at 18,218.10. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Image Is Poor, But Hartford Looks Good To Developers

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
Hartford had a bittersweet moment in the national spotlight last Thursday, when President Clinton came to town to announce that local companies were investing nearly $200 million to redevelop the city. It was good news, of course, but any temptation to bask in civic pride was probably tempered by the occasion for the visit: Hartford was a featured stop on Mr. Clinton's poverty tour, sharing billing with the Mississippi Delta, Newark and Appalachia.
While the president's visit underlined the troubles in Hartford -- afflicted by a loss of jobs and population and by a reputation as a municipal also-ran -- the news of the investment was also taken by many as another sign that the city is beginning to rebound. 
 "Hartford is like the last girl asked to dance," said Larry Charles Sr., executive director of One/ Chane, a neighborhood economic development group. "We're not New York, we're not Boston, but we have character. All the stars appear to be lined up right now, and it's Hartford's turn."
The city has grand plans for a new downtown, with a revitalized waterfront and a stadium for the University of Connecticut. The multimillion-dollar project -- Adriaen's Landing , a retail, entertainment and education center, plus a convention center and housing and parking -- gained momentum from Mr. Clinton's announcement. Boston-area developers have bought the Civic Center Mall and plan to build housing there. Capital Properties, a New York developer, is refurbishing two office towers at Constitution Plaza. The city's plans also include a higher education center and $25 million to rehabilitate housing.
The state and federal governments are also pitching in: the Department of Housing and Urban Development is providing $8.2 million in loans, grants and training programs, and Connecticut has pledged $455 million to the Adriaen's Landing project -- named for the Dutch explorer Adriaen Block, who in 1614 became the first European to reach Hartford -- provided it can attract $210 million in private investment.
There have been other bright spots. The crime rate has decreased 40 percent in the last six years, and the commercial vacancy rate has shrunk to 10 percent from 27 percent or 28 percent, according to the mayor, Michael P. Peters.
The Connecticut River, once described as "the most beautifully landscaped sewer in America," has been made accessible to the public again in the state capital, with floodproof landscaping and events like the Eastern Regional Bass Fishing Tournament (yes, stripers in downtown Hartford) and a Chris Isaak concert. Riverfront Recapture, the nonprofit group spearheading such efforts, won national recognition in 1997 from the Waterfront Center, a national organization that encourages such redevelopment, for being "one of the most heroic waterfront projects in the United States." This year the riverfront alone attracted a half million visitors.
So although the Whalers hockey team left for North Carolina in 1997, and the New England Patriots decided in April to stay put in Boston (after long, wrenching negotiations with Hartford), and although insurance companies have moved thousands of jobs elsewhere, there is hope about the move to refurbish the city.
Mayor Peters recalls the early 1990's, when the school system was failing and people were fleeing to the suburbs. "It looked like we weren't going to survive," he said. He said that New England was the last region in the country to recover economically, and that Hartford was one of the last cities in the state to feel the benefits of the economic upswing of the late 90's.
Lawrence R. Gottesdiener is chairman and chief executive of Northland Investment Corporation, based in Newton, Mass., which has purchased the Civic Center Mall. He was attracted to the city by its location between two international financial centers and its affluent and well-educated population. He ticked off a list of amenities: the riverfront, the Bushnell Theatre, the Hartford Stage and the Wadsworth Atheneum, the oldest continuously operating art museum in the United States. They form a framework, he said, for creating an exciting urban center.
"There's an enormous amount of public money to help add new tile to that mosaic, and ultimately produce something that's extraordinarily beautiful, and not replicable in the suburbs," he said.
But he has found that Hartford continues to have a less than desirable business reputation. "Its perception remains terrible," he said.
Another developer, John Elkington, chief executive of Performa Realty, which refurbished Beale Street in Memphis as well as other urban centers in the South, has been invited to develop an entertainment and restaurant center. He is joining Sheldon Gordon, a developer whose projects include the Bridgemarket under the Queensboro Bridge in Manhattan and the profitable Forum Shops of Las Vegas.
Mr. Elkington said he was enthusiastic about Hartford's untapped market. There are 1.2 million people within a half-hour drive of downtown, he said, and almost half of them make $50,000 to $75,000 a year.
"One hundred million people a year go on Interstate 91 or Interstate 84 past Hartford," he said. "What you've got to be able to do is get those people off there." He hopes to build a $60 million project with a New England feel to it, in the westernmost part of Adriaen's Landing, close to the Atheneum.
But while the insurance magnates and entrepreneurs write their checks, members of community groups are concerned about how the revitalization process will evolve.
Mr. Charles said: "The difficult thing here is we need to answer the question, Whose Hartford is it? Is it the Hartford that's being designed by suburbanites for their entertainment, or is it the Hartford being designed by residents of the community?"
Evelyn Mantilla, a state representative whose district includes the Adriaen's Landing site and half of downtown, is concerned about whether jobs from the new development will go to Hartford residents. She also wants to see a strong commitment for affordable housing.
"I want to make sure that all the decisions include the real residents of Hartford in the process," she said. "Hartford does have a set of very strong community groups, community leaders, people who represent their neighborhood.
"Everything should be done in a democratic way that includes their feedback as well."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about efforts to revitalize Hartford misidentified the owner of the Civic Center Mall. The owner is Aetna; the Northland Investment Corporation has signed a memo of intent to buy the mall.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Treating Exile as a Separate Country

BYLINE: By RICHARD EDER 

 BODY:

THE MUSEUM OF UNCONDITIONAL SURRENDER
By Dubravka Ugresic
Translated by Celia Hawkesworth. Illustrated. 238 pages. New Directions. $24.95.
Exile is the only country without a geography. It has, however, a climate, a culture, an ecology, an archaeology and virtually a national smell. They figure on the doleful map drawn by Dubravka Ugresic, a refugee from the repressive nationalist politics and culture of post-Yugoslav Croatia. 
 It shows us:
"That exile is the history of the things we leave behind, of buying and abandoning hair driers, cheap little radios, coffee pots. . . . That exile is changing voltages and kilohertz, life with an adapter, so we don't burn ourselves. That exile is the history of our temporary rented apartments, the first lonely mornings as we spread out the map of the town in silence, find on the map the name of our street and mark it with a cross in pencil. (We repeat the history of the great conquerors, with little crosses instead of flags.)
"Those little firm facts, stamps in our passport, accumulate and at a certain moment they become illegible lines. Then they suddenly begin to trace an inner map, the map of the unreal, the imaginary. And it is only then that they express precisely the immeasurable experience of exile."
"The Museum of Unconditional Surrender" is a strew of such factlets, a Hansel-and-Gretel trail of crumbs into the witch's forest of our time. Seemingly disjointed and sometimes forced, they assemble a universal -- the human displacements of Bosnia, Kosovo, Rwanda, East Timor, Chechnya -- in strikingly individual terms. Ugresic's stream-of-consciousness exile in Berlin gives us not the gory amputation of refugee flight but arrival's grayer course of tissue-rejection.
The author, who has spent years of expatriation in Germany and the United States and now lives in the Netherlands, is a novelist and essayist. Her style is personal and aphoristic. "Museum," originally in Croatian, is a mix of diary, notebook, commonplace book and memoir; its facts and conversations slide between record and invention. There is much that is arbitrary and self-indulgent, yet "Museum" is a precious portrait of exile as internal displacement.
Ugresic knows she writes in the line of greater and more spacious chroniclers of the theme. She freely quotes Nabokov and Joseph Brodsky; her spitfire artistic assertiveness has a curious humility to it. Nevertheless, she must be numbered among what Jacques Maritain called the dreamers of what is true; she draws us into the dream.
Scattershot and posturing as she can be, there is a startling aim in her master image at the beginning. A display case in the Berlin Zoo holds the contents of the stomach of Roland the Walrus, who died in 1961: a pink cigarette lighter, a water pistol, sunglasses, a toy parachute, a small doll, a beer can, a poodle brooch, a sewing kit, car keys and much else.
I Am the Walrus is the leitmotiv of Ugresic's narrator/alter ego, Bubi. Exiled out of a polar remove, Bubi lives not in a zoo but an equivalent: the museum of the title. Exile reality, no longer nourished by roots, is a collection of orphan sensations, artifacts and memories. One of the most persuasive themes in the Berlin jottings around which the book is constructed -- other parts include childhood memories, the story of her mother and an account of the breakup of Yugoslavia and a band of college friends along with it -- is photographs.
There are two kinds of refugees, a Bosnian friend remarks, "those who have photographs and those who have none." The narrator tells an anecdote about the Bosnian-Serb general and war criminal Ratko Mladic. Noticing that the Sarajevo house of an acquaintance was on his bombardment list, Mladic phoned to inform him he had five minutes to collect his photograph albums and leave.
"The general, who had been destroying the city for months, knew precisely how to annihilate memory. That is why he 'generously' bestowed on his acquaintance life with the right to remembrance."
Remembrance is possession, but it rusts. The narrator haunts the Berlin flea market where Europe's displaced -- Ukrainians, Bosnians, Africans, Gypsies, Turks and her own countrymen -- peddle a tumulus of memory as objects. A shadow passes over the reader. How special a case can exile be? Just across the tracks from the global village the global flea market is setting up.
The narrator promenades a series of tags to test out her particular estrangement. "Ich bin mude" ("I am tired"): her first German phrase, and for a while she wants to learn no other. "Learning more means opening up." Later comes "Guten Tag," exchanged with Herr Schroeder, the postman. Apparently a greeting, to the exile it warns: come no farther.
Herr Schroeder draws arrows on the envelopes to remind her to give him the Croatian stamps. "Berlin loneliness is as acute and unambiguous as Herr Schroeder's arrow," she notes, and she's off to test "I'm lonely" among her exile friends. "It's not surprising," says Zoran. "Everyone in Berlin is lonely. And for some reason, no one ever has any time." Again she's off, asking a dozen people: "Have you some time?" They ignore the question. Only the exile "has" time; the settled, lonely or not, "use" it.
Interspersed with the Berlin wanderings are vignettes from the past. There is a tender account of the narrator's mother, from her girlhood in Bulgaria to the gradually easing rigors of postwar Yugoslavia to the bleakness, for an old Yugoslav believer, of seeing the country fall apart. There is a soured love affair, a cheerful passage with a Portuguese gigolo, a zany feud with three Indian students in a London rooming house.
The writing here can be overmannered. So is the story of eight Croatian, Serbian and Bosnian women whose friendship ruptures when the civil war begins. The many jagged and poignant details are dimmed by fictional and symbolic inflation, including a magic realist angel.
It is the Berlin notes that give "Museum" its sharp and haunting edge. There are times, of course, when a reader may wonder about the treatment of exile as a depressive finality. After all, untold millions have found a life beyond it. For a moment, though, italicize that "have." Like entrails for the ancient Greeks, the inspired particularities of "Museum" have a suggestion of prophecy. The story of illness is not subsumed by the story of cures. In our day is exile still an illness or the beginnings of pandemic?

HEADLINE: Giant Hopes for Tiny Satellites

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The concept of less being more will take on new meaning in space next month when the Air Force launches a fleet of tiny experimental satellites made of miniature components -- diminutive machines that could one day work together in groups to replace or supplement larger spacecraft.
Driven by economics and the desire to approach working in space in a different way, researchers are exploring methods to make and use midget spacecraft -- some weighing less than a pound and hardly larger than a pack of playing cards -- that could be used alone to perform simple tasks or flown in formations to execute more complex ones. 
 Interest in tiny satellites that can distribute the duties and risks of working in space has grown with advances in microtechnology that are reducing the size of machines and components. For example, rapid improvements in microelectromechanical systems, or MEMS, technology are allowing researchers to produce switches, valves, levers, gears and other machine components that are too small to be seen by the human eye. Space engineers say they are harnessing such elements to make bantam satellites with techniques similar to those used to produce computer chips.
"The goal is to one day build a satellite on a chip," said Dr. Siegfried W. Janson, a senior scientist with The Aerospace Corporation, a private research organization in El Segundo, Calif. "We're talking about fully integrated satellites that could be mass produced cheaply by the hundreds and sent into space in groups to perform a variety of tasks."
Satellites are generally classified by weight, with standard ones weighing a ton or more, small satellites coming in between 200 pounds and a ton, and microsats considered those that fall between 20 pounds and 200 pounds. The new wave of smaller satellites that engineers see for the future are so-called nanosatellites ranging from 20 pounds down to 2 pounds, and picosatellites that weigh in at less than 2 pounds.
Dr. Janson said he envisioned producing satellites weighing as little as half a pound that are assembled from layered silicon wafers containing sensors, computing power, communications systems, mechanical devices and even micro rocket thrusters. Swarms of such satellites, launched together on single, inexpensive rockets, could replace more expensive single satellites for some tasks, he said, or spread out to take on entirely new roles in space.
In addition to low cost, networks composed of dozens, if not hundreds, of inexpensive tiny satellites could offer a new standard of reliability, proponents say. If one or several of the machines in a formation fails, others in the group could redistribute themselves and continue performing the assigned task, they say, something not possible with a single-satellite mission.
Peter V. Panetta of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., agrees, saying there is growing interest in increasingly smaller satellites and other spacecraft. "This isn't just a fad," he said. "A lot of people see this as the future and are working toward the technical breakthroughs to make these things possible."
Mr. Panetta, manager of NASA's Nanosat Technology Development Program, said the agency hoped to have a constellation of 100 nanosatellites, weighing as little as 2 pounds each, launched by one rocket on a single mission in 2008. This approach would be ideal for science missions requiring measurements to be taken simultaneously from many locations, he said, such as monitoring the amount of solar radiation absorbed by, and then reflected from, the Earth.
As a step toward the goal of flying formations of nanosats, NASA announced in August that it would sponsor the Nanosat Constellation Trailblazer mission. This flight of three 40-pound microsats, scheduled for 2003, will test MEMS technology, formation flying and methods of operating several spacecraft as a system to pave the way for future nanosat clusters, Mr. Panetta said.
Formations of nanosats could be the only way to study certain phenomenon, he said, such as the dynamics of the magnetosphere, the area around the Earth that traps high-energy particles from the sun in the planetary magnetic field. This moving, tear-shaped region extends more than 150,000 miles from the Earth in the direction away from the Sun, he said, and only a network of satellites could constantly monitor its changes.
Dr. Mark E. Campbell of the University of Washington in Seattle recently completed a NASA-sponsored study of possible deep space missions for clusters of pico or nano-sized spacecraft. Among the possibilities, he said, are teams of semi-autonomous craft that could swarm around asteroids or comets to make measurements and then assemble themselves into a communications array to send the results back to Earth. Another possibility is to send a mother ship to a planet that would release orbiting picosats that would slowly drift down through its atmosphere and send data back to Earth via the mother craft.
"My guess is that it will take 15 to 20 years to put together a system like this, but this is where the technology is heading," Dr. Campbell said.
Engineers also envision jobs for single midget satellites, like launching one along with each expensive, large spacecraft. If a problem arose with the main spacecraft, the tiny satellite buddy could detach and examine the larger ship to help ground controllers diagnose and fix the difficulty.
To test the concept of midget satellites in space, several picosats are scheduled to be launched into Earth orbit early next month on the inaugural launching of a new Air Force booster rocket. The rocket, formally called the Orbital/Suborbital Program Space Launch Vehicle but nicknamed Minotaur, uses the first two stages of decommissioned Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missiles and upper stages from Orbital Sciences Corporation's commercial Pegasus rocket. The Air Force hopes to use surplus ICBM's as a cheap way to launch small government payloads.
Among Air Force and university payloads offered a free ride on the first flight is the Orbiting Picosat Automated Launcher, or OPAL, built by students from Stanford University. The OPAL mother ship is to fire off a half dozen pico-sized daughter satellites, including a pair built by the Aerospace Corporation and the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
The two battery-powered satellites in this pair, each weighing about a half-pound and slightly larger than a pack of playing cards, are to be connected by a 100-foot tether to keep them from drifting too far apart to communicate with one another. The satellites will spend several days communicating with one another and with a third picosat at a ground station to see how they operate as a system, and testing an array of experimental MEMS radio switches.
The tether between the craft contains a gold wire to help Earth-based radar track the tiny objects, which raises the issue of old picosats becoming space debris that could damage other craft through space collisions.
Mr. Panetta of NASA said designers were aware of the potential problem with the tiny, hard-to-follow spacecraft and see it as an issue to address in mission design. One approach, he said, is to put nano-thrusters on Earth-orbiting satellites that could be fired at the end of a mission to slow the craft enough to fall out of orbit and burn up in the atmosphere. "You don't want the solution to one problem to create another," he said.
